content: Verizon Communications (VZ) won an upgrade ahead of its earnings report while Dish Network (DISH) got both a Morgan Stanley price-target cut and the attention of another analyst who thinks it could be a merger target for Verizon.Barclays upgraded Verizon, which reports first-quarter earnings early Tuesday, to overweight. Amir Rozwadowski, a Barclays analyst, says the company may lose postpaid phone subscribers in the quarter. But he expects the telecom firm's wireless service revenue "trajectory" to show improvement year-over-year, excluding new accounting rules.Morgan Stanley lowered its price target on Dish to 45 from 55. Dish's core satellite TV business is deteriorating and it's been unable to partner with a wireless service provider to utilize radio spectrum it has amassed.Verizon climbed 1.6% to close at 48.66 on the stock market today. Dish was nearly flat, up 5 cents to 37.28. Verizon, a high dividend-paying stock, has dropped nearly 10% in 2018 amid rising interest rates. Dish has plunged 19% in 2018 and 41% from Aug. 1.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseWith Dish's valuation lower, Verizon could be more interested in buying the company for its spectrum holdings, speculates Craig Moffett, analyst at MoffettNathanson, in a blog published on Monday. He says one concern for Dish is that federal regulators plan on auctioning more airwaves. As spectrum supply grows, there would be less reason to buy Dish, he said."Dish has every incentive in the world to finally drop their asking price to a level low enough that Verizon might come to the table," Moffett said. "Again, that's not to say that Verizon is necessarily ready to buy even at a bargain price. But it's now or never."YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Telecom Stocks To Watch And Industry NewsSell And Take Profits Or Hold? As new financial planners set up shop, they crave advice. And seasoned advisors are eager to give it.Ask experienced advisors to share success tips and many will dish out eternal truths: Treat clients with respect, deliver superior service and listen more than you speak.Older advisors also urge new entrants to the field to document client meetings with care and never stop learning. Also: Don't pretend to know more than you do. By adopting disciplined work habits and understanding how emotions drive financial decisions, young advisors can gain an edge.Perhaps the most crucial factor in determining whether a new planner will prosper centers on motivation. The more passion you bring to each day, the better.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"There are three levels to how you approach your work," said Rick Kahler, a certified financial planner in Rapid City, S.D. "It can be a job, a career or a calling. Your probability of success goes way up if it's a calling."People treat a job as a grind and a career as a series of milestones to check off. But if they derive deep gratification from helping clients — and they're compelled to excel — then they possess the fortitude to persevere and build a thriving practice.Kahler, 62, also emphasizes the importance of lifelong education. He tells young associates to attend professional conferences, read industry publications and take webinars."Continuing education isn't a nuisance; it's a way to keep learning," he said. "Even now, I spend over 100 hours a year on continuing ed. You can't just go with bare-bones CE requirements; that's a low bar. Be the best fiduciary you can be. "Advisors who polish their people skills work more effectively with colleagues. But young planners can graduate college feeling cocky and project a know-it-all attitude."It's great working with new associates who are savvy and really smart," said Marianela Collado, a certified financial planner in Plantation, Fla. "But if they don't agree with what they hear, there's a difference between saying 'You're wrong' and 'Please help me understand how you arrived at that.' "She counsels newcomers to demonstrate humility and disagree in a diplomatic, respectful tone. Posing questions works better than insisting you know more than a co-worker."This goes a long way to make people want to work with you and appreciate having you on their team," Collado said. "It's the same when working with attorneys and CPAs. Don't put them on the defensive by saying, 'Here's what you missed.' Instead, ask 'What do you think of this other approach?' "Another way that new associates gain acceptance at their firm is to learn the unglamorous side of the business. In addition to amassing technical knowledge to help clients, they can show interest in less visible but vital aspects of the practice."Often, young advisors don't spend much time on back-office operations — things like rebalancing software, compliance updates, financial reporting," said Sammy Grant, a certified financial planner in Sandy Springs, Ga. "But you'll be more valuable to your firm's partners if you understand that stuff, and that knowledge will also serve you well if you launch your own practice."Empathy differentiates top advisors. By communicating with prospects and clients in a sensitive manner, they're more apt to build rapport and earn their trust."Step out of your shoes into the client's shoes," Grant said. "It's something you can't learn in school. You need to respond to what clients do and say by understanding them, not judging them."For newcomers who launch their own firm, the isolation of a solo practice can prove challenging. Longtime advisors recommend that you join a network of other planners."We're social creatures, not lone wolves, so it's important to have peers to bounce ideas off," said Kenneth Robinson, a certified financial planner in Cleveland, Ohio. "Don't go it alone. You'll learn more than you think you'll learn from your peers."Advisors can create their own informal peer groups and meet regularly to share their experiences. Or they can join membership organizations such as the Alliance of Comprehensive Planners, XY Planning Network and Garrett Planning Network.Robinson also advises new planners to carve out a niche and specialize in serving that universe of clients. He suggests an exercise to envision the type of individual you want to attract."Figure out your ideal client," he said. "Then you can play to your strengths."For example, Robinson works with independent professional women. But he's also a fan of index funds, so a professional woman seeking a stock picker for an advisor wouldn't be a good fit.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Before Aging Clients Show Signs Of Dementia, Advisors Take ActionAdvisors Track Economic Reports To Stay One Step Ahead Of MarketsAdvisors Promote Health And Wellness To Help Clients Live Better

Dish Network (DISH) cratered 10% on Tuesday after reporting first-quarter revenue that missed views as investors worried about its long-term strategy amid continued weakness in its core satellite TV business."Dish's satellite TV business is in effect a declining annuity stream that in Q1 declined at a faster than expected pace, with an increasingly difficult outlook," said Jeffrey Wlodarczak, analyst at Pivotal Research, in a report.Dish fell 12.1% to close at 29.81 on the stock market today, falling to a six-year low. Dish has plummeted 55% since Aug. 1.Dish has amassed wireless spectrum for 5G wireless services. But the value of its airwaves has been undercut by the proposed merger of T-Mobile US (TMUS) with Sprint (S) as well as upcoming government auctions.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseWith cable TV companies Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) also bleeding subscribers, investors are focused on Dish's pay TV business rather than wireless options, says Craig Moffett, analyst at MoffettNathanson."The market's blindness to the rapid deterioration of Dish's satellite TV business ended abruptly with the recent meltdown in cable stocks," Moffett said in a note to clients. "Dish is no longer just a way to express a view about spectrum valuations."Verizon Communications (VZ) has stated no interest in acquiring the declining satellite TV business."Investors are likely going to have to continue to be patient given the low likelihood for M&A or spectrum sale/usage until the second half of 2019," added Wlodarczak.Dish's attempts to find a wireless or internet partner to build out a networks has turned up empty."I don't think you should expect announcements on partnerships and anchor tenants," Charles Ergen, Dish's co-founder, said on its earnings call Tuesday.Dish's satellite pay TV service dropped 185,000 subscribers, while its Sling-branded Internet TV service added 91,000. Analysts say the internet video service is not profitable.Dish said it earned 70 cents a share, down from 76 cents a share a year ago, in-line with expectations.Revenue dropped 6% to $3.46 billion, missing views. Analysts had projected $3.5 billion.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Comcast Readies Fox Bid; Investors Mull Debt, Dividend, Stock Buyback ImpactCharter, Comcast, Altice Dive As Cable TV Subscriber Losses MountChart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real Opportunity

Cell-tower operator Crown Castle International (CCI) has bid for broadband-service provider Lightower Fiber Networks in a $7 billion deal that would help Crown Castle provide 5G wireless infrastructure to customers such as Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT&T (T), reports said Monday.XPrivately held Lightower's fiber-optic network would mesh with Crown Castle's plans to build out "small-cell" radio antennas for 5G services in urban areas. The small-cell antennas — hung on utility poles or building rooftops — will require fiber-optic connections to local hubs, which in turn link to cloud-computing infrastructure as well as long-distance networks.Some analysts, though, view the $7 billion price tag, which includes debt, as pricey."Crown Castle has not been shy about its desire to acquire more of the right type of fiber assets to bolster its small-cell business. Should reported valuation levels prove true ($7 billion), an equity component to financing a deal is likely," Barclays analyst Amir Rozwadowski said in a note to clients.Shares in Crown Castle closed down 4.2% at 96.81 in the stock market today. Shares in Zayo Holdings (ZAYO), a rival of Lightower that has been viewed as a takeover candidate, edged up 1.7% to 30.87.Lightower's network has 33,000 route miles throughout the Northeast, Midwest and Mid-Atlantic providing connections to service locations and data centers. Meanwhile, Crown Castle has been investing in small-cell technology more than peers American Tower (AMT) and SBA Communications (SBAC).Crown Castle reports earnings on Wednesday.Jennifer Fritzsche, analyst at Wells Fargo, says Verizon and AT&T are already Lightower's top customers.IBD'S TAKE:  Crown Castle stock is up 12% in 2017 but has been outperformed by peers American Tower, up 27%, and SBA Communications, up 31%. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Fritzsche says there may be upside for Zayo if Lightower is acquired."While Lightower is admittedly growing top-line at a much faster rate than Zayo, it should be noted Zayo covers three times the geography of Lightower — with dense fiber network footprints in many other densely populated U.S. cities," she said in a note to clients.The advent of 5G networks is expected to enable faster wireless internet services to homes as well as high-speed connections to drones and self-driving cars.RELATED:Tesla Stock Drops As Autopilot Feature Blamed For CrashAmazon, Dish Wireless Deal Would Target Internet Of Things: CitiWhen Software Mergers Heat Up, These Companies Will Be Buyers

Charter Communications (CHTR) is testing a live-TV streaming service that starts at just under $20 with no sports content.Time Warner's (TWX) HBO, meanwhile, may be heading to Hulu.Charter, which brands its online service Spectrum Stream, says the base package includes local broadcast channels and 25 cable networks, including AMC, CNN, A&E, History, TNT and Discovery (DISCA).A $12 monthly add-on package includes ESPN channels, NBC Sports, and Bloomberg news. A $15 monthly option includes movie channels.Dish Network (DISH) launched its Sling streaming service at $20 in January 2015 with Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN, but lacked local TV stations from the four broadcast networks.Charter's Spectrum Stream service, if commercially launched, would also compete with AT&T's (T) DirecTV Now, which starts at $35, as well as Hulu and Sony's web offering.Verizon Communications (VZ) has signaled that it could launch a video streaming service in the second half of 2017.IBD'S TAKE: Charter stock is up about 15% in 2017 but is trading near its 50-day moving average. Charter stock has a technical buy point of 341.60. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Hulu is a joint venture of Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA), Disney, and Comcast (CMCSA). Time Warner acquired a 10% stake in Hulu last year.AT&T, which is seeking regulatory approval to acquire Time Warner for $85 billion, has offered a free year of HBO in some DirecTV Now promotions. Time Warner also sells HBO as a stand-alone online product for $15 monthly.RELATED:Sprint Jumps On Comcast-Charter Wireless TalksComcast, Charter Fall; Longtime Industry Bull Downgrades Sector

Sprint (S) is in talks with Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) about reselling wireless services or a merger, according to multiple reports late Monday. That puts on-again, off-again merger talks with T-Mobile US (TMUS) on hold and puts pressure on Verizon Communications (VZ).X Sprint Chairman Masayoshi Son is in exclusive talks with Comcast and Charter Communications through late July, the Wall Street Journal reported late Monday, citing sources. Sprint has put on hold talks with T-Mobile US.The WSJ, later joined by Bloomberg News and Reuters, reported Sprint could offer friendly terms for Comcast and Charter to sell wireless services using its network. Less likely, the cable giants could jointly bid for the wireless firm.Either combination could be negative for Verizon. Comcast and Charter already have a deal to use Verizon's network, but could get a better deal from Sprint. Meanwhile, Verizon had been hoping for a Sprint merger with T-Mobile, with the consolidation easing a fierce pricing war led by T-Mobile.Verizon, a Dow Jones industrial component, could feel a push to reach a deal with satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), which has an abundance of wireless spectrum.AT&T (T) acquired Dish rival DirecTV in July 2015.Sprint shares rose 2.1% to 8.18 on the stock market today, closing below their 50-day line after hitting 8.50 intraday. T-Mobile sank 3.4% to 61.01 after falling earlier to 60.72.Comcast slid 9% and Charter 0.8%. Verizon sank 2%.RELATED:Can Verizon Surge If Sprint, T-Mobile Merge?

Blue Apron (APRN) is serving up a dish that big-money investors have turned away, causing the company to lower the price of its initial public offering by about 34%.Blue Apron cut the estimated price of shares to a range of $10 to $11, down from $15 to $17, lowering its fully diluted market value to $2 billion from $3 billion. Blue Apron planned to raise $480 million, now cut to $315 million. The IPO is scheduled to reach a final price tonight and begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange Thursday under the ticker APRN.Founded in 2012, New York-based Blue Apron provides recipes and pre-measured ingredients that are boxed and delivered to customers for a home meal, designed for two or four people. It also has a monthly wine-delivery option.Investors embraced the cut in share price, which research firm IPO Boutique says is now "multiple times oversubscribed."IPO Boutique said its sources had indicated that the roadshow designed to promote the offering to institutional investors "has continued to be challenging for management as they attempt to diffuse the highly likely fact that extensive losses in the future could and likely will create problems."Blue Apron revenue rose by a blistering 133% to $795.4 million in 2016 from the previous year. It showed a loss of $54.8 million, vs. a loss of $46.9 million. In the first quarter. Blue Apron revenue grew by 42% from the year-ago period to $244.8 million, with a net loss of $52.2 million, vs. a loss of $3 million.IBD'S TAKE: The biggest stock market winners typically make their major price moves within a few months or years of their initial public offering. So it pays to identify and track companies that are getting ready to go or have recently gone public. Learn more at IBD's IPO page. IBD also focuses on the best-performing IPOs of the past three years in its IPO Leaders column."We are hearing from large funds that they are 'sitting this deal out' and, with that being said, retail will more than likely get a disproportionate amount (of shares) as compared to a normal IPO," according to the research note from IPO Boutique. "Investors are also scrutinizing this company's cash flow and very low amount of cash on hand," it said. "Many of the same sources are expecting, despite revenue projections, that they will not meet those numbers."The IPO comes as Amazon.com (AMZN) last week announced a deal to acquire Whole Foods Market (WFM). Amazon's purchase of Whole Foods has some investors worried that Amazon, with low prices, will drive out more competitors in the business of healthy food.One of Blue Apron's closest competitors is Berlin-based Hello Fresh, which withdrew IPO plans last year. Other rivals in the prepackaged-meal delivery market include Munchery, Gobble, Chef'd, Plated and Veestro. Google-owner Alphabet (GOOGL) also provides food delivery services.The lead underwriters of the IPO are Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.RELATED:Nine IPOs Aim To Raise $1.1 Billion In Busy Week

AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and other wireless phone companies are set to discuss 5G and other technologies with President Donald Trump and top administration officials Thursday morning, with radio spectrum usage a key policy issue.The wireless industry gathering follows Trump's meeting on Monday with the heads of 18 U.S. technology companies including Apple (AAPL), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT). The tech meeting focused on making the government's computing systems more efficient.Aside from AT&T and Verizon, also taking part in the wireless industry meeting will be T-Mobile US (TMUS), Sprint (S), venture capital firms and portfolio companies. The wireless meeting will focus on how government can create the right environment for breakthroughs, said a White House release.Ajit Pai, Federal Communications Commission chairman, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, and Gary Cohn, national economic director, also are expected to attend. The Obama administration made several blocks of high-frequency airwaves available for next-generation 5G services.The Obama FCC's initiatives included making frequencies in the 3.5 GHz band available for shared usage. That plan was backed by tech companies led by Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google.IBD'S TAKE: For news on top-performing technology stocks, take a look at IBD reports on tech leaders.T-Mobile and industry trade group CTIA, though, have asked the Trump administration to take a fresh look at the 3.5 GHz rules.5G networks are expected to enable faster wireless internet services to homes as well as high-speed connections to drones and self-driving cars.RELATED:Verizon Makes Big 5G Fiber Deal, But Puts This Option On HoldWhy The Race To Wireless 5G? The Internet Of ThingsAmazon, Dish Wireless Deal Would Target Internet Of Things: Citi

Amid speculation e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN) and Dish Network (DISH) could partner in 5G wireless services, a Citigroup report says a strategic deal could focus on the Internet of Things."The idea of Amazon partnering with Dish may seem unusual, but their aspirations may be intersecting around connected devices and the Internet of Things," the report said.IoT encompasses web-connected cars, advanced robotics, telemedicine, automated factories, smart cities and the development of massive sensor networks in such fields as agriculture. Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT&T (T) are also targeting the IoT as a growth market.Citigroup analyst Michael Rollins says Amazon Web Services, the cloud computing arm of Amazon, could use a wireless network as part of its IoT strategy. With Amazon as an "anchor customer" and possibly making an investment, Dish is more likely to build out a wireless network, the Citigroup analyst says."AWS offers an IoT software platform that can be paired with analytics and other services," Rollins said. "Together, (Dish and Amazon) could bundle cloud (Anything as a Service) with connectivity (Spectrum as a Service) to lower cost and accelerate the development of IoT services."Dish founder and CEO Charles Ergen is slated to speak late Tuesday at a JPMorgan technology conference in Boston. Braxton Carter, chief financial officer of T-Mobile US (TMUS), commented on the Dish-Amazon rumors at the same conference on Monday.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon stock is extended from an 843.94 buy point and an 860.96 alternate entry. Amazon is listed on the IBD Leaderboard, along with Dell Technologies, Workday and Alibaba Group. IBD's Leaderboard follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, up to the point where they start topping. Dish has cobbled together nearly 95 MHz of radio spectrum. Dish could still pursue a 5G mobile video strategy apart from an IoT deal with Amazon, the report says. Rollins says Dish would likely retain full control and ownership of the network and spectrum assets as part of any Amazon deal.Verizon has been viewed as a possible buyer of Dish and its spectrum. Dish stock could take a hit, depending on the terms of a deal with Amazon, Rollins said."Investors in Dish have been hoping for a sale of spectrum or the whole company for some time, and could be disappointed by this (Amazon) development," Rollins said. "If the details of the arrangement are not known, especially any terms around control of the spectrum long-term, this is likely to create confusion for the asset value story. This could lead to a shareholder rotation, with more speculative owners exiting should a near-term sale appear less likely. An injection of funding, however, could mitigate the bearish opinion that Dish cannot fund the construction of a network and would face material cash burn over time."Dish stock rose 0.1% to 63.86 in the stock market today. Shares in Amazon edged up 0.1% to 971.54, hitting a record 975.20.RELATED:Here's One More Thing Amazon May Be KillingWhy The Race To Wireless 5G? The Internet Of ThingsGoogle Trumpets Platform User Base Vs. Apple, Facebook, Amazon

Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) report earnings this week as sell-side analysts look for upside that could spark a rebound in struggling cable TV stocks.Amy Yong, analyst at Macquarie Capital, calls it a "make or break week" for cable TV companies to shift investor sentiment.Shares in Comcast, which reports first-quarter earnings early Wednesday, are down 16% this year and lost 1.5% Tuesday to close at 33.35. Charter has dropped 8% in 2018 and has plunged 23% from Sept. 7. Its shares fell 2.8% to close at 301.28 on the stock market today."Cable stocks have been under pressure, with ongoing concerns around video competition, broadband growth, and M&A," Jefferies analyst Scott Goldman said in a note to clients. "For Comcast, M&A remains a large overhang, which is likely to persist deep into (the second quarter)."Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseComcast made a bid for U.K.-based satellite TV broadcaster Sky in February. Investors worry that a bidding war could erupt vs. Walt Disney (DIS), which has agreed to buy 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and its stake in Sky. Comcast already owns media firm NBCUniversal and could invite more regulatory scrutiny, analysts say.Cable TV firms are expected to lose video subscribers in the first quarter. Analysts estimate Comcast will shed 75,000 video customers and Charter 32,000. Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), which reports earnings on Monday, is expected to lose 287,000 subscribers, though its Sling-branded internet video service will likely gain customers."Cable and satellite shares are meaningfully underperforming the S&P 500, as Wall Street darling days enjoyed through early 2017 are long over," Cowen & Co. analyst Gregory Williams said in his report to clients. "The industry (is) now enduring internet video competition while broadband approaches market saturation. As a result, the industry has undergone a re-rating."Comcast's profit is expected to rise 11% to 59 cents per share, with revenue climbing 11% to $22.74 billion. Charter's profit is expected to fall 2% to 55 cents a share with revenue growing 4.5% to $10.62 billion.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Google Earnings Raise Questions On Amazon.com Rivalry, SpendingFacebook Earnings Report Will Put Spotlight On Data Privacy ScandalTelecom Stocks To Watch And Industry NewsSell And Take Profits Or Hold? Telecom isn't a high earnings- or revenue-growth sector, even though wireless and broadband services are "must-haves" for U.S. consumers. Stocks often run up on merger and acquisition speculation, while tougher regulation can be a worry.X Big cap telecom stocks such as AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) have attractive dividends. And, telecom stocks are sometimes viewed as a safe haven when stock markets turn volatile.T-Mobile US (TMUS) has grabbed subscriber and revenue market share amid speculation it'll be part of wireless industry consolidation. Comcast (CMCSA)'s institutional ownership has been rising as it delivers growth from broadband services and media arm NBCUniversal.Bookmark this page to stay on top of companies such as Charter Communications (CHTR), Sprint (S), Dish Network (DISH), and CenturyLink (CTL). Also note that telecom developments often impact media stocks such as Walt Disney (DIS), Discovery Communications (DISCA) and 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOX).Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.RELATED:Best Stocks To Buy And WatchWhich Stocks Are Showing Rising Relative Strength?

If meal delivery service companies could package the aromas their recipes create, and somehow relay those to first-time users, I'm convinced sales of meal kits would be even hotter than they are now.Meal kits — recipes and ingredients packaged in precise quantities, usually shipped to your home by companies like Blue Apron (APRN), Amazon (AMZN) and Walmart (WMT) — already have a curiosity appeal, despite plenty of reasons not to like them. They take considerable work. The prices aren't exactly alluring. And like any new industry, several bugs remain in the system.Yet many people try them. And once you get a whiff of your first precisely concocted meal, it's all over. I've made meals from cookbooks as well as from scratch, and they've never smelled this good — even when I followed the recipe to a T. With meal kits, the appealing scent was always there — without fail. I began to wonder if they were manufactured.These aromas put a rose-colored tint on most everything I did when it came to meal kits, even when I botched my end of it. They make the meals taste better. They create the illusion you're a good cook. And for many Americans, they help make the time and money seem worthwhile.It's clear meal delivery service companies have found a niche. How big is this business? Statistics portal Statista says meal kits generated $1 billion in revenue worldwide in 2015 and will hit $10 billion by 2020. Packaged Facts put meal kit revenue at $5 billion last year.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseData analytics company Nielsen released data in March that showed 9% of U.S. consumers, or 10.5 million households, bought a meal kit in the prior six months. Another 25% of consumers, or 30.1 million households, said they would consider trying one in the next six months.I am now one of the 9%. In all, I tried six different meal kit companies over the past few months, and made 26 individual meals. I spent $287.51 of my company's money, or $11.06 per plate. I came away thinking this is a good idea — particularly since everyone I told about this story was curious about it.Still, there were questions. Can meal delivery service companies compete as retail giants enter the market? Walmart and Amazon.com are both selling meal kits, suggesting future price pressures. How long can smaller players like Blue Apron hold up? Shares of Blue Apron jumped nearly 6% Monday, but the stock remained at 3.21 a share. Walmart, meanwhile, is around 83 a share while Amazon is at an other-worldly 1,723.79.With a market basket full of competitors — and not a lot to distinguish one from the other — the business will only get more cutthroat as they jockey for position. Who can survive the shakeout?Meal-kit deliveries are somewhere on the cost spectrum between buying the ingredients yourself at a grocery store and going to a restaurant. In fact, some say meal kits are meant to be the bridge between the two, though market forces are moving it closer to the grocery store.A Chef'd chicken Marsala meal, shipped by Amazon, goes for $12.45 a plate. That's 31% cheaper than the $17.99 I'd pay for the same dish at the fairly nice Italian eatery in my neighborhood.But a meal delivery service is considerably more expensive than buying only the ingredients I needed at my local supermarket. The market price would've only come to $8.33 a head — that is, if you could buy only the amounts you need. On Planet Earth, they won't let you do that. So you'd need to make the dish two or three times — replenishing some ingredients along the way — to get that price. In addition to meal kits from Blue Apron, Amazon and Walmart, consumers can choose from a veritable smorgasbord of companies, including Home Chef, HelloFresh, Freshly, Sun Basket, Plated, Green Chef, Terra's Kitchen and PeachDish.Lifestyle mogul Martha Stewart is behind Martha & Marley Spoon. Even New England Patriots Quarterback Tom Brady is jumping in the game by partnering with a veggie-oriented service called Purple Carrot.Meal-kit discounts are getting more plentiful, so the margins are bound to get tighter for them all. You wonder why any company would make the effort, particularly if the cost curve is getting steeper.So far, only one pure-play meal kit provider in the U.S. has gone public, Blue Apron, and its stock is trading near 3, down 72% from its 11 IPO price in June 2017. Blue Apron has yet to turn a profit, and its sales have declined in the past two quarters.HelloFresh is traded on public markets, but only on its home court in Germany. After some ups and downs, the stock has a 2018 gain of 9%. Sales growth is strong, but like Blue Apron, the company is not yet profitable.At first blush, shelling out money for the privilege of slaving over a hot stove seemed unappealing when I could pay just a little more for someone else to do that for me at a restaurant. Not only do they place a meal before me, they do so while I'm sipping a cocktail.I also don't do that much cooking at my house. I do a lot of eating, as evidenced by my formidable girth. And don't get me wrong, I can cook. I grew up in a family that did a lot of work in restaurants. I just don't cook much anymore. It's one of many reasons my wife should be considered for sainthood.Third, my local grocery store — Ralphs, a California chain owned by Kroger (KR) — is less than one block away from my house. Ordering something online and having it delivered seems supremely lazy given my geographical situation, and waistline. But should I get even cheaper and lazier, my local store says it may soon be among the Ralphs stores offering prepackaged meal kits from Home Chef. And I hear the prices may be more inviting.That said, there's plenty to like about meal kits. It's not just the smells. The tastes were quite good, too. There wasn't a bad meal, even though I fumbled the cooking chores a couple of times.The aim of meal kits is to make cooking simple. If you can read, you can cook using this method. You just have to follow directions, which shouldn't be that hard.One plus is you're introduced to cuisine you normally wouldn't cook. Instead of Tuesday's rubber chicken, you can have the elegant-sounding Steak Moutarde with roasted sweet potato wedges. Still insist on poultry? They can dress that up, too. There's the aforementioned chicken Marsala with Linguine and roasted broccoli with goat cheese on the side. No rubber included.You also might encounter a wealth of new ingredients and tastes you never knew existed. Ever heard of Gochujang red pepper sauce? How about shredded Chihuahua cheese? I discovered those, plus Tumari sauce, Fregola Sarda Pasta and a cooking wine known as Verjus Blanc. What's great is if you find you don't like any of these, you're only allotted what you need for that meal. No waste.Further, you get a certain satisfaction from cooking the meal yourself. People who never thought they could cook probably will discover they can.Guys can fool their girlfriends into thinking they're debonair, at least for an evening. Busy people can do it in relatively short order, though probably not in the compressed time frame the makers of meal kits claim. And lazy husbands can help out their soon-to-be-canonized wives.Here are some of the highlights I personally encountered on my prepackaged culinary adventure. In order, we used Blue Apron, HelloFresh, Walmart, Chef'D via Amazon, Freshly and Home Chef. Tech stocks were in favor for most of Wednesday's session as the Nasdaq composite marked another all-time closing high. But a 0.6% intraday gain faded by the close. The Federal Reserve, as expected, hiked its key lending rate by a quarter point to a range of 1.75% to 2%. After today's hike, it sees two more for the rest of the year, although futures traders aren't so sure. According to the CME Group FedWatch tool, futures traders only see a 47% chance of a fourth rate hike at the December meeting.Top-performing tech stocks in the Nasdaq 100 included Leaderboard name Netflix (NFLX). Video game makers Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) also outperformed. So did media stocks like 21st Century Fox (FOX) and Dish Network (DISH) after the AT&T (T)/Time Warner (TWX) merger was approved without conditions late Tuesday.Shares of Comcast (CMCSA) fell slightly ahead of news it's bidding $65 billion for 21st Century Fox. Dow component Walt Disney (DIS) is another suitor of 21st Century Fox. Shares of Disney reversed higher in the Dow after falling 1.6% intraday.At the close, the Nasdaq was down 0.1%, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.5% and the S&P 500 gave back 0.4%. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in slightly higher than Tuesday's levels.On the earnings front, Pivotal Software (PVTL) was one of the best performing tech stocks, rising 33%. A strong earnings report fueled gains. The enterprise software name isn't profitable yet, but sales have been impressive in recent quarters. In the latest quarter, sales growth accelerated for the second straight quarter, rising 28% to $155.7 million.Group peer and IBD 50 name Paycom Software (PAYC) scored its fourth straight gain, rising 1% to 111.72. Its current consolidation shows a 118.55 buy point.Also in the IBD 50, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) extended gains after a heavy-volume bounce off the 50-day moving average Tuesday. Shares rose another 2.7% Wednesday.Meanwhile, a recent breakout from a double-bottom base for Grubhub (GRUB) gained more traction Wednesday. It gained for the second straight session in heavy volume, rising 2.8%.Interest-rate sensitive homebuilders lagged badly Wednesday, with the group as a whole down more than 3%.RELATED:ECB Meeting, Adobe Earnings, Retail Sales: Investing Action PlanThis Top Dividend Stock Breaks Out, Yields 7.8%Two Top Chip-Gear Stocks Hit With Downgrades While One Upgraded

Comcast (CMCSA) launched a takeover bid for 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) on Wednesday, offering $65 billion in cash for Rupert Murdoch's entertainment company and at a 19% premium over Walt Disney's (DIS) offer.Comcast's takeover bid had been expected in the wake of AT&T's (T) court victory late Tuesday that cleared its purchase of Time Warner (TWX). The nation's largest cable TV firm has been waiting for a ruling on the AT&T-Time Warner merger before announcing a formal bid for Fox.Comcast, which also owns NBCUniversal, has already bid $31 billion for satellite TV broadcaster Sky, in which Fox holds a 39% stake.Disney, however, in November agreed to buy Fox — including its stake in broadcaster Sky — for $54.4 billion in an all-stock deal.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseComcast fell 0.7% to 32 in after-hours trading on the stock market today while Disney slipped 0.3% to 105.90. Fox rose 1.6% to 44.13. In Wednesday's regular session, Fox popped 7.4% to 43.41. Comcast edged down 0.2% to 32.32. Disney gained 1.9% to 106.30.While Wall Street fears a bidding war, one scenario is that the companies carve up Fox, with Comcast getting Sky as well as video streaming service Hulu and perhaps other assets.Disney's deal includes Fox's stake in U.K.-based Sky, a film studio, cable networks and other assets. It excludes the Fox Broadcasting Network. Disney already owns broadcaster ABC.One obstacle to a truce is the history between the companies. A much smaller Comcast tried to buy Disney in 2004 but was rebuffed.Meanwhile, AT&T fell 6% to 32.22, despite its court victory. One analyst said AT&T's fall may be tied to arbitrage over the Time Warner transaction. MoffettNathanson also downgraded AT&T to sell.The Department of Justice sued in November 2017 to block AT&T's $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner on grounds that the merger could hurt competition in the pay-TV industry.Shares in CBS (CBS), Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF), Discovery Communications (DISCA) and other media firms rose in the wake of AT&T's (T) court victory.The landmark antitrust victory over the U.S. Department of Justice is expected to open the door to more acquisitions of media assets by telecoms or even internet companies, such as Amazon.com (AMZN).Viacom (VIA) gained 0.7% to 33.55 while CBS was up 3.6% to 54.27. Discovery rose 1.6% to 24.41. Lions Gate closed up 3% to 24.87 after jumping nearly 9% earlier. Media and cable TV industry baron John Malone owns stakes in Discovery, Lionsgate and Starz.Malone is chairman of Liberty Media (LSXMA). Malone's Liberty Broadband (LBRDA), meanwhile, is the biggest shareholder in Charter Communications (CHTR). Charter fell 2% to 285. Charter is the second-biggest cable TV firm behind Comcast.Shares in Dish Network (DISH) climbed 1.4% to 32.86.Verizon Communications (VZ) fell 3% to 47.40. Verizon has stated that it's not interested in buying large media assets.RELATED LINKS:How Big Is The AT&T-Time Warner Ruling? Even These Stocks Are RallyingSell And Take Profits Or Hold? U.S. stocks opened to brisk gains Thursday, following the European Central Bank's outline to potentially wind down its decade-long stimulus program by the end of the year. Stocks received an added boost from positive unemployment and May retail sales numbers.Stock futures and overseas markets had traded lower early, as the fallout from Wednesday's Fed announcement worked its way through global markets. Drugmaker Mylan (MYL) and software giant Oracle (ORCL) dragged on early trade. But IBD Leaderboard name Etsy (ETSY) bolted sharply higher, and IPOs Huya (HUYA) and Pivotal Software (PVTL) posted strong early advances.Thee Nasdaq Composite powered ahead 0.6%, aided by premarket gains from Comcast (CMCSA) and Dish Networks (DISH). Mylan posted the largest decline among both Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 stocks.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each jumped 0.3%. Nike (NKE) and Walt Disney (DIS) jumped to the top of the Dow. Royal Caribbean (RCL) and Comcast topped the S&P 500.Mylan dropped 3%, falling after a regulatory filing revealed the Food and Drug Administration had rejected the application for a Mylan generic asthma drug, based on GlaxoSmithKline's (GSK) blockbuster Advair. The filing said the FDA had found "minor deficiencies" in the drug. Mylan shares closed Wednesday up 19% from a May low, above key levels of support and climbing the right side of a five-month consolidation.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseOracle also dragged on early action, down 4.2% after JPMorgan downgraded the stock to neutral, from overweight, and pared the price target to 53, from 55. The note cited a JPMorgan survey that pointed to a sharp decrease in Oracle's product spending. Oracle shares have been consolidating since March.Meanwhile, three recent IPOs looked ready to add to their recent run-ups.Etsy spiked 23% in early trade. The Brooklyn, N.Y. company  raising its full-year revenue outlook, based on an increase in transaction fees charged to sellers using the arts and crafts marketplace. Etsy said transaction fees would rise to 5%, up from 3.5%. It also said it would charge a $10-per-month access fee, and was preparing to roll out a premium service aimed at larger, better-established vendors.Etsy shares are extended after a mid-May rebound from support at their 10-week moving average. The stock ended Wednesday 8% below its record high, set just after its IPO in April 2015.China-based Huya swung up more than 2% in early trade. The streaming online gaming and entertainment platform has a 7% gain for the week through Wednesday. It is extended after breaking out from an IPO base in May, ending Wednesday 224% above its May IPO price.Pivotal Software, a San Francisco-based developer, vaulted 6.8% in early action. The stock spiked 33% on Wednesday, as analysts ratcheted up price targets following a strong first-quarter report late Tuesday. The gain put shares 43% above an IPO base buy point of 19.72, and 88% beyond its April IPO price.Other than Etsy, early indicators were not good for retailers, with Tailored Brands (TLRD) and Michael's Companies (MIK) taking steep dives on the heels of their first-quarter reports.Tailored Brands, owner of the Jos. A. Banks chain, stripped out a 15% premarket decline. The company reported a narrow beat on its first-quarter sales and earnings lines. But the range of second-quarter earnings guidance was low, relative to consensus views. Shares closed Wednesday up 28% from an April breakout, and extended above a rebound from 10-week support.Craft retailer Michael's also dived 15%. The Irving, Texas-based chain reported earnings above expectations and revenue in line with estimates in its first quarter. But same-store-sales missed analyst targets. The stock has been struggling to recover, within a deep, five-month correction.Global markets shifted lower following Wednesday's losses in U.S. trade. The People's Central Bank of China disappointed markets there, leaving a key interest rate unchanged. China's long-standing strategy has been to track increases and decreases in U.S. rates, maintaining the spread between the two countries' rates.Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 0.9%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 tumbled 1%.Markets in Europe reversed early losses and surged higher in afternoon trade, after the ECB announced it will wind down its bond purchases by December. The CAC-40 in Paris led, up 0.6%. Frankfurt's DAX posted a 0.3% gain. London's FTSE 100 added 0.2%.First-time unemployment claims continued their decline, slipping to 218,000 in the week ended June 9, according to the Labor Department. That was down from the prior week's 223,000 applications, and ran counter to consensus projections for an uptick to 225,000 claims.Retail sales jumped in May, with Commerce Department data showing sales growth accelerating to 0.8%, vs. April's 0.4% gain. Forecasts called for another 4% increase. Sales also rose 0.8% minus auto and gasoline, vs. consensus projections for a 0.4% gain.U.S. benchmark oil prices leaned higher as the global mood turned positive. West Texas Intermediate moved up 0.6% to trade above $67 per barrel. Oil prices steadied above $66 a barrel this week, despite a welter of supply-related news.Oil prices gained 0.4% higher Wednesday, following official data showing a larger-than-expected 4.1 million-barrel draw on inventories for the week ended June 8. On Tuesday, the Energy Information Administration estimated average U.S. oil production in 2018 at 10.8 million barrels per day, up about 14% from the prior year. Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries plan to meet, along with partners including Russia, on June 22 to discuss production strategy.YOU ALSO MIGHT LIKE:The Big Picture: Will A Hawkish Fed Cut Market Rally Short?Breakout Watch: 97 Top-Rated Funds Own This No. 1-Ranked StockThis Chinese Leader's Recent Breakout Requires Patience, DisciplineIBD Stock Of The Day Ferrari Breaks Out Into Buy ZoneThis Top Dividend Stock Breaks Out, Yields 7.8%

Dish Network (DISH) reported a smaller-than-expected decline in first-quarter earnings early Monday, but the satellite and streaming TV service provider saw ongoing subscriber losses that were worse than feared.Adjusted earnings fell 11% vs. a year earlier to 76 cents a share,  still above analyst estimates. Revenue fell nearly 4% to $3.68 billion, below views, for the period ended March 31.Analysts had expected Dish Network  to report earnings of 69 cents on flat sales of $3.78 billion. Dish said it lost about 143,000 net pay-TV subscribers, which include both satellite TV and its video streaming service, Sling TV, far worse than estimates. In the year-earlier quarter, Dish lost 23,000 customers.Shares in the satellite TV broadcaster fell 2.3% to close at 62.93 on the stock market today.Dish Network cleared a 64.84 buy point last Thursday, but pulled back 0.9% to 64.44 on Friday.

The rally in cellphone tower stocks could lose steam, says brokerage Raymond James, which on Monday downgraded American Tower (AMT), Crown Castle (CCI) and SBA Communications (SBAC) on valuation and merger speculation.Ric Prentiss, a Raymond James analyst, downgraded American Tower and SBA Communications to outperform from "strong buy" and Crown Castle to market-perform from outperform."The prospects of an improving U.S. tower leasing environment and lower interest rates have paved the way for an impressive start for tower stocks in 2017 with year-to-date total returns of 19%, 24% and 30% for Crown Castle, American Tower and SBA Communications," Prentiss said in a report.Prentiss added that he's "taking some chips off the table," with valuation multiples expanded "to the upper range of their historical levels."American Tower lost 0.8% to 129.18, Crown Castle was up marginally to 102.21 and SBA slid 1.4% to 132.42 on the stock market today.Wireless phone companies such as AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) rent tower space to house radio antennas. Most towers house radio antennas from multiple carriers.Prentiss notes speculation that Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) could agree to merge. If approved, a Sprint merger with T-Mobile would eliminate one customer of the tower companies.IBD'S TAKE: Both Crown Castle and American Tower are real estate investment trusts (REITs), which pay dividends. REIT stocks perform well when interest rates are low. IBD's Finance-Property REIT group ranks just No. 80 out of 197 industry groups amid worries that interest rates could rise. Learn about other dividend-paying alternatives at IBD's Income Investor. "The prospect of such a deal receiving regulatory approval are far from certain but tower stocks have historically traded down on carrier consolidation deal announcements," Prentiss added.One long-term wild card for tower stocks is the deployment of 5G wireless services. Verizon has stated that it plans to be a leader in next-generation 5G wireless services, which will require "small-cell" technology in urban areas.RELATED:Amazon, Dish Wireless Deal Would Target Internet Of Things: CitiT-Mobile: 'Capital Structure' Would Be Key In Sprint Merger

Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 rose modestly early Friday as investors remained resilient event after after the surprising U.K. election news that the Conservatives have lost their majority in Parliament.The Conservatives remain the largest party and likely will retain control in some fashion, but PM Theresa May's fate is unclear while Brexit negotiations, set to start later this month, could face delay or more. The pound was sharply lower.XKeep an eye on financial stocks. Citigroup (C) broke out Thursday as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Bank of America (BAC) test key levels. Meanwhile, Amazon (AMZN)-Dish Network (DISH) rumors swirled again.Stock futures initially fell Thursday evening after initial exit polls predicted that Conservatives would fall short. But futures gradually firmed somewhat.Futures for the Dow industrials rose 0.2% vs. fair value. S&P 500 futures climbed nearly 0.2% while Nasdaq 100 futures were up 0.1% above fair value.Conservatives ended up with roughly 318 seats, down modestly from 330 before the election and less than the 326 seats needed for an outright majority. Labour should get 261 seats, a big rise, as most third parties lost ground.That would create a hung Parliament. However, Northern Ireland unionists, with 10 seats under the DUP, are set to provide enough support to give Conservatives control via a minority government.When May called the early election this spring, the Conservatives started with a huge lead, with most analysts betting that the ruling party would amass a sweeping majority and a freer hand in Brexit negotiations with the European Union.Now political uncertainty is heightened just before Brexit negotiations are supposed to get underway. Even though Conservatives likely will retain control of Parliament, May not be able to hang on as PM for long. But she apparently will fight to stay on for now.It's also unclear what direction Brexit will take if a handful of anti-EU hardliners or those who favor a "soft"  Brexit hold the process hostage.The DUP itself supports a "comprehensive free trade and customs agreement" with the EU, suggesting it wants a deal that retains as much access to the single market as possible. Northern Ireland does not want a hard border with Ireland.The U.K.'s FTSE 100 rose 0.65% in Friday intraday trading. The internationally focused FTSE 100 benefits from a weaker pound. Germany's Dax advanced 0.5% and France's CAC-40 climbed 0.5%.On Thursday, the Nasdaq composite climbed 0.4%, hitting a record high, while the Dow and S&P 500 eked out tiny gains.Citigroup and Bank of America rose fractionally in premarket action on the stock market today. JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs were not yet active. If global financial markets swing, Wall Street banks could be bellwethers.Citigroup, perhaps the most internationally exposed of the big U.S. banks, rose 2.15% to 63.21 in Thursday's regular session, hitting an 8-year high and clearing a 62.63 buy point. Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase rose more than 1%, all finding resistance at their 50-day moving averages. (Goldman and JPMorgan are Dow industrial components.Treasury yields, which were little changed early Friday, have risen modestly off recent lows in the past few sessions. Ex-FBI Director James Comey's testimony Thursday, though it didn't paint President Trump in a good light, didn't offer new bombshells. Also, the House OK'd legislation to roll back much of the Dodd-Frank financial regulations, though the real hurdle is the Senate.Meanwhile, Dish Network rose 3% late on a Benzinga report that it's in talks with Amazon for an expanded alliance, possibly even a takeover. Amazon-Dish rumors have been swirling for weeks or even months, with Amazon eyeing Dish's unused spectrum for video streaming.Amazon edged higher early Friday.RELATED:U.K. Heads For Hung Parliament As May's Election Gamble FailsThis Financial Giant Is A Buy As Banks Test Key LevelsThe Big Picture: Are These 3 Sectors Ready To Lead Market?Stocks Pull Off Narrow Win, But These Four Soared To New HighsAlibaba Soars On This Stunning Growth Forecast

Amazon.com (AMZN) and Dish Network (DISH) are in talks over a wireless partnership and could announce a deal at a satellite-TV trade show this week, an industry news website reported Wednesday.The report sent shares in cell-tower companies American Towers (AMT), Crown Castle (CCI) and SBA Communications (SBAC) up in midday trading.Dish and Amazon are in talks that would make the giant internet retailer a "foundational customer" of a wireless network Dish plans to build, Satellite Business News reported."We don't have any comment," said Dish spokesperson Bob Toevs. Amazon could not be reached for comment.Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google in 2012 held talks with Dish Network over a wireless partnership, the Wall Street Journal reported that year.Dish stock was up 0.8% to 62.77 in the stock market today.  American Tower stock rose 1.85% to 130.74, Crown Castle stock climbed 2.3% to 98.12, and SBA Communications stock jumped 2.5% to 134.08.Shares in e-commerce giant Amazon were 2.2% to 944.76 amid a broad market sell-off spurred by concerns over the viability of President Trump's administration.Dish has cobbled together nearly 95 MHz of radio spectrum for mobile video services, including 18 MHz of airwaves bought for $6.2 billion in a government auction that recently concluded.Teaming with Dish could give Amazon a wireless network to stream video. Amazon Prime Video competes with Netflix (NFLX).AT&T (T), which acquired satellite broadcaster DirecTV Group in 2015, has launched a mobile video services.Dish, meanwhile, has touted its spectrum as a good fit for next-generation 5G wireless services. Analysts say 5G services could include connections to self-driving cars as well as drones. Amazon is a leader in drone technology.Dish has been unable to forge a deal with wireless companies such as T-Mobile US (TMUS) or Sprint (S). Verizon Communications (VZ) has been viewed as a possible buyer of Dish.RELATED:Here's One More Thing Amazon May Be Killing

Many advisors favor a holistic approach to financial planning. But some take holistic to a whole new level.If they see an opening to help clients enhance their health and wellness, some advisors jump at the chance. They may define their role in expansive terms — as enabling individuals to lead better, richer lives.Coaching clients to improve their well-being may seem to fall outside an advisor's purview. But one's financial and physical health can go hand-in-hand."As an advisor, you have to walk a fine line between providing wellness coaching and therapy," said Chuck Markham, an investment advisor in Vernon, N.J. "You need to recommend a medical professional" if a client presents more serious physical or psychological maladies.Given his background as a licensed professional counselor (LPC), Markham is attuned to mental health issues that beset others. If he senses that a client can benefit from a therapist or other medical provider, he may offer a referral.In most cases, however, polite questioning can in itself forge a bond. If clients mention their weight problem, for example, Markham might ask, "Is there anything you can't do because of your weight?"If they express disappointment that they can no longer enjoy hiking or travel, he might propose action steps."I'll coach them to choose among diet plans and see their doctor," he said. "But that's only if they bring it up. If they don't, we won't introduce it as a problem."As a general rule, Markham avoids giving unsolicited lectures to clients about the need to improve their health and wellness. He does not want to raise sensitive matters that distract from financial planning.Yet his LPC training helps him pose gentle questions that can lead to breakthroughs. If a spouse arrives for an appointment and says, "Sorry, but my husband is late again. He's always late," Markham might reply, "Oh, why is he always late?""She might talk about his poor health or some other problem," he said. "If she does, I might ask, 'Is this something you'd feel comfortable having me follow up about?' They may not expect their financial person to do all this other stuff, so I'll ask their permission" to get more involved.For advisors who want to dish out wellness tips, positioning themselves as role models and preaching about their healthy lifestyle rarely proves persuasive. And berating clients for their poor stress management or self-destructive habits may drive them away for good.Savvy advisors find creative, nonthreatening ways to raise health issues with clients. Technology platforms can prove a good starting point.Danielle Howard, a certified financial planner in Basalt, Colo., asks clients to complete a "financial satisfaction survey" by Money Quotient, a nonprofit that provides financial life planning tools. If their answers reveal anxiety about finances, she might ask, "What kind of exercise are you getting to combat stress?"If they admit they need to exercise more, Howard might suggest daily walks, yoga or other activities. For client meetings, she sometimes says, "Instead of sitting here in our conference room, do you want to walk and talk?""We're in the middle of the Rocky Mountains with lots of parks around here, so it's easy to walk outside," she added.To reinforce the importance of health and well-being, Howard sponsors luncheons that feature guest speakers such as physicians and wellness experts. Geared for women, the sessions are open to the public. But she also invites clients to attend."When I introduce the speaker, I try to tie their topic to financial wellness," Howard said. "It's all part of creating holistic life wellness."Some advisors go further to link their discussions about wellness directly to a client's financial future. Emphasizing that a healthier lifestyle can cut health care costs, they may prod clients to rethink their daily routine.Niv Persaud, an Atlanta-based certified financial planner, asks clients questions such as, "Do you belong to a fitness center?", "Do you have a personal trainer?" and "Do you dine out often?""It might be framed in terms of helping the client address the cost of long-term care," she said. "Unhealthy living catches up with you, and in-home care can be expensive."Persaud finds that clients respond forthrightly, even when they admit unhealthy habits. Radiating a positive attitude, she may refer them to a professional wellness instructor or other resource."My clients are not sheepish in answering my questions," she said. "They know it is part of a larger framework."RELATED:Advisors Fight Off Burnout By Finding Ways To Break From Routine

Keysight Technologies (KEYS) will get a boost as wireless phone companies step up testing of 5G wireless equipment ahead of wide-scale network deployment by 2020, says Citigroup, which initiated coverage on the company with a buy rating.Citigroup analyst Stanley Kovler set a price target of 44 on Keysight stock, which was up nearly 2% to 39.10 at the close of the stock market today.AT&T (T), T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Verizon Communications (VZ) all plan to deploy 5G services, though their strategies differ. 5G networks are expected to enable faster wireless internet services to homes as well as high-speed connections to drones and self-driving cars."Heading into the 5G wireless spending cycle and deployments into late 2018 and early 2019, we are positive on (Keysight's) business and expect orders for new testing equipment to begin ramping in the second half of 2017," said Kovler in a report.The Citigroup analyst, though, says the 5G opportunity may be offset somewhat by weakness in Keysight's aerospace and defense business.IBD'S TAKE: Keysight stock is up 7% in 2017 with Monday's gain. Keysight stock has a technical buy point of 39.46 after forming a cup chart pattern. The Electronics-Scientific Manufacturing group ranks No. 7 out of 197 industry groups. Learn more about the group's companies such as Coherent at IBD Stock Checkup.Santa Rosa, Calif.-based Keysight was spun off from Agilent Technologies (A) in 2014. Keysight in January agreed to buy Ixia (XXIA) for about $1.6 billion in cash, adding network testing software and security products."Near-term upside is somewhat capped owing to weak near-term trends in the aerospace/defense segment," added Kovler. "Combined with the increase in near-term leverage to acquire Ixia, we believe significant EPS upside beyond our current model is somewhat capped in 2017 until planned cost synergies can become more evident over the next 24 months."RELATED:Verizon Makes Big 5G Fiber Deal, But Puts This Option On HoldWhy The Race To Wireless 5G? The Internet Of ThingsAmazon, Dish Wireless Deal Would Target Internet Of Things: Citi

Ahead of its earnings report, Walt Disney's (DIS) quarterly story remains something of a split personality, as its studio segment boasts more hits but its media networks unit — notably ESPN — encounters obstacles.Questions over its recent talent bloodletting at the sports cable network will now likely add to by-now-routine scrutiny over its subscriber figures when the media conglomerate reports after the close Tuesday.For Disney's fiscal second quarter, Street analysts are looking for profit and revenue growth of 4% to $1.41 a share and $13.45 billion, respectively.Late last month, ESPN laid off about 100 of its on-air talent, as network chief John Skipper said that the network navigates "changes in technology and fan behavior." Subscriber loss concerns continue to dog the network.A shift in viewership habits and the proliferation of online platforms have, over the years, hit media companies where it hurts: paid subscriptions and advertising revenue.Last week, HBO and Warner Bros. parent Time Warner (TWX) reported a decline in advertising revenue at its Turner network, while Viacom (VIAB) shares dove, despite a beat, amid concerns that its flagships channels were losing ground in distribution.Notably, "three of four biggest weekly sell-offs in media in the last decade have happened in the last three years, which shows the degree of uncertainty that has crept into the sector," wrote Barclays media analyst Kannan Venkateshwar.Additionally: Hulu, of which Disney is a joint owner, launched on Wednesday a live-TV beta service that promises around 50 channels for $39.99 a month, adding to the fray of over-the-top "skinny" bundle providers that includes Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue.21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal and Time Warner also have stakes in Hulu.Disney shares fell 0.5% to 111.42 on Monday, still below a 112.09 buy point after undercutting that level last week. Viacom slipped 1.1% after diving 13.5% last week. Fox dropped 2.5% Monday, on top of its 4.6% weekly loss.IBD's TAKE: It's not all doom and gloom for media companies in the subscriber wars. There's one — perhaps surprising — media company that is still adding accounts while others bleed subscriptions.Disney's media networks unit makes up the bulk of total revenue — over 42% in the December-ended quarter — which is why ESPN alone receives so much attention. And the strength of the legacy sports news brand may not carry as much weight in the future."In every evolution of OTT, the number of clicks needs to get to a program guide or a network viewing option is actually increasing," said Venkateshwar in his broad note on U.S. media. "Given the importance of consumer inertia in usage patterns, this is not a trivial shift."The interface of streaming platforms also means that coverage is divvied up by content and not by network, he added."Instead, the default interface is organized by sport and/or teams... . As a result, it is tough to see the brands of individual networks retaining any value in the coming years," wrote Venkateshwar.But Disney still has some tricks up its sleeve.ESPN and BAMTech are slated to launch a direct-to-consumer sports streaming service "probably" this calendar year, said CEO Bob Iger in the company's most recent earnings call, though it is designed to be a supplement — and not a replacement — to the main ESPN network. Disney has a one-third stake in streaming technology firm BAMTech.And massive hits for Disney's studio segment as well as optimistic projections for its movie pipeline, which is packed with "Star Wars," Marvel and Pixar films, have some analysts staying bullish."Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" has so far earned over $427.6 million globally, debuting domestically this past weekend with a $145 million haul, according to Box Office Mojo. And Disney's March release of "Beauty and the Beast" remains the U.S. box office leader in 2017 with $487.6 million domestically, for a total of $1.19 billion worldwide."We continue to be buyers of Disney as we believe the robust film slate will continue to broaden the company's moat and drive significant value across key segments," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Stan Meyers on Sunday. He has an overweight rating on the stock.RELATED:Viacom Tries To Calm Fears Its Channels Are Losing DistributionBig Media Stocks Unfazed Even As Hollywood Came To Brink Of StoppageIf You Think Netflix, Amazon Disrupted Hollywood, You'll Love Snap, FacebookESPN On-Air-Talent Layoffs Double What Was Expected

X Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), CBS (CBS), Viacom (VIAB), Comcast (CMCSA) and other big companies sold off on cable advertising concerns. Meanwhile, Hulu, the streaming platform jointly backed by four major media conglomerates, has officially entered the live-television fray with a more-than-50-channel bundle, priced at $39.99 a month.Time Warner (TWX) said Wednesday that advertising revenue fell 2% in the first quarter vs. a year earlier, with declines continuing the quarter. Comcast said last week that its NBCUniversal ad revenue fell in Q1. Pay-TV operators suffered big subscriber losses in Q1 as well.CBS tumbled 3.35% on the stock market today. Disney lost 2.4%, dropping below a buy point and its 50-day moving average. Viacom reversed sharply to sink 7.5%, below its 200-day line. Fox sold off 5.1%. Comcast sank 2%, closing just below a buy point cleared after reporting earnings. Dish Network (DISH) fell 4.4% and Charter Communications (CHTR) 3.9%, both undercutting their 50-day lines. Time Warner, which is being acquired by AT&T (T), dipped 0.3%. AT&T slid 1.4% to a five-month low.Meanwhile, Hulu CEO Mike Hopkins announced the live-TV service's beta launch at its annual upfronts presentation Wednesday, calling it a "natural extension of our business."Disney, Fox, Comcast's NBCUniversal and Time Warner all have a stake in Hulu, which explains its fairly comprehensive channel offerings, such as ABC, NBC, Fox, E!, Bravo, USA, TBS, CNN and CNBC. The service also includes access to the platform's streaming library.Live sports stations are also part of the basket. The live service includes NBC Sports, CBS Sports Network, Fox Sports channels, TNT and a number of different ESPN stations.Like rival products from Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue and Dish Network's Sling TV, Hulu's package isn't all-encompassing, although it does include CBS (CBS), which has been building out its own over-the-top streaming presence through CBS All Access.As Vulture points out, the Hulu bundle lacks AMC Networks (AMCX) channels and Viacom-owned MTV, Comedy Central and VH1.For comparison, Vue's comparably priced $39.99-a-month Access tier, the most basic of four levels, offers around 45 channels. (Its high-end $74.99-a-month Ultra level includes 90 channels, including HBO and Showtime.) Sling's $25 monthly Blue-level subscription includes 45 channels but no CBS or ESPN.Hulu's service includes 50 hours of recorded storage, but 200 more hours in "enhanced cloud DVR" will run subscribers an extra $14.99 a month. Vue offers unlimited cloud DVR storage for 28 days. YouTube TV, from Alphabet (GOOGL) unit Google, has launched a $35-a-month service in several major cities with no cloud storage limits either.Both CBS and Viacom report quarterly results Thursday.

Drugmakers and financial services firms look like attractive investments after years of being beaten down, said Charles Pohl, a manager of the Dodge & Cox Balanced Fund (DODBX), during a panel session Thursday at the Morningstar Investment Conference in Chicago.Financial services are the $15.8 billion mutual fund's largest sector, with 29% of shareholder money as of March 31.That mutual fund is exposed to foreign financials, including ADRs of Netherlands-based Aegon (AEG), which provides insurance, pension and asset management. It also hold bonds from the U.K.'s Barclays (BCS), which provides banking and other financial services, as well as France's BNP Paribas.Still, the fund's financial services exposure is mainly U.S. based, though those holdings do business globally. The fund's top four holdings are U.S. stocks Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC), Charles Schwab (SCHW) and Capital One Financial (COF).In the panel discussion occurring on the conference's first full day, Pohl said rising rates in the U.S. are a tailwind. So are gradually easing regulatory burdens abroad.Noriko Chen, a manager of $63.3 billion American Funds New Perspective (ANWPX), agreed, pointing out that political pressures beating down on financials globally have created buying opportunities.Swiss-based insurer Chubb (CB) is a top-25 holding. So is Hong Kong-based AIA Group, which provides life insurance and other financial services.An aging population is a key factor in making pharmaceutical companies attractive.Among pharmaceuticals, ADRs of France's Sanofi (SNY) and Switzerland's Novartis (NVS) are in the top 10 of Pohl's fund. Britain and Sweden's AstraZeneca (AZN) is also a holding.Chen said she also likes certain state-owned enterprises (SOEs) whose home-country governments mandate that the firms pay relatively hefty dividends. Some of those dividend yields in China and Brazil are 25% or higher, she said.Forty-two percent of her fund's assets are foreign stocks. Fourteen percent are domiciled in the Asia/Pacific region.Panelist Amit Wadhwaney of Moerus Capital Management, another value-oriented investor, said he likes British-based Coats Group, the world's largest manufacturer of thread. He likes its pricing power and elastic demand. Shares have climbed 113% the past 12 months vs. 14% for the S&P 500.His firm's taste for stocks with strength and staying power is reflected in its name, the first word of which is a Latin reference to a city's defensive walls. He manages the young and tiny $21.4 million Moerus Worldwide Value Fund (MOWIX).RELATED:What's Going On At The Morningstar Conference

X President Trump's political woes sent the S&P 500 index, Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite tumbling, but not for long. But Alibaba (BABA) and other China internet stocks rallied on generally upbeat reports. Dow retailers Wal-Mart (WMT) and Home Depot (HD) had strong results, but many other retailers are struggling. Dow tech giant Cisco Systems (CSCO) sold off on its weak guidance.An ongoing stream of damaging media reports took their toll on President Trump, raising concerns that he'll be too distracted or too weak to push tax cuts through this year, if at all. The Dow industrials and S&P 500 fell 1.8% on Wednesday. The Nasdaq composite tumbled 2.6%. But stocks slashed losses on Thursday and Friday, with the Dow and S&P 500 off 0.4% and the Nasdaq 0.6%. Credit Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN) and the other FANG+ stocks, along with Alibaba (BABA) and other Chinese internets.Alibaba's Q1 EPS rose 37% to 63 cents, but missed the consensus by 3 cents as tax expenses and spending on its entertainment and cloud computing businesses ramped up. Revenue jumped 60% to $5.61 billion, beating views. The Chinese e-commerce giant also OK'd a $6 billion buyback. Shares rose 0.5% Thursday after falling 5% early, then rose to a record high on Friday. On Wednesday, archrival Tencent (TCEHY) reported EPS surged 57% in local currency to 22 cents, beating by a penny, as revenue popped 55% $7.18 billion. Tencent stock hit new highs.On Tuesday, internet portal Sina (SINA) and its majority-owned social messaging site Weibo (WB) reported stronger than expected earnings. Weibo reported daily active users of 154 million, up 28% vs the year earlier. Weibo shares soared 25%, Sina 22%.Specialty online retailer Vipshop (VIPS) reported in-line earnings, better-than-expected revenue and solid guidance, but shares tumbled 10.3%.Baozun (BZUN), an Alibaba-backed provider of e-commerce services for brand partners, reported EPS that just met views. Shares dived 12% on Wednesday, but were up 8.6% for the week.Target (TGT) earnings fell 6% while sales dipped 1% to $16.02 billion, but those were not as bad as feared. Comps skidded 1.3% but better than the expected 3.7% tumble. Shares rose Wednesday but finished the week up just 0.4%, still close to five-year lows. Meanwhile, Wal-Mart Q1 profit unexpectedly ticked up 2% to $1 a share, surprising Street estimates for a 2% dip, though 1.4% sales growth to $117.54 billion just missed. Still, U.S. same-store sales rose, unlike Target and many other retailers. The megastore credited organic growth at Walmart.com for its 63% boost in U.S. online sales, although it also acquired two e-commerce properties, Moosejaw and ModCloth, during the quarter. Wal-Mart shares rose 4.1% to a two-year best.Cisco Systems (CSCO) adjusted fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 5% to 60 cents, beating views by 2 cents. Revenue fell 1% to $11.94 billion, above estimates but the sixth straight year-over-year decline as the networking giant transitions from sluggish switch and router hardware to software and security. Current-quarter revenue guidance was far short of forecasts, in part because of concerns that President Trump's economic and tax agenda has stalled.Cisco shares fell 6.7% for the week.Home Depot (HD) reported first-quarter earnings that beat estimates, making it one of the few retailers that isn't cracking under the weight of e-commerce, discounts, discounters, too many stores and not enough traffic. The home-improvement chain hiked its full-year EPS forecast, which was still below expectations. Home Depot shares hit a record high Tuesday but dipped 0.4% for the week. Rival Lowe's (LOW), which reports next week, lost 0.3%, but in buy range.The semiconductor equipment manufacturer's second-quarter profit rose 132% while sales climbed 45% to $3.55 billion, both better than expected. It was the third straight quarter of triple-digit earnings growth for Applied Materials (AMAT). For the current quarter, Applied gave EPS and sales targets above the consensus. Applied Materials jumped early Friday, but closed up just 0.4%.RELATED:Applied Materials Hails 'Tremendous Momentum'; EPS Growth Tops 100% AgainSalesforce.com said fiscal Q1 adjusted earnings were 28 cents a share, up 17% vs. a year earlier, with revenue rising 25% to $2.39 billion. Its July quarter billings outlook was light but the cloud-based, on-demand business software pioneer raised its full-year fiscal 2018 revenue outlook by about $100 million. Salesforce shares rose early Friday but reversed for a 0.4% decline.RELATED:Salesforce.com Beats Profit, Revenue Views, Tweaks Full-Year OutlookT.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods parent TJX (TJX) turned in mixed results, missing on revenue, as same-store sales grew 1%. Guidance was soft. The off-price chain said it is introducing a home-fashions concept to the U.S. this year. Ross Stores (ROST) pulled ahead of estimates with 82 cents in per-share profit and $3.3 billion in sales. Comps grew 3%. But Q2 profit guidance missed, and full-year EPS outlook was a little light. Off-price retailers have typically been gems, but both TJX and Ross are trading below their 50-day moving averages amid a greater retail shudder. TJX shares fell 3.9% for the week. Ross rose Friday, paring its week loss to 2%.Computer-aided design software firm Autodesk (ADSK) saw its stock surge 14.7% to record levels Friday after it beat Wall Street's targets for its fiscal first quarter ended April 30. Autodesk lost 16 cents a share excluding items on revenue of $486 million, when analysts were looking for it to lose 24 cents a share ex items on sales of $470.4 million. The San Rafael, Calif.-based company is taking a revenue hit as it continues its business model transition from licensed software to cloud computing services. Another design software firm, Synopsys (SNPS), also posted better-than-expected fiscal second-quarter sales and earnings. It earned 88 cents a share excluding items, up 9%, on sales of $680 million, up 12%. Wall Street was expecting 86 cents and $672 million. But shares fell nearly 4.65% for the week.Jack in the Box (JACK) earnings beat Q1 forecasts, and the burger chain said it was looking at "potential alternatives" with regards to Qdoba, its fast-casual Mexican chain. CEO Lenny Comma said that over the past year it "has become apparent" that the company's valuation "is being impacted by having two different business models." Shares nearly hit a record high intraday Wednesday, but pared gains for a 3.75% weekly rsise.As Jack in the Box expands delivery services, so has McDonald's (MCD). The Golden Arches announced the expansion of its delivery service to Los Angeles, Phoenix, Chicago and Columbus, Ohio.Sears Holdings (SHLD) CEO Eddie Lampert said on the corporate blog that speculations on the ailing retailer's potential demise had hurt business. Lampert also said that tool supplier One World, seeking to get out of its contract with Sears, had threatened to sue the retailer and had sought to embarrass them. The CEO said Sears "has paid and continues to make all payments to One World" and that it would defend itself against any legal action. Sears shares sank 17.4%.The pharmacy and wireless markets could be the next Amazon (AMZN) next targets. An unconfirmed report that the online giant is seeking to break into the drug-dispensing business weighed on Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), CVS Health (CVS) midweek. But it may not be smooth sailing for the online giant in this competitive space, Mizuho Securities analyst Ann Hynes wrote that the established players have access to discounted drugs that Amazon is unlikely to beat and already offer drug delivery by mail. Plus, the regulatory and infrastructure hurdles to building out a pharmacy business are high. Amazon is also said to be in talks with Dish Network (DISH) over a wireless partnership. Word of a deal is awaited.The race toward an autonomous driving future continues to heat up. On Tuesday, BMW Group, Intel (INTC) and Mobileye (MBLY) announced a partnership with Delphi Automotive (DLPH) to bring self-driving kits to multiple automakers. BMW, Intel and Mobileye were already working on a self-driving vehicle and Mobileye, being acquired by Intel, had an autonomous system pact with Delphi.
