Some regulatory authority on consumer protection would shift to the Federal Trade Commission.Pai says new "transparency" rules requiring policy disclosures by service providers will protect consumers.Moffett says it is unlikely Congress will step in to deal with net-neutrality issues on a bipartisan basis.RELATED:Why AT&T's Antitrust Battle May Quash Other Media MegamergersHow Hulu Live, YouTube TV Are Helping AT&T, Dish StreamingCable TV's Hail Mary: Hike Broadband Prices Amid Cord-Cutting

Internet service providers such as AT&T (T), Comcast (CMCSA) and Verizon Communications (VZ) could get a bigger-than-expected lift from overhauled net neutrality rules under a preliminary proposal from Ajit Pai, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.Pai let trickle some key elements of his proposal via a commentary piece he wrote that appeared in The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday. As expected, Pai proposed that the telecom agency eliminate public-utility-type Title 2 regulations that were foisted on internet service providers by the Obama administration. The Title 2 rules are part of the Communications Act of 1934.Pai may in principle retain rules that bar ISPs from blocking or slowing web content, although they won't be enforced under Title 2 authority."I look forward to returning to the light-touch, market-based framework that unleashed the digital revolution and benefited consumers here and around the world," Pai said in a news release.The Republican-led FCC will vote on Pai's proposal at its Dec. 14 meeting.There's speculation Pai's proposal could open the door to these service providers to seek fees from content producers or business partners for internet "fast lanes" or "paid prioritization." That could be a significant revenue stream for companies like Comcast, Charter Communications (CHTR), AT&T and Verizon.IBD'S TAKE: Read IBD's The Big Picture column each day to stay on top of the market direction, a key indicator that lets you know when you can be aggressive and when you should move to the sidelines.The details of Pai's proposal, which may include paid prioritization, are expected to be posted on the FCC's website Wednesday morning.Pai is expected to propose getting rid of the Obama-era "general conduct" rule that gives the FCC broad power to police all broadband activity by internet service providers.And, Pai proposed that the Federal Trade Commission re-asset its authority to protect consumer privacy in broadband services.Comcast, in a statement released on Tuesday said: "(Pai's) proposal is not the end of net neutrality rules. With the FCC transparency requirement and the restoration of the FTC's role in overseeing information services, the agencies together will have the authority to take action against any (service provider) which does not make its open internet practices clearly known to consumers, and if needed enforce against any anti-competitive or deceptive practices."RELATED:Why AT&T's Antitrust Battle May Quash Other Media MegamergersHow Hulu Live, YouTube TV Are Helping AT&T, Dish StreamingCable TV's Hail Mary: Hike Broadband Prices Amid Cord-Cutting

Cable TV companies and media stocks sold off on renewed worries that pay TV cord-cutting is accelerating after AT&T (T) preannounced Q3 financial numbers, including the loss of 90,000 video subscribers.X"We believe cord-cutting continues to gain steam as streaming builds momentum," said UBS analyst John Hodulik in a report. He estimated that the pay TV industry will lose about 1 million subscribers in the third quarter compared with 325,000 in the same quarter last year, based on recent management commentary.AT&T plunged 6.1% to close at 35.86 on the stock market today. AT&T also blamed recent hurricanes for video subscriber losses. Comcast (CMCSA), which in early September warned of video subscriber losses, shed 3.3% to 36.19.Comcast had attributed some of its video subscriber weakness to aggressive promotions launched by AT&T's landline "U-verse"-branded TV service. Analysts say AT&T's DirecTV satellite TV service likely suffered the bulk of its subscriber losses in the third quarter.Shares in satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) fell 5.1% to 49.03 on Thursday. While AT&T bought DirecTV for $49 billion in 2016, analysts say Dish has had trouble finding a suitor amid continued subscriber losses.Both AT&T and Dish have launched internet video services. AT&T said it added 300,000 online DirecTV Now subscribers in the third quarter, offsetting some of the traditional pay TV losses. However, both AT&T and Dish garner less profit from internet services than traditional pay TV, analysts say.While AT&T is losing a net 90,000 video subscribers, it's traditional pay TV customer losses in third quarter are higher — 390,000 — partially offset by the addition of 300,000 internet video subscribers.IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and the end-of-day The Big Picture (take a free trial) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases.UBS estimates that Dish's Sling service has 1.8 million subscribers and DirecTV Now 760,000. YouTube, the video website of Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google, launched a livestreaming TV service in early 2017.So did Hulu, a joint venture of 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS), Comcast and Time Warner (TWX). UBS estimates that YouTube has 180,000 subscribers; Hulu has 175,000.Shares in Charter Communications (CHTR) fell 2.6% to 355.71 on Thursday. Altice USA (ATUS) slipped 2.7% to 25.15.Worries over accelerated cord-cutting also hit media stocks. That's because they garner per-subscriber programming fees from cable-TV and satellite-TV companies. Disney fell 1.6% to 96.93, CBS (CBS) slipped 1% to 56.51, and Discovery Communications (DISCA) shed 3.6% to 19.28.AT&T also disclosed that wireless customers upgraded to new smartphones at a slower rate in the September quarter vs. the year-earlier period, sparking speculation over tepid demand for Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 8.Apple stock edged down 0.4% to 156.RELATED:AT&T Stock Falls, Near Key Level For Time Warner DealCan Google's YouTube TV Hit 2 Million Subscribers In A Year?Dish Bulls And Bears Agree On One Thing: What's Coming In Q3

Google's YouTube TV has 200,000 subscribers and could hit 2 million by the end of 2018, says one Wall Street analyst.Andy Hargreaves of KeyBanc Capital Markets says YouTube TV isn't yet profitable but that doesn't matter to Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL). Hargreaves says Google aims to build a brand that can take away advertising revenue from traditional TV."The service is now rolled out to almost 50 cities, which should drive accelerating subscriber growth in the second half of 2017 and into 2018," he said in a note to clients.YouTube TV features live content from major broadcasters. It's priced at $35 monthly, or $40 as an app on Apple (AAPL) TV. YouTube TV's progress is being closely watched, because Google is a new entrant in video streaming. Other video streaming services are offered by incumbent pay-TV or media companies, with the exception of Sony.AT&T (T) sells DirecTV Now and Dish Network (DISH) offers Sling TV. Hulu launched a live TV service in May. Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal and Time Warner (TWX) all have a stake in Hulu.Amazon.com (AMZN), similar to Google, is a newcomer to video streaming. Amazon Prime Video does not yet offer live TV from the big four broadcasters. Amazon Prime Video has stepped up investments in original content and is similar to Netflix (NFLX). Apple said in September that it expects to offer an Amazon Video Prime app on its TV platform later this year.Hargreaves has an overweight rating on Google stock, with a price target of 1,100. Alphabet shares ended trading Tuesday up 0.5% to 972.08.IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and the end-of-day The Big Picture (take a free trial) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases."We estimate content costs are $39.55 per sub, and expect operating expenses to be 17% of revenue," he said. "This suggests YouTube TV will generate operating margins of minus 4%, with largely variable costs that are likely to prevent meaningful leverage in the medium term.""Despite a likely lack of direct profits, YouTube TV provides Google with a portion of TV ad inventory on the service," Hargreaves went on to say. "We believe YouTube TV represents a significant opportunity to capture share of the $70 billion U.S. TV ad market."RELATED:EU To Hit Apple, FANG Stocks With Digital Tax If Ireland Goes AlongShort Sellers Step Up Bets Against Netflix, Amazon, FacebookFacebook, Amazon, Google: Should They Now Fear Regulators?Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksLeaderboard: Daily Updates On Stocks With Potential For Big Gains

Dish Network's (DISH) third-quarter EPS is expected to rise 62% from the year-earlier quarter to 68 cents, though analysts expect revenue to be flat as the company again loses satellite-TV subscribers.Dish Network is slated to report Q3 earnings early Wednesday.Dish Network had 13.59 million pay TV subscribers as of June 30, down from 13.93 million a year earlier. The company does not break out its subscribers to its Sling-branded Internet video service but instead lumps them in with its total subscriber count.In Q2, Dish Network reported a net loss of 281,000 pay TV customers, its biggest quarterly subscriber loss ever. On Dish Networks Q2 earnings call, though, management discussed plans to build an addressable advertising platform for satellite TV with AT&T (T), lifting the stock.IBD'S TAKE: Dish Network stock has traded on takeover speculation more than fundamentals, as its core pay TV business slows. Most mergers are on hold until a government spectrum auction ends. Investors interested in growth companies can take a look at IBD's Sector Leaders, where Palo Alto Networks on Monday joined Inphi and Gigamon.Analysts estimate that Dish Networks will report Q3 revenue of $3.74 billion, about even with the year-earlier period.Dish Network has amassed a swath of radio spectrum for mobile video services, but it's been unable to partner with Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US (TMUS) or Sprint (S). AT&T acquired Dish archrival and No. 1 satellite TV firm DirecTV Group in 2015. AT&T last month agreed to buy media giant Time Warner (TWX) for $85 billion, but the deal will face regulator scrutiny.Dish Network, Verizon and T-Mobile are prohibited from engaging in strategic talks until an auction of airwaves owned by local TV broadcasters concludes. It's uncertain when that auction, which began in March, will end.Dish stock is down a fraction for the year, but ticked up 0.8% to 56.68 at the close on the stock market today.RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosWill AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile Bite At Lower Airwave Prices?

Who will be the next top regulator for AT&T (T), Comcast (CMCSA) and Verizon Communications (VZ)?President-elect Donald Trump could be leaning toward appointing pro-business economist Jeffrey Eisenach as the next Federal Communications Commission chairman, though the agency's current senior Republican member, Ajit Pai, also likely is in the running, analysts say.Either Eisanach or Pai would be a relief for AT&T, Comcast and Verizon after four years of battling Obama administration appointee Tom Wheeler on broadband regulation and other issues. Eisenach opposes net neutrality rules.Trump on Monday named Eisenach as a top advisor on his transition team for telecom issues. At minimum, he'll help staff the agency, and he might well wind up as chairman, analysts say."Eisenach is a front-runner for the FCC chair," Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan said in a research report. "Eisenach will likely craft an FCC makeup that rolls back net neutrality."IBD'S TAKE: Internet giants Facebook, Google, Amazon.com and tech companies such as Netflix and Apple have a stake in the Trump administration's broadband and media regulation. After a post-election sell-off, the so-called FANG stocks have bounced back. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup. Eisenach currently is a managing director at NERA Economic Consulting and a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. He has worked as a consultant to Verizon and the National Association of Broadcasters.Net neutrality rules require internet service providers to treat all data equally and bar them from obstructing or slowing down consumer access to web content.Wheeler has been at odds with the cable-TV industry over internet regulation and so-called net neutrality rules; broadband data privacy; opening up the set-top box market to more competition; and specialized business services."Ultimately, Eisenach will likely aim to craft a telecom strategy that erases much of current Chairman Wheeler's work and focuses on less governmental intervention," Horan said.For his part, Pai has been an FCC commissioner since 2012. He's a former FCC deputy general counsel.Shares of AT&T rose 2.2% in the stock market today, with Verizon rising 2.4% and Comcast 1.2%.RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosFCC's Wheeler, At Urging Of Republicans, Pulls Controversial ItemsComcast: Does Trump Win Portend Regulatory Rollback?

AT&T (T) grabbed the headlines last month with its proposed $85 billion acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), but the future of the telecom industry also is riding on what happens next among Verizon Communications (VZ), Comcast (CMCSA), satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and fast-growing wireless firm T-Mobile US (TMUS).How federal regulators would view proposed mergers among these companies figures heavily into the industry's future, analysts say, and talks figure to heat up early next year with the ending of a government spectrum auction that prohibits strategic talks among any bidders.Among the big questions is whether the status quo will be shaken up — cable TV firms dominate in providing high-speed internet services to homes while phone companies AT&T and Verizon generate the lion's share of wireless industry profits.IBD'S TAKE: AT&T stock has shed 16% since Oct. 1 amid speculation over rising interest rates and reaction to the Time Warner takeover bid. Look for news about other dividend paying stocks at The Income Investor.In one scenario, Verizon could deepen its partnership with Comcast, Charter Communications (CHTR) and other cable TV firms. In that case, Verizon and the cable TV firms would update a wireless network access and marketing deal born in 2011, says Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson.If that happens, Verizon could drop its much touted plans to unleash superfast 5G wireless services vs. cable firms in the residential broadband market. Verizon is testing 5G services and could roll out wireless broadband within two years, and it's considered to be ahead of rivals in 5G."Verizon's entry into fixed wireless broadband is a clear threat to cable — and cable's entry into wireless is a clear threat to Verizon," Moffett told IBD. "Each has a fair amount of leverage with the other."If Verizon and the cable industry form an alliance, a Comcast acquisition of T-Mobile or Sprint (S) and a Verizon purchase of Dish Network — deals that have been subject of hot and cold rumors in recent years — would likely be off the table, analysts say.Another wild card in the industry's future is a government auction of radio spectrum owned by TV broadcasters. Begun in March, it's expected to end in early 2017. Companies that filed as bidders will once again be allowed to engage in strategic talks, as anti-collusion rules go away.If Comcast acquires substantial spectrum in the auction, that could be a precursor to buying a wireless firm such as T-Mobile around 2018, one theory goes. On the other hand, Comcast also might gain more spectrum to trade in a network-sharing deal with Verizon, so it wouldn't need T-Mobile.Dish Network has a big stake in the auction's outcome, analysts say. Depending on the results, Verizon could have more reason to acquire Dish Network and its nearly 80 MHz of wireless airwaves, says Citigroup analyst Michael Rollins."As the 600MHz auction winds down, Dish may be a logical acquisition for Verizon," Rollins wrote in a research report. "Dish helps Verizon close its spectrum gap vs. rivals."Second, if Verizon deploys nationwide fixed wireless for in-home broadband (vs. cable), it will need a nationwide team of techs and trucks for installs. Dish has this. Third, Dish could help Verizon bundle video/mobile nationally at scale."AT&T acquired satellite broadcaster DirecTV in 2015 to boost its mobile video strategy, he noted. If Verizon buys Dish Network, it could structure a stock and cash deal to ease concerns over its credit rating and tax worries for Dish founder Charles Ergen, Rollins says.Where do T-Mobile and Sprint fit into merger scenarios? T-Mobile has openly courted cable TV partners on its earnings calls. But amid intensified wireless competition, the most profit-margin-friendly deal remains a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile, many analysts say.Such a deal, though, would reduce the number of national wireless firms from four to three. The Obama administration blocked AT&T's proposed acquisition of T-Mobile in 2011, saying it wanted to retain a four-player national market.It's unlikely a new Democratic administration would be more friendly to a Sprint merger with T-Mobile, analysts say. Both companies are foreign-controlled. Japan's SoftBank owns 83% of Sprint, while Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY) owns a two-thirds stake in T-Mobile.T-Mobile and Sprint, however, could have a better argument to present to regulators if their rivals continue to get bigger.AT&T and CenturyLink (CTL) didn't wait to find out how a Clinton-led or Trump-led Department of Justice would view telecom and media mergers.AT&T's agreement to acquire Time Warner, announced Oct. 22, bears similarities to Comcast's 2011 purchase of NBCUniversal from General Electric (GE), analysts say. Conditions that federal regulators set on the Comcast-NBCU deal might serve as a blueprint for the AT&T-Time Warner deal, though the Internet video market has evolved over the past five years, says Jefferies analyst Mike McCormack.Time Warner's assets include HBO and Turner Broadcasting, which has rights to sports telecasts. It also owns Warner Bros. film studio and cable networks TNT, TBS and CNN, as well as a 10% stake in internet video provider Hulu.CenturyLink (CTL), meanwhile, on Oct. 31 announced an agreement to buy Level 3 Communications (LVLT) for about $34 billion cash and stock. The combined company will be a stronger rival to AT&T and Verizon in the market for business services.Broomfield, Colo.-based Level 3 operates one of the world's largest internet backbones. CenturyLink morphed into the nation's No. 3 local phone company, behind Verizon and AT&T, by purchasing Qwest and Embarq. Neither CenturyLink or Level 3 owns a wireless network.AT&T's acquisition of Time Warner plays into its mobile video strategy, says UBS analyst John Hodulik."It's a watershed event for the communications ecosystem," said Hodulik.Regulators are certain to look at whether AT&T aims to provide some of Time Warner's content exclusively to its customers. Netflix (NFLX) has stated it's fine with the deal as long as AT&T provides equally speedy internet access for its streaming video as its does for rival HBO.The AT&T and CenturyLink acquisitions announcements came amid slowing growth for each of them.AT&T's third-quarter revenue missed analysts' expectations, as it posted a net loss of 268,000 postpaid phone accounts amid intensified wireless competition.Buying Time Warner will boost AT&T's free cash flow to support its dividend payments, as did its 2015 purchase of satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group, says Hodulik. Level 3's cash flow, meanwhile, will support CenturyLink's dividends.The current low interest rates will help both AT&T and CenturyLink finance their acquisitions."Cheap debt makes the numbers work," Hodulik said. "For CenturyLink, keeping the dividend safe was the main concern along with establishing a path to growth."RELATED:How Aggressive AT&T Has Out-Maneuvered Verizon, Comcast

Citigroup started American Airlines (AAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL), and Southwest Airlines (LUV) with buy ratings; Salesforce.com's (CRM) higher-than-expected revenue guidance won the cloud software provider price target hikes; and Raymond James upgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to outperform.Citigroup initiated American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Southwest Airlines and Allegiant Travel at buy. Citigroup analyst set a price target of 55 on American, 61 on Delta, 57 on Southwest and 185 on Allegiant."Key fundamentals are mixed with expenses likely to be up sharply in 2017 as fuel prices drift higher and new labor deals pressure nonfuel unit costs," said Crissey in a report. "The stocks appear reasonably priced to cheap, both in a historical context and relative to the market."Citigroup also started JetBlue Airways (JBLU), Spirit (SAV), Alaska Air Group (ALK), Hawaiian  Holdings (HA), and United Continental (UAL) all at neutral.American stock edged up 0.9% to 46.26 on stock market today. Delta rose 0.8% to 48.90. American, Delta, United and Southwest had big weekly gains after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) disclosed stakes in the carriers.RELATED:Warren Buffett, Who Called Airline Stocks A 'Death Trap,' Invests In Big 4Delta October Unit Revenue In Line, Alaska Air Traffic Outpaces CapacitySouthwest Is Only Airline That Sees Worse Unit Revenue; Stock DivesJetBlue Warns On Q4, Spirit Sees Improving Unit RevenueWedbush hiked its price target on Salesforce.com to 98 from 96, Mizuho Securities to 95 from 85, and BMO Capital Markets to 90 from 86. Salesforce.com late Thursday reported fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue that topped views and also forecast current-quarter and fiscal 2018 revenue above expectations. San Francisco-based Salesforce.com said in fiscal 2018 it expects revenue of about $10.1 billion-$10.15 billion, up 21% at the midpoint, vs. consensus estimates of $10.08 billion."Most importantly, reported billings grew 19% (year-over-year), and we calculate that organic (credit card) billings grew by about 21%," said Keith Bachman, a BMO Capital analyst in a report.Shares rose 3.4% to 77.77 Friday.RELATED:Salesforce.com Fiscal Q3 Beats, Sales Guidance Top Views, Shares UpSalesforce.com M&A Scorecard Raises Questions On Growth, TargetsSalesforce.com Officially Rules Out Twitter BidPacific Crest Securities upped its price target on Applied Materials, a maker of semiconductor manufacturing gear, to 37 from 35; Citigroup bumped up its price target to 38 from 37. Applied Materials late Thursday delivered mixed fiscal Q4 results but gave current-quarter guidance ahead of Wall Street's views. Applied materials stock has popped 64% in 2016. The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of a possible 99.Applied Materials stock rose 1 cent to 30.74. Intraday, shares rose to 31.25, a 16-year high and briefly above a 31.17 buy point.RELATED:Applied Materials Earnings Soar, Guidance Strong, But Sales Just MissApplied Materials Makes 'Compelling Case' For Growth In Chip Gear SectorRaymond James upgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which reports fiscal Q4 earnings on Nov. 22, to outperform. Analyst Simon Leopold set a price target of 29 on HPE stock. With HPE's planned spin off its enterprise services and software businesses, he expects improved free cash flow growth.Shares dipped 1.2% to 23.31. Shares rose to 23.85 intraday, briefly crossing 23.63 buy point.RELATED:Could HPE Go Shopping For Cisco Rival Arista Networks?In other analyst moves, Macquarie Securities downgraded Citigroup (C) to neutral; Raymond James hiked its price target on Best Buy (BBY) to 53 from 45;  RBC Capital lowered its price target on Wal-Mart Stores (WMT)  to 42 from 47. Jefferies hiked its price target on chipmaker Marvell Technology (MRVL) to 18 from 16. BTIG Research upped its price target on Dish Network (DISH) to 90 from 85. Aegis Capital started Match Group (MTCH) with a buy rating and a price target of 20.

Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) are likely to rekindle merger talks during a Trump administration, but their operational rebounds will make it harder to make a case to regulators, says Citigroup.T-Mobile US has been taking revenue and subscriber market share for three years from wireless services leaders AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ). Sprint's subscriber growth has more recently rebounded.Shares of cell tower operators American Tower (AMT), Crown Castle (CCI) and SBA Communications (SBAC), meanwhile, have been hit over worries they could lose business if T-Mobile and Sprint merge."We think Sprint and T-Mobile are more likely than not to reconsider a merger scenario, but the (TV spectrum) auction, other strategic options, and regulatory complexities may slow down any attempt during 2017," Citigroup analyst Michael Rollins said in a research report.Japan's SoftBank owns 83% of Sprint, while Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY) owns two-thirds of T-Mobile.T-Mobile stock rose 1% in the stock market today, to 53.46, while Sprint jumped 3.1% to a more than two-year high of 7.74.IBD'S TAKE: T-Mobile stock has been trading around a nine-year high after reporting Q3 earnings topped views amid speculation over wireless industry M&A. Sprint stock has doubled in 2016. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Amid intensified wireless competition, a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile would be profit-margin-friendly, many analysts say.Such a deal, though, would reduce the number of national wireless firms from four to three. The Obama administration blocked AT&T's proposed acquisition of T-Mobile in 2011, saying it wanted to retain a four-player national market.T-Mobile in October reported higher-than-expected Q3 profit and raised full-year EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) guidance as its wireless subscriber additions in the September quarter again led the industry. Sprint added 344,000 postpaid subscribers."We come back to an essential issue that we believe hurt the companies' prospects for consolidation in the last go around -- if it's not broken, why fix it?," Rollins wrote. "We believe these two companies may need more time to build a thoughtful narrative on the needs for further wireless industry consolidation."AT&T, which bought DirecTV in 2015, in October agreed to buy media giant Time Warner (TWX) for $85 billion. Analysts and industry executives speculate Verizon could acquire Dish Network (DISH) or deepen its alliance with cable TV firms such as Comcast (CMCSA).RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosComcast: Does Trump Win Portend Regulatory Rollback?John Malone Talks Up Apple Buy Of Disney, Likes AT&T Strategy

Bulls and bears disagree on Dish Network's (DISH) long-term outlook but one common view is that the satellite broadcaster's third-quarter subscriber losses could increase.MoffettNathanson, which has a sell rating, on Tuesday lowered its price target on Dish Network to 37 from 54. Jefferies on Monday called Dish stock oversold because of its wireless spectrum holdings and stuck with a price target of 80.Both MoffettNathanson and Jefferies analysts, though, say Dish Networks' third-quarter subscriber losses could increase — due to pay-TV competition, internet video offering and recent hurricanes. Dish lost 116,000 subscribers in the September 2016 quarter.Comcast (CMCSA) has warned of higher subscriber losses in its September quarter. MoffettNathanson and Jefferies analysts say more aggressive pay-TV promotions by AT&T (T) could hit both Comcast and Dish in the third quarter.Dish fell 3.4% to close at 52.15 on the stock market today. Dish is down 17% since Aug. 1. One view is that it could be left on the sidelines as the telecom industry consolidates.Dish has cobbled together nearly 95 MHz of radio spectrum but has been unable to forge a deal with a wireless service provider, such as T-Mobile US (TMUS)."A spectrum sale now looks to be all but off the table," said Craig Moffett, analyst at MoffettNathanson, said in a report. He says it is unlikely AT&T (T) or Verizon Communications (VZ) will acquire Dish, given its mounting pay-TV subscriber losses.IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and the end-of-day The Big Picture (take a free trial) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases.Mike McCormick, analyst at Jefferies, remains upbeat, though. In a report, he said Dish's spectrum is worth nearly $50.7 billion on a pretax basis, or roughly $38.8 billion on a tax-adjusted basis."We believe Dish's spectrum assets should continue to draw attention from top-wireless carriers due not only to the mid-band capacity advantages, but also the availability and speed to market," McCormack said.RELATED:Sprint Falls On Report Of No Big Premium Coming In T-Mobile MergerAT&T Fires Warning Shot Vs. Verizon On FirstNet ContractAmazon, Dish Wireless Deal Would Target Internet Of Things: CitiThree Reasons Why Telecom Merger Party On Hold: Goldman SachsTelecom Mergers: A 'Game Of Thrones' Without The Dragons

Cable TV companies are fighting cord-cutting with price hikes on broadband service, but the big question is whether those increases will come fast enough as premium video subscribers flee.XCable stocks have plunged ahead of third-quarter earnings amid angst that more consumers are turning to internet TV services, like Netflix (NFLX), and canceling subscriptions to premium pay-TV packages.Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) report Q3 results on Oct. 26.In a note to clients Tuesday, Morgan Stanley said that based on its own survey, cable TV companies hiked broadband prices by 12% to $66 monthly from a year earlier for customers that buy only high-speed internet and not a TV package."As video revenue growth is increasingly pressured, leaning on data pricing is tempting to sustain earnings," said Benjamin Swinburne, a Morgan Stanley analyst in a report.Mike McCormack, a Jefferies analyst, in a report published last week, said Comcast and other cable TV firms will need to hike broadband-only pricing to $80 or more monthly to offset the loss of video subscribers. He says the average broadband price, including customers that buy a bundle of high-speed internet and TV services, is now about $49 monthly."Cable companies are likely to raise stand-alone broadband pricing in order to combat the EBITDA declines from downsizing," said McCormack in a report. "This practice is already evident and justified given the lack of a bundling discount. Based on our analysis, we estimate Comcast would need to raise stand-alone pricing to roughly $80 in order to break even from a profitability perspective."He says that Comcast, in some markets, has brought in stand-alone broadband customers with $40 monthly promotions and has been able to hike prices to $65 monthly.IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read  The Big Picture at the day's end (take a free trial) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases.Comcast shares have dropped 11% since early September when it forecast higher-than-expected subscriber losses in the September quarter, normally seasonally strong for cable TV companies. Cable TV and media stocks sold off last week when AT&T (T) preannounced third-quarter numbers, including the loss of 390,000 pay-TV subscribers. AT&T added 300,000 internet TV customers to soften the blow.Comcast is still up nearly 6% in 2017, despite the recent sell-off. Shares slipped 0.4% to close at 36.47 Tuesday.Charter stock is up 24% in 2017 but is down to about 360 from a high of 401 set in early August as speculation cools that it could be acquired. Charter lost 1.3% to finish at 357.84.Shares in Altice USA (ATUS) have dived since its initial public offering in June. Altice went public at 30, with shares rising to 34 the first two days of trading. Altice lost 0.5% to close at 24.49 on the stock market today.Netflix slipped 1.6% to 199.48. Netflix late Monday reported earnings that missed views, though subscriber growth beat expectations.Analysts that cover cable TV companies hope that broadband subscriber additions will quell investor worries in the long term.In a note to clients Monday, UBS analyst John Hodulik said: "Despite the hand-wringing over worsening trends in traditional video, we continue to believe cable is well-positioned given its broadband product."RELATED:AT&T Fallout: Pay TV Industry Could Lose 1 Million SubscribersCan Google's YouTube TV Hit 2 Million Subscribers In A Year?Dish Bulls And Bears Agree On One Thing: What's Coming In Q3

In this city, which is a petri dish of progressivism, a prevailing theory is that when you raise the price of something, people will buy less of it, except when they do not. Another, and related, theory is that constitutional and statutory texts should be construed in the spirit of Friedrich Nietzsche: There are no facts, only interpretations.The city council has voted to impose a tax, effective next year, on sugary soft drinks, raising the price of a 2-liter bottle of soda about $1.18. Presented as a public health measure to combat obesity, the tax is projected to generate about $15 million a year, although the aspiration of sin taxes (e.g., Seattle's taxes on guns and ammunition) should be zero revenues because chastened consumers will mend their benighted ways. Still, proponents of the tax are confident that it will make people behave better by consuming less of the disapproved drinks.Three years ago, the city council, adhering to another current tenet of progressivism, voted — unanimously, of course — to increase the city's minimum wage incrementally from $9.47 to $15 an hour. The council rejected the contention that when the price of entry-level labor increases, employers buy less of it. The city commissioned a study from six University of Washington economists ranging from left to right, presumably expecting their findings to be congruent with other studies purporting to show that the demand for such labor, unlike the demand for sugary sodas, is price-inelastic. (And unlike in Denmark, where the minimum wage increases 40% when a worker turns 18, and the employment of young workers declines one-third.)The University of Washington study, however, published as a working paper by the National Bureau of Economic Research, concluded that the costs to low-wage Seattle workers have been three times larger than the benefits. Using a richer trove of data and more sophisticated statistical methods than have been available for other studies of minimum wages, the report concluded that Seattle's still-advancing increase has cost more than 5,000 jobs, and that workers whose wages were increased to comply with the new minimum lost an average of $125 a month as employers reduced their hours. Although total employment in the restaurant industry, which hires a substantial portion of minimum wage workers, did not decline, employers replaced less skilled, low productivity workers with others able to produce higher-value work products. As one of the study's authors said, "Basically, what we're doing is we're removing the bottom rung of the ladder."The city responded by seeking alternative facts. Forewarned about the six economists' conclusions, it sought more congenial findings from some economists at the University of California, Berkeley, who are known for research that supports the agenda of the national "Fight for $15" movement. The Berkeley economists were so prompt that their findings were publicized before the University of Washington economists' report was released.Seattle's city council is as undeterred by constitutional and statutory language as it is by social science. In July, it enacted — unanimously, of course — a city income tax, setting the tax rate on incomes below $250,000 at 0 and a 2.25% rate on individuals' incomes above $250,000 and on household incomes above $500,000. Washington, which has no state income tax, has a law that says: "A county, city or city-county shall not levy a tax on net income." The city council, which overestimates its cleverness, claims it is taxing "total income" as defined on IRS 1040 forms. But that is net income, after deductions and exclusions. Furthermore, the state's constitution has this "uniformity clause": "All taxes shall be uniform upon the same class of property." Twice the state Supreme Court has held that a graduated income tax is unconstitutional.A suit challenging the city council's tax notes that cities, as creatures of the state, have only such taxing authority as is expressly granted by the state Legislature. And the tax is explicitly designed to "test the constitutionality of a progressive income tax," on which Washington's Supreme Court has repeatedly ruled. The city council must hope that the state's Supreme Court, which is very liberal, can be persuaded, in a third consideration of unchanging language, to say that constitutional and statutory facts can be made to disappear in a mist of interpretations.In 2010, advocates of a progressive income tax submitted this for a referendum. It lost almost 2-to-1 (64-36). It lost even in King County, home of Seattle and its Nietzschean city council.

Goldman Sachs says it knows why the telecom industry's merger party has been put on hold.X"Evolving business models, more immediate priorities and regulatory uncertainty have likely limited deal making," Brett Feldman, a Goldman Sachs analyst said in a note to clients.Despite speculation involving T-Mobile US (TMUS), Sprint (S), Charter Communications (CHTR), Comcast (CMCSA), Dish Network (DISH) and Verizon Communications (VZ), no big deals have been announced in 2017.Feldman looked at what might be holding companies back, ahead of Goldman Sachs' annual Communacopia conference. It starts Tuesday in New York.Some deals would create bigger wireless or cable TV companies while others might combine a wireless company with a cable TV firm."As the industry landscape shifts, we believe that major operators are continually re-evaluating their strategic direction and options," added Feldman. 'It is not hard to understand why companies are not rushing into deals that may set their course for the next decade."AT&T (T) Chief Executive Randall Stephenson kicks off the conference Tuesday morning. Europe-based Altice Group, possibly readying an offer for Charter, and Comcast CEO Brian Roberts also are slated for Tuesday.On Wednesday, media firms Viacom (VIA) CEO Robert Bakish and 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) executive chairman Lachlan Murdoch are expected to be on hand. Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam is scheduled to appear Thursday morning.AT&T is awaiting Trump administration approval for its acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), announced in October. A Sprint merger with T-Mobile is still viewed by analysts as the industry's most likely deal.IBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly-traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? A good starting point is to regularly review screens that highlight the top-rated equities."Under the Trump administration, we have seen a rapid pace of deregulation by the Federal Communications Commission," said Feldman. "While this implies a potentially more favorable regulatory back drop for pursuing M&A, we have not yet seen the FCC or the Department of Justice weigh in on any major mergers under this administration. As such, the major operators lack context for whether regulators take a different view on market structure than we saw under President Obama."RELATED:Top Questions Apple Will Face At Sept. 12 iPhone EventTelecom Mergers: A 'Game Of Thrones' Without The Dragons

Shares in streaming music service Pandora Media (P) stock rose on the naming of a new chief executive — Roger Lynch, who led Dish Network's (DISH) online video business.Lynch replaces Pandora co-founder and CEO Tim Westergren, stepped down in late June. Lynch has headed satellite TV broadcaster Dish's "Sling TV" internet video service.Pandora stock jumped 4.1% to close at 8.40 on the stock market today.In another move, Pandora added Michael Lynton to its board of directors. Lynton was the CEO of Sony Entertainment for 12 years before leaving earlier this year."Mr. Lynch and Mr. Lynton bring decades of valuable experience as high-ranking media executives, which Pandora can surely use more of at this junction," said John Egbert, a Stifel analyst in a report. "Mr. Lynch led DishNetwork's efforts to build one of the first commercially available Internet TV 'skinny bundles,' which the company invested in despite the potential for such a product to cannibalize its core business."Sirius XM (SIRI) announced June 9 that is investing $480 million in Pandora in exchange for a 19% stake and three board seats, including the chairmanship.IBD'S TAKE: Pandora has an IBD Composite Rating of 18, meaning it has been outperformed by 82% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on Pandora, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Sirius XM and majority shareholder Liberty Media (LSXMA) plan to shift Pandora back to its core advertising-supported music streaming business.Pandora competes with Spotify, Apple' (AAPL) Apple Music and others in the streaming music sector.RELATED:BitAuto Earnings Cruise Past Estimates, Guidance StrongHow Google And Others Could Be Profit Machines For AppleComcast Could Partner With Altice To Acquire Charter, Says Citigroup

AT&T (T) and Time Warner (TWX) shares both fell at the open Wednesday, but then recovered some, amid more uncertainty over regulatory approval of their proposed blockbuster merger in the wake of Republican Donald Trump's election as president.Shares of Verizon Communications (VZ) rose a fraction, but shares of T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S) jumped Wednesday, with some observers speculating a Trump presidency might ease they way for any possible merger between the Nos. 3 and 4 U.S. wireless services providers.AT&T stock, down 1% at one point, rose 1.2% in the stock market today.  Time Warner stock, down as much as 2.8% at the open, fell 1.5% Wednesday to 86.59. AT&T announced its $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner on Oct. 24.While AT&T agreed to pay $107.50 per share for Time Warner, but the media giant's stock has been trading far below that level amid uncertain regulatory approval.IBD'S TAKE: Some investors like telecom companies because many pay high dividends, but there are other options at IBD's Income Investor. Republican Trump had voiced his opposition to the deal prior to the Oct. 24 announcement, saying the companies were part of the media "power structure" he's fighting against. Several high-ranking Democratic lawmakers also have raised doubts over the merger.Time Warner faces a potential $1.725 billion breakup fee if a new buyer surfaces, while AT&T's reverse breakup fee would be $500 million if the telecom conglomerate walks away. AT&T acquired satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV in 2015.Analysts had expected the merger review to drag on into early 2018. Time Warner shareholders will own about 15% of the combined company.Sprint stock soared 13% Wednesday, while T-Mobile stock rose 5.1%. The Obama administration has been opposed to a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile, which lag far behind AT&T and Verizon among wireless services providers.RELATED:AT&T Downgraded, FCC Might Also Review Time Warner AcquisitionDOJ Files Antitrust Lawsuit Vs. AT&T-DirecTV Over L.A. Sports ChannelHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosTime Warner Shrugs Off Low AT&T Breakup Fee, Merger Naysayers

Shares of Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) rose Wednesday as analysts speculated President-elect Donald Trump and a Republican-controlled Congress could ease up on regulation after current FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler battled the industry on broadband and other issues.Comcast stock was up 1.5% and Charter stock 2.9% in the stock market today. Shares of Cable One (CABO) were down 1%.Wheeler has been at odds with the cable-TV industry over internet regulation and so-called net neutrality rules; broadband data privacy; opening up the set-top box market to more competition; and specialized business services."If the rhetoric of those surrounding Trump's campaign rings true, we can expect a Republican FCC to make a big push to roll back some of the regulations put in place under President Obama, such as the Title II/net neutrality rules," said Jennifer Fritzsche, a Well Fargo analyst, in a research report. "There may also be a push to roll back some or all of what the FCC just did on privacy."It's unclear whether Chairman Wheeler will be able to act on the open items related to business data services or set-top box reform before he departs."IBD'S TAKE: Facebook, Google, Intel and other high-tech companies also have a stake in the Trump administration's trade policies. Learn more at IBD's Leaderboard on how stocks reacted Wednesday. Trump has picked Jeffrey Eisenach, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, as head of his telecom transition team, according to a report from Politico. Eisenach, who formerly led the Progress and Freedom Foundation think tank, favors a light regulatory approach. He's been a Wheeler critic.The Obama administration's antitrust regulators in 2015 thwarted Comcast's proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable.Comcast acquired NBCUniversal, a media and entertainment company, from General Electric in 2011. The FCC approved that deal with conditions that sunset in 2018.Comcast's top lobbyist, David Cohen, has been a fundraiser Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, according to media reports.Comcast's NBCUniversal and Trump cut ties in late June 2015. NBCU said it would no longer broadcast the "Miss USA" and "Miss Universe" pageants, which are produced by Trump, because of his views on immigration policy. Trump did not star in a new season of NBCU's "The Apprentice" in the fall of 2015, though he did appear on the network's "Saturday Night Live," as did Clinton, during the campaignThe cable-TV industry's trade group issued a statement greeting President-elect Trump."As the transition to a new Administration gets underway, we look forward to participating in a constructive and robust discussion about policies that will continue to make America a global technology and entertainment leader," said the Internet & Television Association.RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosFCC Adopts Privacy Rules: Will Facebook, Google Gain Vs. ISPs?AT&T, Comcast Cheer: FCC's Wheeler Pulls Set-Top VoteNet Neutrality Upheld: Big Win For FCC, Netflix; AT&T Vows To Appeal

Zayo Group Holdings (ZAYO) said it swung to a 6-cent per-share profit in the September quarter vs. a 6-cent loss in the year-earlier period, edging views, but revenue missed consensus estimates.Zayo stock was down a fraction in after-hours trading, after the company released its earnings. Shares rose 1.2% to 32.74 in the regular session in the stock market today.Boulder, Colo.-based Zayo said fiscal Q1 revenue increased 38% to $505 million including acquisitions.Analysts had forecast a 5-cent profit on revenue of $511 million.Zayo operates fiber-optic networks in metropolitan areas, as well as between cities. It leases fiber-optic cables to wireless phone companies and other customers. It also operates data centers.IBD'S TAKE: Some investors like telecom companies because many pay high dividends, but there are other options at IBD's Income Investor. Zayo's shareholders include private equity firms M/C Partners, GTCR, Oak Investment Partners and Columbia Capital.Two firms similar to private equity-controlled Zayo have recently been acquired. Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy XO Communications in February for $1.7 billion, while CenturyLink (CTL) last month announced a merger with Level 3 Communications (LVLT) for $34 billion in cash and stock. The combined firm will be a stronger rival to AT&T (T) and Verizon in the business market, analysts say.RELATED:Windstream, EarthLink Merge As Telecom Takeovers Heat UpHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A Scenarios

The Federal Communications Commission could get involved in the review of AT&T's (T) proposed acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), joining the Department of Justice, says Oppenheimer, which downgraded the telecom conglomerate's stock.Oppenheimer analyst Time Horan says AT&T stock will likely be range bound during the regulatory review, which he expects to drag on into 2018. MoffettNathanson on Monday also forecast that the AT&T-Time Warner review would continue into early 2018. While the DOJ looks at mergers on antitrust grounds the FCC determines whether deals are in the public's interest. MoffettNathanson, like Oppenheimer, also says there's a good chance the FCC will push its way into the AT&T-Time Warner review.Horan, meanwhile, upgraded CenturyLink (CTL) to outperform. CenturyLink last week agreed to acquire Level 3 Communications (LVLT) in a $34 billion cash and stock merger. CenturyLink's stock sold off more than 20% since the deal was announced.IBD'S TAKE: Some investors like telecom companies because many pay high dividends, but there are other options at IBD's Income Investor. "We are downgrading AT&T from outperform to perform as we believe CenturyLink's dividend is relatively more attractive," said Horan in a research report. "We also see the Time Warner merger as facing higher regulatory hurtles and taking more like 15 months to complete vs. nine for CenturyLink-Level 3."AT&T agreed to pay $85.4 billion in cash and stock for Time Warner. Time Warner shareholders will own about 15% of the combined company.If regulators approve the Time Warner acquisition, AT&T will have a national wireless network plus the assets of satellite broadcaster DirecTV, acquired in 2015, and the programming of Time Warner to whisk content to mobile devices."We see the DOJ suing DTV over the Dodgers as an ominous sign," added Horan. "Also, the FCC may initiate a formal review with an eye toward its zero rating (data billing) policy."AT&T's stock tends to take a pause when the company is in the process of closing on a major acquisition, and we suspect a similar outcome and see a better opportunity in CenturyLink currently."AT&T stock rose 0.54% to 37.01 in the stock market today, while CenturyLink stock jumped 3.6% to 24.15.Time Warner's media empire includes HBO and Turner Broadcasting, which has rights to sports telecasts. It also owns Warner Bros. film studio and cable networks TNT, TBS and CNN. Time Warner owns a 10% stake in internet video provider Hulu.RELATED:DOJ Files Antitrust Lawsuit Vs. AT&T-DirecTV Over L.A. Sports ChannelHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosTime Warner Shrugs Off Low AT&T Breakup Fee, Merger Naysayers

Telecom business services provider Zayo Group Holdings (ZAYO), viewed by some analyst as a takeover candidate, is expected to swing to a profit when it reports fiscal Q1 earnings after the close Tuesday.Boulder, Colo.-based Zayo operates fiber-optic networks in metropolitan areas as well as between cities. It leases fiber-optic cables to wireless phone companies and other customers. It also operates data centers.Two firms similar to private equity-controlled Zayo have recently been acquired. Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy XO Communications in February for $1.7 billion, while CenturyLink (CTL) last month announced a merger with Level 3 Communications (LVLT) for $34 billion in cash and stock. The combined firm will be a stronger rival to AT&T (T) and Verizon in the business market, analysts say.IBD'S TAKE: Fast-growing companies such as Gigamon and Arista Networks are also takeover candidates, say some analysts. They're among companies in the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.The Verizon-XO deal, meanwhile, still awaits regulatory approval. Verizon is expected to use XO's network and spectrum as part of its plans to launch 5G services.CenturyLink's purchase of Level 3 "increases the takeout/scarcity/strategic value of Zayo as the only stand-alone nationwide pure-play fiber provider," Colby Synesael, an analyst at Cowen & Co., said in a research report.Zayo is expected to post a 5 cent profit in the September quarter vs. a 6-cent loss in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters estimate revenue will climb 40% to $511 million, including acquisitions.Zayo stock has shot up more than 20% in 2016. Shares of Zayo closed up 2% to 32.36 in the stock market today. Zayo's backers include private equity firms M/C Partners, GTCR, Oak Investment Partners and Columbia Capital.Boulder, Colo.-based Zayo, along with Level 3 Communications, are two telecom survivors of the dot-com bubble. Zayo bought bankrupt firms AboveNet in 2012 and 360networks in 2011 amid numerous acquisitions that it has made since 2007.RELATED:Verizon XO Purchase Could Boost 5G Wireless, 'Small Cell' PlansWindstream, EarthLink Merge As Telecom Takeovers Heat UpHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A Scenarios

AT&T (T) stock jumped on Wednesday as analysts cheered an earnings beat while Dish Network (DISH) fell on a downgrade to sell.XA Citigroup analyst, meanwhile, said cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA) should acquire Verizon Communications (VZ) in a blockbuster deal.AT&T rose 4.7% to 37.94 on the stock market today, a big move for the big-cap telecom conglomerate. With the gain, AT&T is still down 10% in 2017.Dish stock fell 0.3% to 64.27, off intraday lows of 62.71. Citigroup downgraded the satellite TV broadcaster to sell amid slowing revenue and subscriber growth. Citigroup has viewed Dish as a takeover target of Verizon, but the phone company has stated it has no interest in a deal.In a separate report, Citi analyst Jason Bazinet speculated that Comcast could pay around a 20% premium for Verizon.Verizon rose about 1% to 44.40 while Comcast slipped 1% to 39.35.Both Comcast and Verizon report second-quarter earnings early Thursday.IBD'S TAKE: T-Mobile stock has retreated from all-time highs in early June as speculation over a merger with Sprint cools. A deal faces regulatory and valuation issues. T-Mobile stock is still up 8% in 2017 and is the top-rated company in the IBD Telecom-Services Wireless group. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Analysts expect Comcast to report earnings growth of 14% to 48 cents, with revenue rising 8% to $20.86 billion. Verizon's revenue is expected to fall 2% to $30.53 billion amid intensified wireless competition. Analysts estimate Verizon profit will edge up 2% to 96 cents from a year earlier.AT&T late Tuesday reported second-quarter adjusted profit that topped views and in-line revenue as pay-TV subscriber losses were higher than expected. About three cents of the earnings beat came from one-time benefits."Cost discipline drove the beat, contributing to record wireless margins," said Mike McCormack, a Jefferies analyst in a report.RELATED:What AT&T, T-Mobile Earnings Mean For Apple iPhone DemandApple Analysts Brace For 'Big Guide Down' Amid iPhone 8 Delay ReportsT-Mobile Smashes Second-Quarter Earnings Estimate

Comcast (CMCSA) reported second-quarter profit and revenue that topped estimates, as NBCUniversal's filmed entertainment business delivered strong box office results, but video subscriber losses were higher than expected.XComcast said second-quarter earnings were 52 cents a share, up 27% from a year ago, with revenue rising 9.8% to  $21.16 billion. A year earlier, Comcast earned 42 cents a share on sales of $19.27 billion.Analysts had estimated earnings of 48 cents on revenue of $20.86 billion. Comcast added 175,000 broadband customers and lost 34,000 video customers, missing estimates. Analysts had modeled video subscriber losses of 24,000 and 1888,000 broadband additions."The standout result in the cable segment was stable (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) margins, despite a 12% increase in programming expense," said Jonathan Chaplin, analyst at New Street Research.NBCUniversal increased revenue 17.3% to $8.3 billion, with filmed entertainment jumping 59.6% to $2.2 billion.Shares in the cable TV firm, which owns NBCUniversal, rose 0.2% to 39.43 on the stock market today. Comcast has a technical buy point of 42.28 out of a flat-base chart pattern. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.There's speculation Comcast could acquire a wireless firm, such as Verizon Communications (VZ).Verizon, a Dow Jones industrial average component, also reported second-quarter results early Thursday. Verizon revenue was flat from a year-earlier but topped estimates, while adjusted earnings per share were in-line. Verizon shares soared 7.7%RELATED:Telecom: AT&T Rallies, Dish Slides, Comcast-Verizon Deal Seen

Dow component Verizon Communications (VZ) stock jumped Thursday on better-than-expected wireless subscriber additions during the second quarter as its chief financial officer extolled its premium pricing strategy on the earnings call.XShares in the broadband and wireless services provider were up 7.7% to 47.84 on the stock market today. With the gain, Verizon is still down about 12% for 2017 amid fierce wireless competition.Verizon added 358,000 postpaid phone subscribers in the second quarter, up from 86,000 in the year earlier period and topping estimates of 70,000. Verizon and AT&T (T) reintroduced unlimited data wireless plans early in 2017 amid market share gains by Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS).Verizon's unlimited plans are priced higher than those of T-Mobile and Sprint, though. Matthew Ellis, Verizon's CFO, said on its earnings call that the results show its strategy is clicking."Our net adds show that once we had a comparable offering out there against the competition — by being unlimited — even with the price premium we have it shows that customer value the high quality network experience."T-Mobile earlier reported that it added 786,000 postpaid phone subscribers while AT&T said it lost 89,000, narrowing its loss from 180,000 in the year-earlier-period. Postpaid subscribers billed monthly spend the most on wireless services.AT&T was up 3.6% to 39.41 on Thursday, extending a rally. AT&T stock popped nearly 5% on Wednesday following its earnings. AT&T also performed better on wireless customers than feared."(Verizon's) Q2 highlight was postpay phone adds — an impressive stat especially given the amount of competitive behavior seen in the marketplace in the quarter," said Jennifer Fritzsche, a Wells Fargo analyst in a report. "The strength of this growth could read through for the remaining big four carrier yet to report (Sprint)."Sprint shares slipped 1.6% to 8.40 on Thursday. T-Mobile was up a fraction.Verizon's second-quarter earnings included two weeks of financial results from internet firm Yahoo, acquired in June.Verizon said that adjusted earnings were 96 cents a share, up 2% from a year ago, with revenue roughly flat at $30.55 billion.A year earlier, Verizon earned 94 cents a share on sales of $30.53 billion. Analysts expected Verizon to report earnings of 96 cents on sales of $29.91 billion for the period ended June 30.Verizon, a member of the Dow Jones industrial average, rose 1% on Tuesday to 44.40, approaching its declining 50-day line. Verizon rallied as Citigroup proposed that Comcast (CMCSA) acquire the telecom. Comcast also reported second-quarter earnings early Thursday and topped estimates.RELATED:Comcast Q2 Earnings, Revenue Top Views Amid Verizon SpeculationTelecom: AT&T Rallies, Dish Slides, Comcast-Verizon Deal Seen

Rural phone company Windstream Holdings (WIN) and Internet service provider EarthLink Holdings (ELNK) agreed to merge in an all-stock $1.1 billion deal, including debt.Windstream expects to issue 93 million shares worth $673 million. Windstream shareholders will own 51% of the combined company, pro forma. The companies expect the deal to close in the first half of 2017. Earthlink had $466 million in debt as of June 30.EarthLink's stock jumped 15% on Friday amid speculation over a merger, to 6.22, but the stock has traded between 7.57 and 5.38 all year on continued losses and declines in revenue.Under deal terms, EarthLink shareholders will receive 0.82 shares of Windstream for each EarthLink share owned. The deal values EarthLink stock at $5.92 a share, below Friday's closing price of 6.22 but about 10% above Thursday's closing price of 5.42. EarthLink stock plunged 10% to finish trading at 5.60 on the stock market today.Windstream stock was flat at 7.23 after jumping 6.8% Friday to 7.24, and shares touched an 18-month high of 10.45 on Sept. 29.IBD'S TAKE: Some investors like telecom companies because many pay high dividends, but there are other options at IBD's Income Investor. "The combined company will have significantly more scale particularly within EarthLink's focus enterprise/mid-market business, which would likely allow it to more effectively compete against many of its much larger competitors," Cowen & Co. analyst Gregory Williams said in a research report. "Finally, we would also expect the combined company to continue to pay Windstream's annual 60-cent-per-share dividend, which has a current yield of 8%, compared to EarthLink's annual 20-cent-per-share dividend, which has a current yield of about 3%."Little Rock, Ark.-based Windstream in April spun off its network assets into a real estate investment trust called Communications Sales and Leasing, in which it retains a nearly 19% stake."The (Windstream-EarthLink) merger would mark another step toward consolidation in the enterprise communications space in an effort to benefit from scale and synergies," said UBS analyst Batya Levi in a research report.Telecom takeovers have heated up. The Windstream-Earthlink merger follows CenturyLink's (CTL) acquisition of Level 3 Communications (LVLT). AT&T (T) last month agreed to buy media giant Time Warner (TWX) in an $85 billion deal.Verizon Communication's (VZ) purchase of web portal Yahoo (YHOO) is expected t close in Q1 2017.RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosAT&T CEO On Time Warner Deal: Aiming To Set Pace In InnovationCenturyLink, Level 3 Stocks Spike; Merger Of Equals?

Hulu has struck content deals with parents 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS) for its upcoming live web TV streaming service, joining rivals AT&T (T) and Google in adding programming deals.Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) has signed on CBS as a partner for its "Unplugged"-branded service. CBS (CBS) might not provide programming to Hulu's new service, some analysts say.AT&T (T) last week said it would price a new video streaming service at $35 a month, lower than expected, though it's not clear if that's a discounted rate for wireless customers.Hulu said its new streaming service will feature entertainment, news, and sports channels from Fox and Disney.Hulu is a joint venture of Fox, Disney and Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal. With parents Disney and Fox announcing a Hulu live TV deal, the spotlight will turn to Comcast's NBCU.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Media-Diversified group ranks only No. 76 out of 197 industry groups. The leading stock in the group, CBS, has a Composite Rating below 90, where the CANSLIM investing system says winning stocks usually are 90 or better. Time Warner (TWX) recently bought a 10% stake in Hulu. AT&T last week agreed to buy Time Warner for $85.4 billion in cash and stock.Dish Network's (DISH) "Sling" service starts at $20 a month but doesn't provide programming from the four major broadcast networksAT&T has stated DirecTV Now will have lower profit margins than its traditional U-verse pay-TV services. Like other providers of so-called OTT (over-the-top) services, AT&T will not bear distribution costs, including network transport or set-top boxes.Shares of Fox, Disney and Comcast were all down a fraction in late-afternoon trading in the stock market today.RELATED:AT&T Swallows Razor-Thin Margins On $35 Video Streaming DealAT&T's DirecTV Now Pricing Will Be Key For Comcast, Hulu, AmazonAT&T CEO On Time Warner Deal: Aiming To Set Pace In Innovation

TV broadcasters reduced their asking price for prime wireless airwaves by about 36% to $54.6 billion in the second-stage of bidding in a government auction of radio spectrum, raising expectations that AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) could bite.In the first stage of the auction, TV broadcasters had sought $86 billion for 100 megahertz of usable radio spectrum, an asking price viewed as much too high by telecom industry observers. The Federal Communications Commission lowered the spectrum to be auctioned off to 90 MHz from 100 in the second stage.IBD'S TAKE: A successful auction is important to T-Mobile, which most needs more airwaves and could engage in merger talks after the auction is over, analysts say. T-Mobile stock is up 18% in 2016 but has been in a trading range since early August. Learn more about T-Mobile and Comcast, another possible auction bidder, at IBD Stock Checkup.The bigger-than-expected reduction makes it more likely that AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile and other bidders will buy the spectrum, though perhaps at a still lower price, analysts say. The next phase of bidding starts on Oct. 19."The reduction is larger than we expected, and suggests the auction could end more quickly," said UBS analyst John Hodulik in a research report. "Were the broadcasters to lower their ask in Stage 3 by a similar amount, 80 MHz of spectrum would be priced at around $35 billion, within our expectations for industry demand."TV broadcasters can walk away at any point if they determine that bids are too low."To us, the ($54.6 billion) target is still likely to be far off from what carriers might be willing to pay, given our projected spend for top industry players," Jefferies analyst Mike McCormack wrote in a research note.The auction's outcome is important to Dish Network (DISH), which has amassed nearly 80 MHz of spectrum but is still looking for a wireless partner. Cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA) has registered as a bidder and could buy airwaves as it readies a push into wireless services.UBS' Hodulik estimates that AT&T could spend $10 billion in the auction, followed by T-Mobile at $8 billion, Verizon at $6 billion and Comcast at $5 billion to $6 billion.If the auction drags on until the spring of 2017, it'll put a chill on telecom industry mergers and acquisitions. The FCC has imposed a quiet period on bidders, banning strategic talks among them until the auction is over.RELATED:Yahoo Stock Falls On Verizon Counsel Comments On Acquisition PriceAT&T Still Pays Big Dividends; Earnings On TapVerizon, T-Mobile, Dish Strategic Talks On Hold As Auction Drags On

AT&T (T) will sell a 100 channel-plus video-streaming service branded "DirecTV Now" starting at $35 monthly, its CEO Randall Stephenson said at a conference on Tuesday. Programming may not include much content from CBS (CBS) or 21st Century Fox (FOXA), based on earlier reports.AT&T's $35 price-tag is about $15 below estimates by Wall Street analysts.AT&T's pricing could impact the strategies of Hulu, which is expected to launch a live-streaming TV service in early 2017, as well as Amazon.com (AMZN). Hulu is a joint venture of Walt Disney (DIS), Fox and Comcast (CMCSA).AT&T has stated DirecTV Now will have lower profit margins than its traditional, U-verse pay-TV services. Like other providers of so-called OTT (over-the-top) services, AT&T will not bear distribution costs, including network transport or set-top boxes.At $35 a month, AT&T's package might not include sports channels such as Disney's ESPN.IBD's TAKE: AT&T stock has dropped nearly 7% since reports of the Time Warner deal surfaced and subsequently announced. Time Warner stock is trading at near 87, roughly 20 below AT&T's cash and stock offer of 107.50 per share. Analysts say TWX shareholders may be unsure of regulatory approval. Analysts do not expect another bidder such as Walt Disney or Apple to swoop in for TWX. Media stocks have cooled off since Friday. Learn more about CBS and other media stocks at IBD Stock Checkup.Stephenson, while announcing AT&T's proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner (TWX) on Monday, disclosed that DirecTV Now would be launched in November. Time Warner owns a 10% stake in Hulu.AT&T acquired satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group in 2015."We estimate monthly programming costs for DirecTV Now in the low $30 range, similar to the price AT&T will charge, meaning the company will not make much on this service," UBS analyst John Hodulik said in a research report. "However, it will avoid costs for satellites, set-top boxes and installations/trouble-shooting, while also reaching customers who have left the pay TV market or never joined."Strong growth in this product would support AT&T's vision for the TWX transaction and likely sit well with regulators concerned about the OTT ecosystem."

Dish Network's (DISH)"Sling" service starts at $20 monthly but does not provide programming from the four major broadcast networks. Dish has experimented with different Sling packages, with and without ESPN and Disney in the basic offering. Extra Sling programming tiers cost an extra $10 a month.AT&T will limit the DirecTV Now offering to two simultaneous video streams. The offering doesn't include DVR functions, analysts say.AT&T is also expected to launch a mobile version of the DirecTV Now product as well as a free, ad-driven version with fewer channels.AT&T's success or not in bundling video and mobile services, analysts say, is a big factor in whether Comcast, Charter Communications (CHTR) and cable TV firms decide to acquire a wireless network.AT&T stock was down a fraction, near 36.75, in late-afternoon trading in the stock market today.RELATED:AT&T's DirecTV Now Pricing Will Be Key For Comcast, Hulu, AmazonAT&T CEO On Time Warner Deal: Aiming To Set Pace In InnovationHow Aggressive AT&T Has Out-Maneuvered Verizon, Comcast

Google has signed up its first broadcasting content partner -- CBS (CBS) --  for a web TV service set for an early 2017 launch.The over-the-top (OTT) market is expected to heat up with new offerings from AT&T (T), Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Hulu. What differs in this new wave from earlier Internet video services is the expected inclusion of more live broadcast content. Most OTT services have featured on-demand programming.Google has gain edrights to all of CBS' content, including live NFL games, Reuters and the Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday. CBS has marketed its own stand-alone, direct-to-consumer, web TV service.IBD'S TAKE: The new "Unplugged" OTT service will be part of Google's YouTube platform. Google has not disclosed YouTube's profitability or revenue. Read this IBD in-depth report about YouTube's mysterious financials.AT&T is expected to launch DirecTV Now this quarter. AT&T has leveraged satellite broadcaster DirecTV's programming deals to cobble together an Internet video service. But AT&T has not finalized deals with CBS and 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), analysts say."The Google deal is understood to pay CBS a rate card premium to its traditional (pay-TV) services," said Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil in a report. The deal does not include Showtime movies and TV shows, he said.Google reportedly is in talks with  21st Century Fox and Walt Disney (DIS), owner of broadcast network ABC.Dish Network (DISH)  launched SlingTV, its OTT service in early 2015. Sony (SNE) offers PlayStation Vue, a high-end option.AT&T is expected to price its DirecTV Now service at around $50 to $55 monthly. Google's "Unplugged"-branded service may be priced lower, say reports.Hulu is a joint venture of Disney, Fox, and Comcast (CMCSA). Time Warner (TWX) recently bought a 10% stake in Hulu.Apple (AAPL) last year shelved its web TV service as talks with programmers stalled. Cost-sharing to distribute the service was reportedly one issue.Google stock climbed 0.7% to 827.09 in the stock market today, earlier touching an all-time high for the second day in a row.RELATED:AT&T's DirecTV Now Pricing Will Be Key For Comcast, Hulu, Amazon

T-Mobile US (TMUS) and cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA) will be the top two bidders in the government auction of radio spectrum owned by local TV stations, together amassing what would be a surprising three-fourths of the spectrum sold, predicts UBS.UBS analyst John Hodulik estimates that T-Mobile will end up spending a range of $8 billion to $10 billion for around 30 MHz of spectrum, with Comcast spending $5 billion to $6 billion for 20 MHz of airwaves. Hodulik estimated AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Dish Network (DISH) will acquire 5 MHz of spectrum each in the auction.Hodulik says if T-Mobile was able to buy 30 MHz of spectrum, wireless competition will further intensify."If T-Mobile secures 30 MHz of low-band spectrum, this will only further close the network (performance) gap with the incumbents and ramp up competition across the country, including rural America, where T-Mobile has been less competitive historically," said Hodulik.AT&T and Verizon likely did not bid aggressively in the auction, says UBS. AT&T on Thursday was officially declared the winner of the FirstNet contract for building a national, wireless public safety network.The Federal Communications Commission is expected to announce the auction's results by mid-April. Bids topped $19.6 billion, the FCC said in February.T-Mobile stock was up a fraction to close at 65.13 on the stock market today. Shares in Comcast were up 0.8% to 37.51.IBD'S TAKE: T-Mobile stock has gained 12% in 2017 and has neared a buy point of 65.51. T-Mobile has had the highest revenue growth among the top four wireless firms for three years. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.The UBS analyst also speculates that a T-Mobile merger with Dish Network is less likely, while a Sprint deal remains an option."We believe sizable auction winnings for T-Mobile would help address near-term capacity needs, position the company for long-term growth, and make them less reliant on M&A to build value," said Hodulik in the report.Under auction rules, registered bidders have been barred from holding strategic talks until it's over.Comcast has stated it plans to sell wireless services by late 2017 through a network leasing arrangement with Verizon. However, Hodulik doesn't expect Comcast to make a big push in wireless services until competition eases, perhaps through industry consolidation.Comcast, Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks in late 2011 sold spectrum to Verizon for $3.6 billion. Some analysts say Comcast could use its new spectrum to renegotiate its network leasing deal with Verizon.RELATED:It's Official: AT&T Wins Pact For FirstNet Public Safety NetworkThink Your Wireless Carrier Is Planning A Merger? Not So Fast

Aging advisors often find themselves serving aging clients. To diversify their customer base, they may seek to attract millennials as well.Seasoned advisors may conclude that wooing younger clientele will sustain their practice for decades to come. Cultivating relationships with millennials — those born in the 1980s and 1990s — enables advisors to gain assets over time as early-career professionals' earning power increases.It's relatively easy for advisors in their 20s and 30s to reach out to their peers to drum up business. But it's tougher for graying wealth managers to appeal to investors half their age."It can be hard for older advisors," said Joe Pitzl, 36, a certified financial planner in Minneapolis. "Millennials expect a different approach, so a 50- or 60-year-old advisor has to change" to curry favor with younger generations.The challenge starts with piercing long-held beliefs that millennials lack sufficient assets to make good clients. They will experience the fastest growth rate of net wealth among any age group, according to the Deloitte Center for Financial Services. As their incomes soar, so will their need for advisors' expertise.Older financial planners may assume that they have little in common with social media-loving millennials who are supposedly quirky, cynical and reluctant to pay experts for advice. It's tempting to give up and remain wedded to aging clients with a more familiar profile.While a small percentage of millennials have amassed vast wealth as visionary entrepreneurs, most do not possess sizable assets. But despite their modest savings, they may still crave investment and retirement-planning guidance.As a result, financial planners of all ages are embracing robo-advisor tools as an extension of their service offerings. Integrating financial technologies may limit the personal service that traditional advisors are accustomed to providing, but it's a cost-effective way to accommodate millennials with relatively simple asset-allocation needs.At some point, however, older advisors will need to connect with younger clients face-to-face. And that can prove vexing, at least at first."The No. 1 thing I tell older advisors is millennials' learning styles and communication are very different," Pitzl said. "A lot of older advisors think of themselves as the wise old sage who's there to educate clients. But if you think of how millennials have been educated, everything happens in teams. So they want a collaborative partner," not a lecturer bequeathing knowledge.When batting around investment ideas with millennials, for example, share your research reports and other raw data. Engage them in the process of analyzing risk and reward so that they fully participate in decision-making."They want to see and understand the mechanics of what's going on," Pitzl added. "They want a more transparent process as opposed to you making it sound like there's some mystique that they can't possibly understand."As part of that transparency, millennials expect to be able to track their portfolio online. Advisory firms that seek to attract younger clients need to offer secure cloud-based platforms."Client portals and aggregation tools are very important," Pitzl said. "Millennials want 24/7 access to their information, whether they use it or not."In their efforts to win over millennials, graying advisors need to position themselves as nonjudgmental allies who can help young professionals attain the lifestyle they want. This requires careful listening and the shrewd use of open-ended questions.Probe to determine how they define career success and how they would describe their ideal lifestyle. Show interest in their aspirations and values."Brainstorm with them on how to make their day-to-day life mean more," Pitzl said. "Millennials want a teammate who can get into the nuts and bolts — like wrestling with day-care costs — to help them figure out a plan" that will make them happy and fulfilled.He cites an example of a young couple, both well-paid retail executives, who came to him in a quandary.
