Who Wants Dish's Spectrum?

Horan opines that Verizon is the only "real" potential buyer of Dish Network's radio spectrum, but says Verizon "won't pay a premium for it." JPMorgan last year said a partnership structure between Verizon and Dish Network made sense, though it could take time for a deal to jell.
Meanwhile, existing-home sales rose to an eight-year high in July, but millennials were still missing in action as the share of first-time buyers fell to the lowest since January.
Existing-home sales surged to a stronger-than-expected 5.59 million annual rate, up 10.3% vs. a year earlier.
Inventories are lean — the current supply is 4.8 months' worth. That's been pushing up prices, though they cooled by 1% in July.
However, first-timers fell to 28% of the total in July, the lowest since January. That's down from 30% in June and May's 32%, the strongest since 2012.

Many homebuilders catering to first-time and millennial buyers have fared well, with shares of D.R. Horton (DHI), LGI Homes (LGIH) and Lennar (LEN) hitting longtime or record highs over the past week, though so has luxury builder Toll Bros. (TOL)
Horton pulled back in mild fashion on Thursday, falling less than 2% in slightly above-average trade. The stock is up 10% past a 28.80 cup-with-handle entry.

It's not your imagination — the cost of pay-TV service is going through the roof. U.S. household spending on pay-TV service has risen 39% since 2010, according to a new report by Leichtman Research Group. Average reported monthly spending on pay-TV service is now $99.10, Leichtman said. That's up from $89.78 last year and $71.24 in 2010. Ten years ago, the average was $49.51.Leichtman notes that the figures are self-reported and that 18% of 2015 survey respondents either didn't know or did not provide their current spending.For its latest survey, Leichtman conducted a phone survey of 1,222 U.S. adults in June.Rising cable TV bills are often cited as a reason for talk of cord-cutting and cord-trimming — subscribers either canceling their pay-TV service or reducing the number of channels they get. There are also cord-nevers, who have never paid for cable, satellite or telecom TV.About 83% of U.S. households subscribe to some form of pay-TV service, analyst Bruce Leichtman said in a statement Thursday. The percentage of households that subscribe to a pay-TV service peaked at 88% in 2010 and has slid nearly every year since.Among TV households that do not currently subscribe to a pay-TV service, 17% paid for a service in the past year, while 70% of non-subscribers last subscribed over three years ago or never subscribed to a pay-TV service.Overall, about 2.5% of TV households paid to subscribe to a service in the past year, but currently do not — compared with 1.5% in 2010 and 2.3% in 2005, Leichtman said.Among the non-subscribers, 63% get a subscription Internet video-on-demand service like Netflix (NFLX) or Hulu and 62% have an over-the-air broadcast TV antenna.Renters are much more likely not to subscribe to pay TV.In households using a TV, 12% of homeowners do not subscribe to a pay-TV service, compared with 23% of renters.In the first six months of 2015, the 13 largest pay-TV providers in the U.S. lost a combined 463,000 subscribers. They lost 126,000 subscribers last year and 105,000 in 2013, Leichtman says.Comcast (CMCSA) has lost 77,000 video subscribers this year, after losing 194,000 in 2014 and 305,000 in 2013.Time Warner Cable (TWC) lost 10,000 video subscribers in the first half of 2015. It lost 401,000 in 2014 and 825,000 in 2013.Charter Communications (CHTR) lost 35,000 video subscribers in the first six months of this year. It lost 49,000 last year and 121,000 in 2013.Cablevision Systems (CVC) has lost 44,000 video subscribers so far this year. Cablevision lost 132,000 in 2014 and 80,000 in 2013.Satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) shed 215,000 subscribers in the first six months of the year. It lost 79,000 last year and gained only 1,000 in 2013.Telecom companies have been net gainers recently.AT&T (T) added 28,000 video subscribers in the first half of 2015, after signing up 660,000 in 2014 and 924,000 in 2013.Verizon Communications (VZ) tacked on 116,000 video subscribers in the first half of 2015. It added 387,000 in 2014 and 536,000 in 2013.

Federal Spending: President Obama has been crowing over a decline in the budget deficit. But what he doesn't mention — and Republicans shouldn't forget — is a major reason for that progress: budget caps.The deficit has dropped to less than $500 billion this year from the towering heights of $1.5 trillion during Obama's first term. But as the nearby chart shows, much of the improvement came after spending restraints were imposed under the Budget Control Act of 2011, during the fiscal fight between the president and congressional Republicans.Now Obama (again) wants to wriggle out of those spending restraints and go on another Washington shopping spree. The caps legally constrain domestic non-entitlement programs and national defense spending.The White House plan would increase discretionary spending to $1.091 trillion from $1.017 trillion. This $74 billion increase would be split evenly between defense and domestic spending. The 7% hike in 2016 would dish out plums to unions, foreign aid groups, the education blob, government contractors, federal employees, the climate change lobby and other tax guzzlers.Our Senate sources tell us that Minority Leader Harry Reid is threatening in private that if Republicans don't give Democrats the raise they want, there will be fiscal paralysis in the Senate and another government shutdown Oct. 1 — which, of course, they will blame on the GOP.Many Republicans are inclined to go along with the great fiscal escape plan. Some have legitimate concerns about more money needed for our military in times of growing national security threats. Already 60% of the cuts are in defense, even though military spending is less than 20% of the budget. But many GOP appropriators just want more domestic pork for their own districts.Wait a minute. Since 2012, these spending ceilings have been breached at least three times — it's become an annual fall ritual. Spending as a share of GDP bumped up this year because of the upward revisions in the caps.Republicans should force Obama to live by the law he signed. The caps are the best leverage they have to keep a lid on spending, given the president's planned blowout. And keep in mind that this year's caps aren't even a real cut. They simply hold spending to last year's levels. Capping government spending and debt helps the economy because it frees up resources for private investment and consumption.If Republicans fold on the caps again, it won't be just a fiscal setback but a political election-eve disaster as well. They keep running for office as fiscal disciplinarians only to cave to their most craven instincts to spend. Less than a year ago, the voters gave the GOP control of the House and the Senate in no small part to clean up the fiscal mess. Have they forgotten that pledge already?Perhaps Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker John Boehner hope that voters aren't paying attention to the spiraling debt and runaway spending. That's a bad bet.Donald Trump's poll surge should be a blaring siren that voters have grown weary of the Republicans going to Washington and breaking solemn promises. A GOP betrayal of fiscal conservatives this year would only intensify that voter contempt.If clueless Republican leaders think voters are angry now, wait till McConnell and Boehner must confront the fury after another spend-and-borrow binge. A budget surrender is the best way to ensure that Reid is reinstalled as majority leader in 2017 — reason alone why the caps must stick.

Dish Network's  (DISH) Q2 subscriber losses nearly doubled from the year-earlier period despite Sling Web TV subscriber growth, but earnings and revenue topped views. Dish Network, which launched a Web TV service called Sling in February, included Sling in financial data for the first time with its earnings release early Wednesday. Sling had 169,000 customers as of March 31,…

Cellphone tower operators should get a boost in 2017, when capital spending by customers AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Sprint (S) picks up, says SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, which initiated coverage on American Tower (AMT), Crown Castle (CCI) and SBA Communications (SBAC) with buy ratings."As we look forward to 2017, we believe the outlook is relatively brighter. U.S. carrier activity remains stable at historically low levels, but a number of growth drivers — new spectrum deployments/re-farming, 5G trials and FirstNet, for example — could modestly re-accelerate growth for the group," said Greg Miller, a SunTrust analyst, in a research report.IBD'S TAKE: Both Crown Castle and American Tower are real estate investment trusts (REITs), which pay dividends. REIT stocks perform well when interest rates are low. But IBD's Finance-Property REIT group ranks just No. 90 out of 197 industry groups amid worries that interest rates could rise. A good place to check on industry group ratings is Stock Checkup. After a big run, dividend-paying AT&T and Verizon are also being pressured by views that the Federal Reserve may hike short-term rates.Verizon has stated it plans to be a leader in next-generation 5G wireless services. The U.S. government, meanwhile, is expected to soon award a contract for FirstNet, a nationwide wireless broadband network dedicated to public safety.Miller expects intensified wireless competition to drive investments in network capacity. T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint have stepped up marketing for unlimited data offers, while AT&T and Verizon are selling bigger data buckets."In our view, the U.S. wireless industry remains fiercely competitive, and the risk of standing still from a network-quality perspective is just as great if not greater than ever," added Miller in the report. "We believe carriers — particularly AT&T and, to a lesser degree, Verizon — will need to continue to spend on networks in order to maintain long-term competitiveness and, should 2016 play out as we expect, the odds of greater activity next year increase from a historical perspective."Crown Castle, American Tower and SBA Communications all fell hard in the stock market today. Crown Castle stock fell 2.2%, to 91.87, while American Tower stock dropped 2.8%, to 108.11, and SBA fell 2.3%, to 108.99. Crown Castle and American Tower touched record highs in July, above 102 for the former and above 118 for the latter.RELATED:Verizon, T-Mobile, Dish Strategic Talks On Hold As Auction Drags OnAT&T, Verizon Get Their Wish: FCC Opens Up 5G AirwavesSpectrum Wild Cards May Add Supply, Impact Verizon, T-Mobile, AT&T

Both names have come under selling pressure in recent weeks, but another bellwether income stock in the group is trading tightly near highs and deserves a closer look. [ibdchart symbol="MRK"…

A government auction of spectrum owned by TV broadcasters might drag on until the spring of 2017 -- putting a prolonged chill on telecom industry mergers and acquisitions.AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US (TMUS), cable firm Comcast (CMCSA) and satellite-TV firm Dish Network (DISH) are among companies that have filed as bidders in the auction, which began March 29.In the first stage of the auction, TV broadcasters agreed to sell spectrum in local markets within a price range set by the Federal Communications Commission.The second phase of the complex, so-called "broadcast incentive" TV auction, started Tuesday, with the FCC providing auction updates.While some 126 megahertz of spectrum will be available overall in the second stage of the auction, about 100 MHz of that will be for commercial wireless use after the FCC "re-packs" broadcast airwaves.Broadcasters are seeking over $86 billion for the spectrum. But there's a wide gap between how much money TV broadcasters are seeking to part with their airwaves and how much wireless and other companies are prepared to bid, though it might be posturing, analysts say."We expect $30 billion to $40 billion of spending from the wireless industry -- including AT&T ($10 billion), T-Mobile ($8 billion), Verizon ($6 billion), and Comcast ($3 billion to $5 billion) -- well below the broadcasters' $86 billion ask for 100 MHz of spectrum," said UBS analyst John Hodulik in a research report.The FCC has imposed a quiet period on bidders, banning strategic talks among them until the auction is over."The process will likely require at least four rounds of auction, which could push it into 2017," Jonathan Atkin, an analyst at RBC Capital, said in a report. "The FCC's anti-collusion rules will continue to apply during this period, having a continuing chilling effect on sector M&A."IBD'S TAKE:  Shares of Comcast, AT&T, Verizon and T-Mobile have all gained in 2016, but Dish Network is down as its core pay-TV business slows. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Some analysts expect demand by wireless and other firms to peak at around 60 MHz to 70 MHz of commercial-ready spectrum.Michael Rollins, a Citigroup analyst, said in a report: "We see the auction finishing in the winter or spring of 2017, recognizing the auction could go longer if the reverse and forward auction values don't meet the final stage rule within a range of auctioned mobile spectrum of 60 to 80 MHz."Indeed, TV broadcasters could walk away from the auction if they deem bidding prices in local markets to be too low.Analyst Hodulik says a "failed" auction could be a plus for Dish Network, which has cobbled together nearly 80 MHz of spectrum and needs a wireless partner.Shares of AT&T fell 2.5% to 41.96, closing below their 50-day line, on the stock market today. Verizon fell 1.6%. Disney lost 0.2%, Comcast eased 0.3%, and T-Mobile fell 1.1%.

Macquarie Capital upgraded Dish Network (DISH) to buy on views that most scenarios on how a government spectrum auction could play out look better for the satellite TV broadcaster.Macquarie Capital analyst Amy Yong upgraded Dish Network to buy from neutral and maintained a price target of 62, in a research report.Dish Network stock closed up 1.85% at 52.24 in the stock market today. The pay TV provider's stock, however, is down 8% in 2016.Dish Network has amassed nearly 80 megahertz of radio spectrum for mobile video services, but it's been unable to partner with Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US (TMUS) or Sprint (S) on a service. AT&T (T) acquired No. 1 satellite TV firm DirecTV Group in 2015.The Federal Communications Commission is auctioning off radio spectrum owned by local TV broadcasters. The second phase of the complex auction is slated to start Aug. 16. The auction is expected to continue into late 2016.AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile and Comcast (CMCSA) are among the expected bidders.Macquarie's Yong says the value of Dish Network's nearly 80 MHz of airwaves could rise, depending on what bidding levels are reached in the TV spectrum auction. If the TV spectrum auction falls apart, Dish would could also be better-positioned, Yong says. TV broadcasters could walk away from the auction if they deem bidding prices in local markets as too low."Auction postponement or hiccups could make Dish one of few near-term sources of spectrum," Yong wrote.IBD'S TAKE: The Telecom-Services Cable/Satellite group is ranked No. 168 out of 197 industry groups. Comcast is top-ranked within the group but has a so-so IBD Composite Rating of 75 out of a possible 99. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Dish Network could lease its spectrum to a wireless partner, Yong speculated, or the pay TV services provider could be bought outright."Our assumption is that Dish would like to position itself as a connectivity company. Thus, separating its spectrum from its core pay TV business is less likely," Yong added.

Walt Disney (DIS) topped Wall Street estimates and announced Tuesday plans to bring to life an "ESPN-branded multisport subscription streaming service," a move that has been hinted at for months now as the House of Mouse seeks to soothe fears of cable TV cord-cutting.The company is paying $1 billion to acquire a 33% stake in BAMTech, which has been Major League Baseball's MLB Advanced Media streaming unit. The news comes weeks after reports of the deal first surfaced.Under the agreement, expect to see a collaboration between BAMTech and ESPN "in the future," according to a Disney statement, though a timeline was not specified. Disney said that BAMTech was separated from MLB Advanced Media as part of the deal."The direct-to-consumer service will feature content provided by both BAMTech and ESPN, and include live regional, national and international sporting events," the company said in the release.CEO Bob Iger said on the earnings call late Tuesday that he sees the streaming service as a companion to ESPN, and that the goal was not to pluck content from ESPN's current offerings but to use existing licensed content that is not found elsewhere on the sports network.At ESPN, advertising and affiliate revenue grew during the quarter, but subscribers continued to decline at the network, a key moneymaker for Disney in years past.Iger also said that ESPN and select Disney channels would be available on AT&T's (T) DirecTV over-the-top bundle. Disney content can already be found on Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue, two streaming services.When asked about the significance of Disney's presence in streaming packages, Iger pointed out that Sony saw subscriptions increase "substantially" when ESPN was added to the PlayStation bundle."Our best interest is to invest more in the total pie even if it means fragmentation," said Iger on the call, because the addition of those new parts will "result in a greater whole."For the fiscal third quarter, Walt Disney earned an adjusted $1.62 a share, up 12% and above expectations for $1.61. Revenue grew 9% to $14.28 billion vs. the Street's projections for $14.15 billion.Disney's media-networks revenue rose 2%, with a 1% gain in the cable-networks subsegment. Parks revenue rose 6%. Studio revenue jumped 40%, thanks to movies such as "The Jungle Book," "Captain America: Civil War" and "Finding Dory." Consumer products and interactive media revenue fell 1%.Shares were down 1.6% in late trade, after finishing the regular session up almost 1% to 96.67.Now the question becomes how Disney will manage pricing for the new streaming service, said Edward Jones analyst Robin Diedrich."How do you keep the cash cow going when you're growing the new service?" she told IBD. She added that customers "are clearly wanting that service. If they price it right, there's room for both business models to live and keep the brand strong."Meanwhile, Hulu, of which Disney is part owner, is launching a live-streaming package of its own next year, but Diedrich does not necessarily expect that to cannibalize the new ESPN streaming service."The vast majority -- well over 90% -- of Netflix (NFLX) subscribers still have a connection for some other kind of service," she said, indicating that the various platforms have space to co-exist.

Media stocks continued their collapse Thursday, with investors worried that a day of reckoning is at hand for the pay-TV ecosystem. Walt Disney's (DIS) warning late Tuesday over slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees, the payments media firms garner from pay-TV companies, set the sell-off in motion. Generally soft media earnings didn't help. Disney shares fell 1.8% after losing 9%…

T-Mobile US outpaced bigger rivals AT&T and Verizon Communications by posting Q2 revenue growth of 14% early Thursday, topping Wall Street views amid signs that T-Mobile's falling revenue per subscriber might have bottomed despite an industry price war. Analysts had forecast revenue growth of 10%. T-Mobile's  (TMUS) average monthly revenue per user (ARPU) for postpaid phone customers fell only…

It's clear that Apple (AAPL) iPhones and Tesla (TSLA) luxury electric cars command star power overseas. But Hollywood has long been one of America's most influential exports, and Netflix (NFLX) has become a dominant portal for the product. The world's infatuation with U.S. film and other Western content plays well for streaming king Netflix. "This is an American brand with…
What cable channels make the cut and are included in Apple's (AAPL) expected Web TV service could take on more significance after the recent sell-off in media and entertainment stocks.

Apple, it's widely reported, has been in talks with programmers to offer a slimmed-down bundle of TV networks. While Apple is said to be keen on including live broadcast networks NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox, its plans for cable TV channels remain unknown.
UBS analyst Doug Mitchelson, in a research report Tuesday on Discovery (DISCA), calls Apple's Web TV launch a wild card for cable channels.

Discovery is perhaps best known for its popular "Shark Week" programming, but Discovery stock is down nearly 35% in the past year as the pay-TV and video content industry goes through a transition, with more viewers moving to Internet services and dropping cable services, or cutting the cord.

"Key for (Discovery) shares will be continuing ratings strength, investors gaining comfort with the pace of decline for the U.S. pay-TV bundle, whether Discovery will be included in any Apple TV OTT (over the top, or Web TV) offering (at reasonable economics), and the health of the TV ad market this fall," he said in the report.

When Dish Network (DISH) launched it's limited-channel, $20-per-month Sling Web TV service in January, it left out broadcast networks as well as cable channels from AMC Networks (AMCX), CBS (CBS), Discovery, 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's NBCUniversal and Viacom (VIA).

Referring to Sling, RBC Capital analyst David Bank said in a May research report: "Many are concerned this is the beginning of breaking down the bundle into a more a la carte skinny version that has only those networks the consumer most wants." Viewership of cable channels, meanwhile, continue to fall, according to ratings tracker Nielsen.

The biggest media firms that own broadcast TV networks as well as popular cable channels, such as Disney's (DIS) ESPN sports channel, might be best-positioned to hammer out a deal with Apple. However, Apple's talks with Comcast (CMCSA), owner of NBCU, reportedly hit a rough patch earlier this year.
Apple is said to be mulling a Web TV service with about 25 channels, priced around $35 a month. The service had long been anticipated, but many observers don't see it becoming a reality this year.

CBS CEO Leslie Moonves in May said Apple is "is trying to change the universe a little bit as did Sling, as did Sony (SNE) (which is launching an Internet TV service). What Apple will offer ... is a more select group (of channels) for a lower price."
Apple's Web TV service has been delayed until 2016, Bloomberg reported, amid stalled negotiations with content companies and quality concerns over online video delivery.
Media stocks were torched in early August after Disney warned over over slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees and Discovery stopped a stock buyback.

Disney stock is down 12% since touching a record high of 122.08 on Aug. 4.What cable channels make the cut and are included in Apple's (AAPL) expected Web TV service could take on more significance after the recent sell-off in media and entertainment stocks.Apple, it's widely reported, has been in talks with programmers to offer a slimmed-down bundle of TV networks. However, Apple's talks with Comcast (CMCSA), owner of NBCU, reportedly hit a rough patch earlier this year.Apple is said to be mulling a Web TV service with about 25 channels, priced around $35 a month. What Apple will offer ... is a more select group (of channels) for a lower price."Apple's Web TV service has been delayed until 2016, Bloomberg reported, amid stalled negotiations with content companies and quality concerns over online video delivery.Media stocks were torched in early August after Disney warned over over slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees and Discovery stopped a stock buyback.Disney stock is down 12% since touching a record high of 122.08 on Aug. 4.

Walt Disney (DIS) reports third-quarter results after the close Tuesday. Between its studios, networks, theme parks and products, there's a lot going on at the House of Mouse.Read on for what to expect, and come back later for the results.Wall Street is expecting 11% third-quarter profit growth to $1.61 per share on 8% in revenue gains to $14.15 billion.The entertainment conglomerate has been disappointing analysts in recent quarters, missing earnings estimates in the second quarter and falling short of revenue expectations for three out of the last four quarters, according to Thomson Reuters.Shares shaved 8 cents off their price to 95.75 at the close Monday, ahead of earnings, and are trading up about 0.3% to 96.02 in the pre-market hours Tuesday.As it builds a flat base, the stock has been trading below its 200-day line since early May. And since mid-May, shares have infrequently come up for air above their 50-day moving average.Is Disney still a Hollywood sweetheart? The mega-success of the seventh "Star Wars" was a high point for Disney's theatrical arm. But some worried that Han Solo would be a solo studio-revenue spike.Even outside of the Lucasfilm franchise, however, Marvel and Pixar have been pumping out hits, feeding the public's appetite for superhero movies and adorable animation.Flicks like "The Jungle Book," "Captain America: Civil War" and "Finding Dory" performed well during the quarter.Per Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil: "We continue to be of the view that the Studio and corresponding Consumer Products segments continue to deserve a strong multiple reflecting the very strong pipeline which the Studio continues to have and which we believe no longer justifies an asterisk or a one-off and instead is more reflective of a strong cycle from not just from Marvel and Pixar, but increasingly from Disney Animation and Disney live action."Is ESPN experiencing more subscriber losses? Ever since Bob Iger's year-ago comments on "modest" ESPN subscriber losses that prompted investors to take a light saber to media stocks, it's practically become a staple on earnings calls now for the Disney chief to field questions about the state of the company's cable moneymaker.Why all the pearl-clutching over how many people pay to get ESPN? For reference, Disney's cable networks segment alone made up over 30% of revenue in the previously announced quarter, and its broader media networks unit -- which includes cable -- accounted for about 45% of total revenue.And in the age of cord cutting, every eyeball matters.IBD'S TAKE: Media conglomerates are searching for new ways to reel in young viewers, and virtual reality is an appealing medium. Read IBD's recent cover story for more: Disney, Comcast Pour Cash In Virtual Reality As The 'Netflix Of VR' Looms.The panic has subsided to a nervous whisper. In May, Iger told analysts on the call that Disney's inclusion on bundles from Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue had contributed to "incremental subs" for ESPN during the quarter.Still, Edward Jones analyst Robin Diedrich expects "slower growth than in the past as competition for consumer time and entertainment dollars increases," according to a July 29 note.What's going on with Hulu? Hulu -- the streaming service jointly owned by Disney, 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal, and now Time Warner (TWX) -- is launching a live-streaming TV package next year. (Yahoo (YHOO) and Hulu just struck a licensing deal for its free content, by the way.)Iger said last quarter that Hulu has "become an important investment for us," not just as a distributor, but also as a buyer of original content and distributor of Disney's channels.He added that the company "feel(s) really good about the opportunity."Expect more commentary on Disney's new Shanghai Disney Resort, which opened to praise and good reviews.

BAMTech invested an undisclosed amount in college sports streaming company Silver Chalice just weeks after Walt Disney (DIS) took a one-third stake in BAMTech.The digital media rights, technology and investment partnership announced Monday between BAMTech, Major League Baseball's streaming media service, and Silver Chalice includes a new suite of live streaming products for college sports fans across mobile and connected platforms, to be released later this year. Financial terms of the BAMTech-Silver Chalice deal weren't disclosed.Silver Chalice CEO Brooks Boyer said in a written statement that, "Silver Chalice has focused on building partnerships with rightsholders, producing compelling content and delivering it to college sports fans where they want it, when they want it."It's BAMTech's first initiative in college sports programming. Silver Chalice is controlled by Chicago White Sox and Bulls owner Jerry Reinsdorf, who is also chairman. Silver Chalice owns sports news and information site Campus Insiders and the Atlantic Coast Conference network, among others, according to Bloomberg.IBD'S TAKE: Walt Disney has announced plans for an ESPN streaming service. Here's why the ESPN streaming offering isn't what you think it is.Silver Chalice networks are available on Verizon (VZ) offering Go90, Dish Network (DISH) streaming offering Sling TV, Twitter (TWTR), Microsoft (MSFT) unit MSN.com, Yahoo (YHOO) -- which is being acquired by Verizon for $4.8 billion -- Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google's YouTube and USA Sports, among others.Walt Disney CEO Bob Iger disclosed the investment in BAMTech on Aug. 9, saying Disney is "investing for change," including its recent announcement of an over-the-top ESPN service, which could debut as early as end of this year.Disney stock has been working on a flat base since mid-May with a 106.85 buy point. The House of Mouse has lined up five new Star Wars movies to roll out over as many years, and showed a trailer for the first one, "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story," during the Rio Olympics. That movie is slated for release on Dec. 16.Disney shares fell 0.5% to 95.87 on the stock market today. The stock is trading below its 50-day line as part of a downtrend that started in early November.

Dish Network (DISH) stock fell in heavy volume Tuesday after the company announced plans to raise $2 billion in a convertible-debt sale amid a government auction of airwaves owned by local TV broadcasters.Dish Network stock plunged 8% to close at 49.19 in the stock market today.The Federal Communications Commission's auction of radio spectrum owned by local TV firms could drag on into Q4. AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Comcast (CMCSA) have been expected to be the leading bidders. Federal regulators have banned strategic talks among listed bidders until the auction is over.Dish Network spent nearly $10 billion in the so-called "AWS-3" auction, which ended in early 2015.Dish Network has amassed nearly 80MHz of radio spectrum for mobile video services, but it's been unable to partner with Verizon, T-Mobile or Sprint. AT&T acquired No. 1 satellite TV firm DirecTV Group in 2015.IBD'S TAKE: Dish Network has added sizable debt to fund its wireless spectrum purchases. T-Mobile's Q2 earnings fell 52%, to 20 cents, on higher interest costs tied to its borrowing to fund auction bidding. T-Mobile stock has gained 19% in 2016. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Dish Network's core pay TV business has been losing subscribers. In Q2, Dish Network said it had a net loss of 281,000 pay TV customers, including satellite and the Sling web TV service, marking it biggest quarterly subscriber loss ever.Dish Network shares bounced back, though, when Dish Network on its earnings call mentioned joint work with AT&T to build an advertising platform. There's speculation that AT&T could be a buyer of a small block of airwaves that Dish Network owns in the 700 MHz frequency band.Dish has told analysts that it will not face pressure to build out a wireless network until 2020, under its agreements with federal regulators.

Walt Disney (DIS) Chief Executive Bob Iger said Tuesday that the House of Mouse is "aggressively investing for change," led by its one-third stake in streaming company BAMTech and newly announced plans to launch an over-the-top ESPN service, "probably" by the end of 2016.Despite more ESPN subscriber losses, Wall Street seemed happy with both the streaming news and the better-than-projected third quarter, as shares were up Wednesday afternoon, looking to close above their 50-day line.But before cable subscribers get scissors-happy and cut the cord, let's take a look at what that new service might actually include, and what it means for Disney's place in this brave new digital world.Iger stated plainly that the ESPN-branded service will be a "complementary service to what ESPN is already providing," making clear that Disney wasn't planning on nicking current ESPN content."The goal is not to take product off ESPN's current channels, but to use sports and product that ESPN has already licensed that's not appearing on the channels," he said during the call.If that's the case, don't expect to watch the Wimbledon championship or NBA conference finals via an over-the-top ESPN platform. Sports enthusiasts will still need a regular cable subscription (or Sling TV or Vue) for that. What the new digital sports-network service will feature, according to Iger, is licensed content from BAMTech's stable of MLB and NHL programming, plus "college sports, football and basketball, tennis, rugby, cricket, etc."For investors, the bright spot of this deal comes not from what sports cord-cutters might be able to access, but what the Mouse has in store for this technology down the road."We think Disney has bought its way into a commanding position on future content viewership," said Macquarie analyst Tim Nollen, who upgraded Disney to outperform from neutral on Wednesday. "BAM Tech is a premier (over-the-top) streaming technology in its own right, and Disney now has the means to connect directly with consumers."IBD'S TAKE: Media conglomerates are searching for new ways to reel in young viewers, and virtual reality is an appealing medium. Read IBD's recent cover story for more: Disney, Comcast Pour Cash In Virtual Reality As The 'Netflix Of VR' Looms.The entertainment giant is spreading its tendrils across the digital universe, most recently adding AT&T's (T) DirecTV service as a streaming partner that will have access to Disney content.So that means that in addition to those two MVPDs (multichannel video programming distributors), Disney has streaming content on Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue and Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV. And let's not forget Hulu -- Disney is a part owner -- which has its own live-streaming service launching in 2017 that will reportedly include ESPN, ABC and Disney Channel, according to the Wall Street Journal.The question now becomes: Is the Mouse spreading its digital content too thin?Anticipating that, Iger tackled the concern during Tuesday's call with analysts: "What will be interesting is, long term, to what extent do we hold back product to put on services that are ours that we're selling direct to consumer vs. third-party distributors, but it's really premature to get into all of that because, right now, we've got kind of a best of all worlds in the sense that we're monetizing really well on multiple platforms from multiple parties."Disney shares rose 1.2% to 97.86 in the stock market today.

Dish Network (DISH) reported second-quarter earnings that topped views but said it had a net loss of 281,000 pay-TV customers, including satellite and the Sling web TV service, marking it biggest quarterly subscriber loss ever.Sales missed Wall Street views, but Dish Network stock reversed course and ended the day up 3.3% to 53.66 on the stock market today, near 50.Dish Network does not break out satellite and Sling services separately. Sling starts at $20 monthly, while satellite TV customers spend more than four times that on average."Dish's dismal Q2 results in their core business suggest that there is less sand in the hourglass, faster than we thought," said Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, in a research report. "Dish combines the core with Sling TV, two fundamentally different businesses."Over the past year, gains at Sling TV have softened the blow of losses in the satellite core. This time, combining the two businesses likely obscures how quickly Sling TV is hitting a wall. By our estimates, Dish added just 49,000 new Sling TV subscribers."Dish Network said it earned 88 cents per share, up 26% from the year-earlier quarter, with revenue about flat at $3.84 billion. Analysts had modeled profit of 73 cents and $3.86 in revenue."Our pay-TV churn (disconnection) rate continues to be adversely affected by increased competitive pressures, including aggressive marketing, bundled discount offers combining broadband, video and wireless services, as well as cord cutting (online video)," Dish Network said in a regulatory filing.The filing went on to say: "As part of our increased emphasis on retaining higher-quality subscribers, we have been more selective in issuing retention credits, which has had a negative impact on our pay-TV churn rate."IBD'S TAKE:  Dish Network's broadband services in rural areas are no match speed-wise for those of cable TV rivals such as Comcast. Analysts expect more broadband gains by Comcast. Dish stock is down more than 10% this year. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Dish Network has amassed a swath of radio spectrum for mobile video services, but it's been unable to partner with Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US (TMUS) or Sprint (S). AT&T (T) acquired Dish archrival and No. 1 satellite TV firm DirecTV Group in 2015.Dish Network, Verizon and T-Mobile are prohibited from engaging in strategic talks until an auction of airwaves owned by local TV broadcasters concludes. It's uncertain when that auction, which began in March, will end.Dish Network had 13.59 million pay-TV subscribers as of June 30, down from 13.93 million a year earlier.

Reports that federal regulators will disallow bidding discounts awarded to Dish Network (DISH) partners in a blockbuster government spectrum auction and that the satellite TV broadcaster's merger talks with T-Mobile (TMUS) are going nowhere sent Dish stock down late in Thursday's regular session. Dish stock had recovered a bit in after-hours trading. Sprint (S) stock, meanwhile, rose in after-hours trading…
Media-focused ETFs sold off briskly Thursday on a slew of lackluster earnings foreshadowed by the Disney (DIS) bust earlier this week.
The latest results confirm the trend of cable customers abandoning pay TV bundles for cheaper Internet streaming services such as Netflix (NFLX).

PowerShares Dynamic Media (PBS) slumped 4.8% to 24.33. The $159.6 million ETF slipped through its 200-day line on the stock market today, with Viacom (VIAB), Gray Television (GTN) and AMC Networks (AMCX) leading the decline.
Viacom, the owner of MTV and Comedy Central, sank 15% on its report today that profits fell as U.S. advertising sales continue to decline.
Disney fell a further 5% Thursday as investors grappled with subscriber losses on its ESPN sports network.
Gray Television, the Atlanta-based TV station owner, tanked 17% after Wednesday's report of higher operating expenses in Q2. It forecast that costs would climb 42% in the current period.
Cable content provider AMC Networks sank 9% despite strong Q2 profits as international revenue took a hit.
Other media earnings Wednesday also weighed on PowerShares media ETF in early afternoon trade.
Satellite TV provider Dish Network (DISH) fell 3% on subscriber losses, Time Warner (TWX) 6% and CBS (CBS) 4%. All three stocks are among the ETF's top 10 holdings.
Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) also fell 11%. PBS does not hold this stock.
Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR (XLY) lagged every other sector SPDR ETF peer Thursday. It allocates almost a quarter of its $11.44 billion in assets to media stocks.

EMQQ Emerging Markets Internet & E-commerce (EMQQ) fell 0.94% to 23. Two of the $11.57 million ETF's top five holdings, Alibaba (BABA) and JD.com (JD), tracked lower midday ahead of upcoming earnings.
JD.com is due to release its earnings report Friday before the market opens. Results from the online retailer are viewed as a gauge of Internet strength in China, the world's second-largest economy.
JD.com is a leading rival of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce leader that reports Aug. 12.
Most major U.S. and international ETFs slipped ahead of a key jobs report Friday. Gold prices gained.
Here's a look at how benchmark exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes are performing today. Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing.

It allocates almost a quarter of its $11.44 billion in assets to media stocks.EMQQ Emerging Markets Internet & E-commerce (EMQQ) fell 0.94% to 23. Two of the $11.57 million ETF's top five holdings, Alibaba (BABA) and JD.com (JD), tracked lower midday ahead of upcoming earnings.JD.com is due to release its earnings report Friday before the market opens. Results from the online retailer are viewed as a gauge of Internet strength in China, the world's second-largest economy.JD.com is a leading rival of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce leader that reports Aug. 12.Most major U.S. and international ETFs slipped ahead of a key jobs report Friday. Gold prices gained.Here's a look at how benchmark exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes are performing today. Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing.10 BELLWETHER ETFS:SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.5%, RS 30IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond  (AGG), +0.2%, RS 54PowerShares DB US$ Bullish  (UUP), -0.1%, RS 75IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.3%, RS 59SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.5%, RS 61SPDR S&P 500  (SPY), -0.6%, RS 68Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), -0.7%, RS 30IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.7%, RS 68IShares Russell 2000  (IWM), -0.9%, RS 68PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -1.4%, RS 78Follow Aparna Narayanan on Twitter: @IBD_ANarayanan.

Viacom's (VIAB) 9% drop in fiscal Q3 U.S. ad revenue due to a decline in ratings added to fears that traditional media and cable firms are losing the battle againstNetflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN). Earlier in the week, Walt Disney (DIS) sparked the media stock sell-off after saying ESPN has lost a "modest" number of subscribers and trimming its guidance…

With Stream, Comcast (CMCSA) hopes to hit upon what young adults, called Millennials, want from a streaming video service provider. Comcast strutted out a new low-priced streaming video service on Monday that rivals will struggle to match, at least in a battle for new customers in areas where Comcast sells high-speed Internet. Comcast stock was up nearly 1% in afternoon…

Not only are young adults more likely to "cut the cord" and give up pay-TV services, they're also more likely to switch among providers of Internet video streaming services, says a BMO Capital Markets report.The report cites data from TV ratings provider Nielsen.Young adults, oft-called called millennials, have been big users of Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com 's (AMZN) video service, and Hulu. Dish Network (DISH) and Sony early in 2015 launched over-the-top (OTT) services — so called because they piggyback landline broadband services sold by other companies. Even if consumers don't buy a traditional pay-TV package, they still need broadband Internet to stream video.Apple (AAPL) is widely expected to launch a new Web TV service. Apple's entry could spur some subscription video-on-demand (SVOD) users to switch, a trend already underway, says Daniel Salmon, a BMO Capital Markets analyst, in his research report."SVOD households generally churn at a higher rate than multi-channel video programming distributor (cable TV) households," Salmon said. "We expect this is in part due to SVOD services' generally non-restrictive cancellation policies."For example, over a three-month period, Nielsen generally finds that 99% of the households in the sample who had cable still have cable. However, 5-7% of people who had SVOD won't have it three months from now."According to Nielsen data, 10% of persons aged 18-34 use only OTT services when they turn on a TV. SVOD users tend to watch less television overall.Among U.S. households, 41% now subscribe to a video streaming service, up from 36% a year earlier, said a Nielsen study released this year. Netflix by far is the most popular streaming video service, with Amazon No.2. Netflix stock recently got a boost when the company announced a 7-for-1 stock split.Another rival is Hulu — owned by 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA). It offers a free option with ads, as well as a paid service.

Internet television services like Netflix (NFLX) are often described as beneficiaries of the cable and satellite TV "cord cutting" trend. But slowing subscriber growth at Netflix has some wondering whether cost-conscious consumers are now "stream cutting."Netflix added just 160,000 net new streaming subscribers in the second quarter, a steep drop from 900,000 in Q2 last year. Netflix blamed higher churn, or the percentage of customers canceling the service, for the shortfall.The churn coincided with press coverage of price hikes for longtime subscribers who had been grandfathered for up to two years at the old prices and were starting to see increases.The higher churn indicated that Netflix customers were more price sensitive than previously thought. Some of the customers who quit had decided that the current price ($9.99 a month for the standard plan) wasn't worth what they were getting. Others, though, might have tired of Netflix's offerings and opted to switch to another streaming service with a different lineup.The nature of subscription video-on-demand services like Netflix, Hulu, HBO Now and others makes it easy to cancel, especially after binge-watching all the shows of interest. Videophiles easily can switch among different over-the-top TV services from their Roku box, smart TV or other device.By comparison, cable companies make it difficult to start and stop their video services. They'll often lock customers into two-year contracts and charge fees for reconnecting service. Then there's the hassle of returning set-top boxes or having to go through the set-up process if you want to start again."Even if you've had Netflix for three to five years, you can drop them for a few months and pick them right back up," Phillip Swann, president and publisher of TVPredictions.com, told IBD. "What's the big deal? It's not like you have to have someone come out and put up a satellite dish or bring you a cable box."Streaming video news website Extreamist suggests Netflix's shrinking library of content was behind the increased churn, not just the price hike. Extreamist reported in June that the size of the Netflix library had fallen 40% over the past four years.That puts pressure on Netflix to continue adding good content, including licensed Hollywood content and original shows, to keep subscribers happy.Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter warned in May that Netflix had fallen behind Amazon (AMZN) Prime Video when it comes to making quality original content. Netflix this year has released a bunch of critical turkeys, such as the comedy series "Fuller House" and Adam Sandler movie "The Do-Over."The higher Netflix churn last quarter was likely a combination of the price hike, reduced content selection and churn from increased streaming competition, Swann said."There's been an explosion of streaming services of various kinds over the last 12 to 18 months that finally had an effect on Netflix," Swann said. "You've got now HBO, Showtime, Starz (STRZA), Seeso, Sling, Sony (SNE) Vue and so on. There are so many internet TV options now that the competition for that audience has grown."Many subscribers might sign up for a streaming video service when it offers a new season of a popular show, such as "Game of Thrones" on Time Warner's (TWX) HBO, "Marvel's Daredevil" on Netflix, and the upcoming "Star Trek: Discovery" on CBS (CBS) All Access. Then, once they're done watching all the episodes, they cancel and move on to another streaming service.Premium cable channels like HBO and Showtime have dealt with this for years, Swann said. People will sign up for big shows and cancel when the season is over, he said."The same thing will happen to Netflix," Swann said. "If you're a 'House of Cards' fan, you might cancel and wait for the new season to premiere."With the growing number of streaming services, churn will be an issue as consumers experiment with different offerings, Brett Sappington, senior director of research for Parks Associates, told IBD.There were 101 subscription streaming video services available in the U.S. market as of March, Parks reported.Beyond major services like Netflix, Hulu and Amazon, there are a host of smaller niche services. They include NBCUniversal's comedy network Seeso, anime video service Crunchyroll and horror movie provider Shudder.At the end of 2015, about 20% of U.S. broadband households had canceled at least one over-the-top video service in the previous 12 months, Parks Associates said. Some 64% of U.S. broadband households subscribe to an OTT video service, the firm said.Netflix shouldn't be too worried about its recent increase in subscriber churn, Sappington said. It holds a commanding lead in subscribers (47 million in the U.S. alone in Q2) and has a solid track record for giving viewers what they want."As over-the-top services mature, their churn rates tend to drop over time," he said. "In fact, Netflix is the longest-running one, and it's got the lowest churn relative to the size of its base of customers among all of the services out there."At the end of last year, 52% of all U.S. broadband households subscribed to Netflix, according to Parks. Some 5% of U.S. broadband households canceled Netflix in 2015, the research firm said.Besides offering popular content and competitive prices, there's not much streaming services can do to reduce churn. The phenomenon of consumers canceling streaming services and hopping to another one could continue for a few years, until the number of services is winnowed down, Swann said.Once the culling has finished, Netflix is almost certain to remain one of the leaders, both Swann and Sappington said.

Walt Disney (DIS)-owned ESPN is said to be in talks with Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and other online distributors to feature its sports content, according to The Street, citing people familiar with the matter.Further specifics weren't provided, and sources told the outlet that an announcement is not necessarily expected from the negotiations.Shares of Disney dipped 0.3% to 99.88 on the stock market today. Amazon, which reported strong Prime Day sales, slid 0.75%. Facebook fell 1%. Facebook once again undercut a 117.09 buy point and closed just above its 50-day line.For the last year, the sports cable network and Disney moneymaker has faced scrutiny over worries about viewer migration away from traditional cable packages, particularly as services like Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon Prime Video have gained steam.That has put Disney on the defensive -- and ESPN subscriber figures under the microscope. The media conglomerate has been exploring new platform providers for ESPN, and CEO Bob Iger said earlier in the year that Disney has seen positive signs from ESPN's inclusion in over-the-top bundles from Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE) PlayStation. Both platforms contributed "incremental" subscribers for ESPN in Q2, he said in May.IBD'S TAKE: Walt Disney stock has been in a downtrend. Not coincidentally, so has earnings growth. Investors should turn the dial over to CBS, which has accelerating earnings and is trading just below a 57.99 buy point. For a detailed analysis of CBS, see IBD Stock Checkup.And Hulu, the over-the-top programmer jointly owned by Disney, Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal and 21st Century Fox (FOXA), said in May that it is preparing a live-TV package that will feature live sports and news among its broadcast and cable channels. The service, which launches next year, is said to include ESPN and other Disney channels.RELATED:Disney Treasures This Netflix Rival, While ESPN Bleeding Slows

Internet television network Netflix (NFLX) received its second stock downgrade in as many days on Wednesday.Investment bank Jefferies lowered its rating on Netflix stock to underperform from hold and cut its price target to 80 from 120, as analyst John Janedis assumed coverage of the company.On Tuesday, Needham downgraded Netflix stock to hold from buy.Netflix stock ended trading down 3.4% to 94.60 on the stock market today."Although Netflix's runway will span multiple years, our research suggests the domestic subscriber growth trajectory may be somewhat flatter than the market's current expectations," Janedis said in a research report. "While international will remain strong, we think the slowing U.S. market will pressure the stock's multiple."Netflix is seeing more competition in the U.S. streaming market from the likes of Amazon.com (AMZN) and Hulu, compared to what it's seen in years past, Janedis said. Also, U.S. content owners are being more selective in licensing content to Netflix, he said."The landscape will be much more competitive over the next 5-plus years," Janedis said.Netflix management has guided to a long-term target of 60 million to 90 million U.S. subscribers. It said it ended Q1 with 47 million U.S. subscribers."Given (Netflix's) existing penetration rate, and the threat of building competition, we expect growth to moderate going forward," he said. Janedis predicts Netflix will have 58.3 million paying U.S. subscribers in 2020.Netflix's international growth opportunity is large, but it will be more challenging than expected in the near term, Janedis said."Key challenges include a limited amount of local content, language barriers, an expensive price point in certain markets and underdeveloped payment processing and broadband infrastructure," he said. Janedis predicts Netflix will have 91.3 million paying international subscribers in 2020, vs. 32 million in Q1 2016.Meanwhile, Netflix received favorable reports from Oppenheimer and Pacific Crest Securities for its deal with Comcast (CMCSA), reported Tuesday. Comcast, the nation's No. 1 pay-TV operator, will soon offer direct access to Netflix through its broadband-based X1 set-top box.Comcast would offer Netflix through its "triple play" digital media platform, Oppenheimer analyst Jason Helfstein said in a report."This demonstrates that the largest U.S. MSO (multiple system operator) has decided that Netflix will be a permanent media offering, and Comcast can benefit from a partnership in several ways," he said.First, since Netflix subscribers are heavy data users, Comcast can aggressively price its broadband data packages. Second, the integration of Netflix with the cable TV interface reduces the risk of cord-cutting. Third, Comcast likely will receive a bounty for new subscribers who sign up through its platform, Helfstein said.Helfstein rates Netflix stock as outperform.Pacific Crest analyst Andy Hargreaves called the Comcast-Netflix deal a "win-win.""For Netflix, this should reduce consumer friction and help support higher usage and subscriber levels," Hargreaves said in a report. "For Comcast, the deal should improve its competitive position vs. virtual (multichannel video programming distributors like Sling TV from Dish Network (DISH)) and benefit demand for higher broadband tiers."Hargreaves rates Netflix as overweight with a price target of 130. The firm rates Comcast as overweight with a price target of 65.Comcast stock was up a fraction, to 65.10, at the close Wednesday.

AT&T (T) stock slipped Friday after the telecom conglomerate late Thursday reported in-line Q2 earnings but light revenue, as it again lost wireless "postpaid" phone users and U-verse video subscribers despite growth at its satellite broadcaster DirecTV.On their earnings conference call with analysts, AT&T executives touted plans to take on Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com (AMZN), Hulu, Dish Network (DISH) and others with a web TV offering, using DirecTV's programming.AT&T said Q2 adjusted earnings rose 3% to 72 cents per share, meeting estimates, while revenue rose 23%, including DirecTV, to $40.5 billion. Analysts had modeled revenue of $40.64 billion.AT&T said it shed 160,000 postpaid phone users, marking the sixth straight quarter of postpaid phone losses. Postpaid users have contracts and are more lucrative than pay-as-you-go prepaid users."Results were again in line with expectations, though AT&T continues to lose postpaid phone customers and offset DTV additions with U-verse losses," Michael Bowen, a Pacific Crest Securities analyst said in a research report.AT&T shares rose 1.4% to 43.11 in the stock market today. The stock has been consolidating since reaching 43.89 on July 7, the highest since October 2001.IBD'S TAKE: Shares of AT&T and Verizon Communications jumped in the first half of 2016 as investors flocked to dividend-paying stocks amid falling global interest rates. AT&T has been a member of the IBD Big Cap 20 list of large-cap growth stocks that investors might want to consider.DirecTV added 343,000 video subscribers, but U-verse shrank by 391,000, resulting in a net loss of 49,000 video subscribers.John Stephens, AT&T's chief financial officer, on the call touted  plans to roll out a streaming-TV subscription offering, branded DirecTV Now, by year-end .AT&T aims to reverse wireless postpaid subscriber losses with an over-the-top (OTT) video offering, as well as offset continued subscriber losses in its landline, U-verse-branded TV service.Analysts seem upbeat on AT&T's plans."Management spoke very highly of the much-awaited, Q4 OTT video product release, which is in line with our own bullish view," said Colby Synesael, an analyst at Cowen & Co., in a report."AT&T expects DTV Now to have very similar channel choices to what is currently offered on the traditional DTV platform," said Mike McCormack, an analyst at Jefferies. "This could be the most compelling OTT offer in the market."Jennifer Fritzsche, analyst at Wells Fargo, says stakes are big. AT&T acquired DirecTV for $49 billion in 2015."We believe Q4 2016 will be the 'rubber meets the road' quarter, as we gauge the customer acceptance of the new over-the-top (OTT) plans," Fritzsche said.

MoffettNathanson downgraded Dish Network (DISH) stock on views that neither AT&T (T) nor Verizon Communications (VZ) will buy Dish's radio spectrum at a hypothetical price tag of $30 billion, and that Dish's prospects for a merger with T-Mobile US (TMUS) have dwindled.While cash-rich Apple (AAPL), Alphabet (GOOGL) or Amazon.com (AMZN) have the money to acquire Dish Networks' spectrum, they will not make an offer, says analyst Craig Moffett, who downgraded the satellite TV broadcaster to sell, with a price target of 40. He says "downward pressure on Dish shares will mount" as investors realize an asset sale is a long shot."We suspect that Dish's exit options are more tightly constrained than many believe," said Moffett in a research report. "The option to buy their way out of their spectrum position by using their equity as currency (or acquire another company such as T-Mobile) may already be gone."What is left is an outright sale -- leasing the spectrum to a suitor would be accounted for as a sale for balance sheet purposes, so it's a distinction without a difference. Dish's suitors (AT&T and Verizon) simply don't have the strong balance sheets many believe them to have."Dish Network stock closed up 1.5% at 50.33 in the stock market today.The pay-TV company has amassed some 77 MHz of radio spectrum, spending some $15 billion in the process, but it lacks a wireless partner to deliver mobile video services over that spectrum.AT&T, Verizon and T-Mobile US have filed as bidders in a federal auction of airwaves now owned by local TV broadcasters. The auction, begun in late March, might drag on until Q4.Verizon and AT&T are also considered among the most likely buyers of Yahoo's (YHOO) core internet and advertising business. Yahoo's final round of bidding is expected to end in July.Moffett left open the possibility that Dish Network could forge a long-term spectrum leasing deal with AT&T, Verizon or T-Mobile, though he said there are financial hurdles under that scenario as well.

Verizon (VZ) and Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI) have struck a multi-year deal to stream Food Network, HGTV and other programming to Verizon Wireless users. The "mobile first video" content licensing agreement includes over 45 lifestyle shows, such as Food Network's "Cutthroat Kitchen," HGTV's "House Hunters" and Travel Channel's "Bizarre Foods," the company said. Wingstop on Friday joined the menu of fast-casual restaurants that have turned in a finger-licking first-day performance with their initial public offerings. Stock in the purveyor of chicken wings, fries and sides priced at 19 late Thursday, above the high end of its range, and closed Friday at 30.59, up 61%. It raised $110 million in proceeds. Wingstop (WING) was…

Verizon Communications' wireless and landline businesses showed weakness in Q2, sending the telecom firm's stock down 2.4% Tuesday. Verizon (VZ) also lowered its full-year consolidated revenue forecast to 3% growth from its earlier guidance of 4%, amid intensified wireless competition with AT&T (T), T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S).

A wireless price war has taken a toll industrywide on average monthly revenue per account, or ARPA, a closely watched financial metric. Verizon's postpaid ARPA, for customers billed monthly, fell 3.8% in Q2 to $153.73.
Verizon has doubled down on wireless services — it bought out Vodafone's 45% stake in their U.S. joint venture, Verizon Wireless, in early 2014 for $130 billion — while selling off landline assets.

Rival AT&T last year agreed to buy satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group (DTV) and recently expanded into Mexico. The regulatory review of the deal has lagged, but the Wall Street Journal reported late Tuesday that approval is imminent.

"AT&T has become the consensus favorite of the large-cap telecoms," said Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, in a report. Investors seem to believe that Verizon's decline is still accelerating while AT&T's is still slowing, added Moffett, who rates Verizon stock neutral.
AT&T stock fell 1% Tuesday.
'Strategic Asset'

Verizon in February agreed to sell wireline assets in California, Florida and Texas to Frontier Communications (FTR) for $10.5 billion. If that deal closes in the first half of next year, wireless will represent nearly three-fourths of Verizon's projected 2016 revenue and more than 80% of EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization), says UBS.
On Verizon's Q2 earnings conference call with analysts Tuesday, CFO Fran Shammo downplayed speculation Verizon could sell off its FiOS business and more East Coast residential, landline assets.

"We have an incredible footprint that stretches from Washington, D.C., up through Boston. The broadband connection to those homes along with our wireless product and the population of that segment is critical to us and it is a strategic asset for us," he said.

"I'm not saying that if someone didn't come in and take a look at the assets — as we've always said — we're open to anything," Shammo added. "But right now strategically we are very satisfied with the asset portfolio we have."
Verizon has stated it's not interested in buying satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) outright, though some analysts say a wireless partnership may be do-able.

Verizon's full control of the wireless business, meanwhile, means it doesn't have to defer to Vodafone on strategic decisions, such as acquiring radio spectrum. Verizon in June acquired AOL for $4.4 billion, giving it a digital advertising platform.

Shammo on Tuesday said Verizon plans to launch a mobile video service by "late" summer, pushing back the time frame a bit. It's unclear how much a lift Verizon's wireless business will get from that service .
Verizon completed its $4.4 billion acquisition of Web portal AOL last month, looking to boost its mobile and ad platforms.

Verizon said Q2 earnings per share rose 14% from the year-earlier quarter to $1.04, topping views. Revenue rose 2.4% to $32.2 billion, slightly below expectations. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had modeled EPS of $1.01 on revenue of $32.45 billion.
Subscriber Shortfall

Verizon said it added 26,000 FiOS TV customers and 72,000 broadband subscribers in the June quarter, far below estimates. Analysts had expected 89,000 FiOS TV subscriber additions and 123,000 FiOS broadband adds.

Wireless revenue rose 5% to $22.6 billion, while wireless service revenue, which excludes mobile phone sales, fell 2% to $17.69 billion. Wireless margins rose to 43.9% from 42.3% in Q2 2014, but fell from 44.8% in Q1 2015.
Shammo played down expectations for wireless customers upgrading their devices after Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 6S is released, likely in September.

"I just don't see that the next iconic device is going to be substantially different and therefore, I don't see — and this is just me speaking — I don't (expect) the volume there in the fourth quarter (of 2015) that we had last year from a total iconic change of the 6 and the 6 Plus," he said.Verizon Communications' wireless and landline businesses showed weakness in Q2, sending the telecom firm's stock down 2.4% Tuesday. Verizon (VZ) also lowered its full-year consolidated revenue forecast to 3% growth from its earlier guidance of 4%, amid intensified wireless competition with AT&T (T), T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S).A wireless price war has taken a toll industrywide on average monthly revenue per account, or ARPA, a closely watched financial metric. Verizon's postpaid ARPA, for customers billed monthly, fell 3.8% in Q2 to $153.73.Verizon has doubled down on wireless services — it bought out Vodafone's 45% stake in their U.S. joint venture, Verizon Wireless, in early 2014 for $130 billion — while selling off landline assets.Rival AT&T last year agreed to buy satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group (DTV) and recently expanded into Mexico. The regulatory review of the deal has lagged, but the Wall Street Journal reported late Tuesday that approval is imminent."AT&T has become the consensus favorite of the large-cap telecoms," said Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, in a report. Investors seem to believe that Verizon's decline is still accelerating while AT&T's is still slowing, added Moffett, who rates Verizon stock neutral.AT&T stock fell 1% Tuesday.'Strategic Asset'Verizon in February agreed to sell wireline assets in California, Florida and Texas to Frontier Communications (FTR) for $10.5 billion. The broadband connection to those homes along with our wireless product and the population of that segment is critical to us and it is a strategic asset for us," he said."I'm not saying that if someone didn't come in and take a look at the assets — as we've always said — we're open to anything," Shammo added. "But right now strategically we are very satisfied with the asset portfolio we have."Verizon has stated it's not interested in buying satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) outright, though some analysts say a wireless partnership may be do-able.Verizon's full control of the wireless business, meanwhile, means it doesn't have to defer to Vodafone on strategic decisions, such as acquiring radio spectrum.
