Wireless margins rose to 43.9% from 42.3% in Q2 2014, but fell from 44.8% in Q1 2015.Shammo played down expectations for wireless customers upgrading their devices after Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 6S is released, likely in September."I just don't see that the next iconic device is going to be substantially different and therefore, I don't see — and this is just me speaking — I don't (expect) the volume there in the fourth quarter (of 2015) that we had last year from a total iconic change of the 6 and the 6 Plus," he said.

Federal regulators on Thursday proposed a cap on discounts given to small businesses when the government auctions off radio spectrum, in the wake of a review into Dish Network's (DISH) bidding practices with two partners in the recent AWS-3 auction.Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, also proposed placing limits on bidding partnerships that can be formed during auctions.The FCC is reviewing whether to award Dish Network spectrum it won in the AWS-3 auction along with two bidding agents, Northstar Wireless and SNR Wireless. That airwaves auction ended in late January. Northstar and SNR spent $13.3 billion in the auction but received a 25% discount, lowering their bill to about $10 billion.AT&T (T) spent $18.2 billion in AWS-3, the most of any company, while Verizon Communications (VZ) spent $10.4 billion.The FCC on Thursday made no comment on the ongoing review of Dish Network.Wheeler said the proposed rules are aimed at preventing big companies from tapping a discount program intended for small businesses. The FCC plans another big spectrum auction in 2016 involving airwaves now owned by TV broadcasters.Wheeler's proposal would cap the discount for small businesses at $150 million and for rural service providers at $10 million for the 2016 auction.The FCC may vote on the proposal at its July 16 meeting.The Department of Justice, meanwhile, has sent the FCC a letter that could help T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S) in the upcoming Broadcast Incentive Auction, says a report by Re/code.T-Mobile US, controlled by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), and Sprint, majority owned by Japan's SoftBank, are pushing the FCC to set aside more spectrum for smaller wireless firms in the Broadcast Incentive Auction.The FCC has reserved for smaller firms 30 MHz of the expected 70-80 MHz of airwaves expected to be auctioned, but T-Mobile and Sprint are seeking 40 MHz.The FCC has been leaning against reserving more spectrum. TV broadcasters, who would sell spectrum in the auction, have voiced concern that bidding revenue would be lower if rules prevent AT&T and Verizon Communications from obtaining a large chunk of the airwaves, as IBD reported.

ESPN parent company Walt Disney (DIS) has agreed to purchase one-third of Major League Baseball's digital business and take a four-year option to increase its stake to two-thirds, sources told Bloomberg.The reported deal would provide the media giant with access to an online streaming platform at a time when Netflix (NFLX), Hulu and other web-based programming have eroded its subscriber base.MLB Advanced Media, which handles online services from digital ticketing to sponsorships to live streams, says on its website that it distributes "25,000 live events annually and 10 million streams daily," and that it has the resources to support "millions of multi-platform subscribers and processes." Paid streaming subscription services like MLB.tv and the WWE Network are MLB Advanced Media partners.The transaction with Disney is said to value the MLB company at $3.5 billion or so.Disney CEO Bob Iger has frequently been put on the defensive in recent quarterly earnings calls since last year's media market maelstrom, spurred by concern over the health of the pay-TV environment.But Disney, which also owns Marvel, Lucasfilm and the TV network ABC, appears to be exploring its online options.In the company's May earnings call, Iger told listeners that streaming service Hulu -- which it jointly owns with 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal -- was an "important investment" and that Hulu's newly announced live-TV package was a "best of cable approach" between a skinny bundle and mega-cable package.ESPN has been bleeding subscribers, but its inclusion in streaming bundles -- such as Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV and others -- could be linked to some "very encouraging sign-ups," Iger said in May. Prior to that, he alluded in February to partnering ESPN with "new platform providers."Disney shares were up 0.2% on the stock market today. Netflix shares surged 5.7% on bullish analyst comments. Fox added 0.8%, and Comcast edged up 0.1%.

Telecom stocks have flexed their muscles this year, so it would seem natural that companies that support them would also show some strength. That's the case with CSG Systems (CSGS), which is an outsourcer for the telecom companies, such as Verizon (VZ) and AT&T (T). It also provides services to cable companies like Time Warner and Comcast (CMCSA); satellite providers,…

Mergers and acquisitions involving wireless phone companies and the likes of Dish Network (DISH) and Comcast (CMCSA) could be on hold longer than expected, as the government auction of radio spectrum now owned by local TV broadcasters drags on.The Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday disclosed first-stage results of the complex, so-called "broadcast incentive"  TV auction. In the first stage of the auction, TV broadcasters agreed to give up spectrum in local markets, such as New York or Chicago, at set prices.While the FCC said that some 126 megahertz of spectrum will be available in the next stage of the auction, that's more airwaves than bidders are prepared to buy, analysts say. The proposed value of the 126 MHz of spectrum is $86.4 billion, based on prices for airwaves in local markets. TV broadcasters are seeking market valuations much higher than expected, at least according to Wall Street analysts that follow phone and cable companies.AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US (TMUS) and cable TV leader Comcast have been among expected bidders. Upfront deposits are due Friday.Some analysts, however, say wireless firms might be interested in bidding on only 70 MHz to 80 MHz of spectrum, which would lower auction proceeds. If not enough bidders show up for the 126 MHz of spectrum, the FCC would lower the amount of airwaves available in follow-on rounds. The spectrum to be sold would be reduced from 126 MHz to 114 MHz at the next stage, and to 108 MHz, 84 MHz, 78 MHz, 72 MHz and 60 MHz in follow-on bidding rounds.The process could drag into 2017, some analysts speculate. The FCC has imposed a quiet period on bidders, banning strategic talks among them until the auction is over.TV broadcasters could walk away at any point if spectrum demand is too low or if bid prices don't meet their expectations. Wireless firms or Comcast, on the other hand, might not be able to cobble together enough national spectrum to meet their strategic needs.If the auction falls apart, Dish Network would be in a better position to sell its spectrum or form a partnership with a wireless firm such as Verizon, analysts say."Wednesday's news suggest multiple stages, a protracted timeline and greater likelihood of a failed auction," UBS analyst John Hodulik said in a research report. "Less spectrum in the wireless market would put upward pressure on spectrum valuation, a positive for holders such as Dish and Ligado Networks. Multiple stages will also prolong the quiet period and dampen any near-term strategic activity across the space."Citigroup analyst Michael Rollins said in a research report that "with the auction potentially going through multiple stages, it could last longer than the FCC's hoped-for 3Q/16 completion. If that were to happen, it would lengthen the time in which strategic discussions between bidders would be largely prohibited under the anti-collusion rules attached to the auction."While registered bidders could get held up longer from strategic pursuits within the wireless category during an extended auction period, we believe the likelihood for less spectrum to be licensed at this band at better valuations could be positive for other holders of spectrum, including Dish."Some auction estimates were as high as $60 billion in mid-2015, though most analysts have forecast spending in a range of $35 billion to $43 billion. But a different government spectrum auction that ended in early 2015 blew past estimates.Shares of Dish Network rose 0.9% to 52.40 on the stock market today. Comcast climbed 1.9% to 65.12, rising to a new high, clearing a consolidation going back to July 2015. AT&T advanced 1.6% to 43.21, further extended from an early June breakout. Verizon grew 1.4% to 55.84, a new high but still in buying range. T-Mobile US fell 0.4%.

Comcast (CMCSA) stock Monday touched an all-time high for the fifth day in the past seven trading days, as an Oppenheimer analyst called the cable-TV and media company the "most attractive" large-cap telecom stock for the rest of 2016.Shares of Comcast, which owns NBCUniversal, rose 0.45% to 67.41 in the stock market today. The benchmark S&P 500 index also hit an all-time high Monday.Comcast stock is up 19% in 2016, and the run isn't over, said Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan in a research report."We believe Comcast shares offer attractive upside despite the strong performance year to date," said Horan, Oppenheimer's telecom analyst.While Comcast's dividend yield is lower than AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ), the cable TV firm's stock rise comes amid falling interest rates globally, which has helped steady dividend-paying stocks.As of March 31, Comcast had $8.8 billion available under its share repurchase authorization. In Q1, Comcast paid $611 million in dividends and repurchased $1.2 billion of its own stock.Comcast is scheduled to report Q2 earnings on July 27.AT&T stock has jumped 23% in 2016, while Verizon stock is up 20%. AT&T fell 0.2% to 42.51 on Monday. Verizon rose 2 cents to 55.92, still in buy range.Comcast's rise comes despite regulatory headwinds. The Obama administration has been tough on cable-TV firms and internet service providers. Federal regulators thwarted Comcast's takeover of Time Warner Cable in 2015.Horan says "reduced marketing spending" by Dish Network (DISH), AT&T and Verizon is a plus for Comcast."Cable's favorable competitive position in broadband, improving competitive position in video, and a hedge on inflation costs with NBC all offer catalysts for earnings growth," said Horan.

Verizon Communications (VZ) and wireless rival AT&T (T) showed resilience during the Brexit sell-off and have moved higher in the market rebound that followed. AT&T and Verizon rank No. 1 and 2, respectively, within the integrated telecom services group, followed by 8x8 (EGHT), Consol Communications (CNSL) and IDT Corp. (IDT). After completing its $4.4 billion purchase of AOL last year, Verizon is among the…

Did Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) add more sizzle than expected during the second quarter? Investors will find out Tuesday after the stock market closes when the trendy burrito chain reports the quarter's results. The company's business has stayed strong with double-digit profit growth in all but one of the past 18 quarters. Analysts are betting that Chipotle is poised to…

SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son is taking a more active role at Sprint, which could help the struggling wireless phone company get back on track, says Macquarie Capital. Sprint CEO Marcelo Claure last month outlined a massive network upgrade aimed at making Sprint's service coverage No. 1 or No. 2 in major U.S. markets. It's unclear how Sprint will fund the…

Apple's  (AAPL) decision to stop selling subsidized iPhones with two-year AT&T (T) contracts puts the exclamation mark on the industry's shift to installment payment plans for smartphones, says Morgan Stanley, which expects that trend to continue to pressure industry revenue growth. Amazon.com (AMZN) has gained ground on Netflix (NFLX) in prime-time video streaming, while usage of Facebook (FB)-owned Instagram on mobile networks is booming, says Sandvine's new internet report.Facebook disclosed on Tuesday that Instagram, its photo- and video-sharing service, has grown to 500 million monthly active users, up from 400 million in September. Instagram's popularity is reflected in Sandvine's report on fixed-line and mobile data traffic released today.Instagram accounted for 6.7% of mobile data traffic in North America as of March 2016, up from 4.4% a year earlier -- behind Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned YouTube's nearly 21% and Facebook's 14%.Facebook -- along with Instagram and its WhatsApp messaging service, all combined -- topped Alphabet's YouTube with over 22% of mobile traffic.Privately-held Snapchat ranks fourth in mobile, at 5.2%, with Netflix at 3.7%, down a bit from a year earlier. Netflix's long-form content is less geared for mobile.Netflix's share of fixed-line data traffic slipped to 35.2% from 37% a year earlier, a decline that Sandvine, a broadband networking gear maker, attributes to the use of more efficient video transmission. YouTube ranked No. 2 at 17.5%.While Sandvine says Netflix usage has probably not peaked, rivals are gaining. Amazon's video streaming service accounted for 4.3% of fixed-line data traffic in March, doubling from a year earlier and overtaking Apple.Apple's iTunes store had 2.9% of streaming traffic while Hulu came in at 2.7%. Hulu is a joint venture of 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA).Sling TV, a Web-only TV service launched by satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), accounted for less than 1% of peak downstream traffic.Amazon shares fell 0.7% on the stock market today. Netflix lost 1.1%. Facebook and Apple retreated 0.4%.

Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) head Warren Buffett, Facebook (FB) COO Sheryl Sandberg and Alphabet (GOOGL) Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt were among the dozens of business leaders announcing Thursday their endorsement for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton."Trump would destroy much of what is great about America," said Netflix (NFLX) CEO Reed Hastings in a statement released by the Clinton camp that includes the full list of endorsements. "Hillary Clinton is the strong leader we need, and it's important that Trump lose by a landslide to reject what he stands for."Also on the list are Delta Air Lines (DAL) Executive Chairman Richard Anderson, Salesforce (CRM) CEO Marc Benioff, Sunrun (RUN) CEO Lynn Jurich and Qualcomm (QCOM) Executive Chairman Paul Jacobs.Some are switching party allegiances to vote for Clinton, including General Motors' (GM) former chairman and CEO Dan Akerson and AT&T (T) Services senior executive vice president Jim Cicconi."Serving as the leader of the free world requires effective leadership, sound judgment, a steady hand and most importantly, the temperament to deal with crises large and small," said Akerson in the statement, who has "consistently" voted for Republicans for president. "Donald Trump lacks each of these characteristics. Hillary Clinton has the experience and judgment to serve as an effective commander in chief. In this election, I will cast my ballot for Secretary Clinton."Meanwhile, Continental Resources (CLR) CEO Harold Hamm, Home Depot (HD) co-founder Bernard Marcus and Facebook board member and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel are among those in the business world supporting Donald Trump's run for presidency.The full list of those announcing Clinton endorsements, as published on her campaign site, is as follows:

Netflix (NFLX) could sway Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) into making a Netflix app available on set-top boxes by cutting a deal similar to what it has with Apple (AAPL), says Morgan Stanley.Apple garners a 30% commission on any digital purchases made from apps listed in its iOS app store. Netflix last year enabled in-app subscriptions for iOS users for the first time.“We think Charter, and perhaps even Comcast, could move to integrate Netflix into their video offerings,” Benjamin Swinburne, a Morgan Stanley analyst, wrote in a research report.He said there’s upside for Netflix if it can add “older demographics,” which he called a “key area where it remains under-penetrated.”While Comcast and Charter have been holdouts, Swinburne pointed out that Dish Network (DISH), Suddenlink, Cablevision Systems (CVC) and Verizon Communications (VZ) offer Netflix or Hulu apps.“We would expect Netflix to give up some economics, similar to other distribution partners like Apple or TiVo (TIVO), but we do not believe it would meaningfully alter the direction of Netflix profits over time,” Swinburne said. “Payments to distribution partners are reported in marketing expenses on Netflix's consolidated financials.”The Morgan Stanley analyst, though, says the cable TV firms might see a reduction in pay-per-view movie revenue if they integrate Netflix content into set-top boxes.Netflix stock, down about 12% in 2016, closed up 1.15% in the stock market today. Morgan Stanley maintained its overweight rating on the stock.Shares of Comcast and Charter lost 0.2% and 1.45%, respectively on Monday. Charter recently acquired Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks, becoming the No. 2 cable TV firm behind Comcast.

Despite a German media report that Comcast (CMCSA) is in talks with Deutsche Telekom to acquire U.S.-based T-Mobile (TMUS), a source close to Comcast says the cable TV firm isn't interested. "Comcast is not interested in T-Mobile," the industry source told IBD. Comcast has touted its plans to expand public Wi-Fi networks. Comcast also has the option of leasing wholesale…

The Federal Communications Commission next week aims to take a big step toward making a wireless spectrum auction happen in the first half of 2016, though TV broadcasters continue to make noise over proposed rules. The agency on July 16 aims to vote on a complex structure for the "Broadcast Incentive Auction." AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US and…
The flirtation between wireless carrier T-Mobile US (TMUS) and satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) has reportedly blossomed into merger talks, sending both stocks rising.
The merger would create a stronger competitor to AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Sprint (S).
T-Mobile CEO John Legere would lead the combined company, the Wall Street Journal said. Dish Network CEO Charlie Ergen would be chairman. Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY) controls T-Mobile.

"Deutsche Telekom holds the keys to T-Mobile and there are no guarantees that minority DT shareholders will be happy with the price in what is likely to be a mostly-stock deal with a 12- to 15-month regulatory review, with some spectrum divestitures required," said Kevin Smithen, an analyst at Macquarie Capital, in a research note.
Ergen and T-Mobile executives have exchanged favorable comments about each other in recent months.
The merger would give T-Mobile wireless spectrum it needs in major U.S. markets, while Dish Network would be able to offer an Internet-based TV service to mobile phone users.
Verizon is expected to soon launch an over-the-top (OTT) mobile video service.
Lots Of Deals Pending

Telecom M&A speculation continues, with Citigroup on Wednesday saying France-based Altice could buy Verizon's local, residential wireline business, including its FiOS TV and Internet business. Altice recently acquired a 70% stake in U.S. No. 7 cable firm Suddenlink Communications for $7.9 billion.
And in late May, Charter Communications (CHTR) agreed to buy Time Warner Cable (TWC) in a $56 billion deal.
Federal regulators would likely approve a Dish Network merger with T-Mobile, analysts say. The Federal Communications Commission in 2014 signaled its opposition to a Sprint merger with T-Mobile.
Comcast (CMCSA) terminated its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable in April amid reports that the FCC and Department of Justice might block that deal.
AT&T's proposed merger with satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group (DTV) is expected to get a green light this month or next.
Verizon has said it's not interested in acquiring Dish Network outright, though some analysts have speculated that Verizon and Dish will form a partnership involving radio spectrum.
The public flirtation between T-Mobile and Dish Network has fueled merger speculation. Dish Network has cobbled together an average of 80 MHz in major U.S. markets, more than T-Mobile.
Ergen on Dish's Q1 earnings call said T-Mobile remains a potential partner.
"We're keeping all our options open, and we admire what (CEO John Legere) and his team have done with T-Mobile," Ergen said at the time.
T-Mobile's aggressive Uncarrier promotions, which started with installment payment plans for mobile phones, spurred subscriber growth in 2013 and 2014.
At a financial conference in late February, Legere said: "Dish and we, that makes some sense." T-Mobile CFO Braxton Carter echoed Legere's remark a week later.

Dish Network stock was up 6% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 75. T-Mobile stock was up nearly 5%, at a more than seven-year high above 40. Verizon stock was down nearly 2% in morning trading Thursday.
Mike McCormack, analyst at Jefferies, says much remains uncertain about the talks.

"The deal structure remains in question. A partnership scenario is also possible," said McCormack in a report. "While financially possible under numerous scenarios, particularly with spectrum divestitures, we question the strategy for DISH, given the new business opportunities offered by the transaction would have to trump the potential return from a eventual sale of the spectrum."The flirtation between wireless carrier T-Mobile US (TMUS) and satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) has reportedly blossomed into merger talks, sending both stocks rising.The merger would create a stronger competitor to AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Sprint (S).T-Mobile CEO John Legere would lead the combined company, the Wall Street Journal said. Rising interest rates normally pose issues for telecom stocks, but Verizon Communications (VZ) might see upside if rising rates reduces its pension liabilities, helping enable a sale of its residential wireline FiOS business.

Analysts have been speculating over a Verizon sale of its residential wireline business. The company has focused on wireless services since buying out Vodafone's (VOD) 45% stake in their Verizon Wireless joint venture for $130 billion last year.

With their high dividend yields, AT&T's (T) stock and that of Verizon have been bolstered since the 2008 global financial crisis by the low interest rates. With the U.S. economy gaining traction, mortgage and other long-term rates have begun rising in anticipation of a Federal Reserve rate increase.
Goldman Sachs downgraded telecom stocks last week, even though the sector's 4.9% dividend yield, the highest in the S&P 500, "remains attractive to income-starved investors."
"Rising rates remain the key risk, as Fed hikes will push back on the performance of high dividend yielding stocks," said Goldman Sachs.
Morgan Stanley, too, is underweight the telecom sector.
There might be upside for Verizon, though, amid speculation it is looking to sell its FiOS Internet and TV business as well as its copper wireline network serving residential customers.
Reduction In Liabilities Seen
Barclays analyst Amir Rozwadowski, in a recent research report, said pension liabilities that a buyer would assume pose a hurdle to a Verizon sale.
But Citigroup analyst Michael Rollins, in a June 11 report, says rising rates could come to the rescue.

"We believe Verizon is open to further monetizing its wireline assets if valuations were favorable, but the ongoing liabilities from pension and post-retirement benefits remain significant hurdles to clear, especially within its Northeast wireline footprint," wrote Rollins. "A higher rate environment could reduce the present value of the liabilities and improve the prospects for further monetization."
Pension liabilities would be reduced by rising rates, agrees Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson.
"The future liability is calculated in today's dollars using a discount rate. Higher rates allow for a higher discount rate and therefore a smaller liability," Moffett said.

Some observes have speculated that French telecom firm Altice will buy Verizon's local, residential wireline business, though the fact that Verizon provides telecom service to government agencies might pose national security issues.

Verizon in February agreed to sell wireline assets to Frontier Communications (FTR) for $10.54 billion in cash. That deal includes Verizon's local wireline operations in California, Florida and Texas.

In wireless, Verizon is dealing with much stiffer competition from T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S). Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) reportedly is mulling an acquisition or partnership with T-Mobile.

Verizon stock was down a fraction in early trading in the stock market today.Rising interest rates normally pose issues for telecom stocks, but Verizon Communications (VZ) might see upside if rising rates reduces its pension liabilities, helping enable a sale of its residential wireline FiOS business.Analysts have been speculating over a Verizon sale of its residential wireline business. Higher rates allow for a higher discount rate and therefore a smaller liability," Moffett said.Some observes have speculated that French telecom firm Altice will buy Verizon's local, residential wireline business, though the fact that Verizon provides telecom service to government agencies might pose national security issues.Verizon in February agreed to sell wireline assets to Frontier Communications (FTR) for $10.54 billion in cash. That deal includes Verizon's local wireline operations in California, Florida and Texas.In wireless, Verizon is dealing with much stiffer competition from T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S). Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) reportedly is mulling an acquisition or partnership with T-Mobile.Verizon stock was down a fraction in early trading in the stock market today.
Verizon Communications (VZ) looms as a buyer if Sprint (S) sells some of its radio spectrum to raise cash for a network upgrade that it badly needs to stay competitive in the U.S. wireless market.

"For a company that we expect to burn through another $4.5 billion in cash this calendar year, selling some 2.5 GHz spectrum would certainly provide some level of near-term relief," said Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, in a blog post.
Verizon and cable TV companies loom as possible buyers of a chunk of Sprint's spectrum, most of which is in the high frequency of 2.5 gigahertz, says Moffett.
Sprint obtained a 120 MHz swath of airwaves in the 2.5 GHz spectrum band through its 2013 acquisition of Clearwire. Sprint outbid Dish Network (DISH) for Clearwire.

Wireless networks in higher-frequency bands require more expensive network gear as well as more radio antennas, which is one reason why Sprint might part with some of its airwaves. Sprint needs more low-band spectrum.

Moffett doesn't spell out who the most likely buyer of Sprint spectrum might be. Based on its track record, it could be Verizon. Clearwire in 2013 disclosed that Verizon had offered to buy some of its spectrum for $1.5 billion. Verizon made an offer for long-term spectrum leases and would have deducted lease payments that Clearwire owed from the purchase price.

Barclays analyst Amir Rozwadowski in a report last week noted that Verizon could still be interested in some of Sprint's spectrum. But Rozwadowski noted that Sprint would need to provide assurances on the structure of the leases so that Verizon would have "visibility on its ability to invest in the spectrum."

Clearly, Verizon will need spectrum if data demand continues growing at a 50%-plus rate annually, says JPMorgan analyst Philip Cusick, who last week downgraded Verizon stock to neutral. He noted that Verizon has the least spectrum per subscriber and spent only $10 billion in a recent government auction of airwaves.
It's also clear that Sprint is burning cash and may need more help from parent SoftBank.
SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son in 2014 promised to deliver wireless data speeds surpassing network speeds for Verizon and AT&T (T).

The catch: Softbank wanted federal regulators to approve a Sprint merger with T-Mobile US (TMUS), which reportedly is in talks with Dish Network.Verizon Communications (VZ) looms as a buyer if Sprint (S) sells some of its radio spectrum to raise cash for a network upgrade that it badly needs to stay competitive in the U.S. wireless market."For a company that we expect to burn through another $4.5 billion in cash this calendar year, selling some 2.5 GHz spectrum would certainly provide some level of near-term relief," said Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, in a blog post.Verizon and cable TV companies loom as possible buyers of a chunk of Sprint's spectrum, most of which is in the high frequency of 2.5 gigahertz, says Moffett.Sprint obtained a 120 MHz swath of airwaves in the 2.5 GHz spectrum band through its 2013 acquisition of Clearwire. Dish Network (DISH) will not spin off its wireless spectrum holdings into a separate company, aims to deliver a wireless version of its Sling Web TV service, and views T-Mobile US as a likelier partner than Sprint.
That's the upshot from the satellite TV broadcaster's Tuesday meeting with analysts. Dish Network stock was down nearly 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 71.
Shares in the No. 2 satellite TV broadcaster, behind DirecTV Group (DTV), have slipped 12% since hitting an all-time high of 80.75 on Feb. 23.

Some analysts have questioned Dish CEO Charlie Ergen's strategy of amassing about 80 MHz of radio spectrum for wireless phone service with no apparent buyer of those airwaves or a strategic wireless partner.

Amid the options explored by Ergen were spinning off the spectrum holdings into a separate company that would lease airwaves to wireless firms. However, Ergen on Tuesday told analysts that Dish Network has no near-term plans to do so.

"While some have speculated about a possible spectrum spinoff, management believes the best way to maximize spectrum value is to maintain the current corporate structure, for now," said Mike McCormack, an analyst at Jefferies, in a research report.
Likes T-Mobile's Network

Jonathan Schildkraut, an analyst at Evercore ISI, said in a report that Ergen's comments Tuesday signal that "T-Mobile (TMUS) is a more likely partner than Sprint, should Dish choose the partnership route."
Japan-based SoftBank in 2013 outbid Dish Network for a controlling stake in Sprint (S).
"In discussing T-Mobile, Ergen highlighted that company's simpler network design, more common spectrum bands, and already dense network," wrote Schildkraut.

Federal regulators are probing Dish Network's tactics in a recent U.S. radio spectrum auction, including $3 billion in discounts won by using bidding partners. In the AWS-3 auction, Dish Network spent $10 billion to buy 27 MHz of spectrum in the top 100 U.S. markets.

In 2012, Dish acquired spectrum from two bankrupt companies. Federal regulators granted Dish Network a waiver to use the airwaves, originally earmarked for satellite service, for 4G wireless, as long as Dish built out a network.
UBS analyst John Hodulik, in a report, said Ergen "doesn't seem worried about pending build-out deadlines, the first of which are in March 2017."
Dish is unlikely to enter the wireless market without a partner.
"Even with a nationwide spectrum footprint and licenses that can be used solely for 4G, we note that Ergen continues to display a reluctance to enter the wireless market on his own," added Hodulik.
Ergen recently said he expects the Sling online TV service to generate meaningful revenue.

Verizon Communications (VZ), meanwhile, is expected to soon launch Internet video product focused on wireless subscribers.Dish Network (DISH) will not spin off its wireless spectrum holdings into a separate company, aims to deliver a wireless version of its Sling Web TV service, and views T-Mobile US as a likelier partner than Sprint.That's the upshot from the satellite TV broadcaster's Tuesday meeting with analysts. Dish Network stock was down nearly 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 71.Shares in the No. 2 satellite TV broadcaster, behind DirecTV Group (DTV), have slipped 12% since hitting an all-time high of 80.75 on Feb. 23.Some analysts have questioned Dish CEO Charlie Ergen's strategy of amassing about 80 MHz of radio spectrum for wireless phone service with no apparent buyer of those airwaves or a strategic wireless partner.Amid the options explored by Ergen were spinning off the spectrum holdings into a separate company that would lease airwaves to wireless firms. However, Ergen on Tuesday told analysts that Dish Network has no near-term plans to do so."While some have speculated about a possible spectrum spinoff, management believes the best way to maximize spectrum value is to maintain the current corporate structure, for now," said Mike McCormack, an analyst at Jefferies, in a research report.Likes T-Mobile's NetworkJonathan Schildkraut, an analyst at Evercore ISI, said in a report that Ergen's comments Tuesday signal that "T-Mobile (TMUS) is a more likely partner than Sprint, should Dish choose the partnership route."Japan-based SoftBank in 2013 outbid Dish Network for a controlling stake in Sprint (S)."In discussing T-Mobile, Ergen highlighted that company's simpler network design, more common spectrum bands, and already dense network," wrote Schildkraut.Federal regulators are probing Dish Network's tactics in a recent U.S. radio spectrum auction, including $3 billion in discounts won by using bidding partners. In the AWS-3 auction, Dish Network spent $10 billion to buy 27 MHz of spectrum in the top 100 U.S. markets.In 2012, Dish acquired spectrum from two bankrupt companies. Federal regulators granted Dish Network a waiver to use the airwaves, originally earmarked for satellite service, for 4G wireless, as long as Dish built out a network.UBS analyst John Hodulik, in a report, said Ergen "doesn't seem worried about pending build-out deadlines, the first of which are in March 2017."Dish is unlikely to enter the wireless market without a partner."Even with a nationwide spectrum footprint and licenses that can be used solely for 4G, we note that Ergen continues to display a reluctance to enter the wireless market on his own," added Hodulik.Ergen recently said he expects the Sling online TV service to generate meaningful revenue.Verizon Communications (VZ), meanwhile, is expected to soon launch Internet video product focused on wireless subscribers.

Amid the hand-wringing over cord-cutting and lackluster subscription numbers from Disney's (DIS) sports network, ESPN head John Skipper said Wednesday that the broadcaster will not go it alone as a paid subscription service. But it is exploring options to become part of some skinny bundles and over-the-top streaming offerings. "We can sell ESPN as a standalone product, but we do not believe…

Stocks wrestled in and out of narrowly mixed territory early Thursday, as rising oil, mixed economic data and earnings news all factored into opening trade.The Dow hashed back and forth, in and out of narrow gains. The Nasdaq slipped 0.4% as Discovery Communications (DISCA), Dish Network (DISH) and Garmin (GRMN) all dragged on the index. The S&P 500 shed 0.2%.Volume moved lower, down 14% on the Nasdaq and off 9% on the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Wednesday.  Lighter volume can signal that institutional investors are not significantly active.The stock market today felt some early push from overseas markets, with benchmark indexes in Hong Kong and Tokyo closing more than 2% higher. But Europe's markets backed away from early gains and turned mixed in afternoon trade following the start of U.S. markets.A positive reading on weekly jobless claims also aided opening action. But continued contraction in mid-Atlantic manufacturing, as gauged by the Philly Fed Index, stirred concerns over the state of the economy.The Conference Board reported its January Leading Indicators Index slipped 0.2% -- in line with expectations. It also revised December's decline upward to 0.3%.Oil prices pushed up more than 3%, lifting West Texas Intermediate to near $32 a barrel and Brent crude well above $35. American Petroleum Institute data on Wednesday showed U.S. oil inventories declined 3.3 million barrels in the week ended Feb. 12. The Energy Information Administration plans to releases its weekly inventory report at 11 a.m. ET.IBM (IBM) bucked up 5% to lead the Dow. The company announced it was buying health care software provider Truven Health Analytics for $2.6 billion.Wal-Mart (WMT) dropped almost 5%, the Dow's worst loss, after Q4 earnings narrowly beat, but fourth-quarter revenue and full-year revenue guidance missed consensus projections.Nvidia (NVDA) charged to the head of the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 indexes, spiking 10%.  Nvidia's fourth-quarter earnings and revenue, along with guidance, easily outpaced analyst expectations in a report following Wednesday's close.Generic drug maker Perrigo (PRGO) tumbled more than 9% lower. Earnings and revenue missed analyst consensus estimates, and management significantly pared the top end of its full-year EPS guidance. The stock had been correcting, rising briefly above its 10-week line since August.Among IBD 50 stocks, Universal Display (OLED) rumbled up almost 4% in strong trade – working on a seventh straight advance. The move positioned shares for a test of resistance at their 50-day moving average after retaking support at their 200-day line on Wednesday.Turf tending equipment maker Toro (TTC) bolted 4% higher in heavy action. That sent shares into buying range above a 75.22 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.At the low end of the list, Five Below (FIVE) dropped 3%, pulling back in light trade after a six-day rally. The slip put shares back below a 36.59 buy point in a cup with handle base.

How is Comcast’s (CMCSA) $15-per-month Web-based TV service, called Stream, doing? Comcast, the nation’s biggest cable TV firm, launched Stream in Boston and Chicago last quarter. Comcast's Stream service targets broadband-only homes, mainly millennials who have never subscribed to pay TV services. No set-top box is required, and Stream works with Apple (AAPL) TV, Roku and other devices.With Stream, Comcast got the jump on Apple, which has been delayed in launching its expected Web TV service.Comcast included Stream subscribers in its surprising 89,000 net video subscriber additions in Q4.But Comcast did not break out how many Stream subscribers it has. “Stream is in the numbers, but I don't think it moves the needle a lot,” UBS analyst John Hodulik told IBD in an email.Comcast has stated plans to bring Stream to its entire cable TV territory in 2016. Comcast's Stream service includes the major live broadcast networks -- ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox -- along with HBO and local TV channels.Comcast Cable CEO Neil Smit, on the company's earnings conference call Wednesday, said "it's probably too early to say what it (Stream) will be, what it will turn into over time. But we feel good about the usage and good about the product. It's a good value proposition for the customer, and we'll continue to roll it out to other markets."The Federal Communications Commission is likely curious about how Stream is doing in hard numbers, given that the agency has been asking questions about the Web service related to its net neutrality rules. The problem, according to critics, is that Comcast does not count its own Stream service toward the monthly data caps of its broadband customers. Comcast says the Stream service is not a net neutrality issue because the service uses IP technology over its own network, not the public Internet, to reach households.A federal court is expected to rule on the FCC’s net neutrality rules in April. The agency's clout could again be gutted -- or not, which might lead to more enforcement of the new net neutrality rules.Comcast joins Dish Network (DISH) in mashing new Web streaming video subscribers along with traditional pay TV customers in earnings reports. In Dish’s case, new subscribers to its $20-per-month Sling Web TV service have helped offset its loss of satellite TV customers.Dish discussed Sling subscriber additions for the first time when reporting Q2 earnings in early August. Sling had 240,000 subscribers as of June 30.Dish Network did not update Sling’s subscriber total when reporting Q3 earnings. Goldman Sachs has forecast that Sling could hit 2 million by the end of 2016.For Comcast, Stream numbers might be more material by the time it reports Q1 earnings. Comcast’s 89,000 video subscriber additions in Q4 were way up from 6,000 in the year-earlier period.Aside from launching Stream, Comcast has also stepped up its promotion of lower-priced skinny bundles, with fewer TV channels and broadband-first promotions to college students.Analysts say its deployment of  Internet-ready X1 set-top boxes and improved customer service have improved video subscriber results.On Comcast’s earnings call, Smit played down the impact of  lower-revenue skinny bundles. He said 75% of video subscribers added in the December quarter had “higher-end packages.”

Celebrity chef Paul Prudhomme took pretension out of the kitchen and popularized Creole-Cajun cuisine.His view: “You don’t need a silver fork to eat good food.”The 13th child of a Louisiana sharecropper, he learned to cook as a tot stirring the pot for his mother. Prudhomme’s culinary school was 12 years traveling the U.S., taking kitchen jobs in truck stops, swank resorts and various spots in between. The Americana apprenticeship led Chef Paul back home.''I was struck by the reactions to my food from people all over the country. I began to understand how unique the traditional foods of my family were,” he wrote in “Chef Paul Prudhomme’s Louisiana Kitchen.”Drawing on those roots, Prudhomme (1940-2015) started a Cajun-Creole craze.It began at Commander’s Palace, New Orleans’ fine-dining jewel, where he became the restaurant’s first American executive chef in 1975.“Everybody believed you had to import a chef from France. With Paul, that mold was broken,” said Poppy Tooker, host of NPR-affiliated radio show “Louisiana Eats!”Chef Paul deftly mixed his down-home Cajun approach into the restaurant’s upscale Creole fare.“He was the reason the words Creole and Cajun got hyphenated,” Tooker told IBD. “What he was creating was the first American fusion food.”Four years later, Prudhomme opened his own Crescent City restaurant, called K-Paul’s Louisiana Kitchen. Lines stretched around the block for his signature dish -- blackened redfish -- and other specialties.A retail seasoning line followed, as did cooking shows on PBS, public appearances in the U.S. and abroad, and a string of cookbooks -- all raising Prudhomme’s stature as one of America’s first celebrity chefs.He never acted like an unapproachable luminary.Chef John Besh, author of “Besh Big Easy,” recalls Prudhomme as unfailingly generous.“He selflessly passed his television show on to me with the directions to continue to share our great cuisine and culture with the world,” said Besh, whose 12 restaurants celebrate Louisianan gastronomy. “He also carved the way for chefs to break out of the kitchen, into entrepreneurship, and called each of us to follow his example. We are all indebted to him and his leadership.”Born in Opelousas, La., Prudhomme was the son of Eli, a sharecropper who grew cotton and sweet potatoes. After the family’s youngest daughter left home, Paul, 7, was drafted into the kitchen.Every day, Prudhomme harvested roots and vegetables, tended barnyard animals and helped his mother, Hazel, prepare meals for the large family.“Cooking with her was like working for a small restaurant,” he wrote.He learned nuances, such as how the order of ingredients influenced a dish’s taste. “My mother was also a great storyteller, and she talked to me a lot about food -- its lore, the different kinds of food, and how they’re prepared.”Prudhomme decided to make a career of the kitchen. His first restaurant -- a hamburger stand outside Opelousas dubbed Big Daddy O’s Patio -- folded after nine months.Still determined to break into the business, the 17-year-old aspiring chef hit the road. With each new cooking job, he learned regional tastes and techniques, also sharing his own flavors. Some chefs, he felt, didn’t add enough spice.“I would yearn to season food, so I would mix up little packets of different herbs and spices, sneak them into the restaurants and use them as I cooked,” he wrote.Prudhomme never tired of sharing Louisiana’s flavors with diners up north.“At the same time, I would notice when I returned home for visits that my Cajun family and friends didn’t seem to recognize the uniqueness of their cooking,” he wrote.In 1970, Prudhomme returned to New Orleans, first working as a sous chef at Le Pavillon Hotel and later helping Clarence Dupuy open his restaurant, Maison du Puy. That’s where Prudhomme met waitress Kay Hinrichs. She became his second wife (Paul had been briefly married as a teen).By 1975, Commander’s Palace proprietors Ella and Dick Brennan had spotted something special in Prudhomme and hired him as their first non-European executive chef.The restaurant was already known for its white-tablecloth service and sophisticated Creole cuisine. Considered city cooking, Creole’s roots came from the kitchens of New Orleans’ upper-crust families, and its flavors were influenced by French, Spanish, Italian, American Indian and African chefs.The Cajun cooking that Prudhomme grew up with simply wasn’t found in New Orleans restaurants at that time. It was French country cooking -- simple and hearty -- and spiced with regional ingredients like bay leaves, peppers and file powder from the sassafras tree. No one had mixed the two styles -- Creole and Cajun -- until Prudhomme created a sensation with dishes like his andouille gumbo.“The result was an explosion of spectacular flavors and wonderful cooking that influenced the city, state, country and the world,” Ella Brennan said after Prudhomme’s death.In 1979, while still working at Commander’s Palace, Chef Paul and wife Kay opened K-Paul’s Louisiana Kitchen in the French Quarter. At the 64-seat eatery, reservations weren’t accepted, and celebrities and city workers sat side by side at communal tables.Prudhomme’s food was the star.This was where Chef Paul introduced blackened redfish -- colored with spices and seared for flavor -- which would become his signature dish. It was so popular, the local redfish population was temporarily depleted.To perfect his flavors, Prudhomme recalled his roots.“I couldn’t seem to get a potato to taste like my mother’s until I realized that it wasn’t anything that was done in the kitchen; it was just the freshness of the potato that made it completely different,” he wrote.Ahead of the farm-to-table trend, Prudhomme bought direct from local growers. Available ingredients dictated Chef Paul’s menu, which was written anew each day.To help home chefs replicate his dishes, Prudhomme launched Chef Paul’s Magic Seasonings in 1983. The line of spices, rubs, sauces and marinades sells globally.The Louisianan chef became a regular guest on “Good Morning America” and other TV shows in the 1980s. In 1986, the first of Prudhomme’s nine cookbooks became a New York Times best-seller. That same year, Kay was diagnosed with incurable lung cancer. She died seven years later at age 48.Prudhomme continued reaching into America’s kitchens via his 1995 PBS cooking show, “Chef Paul’s Fork in the Road,” and later “Chef Paul Prudhomme’s Always Cooking!” His catchphrase: “My mission is to make your dinner better.”A firm believer in hospitality and a helping hand, Prudhomme stepped up after Hurricane Katrina decimated New Orleans in 2005. He and his crew turned K-Paul’s into a relief center and prepared thousands of meals for military personnel and locals.“He cooked in the street. He hired a band,” Tooker said.In 2010, Prudhomme married Lori Bennett, his third wife. He’d struggled with his weight throughout his life and died last year at age 75.Over his distinguished career, Chef Paul spoke internationally, cooked for two presidential inaugurations (1985, 2005) and received several honors, including France’s Order of Agricultural Merit in 1980 and Bon Appetit’s Humanitarian Award in 2006.His greatest pride was serving fabulous food: “I came to realize that the joy of cooking Cajun and Creole food was not just that I appreciated its goodness so much, but that there was this great pleasure I got from watching other people eat it and seeing the joy in their eyes.”Created and popularized Cajun-Creole cuisine.Overcame: Lack of means and formal education, entrenched cooking traditions.Lesson: Learn the business, stay true to your roots, share what you know.“I think the most wonderful thing in the world is another chef. I'm always excited about learning new things about food.”

Verizon Communications (VZ) will bite the bullet and include sports channel ESPN in its “Custom TV” package, giving Walt Disney (DIS) a boost amid worries over falling pay-TV subscribers, speculates Deutsche Bank in a research report. “We believe Verizon will soon adjust its Custom TV packages to include ESPN in the base tier, which will be one less source of pressure…
Stocks traced thin losses early Thursday as investors largely looked toward what promises to be a big news day on Friday.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq dropped to fractional losses. The S&P 500 shaved off 0.3%, weighted by losses among energy and chemical stocks.

Factors affecting the stock market today include the Eurozone's dilemma over Greece's debt, which faces a steep hurdle in the form of a $334 million debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund on Friday. That uncertainty has helped trigger a volatile week in global bond markets, a situation given an additional stir by comments Wednesday from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi.
Markets are also positioning for a U.S. payroll report for May and a meeting of the Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries, both on Friday.
That being said, not much positioning is going on in the U.S. stock market, where the Nasdaq and S&P 500 remain in a tightly rangebound posture.

In economic news, layoff data were positive early Thursday. The Challenger Job Cuts Report announced a 23% year-over-year decline in job reductions, down 33% from an oil-spurred surge of layoffs in April. Weekly jobless claims declined 2%, in line with consensus forecasts, but first-quarter productivity and unit labor cost revisions from the Labor Department were worse than expected.

In stocks, dollar store chain Five Below (FIVE) surged 10% out of the starting gate. The Philadelphia-based retailer's earnings and revenue narrowly topped Q1 consensus views. Management reported 19 new stores opened during the quarter and said store growth remained its No. 1 priority. Five Below has been in a general uptrend since March, trying to haul itself out of an eight-month consolidation.

T-Mobile (TMUS) and Dish Network (DISH) also staked out the early high ground. Dish jumped 5% to lead the Nasdaq 100. T-Mobile powered up 4%. News reports said the two companies were in discussions regarding a possible merger. The gain sent T-Mobile to a fresh high. It sent Dish further up the right side of a four-month cup base.

Casino owner Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) surged more than 5% at the start of trade. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) jumped 4% to top the S&P 500. MGM Resorts (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) gained 2% each. The group has largely been consolidating for the past 14 months.

Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) scratched out a 2% gain to lead the IBD 50 list in early trade. The Mississippi-based egg producer is in the fourth week of an eight-week hold rule, after rising more than 20% above a 47.61 buy point in fewer than 2 weeks.Stocks traced thin losses early Thursday as investors largely looked toward what promises to be a big news day on Friday.The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq dropped to fractional losses. Stock futures were down but trimming some losses early Thursday as investors processed a broad range of U.S. and overseas influences.

Dow futures traded 36.3 points below fair market value, but were well off their early lows. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 17.3 points, nearly halving their losses over the prior hour. S&P 500 futures fell 5 points, also cutting their losses by nearly half.

The stock market today has a lot to chew on. Global stock, bond and currency markets have been positioning for a possible default by Greece vs. a debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund on Friday, as well as the U.S. payroll report for May due out from the U.S. Labor Department and a production policy decision from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Markets for now remain cramped in their months-long trading range.

Economic news opened on a positive note. U.S. employers announced 23% fewer layoffs in May vs. the year-ago period, according to the Challenger, Gray & Christmas Job Cuts report, and down 33% vs. April's three-year high. The financial sector reported the highest level of layoffs during the month, trimming more than 5,500 jobs.

Unemployment claims declined in line with expectations, down 2% to 276,000 in the week ended May 30, according to the Labor Department. The four-week moving average ticked up to 274,750 in a second straight increase.

Less positive was the Labor Department's Q1 productivity estimate, revised downward to a 3.1% decline vs. initial views of a 1.9% slip. Unit labor costs jumped 6.7%, above an initial estimate of a 5% increase. Analysts had expected a 2.9% slip in productivity and a 6% rise in unit labor costs.

In stocks, dollar store chain Five Below (FIVE) blipped up 7% before the bell. The Philadelphia-based retailer reported Q1 earnings and revenue above consensus expectations, and Q2 guidance in line with analysts' views. The stock has a healthy earnings record, but has been in a deepening consolidation for 19 months.

T-Mobile (TMUS) jumped 6% and Dish Network (DISH) climbed 4% as reports circulated that the wireless carrier and broadcast satellite network were discussing a merger. The Wall Street Journal quoted unnamed sources, saying the two companies were in close agreement on a number of points regarding integration. T-Mobile ended Wednesday just below Monday's high after clearing a long, cup-with-handle base in April. Dish is climbing the right side of a four-month consolidation.

Security software developer FireEye (FEYE) punched up 4% after announcing late Thursday it launched a merchant cybersecurity initiative with Visa (V). The venture aims to provide merchants with "cyber intelligence and enhanced threat monitoring," the companies said. FireEye shares ended Wednesday at a 52-week high, just above a cup-base buy point of 46.54.

Overseas, edginess in bond markets spread on Thursday, uneasy over the potential effect of a possible default by Greece and after Wednesday's comments from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi. The German Bund tumbled for a third session. Asia's bond markets turned volatile, sending yields surging in Thailand, Australia and Japan. U.S. bonds were relatively sedate after a three-day slide.
China's mainland stock markets marked violent reversals, with benchmark indexes in Shanghai and Shenzhen recovering from 5% and 6% dives to a tightly mixed close.
Sellers controlled Europe's markets at midday, with the CAC-40 in Paris down 1.6% and Frankfurt's DAX and London's FTSE 100 down 1.3% apiece.

The dollar dipped vs. both the euro and the yen. T-Mobile US (TMUS) parent Deutsche Telekom could sell off some of its stake in TMUS, diluting shares, if M&A prospects with Dish Network fade and another buyer doesn't step up, says Macquarie Capital, which downgraded T-Mobile stock to neutral on Wednesday. T-Mobile stock has shot up on views that Dish Network (DISH) could bid to acquire the wireless carrier. The…

Though it's widely accepted that the images on a 4K television set are unrivaled — with unmatched levels of brightness, resolution and clarity — widespread adoption of this technology has been slow. But that may change due to a one-two punch that could jump-start the 4K rollout: the release of a lot of new 4K programming and the rising adoption…

Stocks were trading near the low of the day as investors watched events in Europe and anticipated Friday morning's employment report. The Nasdaq fell 0.5%; the S&P 500 was 0.6% off, and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.7%. Volume tracked higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq exchange in the stock market today.Among IBD 50 stocks, 15 were higher and 35 were lower. Easily the best performer was Ambarella (AMBA), up 4% in big volume. It reported better-than-expected earnings after the close Tuesday. It's well extended after finding support at its 50-day moving average.Gray Television (GTN) was among the worst performers, down 3%. It's retracing part of a nearly 10% gain after breaking out of a flat base with a 14.90 buy point.Big moves highlighted action among big wireless carriers as T-Mobile (TMUS) and Dish Network (DISH) are reported to be in merger talks.T-Mobile was up 4% at a new high. Dish rose 5%. Competitors Sprint (S) and Verizon (VZ) were down, but AT&T (T) rose.

As banks farm out more tech services and try to keep up with customers managing more of their money via their phones, Fiserv (FISV), a company that provides back-end technology to the finance industry, seems to be expanding at a solid, measured pace.Companies spilling over with triple-digit growth every quarter are drawing more adventurous investors, which is why many on Wall Street seem to like Fiserv’s steadiness. The company routinely generates single-digit sales gains and low-double-digit earnings growth, aided by share buybacks.Following the Fed’s rate hike last year and forecasts for fatter industry tech budgets, more of the same could be in store despite worries over a downturn and consolidation, the company and analysts say. That's due primarily to a steady income base.“When you have 85% of revenue recurring, it gives them a very good visibility into their numbers,” helping enable more accurate guidance and minimizing surprises when earnings season rolls around, Monness Crespi Hardt analyst Alexander Veytsman told Investor's Business Daily.“They do increase pricing, but given the longevity of those contracts and given the fact that these clients have been with them for a number of years, I would say they’re growing it slowly and steadily,” Veytsman said.The nature of the company’s contracts with clients helps Fiserv maintain its firm footing. Many deals are longer-term and retention is high, Morningstar notes in its research on the company. In addition, it’s costly and potentially hugely disruptive for financial companies to switch from one core-processing service to another, helping Fiserv keep customers in the fold.And even amid Wall Street’s hand-wringing over a possible recession, Chief Executive Jeffery Yabuki told IBD that he sees the trends in tech spending among Fiserv’s own clients continuing."Most of our revenue is based on non-discretionary, mission-critical technologies under longer term contracts and is not subject to dramatic fluctuation,” he said via email. “We are seeing stable and growing demand for newer technologies that enhance experiences in the increasingly digital world.”Brookfield, Wis.-based Fiserv serves 13,000 banks, credit unions, retailers and other clients around the world. If you’ve withdrawn money from an automated teller or transferred a balance from one account to another, there’s a good chance it went smoothly in part because of Fiserv.Created in 1984 through a merger, Fiserv handles everything from transaction processing to data analysis to person-to-person payment systems. With this year’s technology spending seen growing 4%-5% among banks and credit-union customers -- Fiserv’s bread and butter -- the company is set to follow, Argus Research says.“We believe that Fiserv remains well positioned to benefit from technology infrastructure spending among its primary customers (banks and credit unions), many of whom are working to improve processing efficiency for online bill payment and debit card transactions,” Argus analyst Stephen Biggar said in a research note last month.“This should help revenue to keep rising at a modest mid-single-digit pace,” Biggar said, adding that Argus sees 5.5% in sales growth this year.Shares are up 25% over the past 12 months. The company has a Composite Rating of 93 out of a best-possible 99, boosted most recently by its strong fourth-quarter results that were marked by better-than-expected operating margins.The company also has tried to stay relevant through acquisitions. In 2011, Fiserv snapped up mobile banking company M-Com and digital payments outfit CashEdge, which gave it Popmoney, a bank-based person-to-person payments system for participating institutions that has helped drive sales growth. The company in 2013 announced that it acquired Open Solutions, giving it real-time account-processing technology.“You don’t need a new product every day,” Biggar said, “but you need something fairly significant every 2-3 years that would have its own sort of life cycle.”Last month, Fiserv said the United Nations Federal Credit Union for U.N. employees, among the largest in the U.S. by assets, will begin using Fiserv’s core account-processing technology. Analysts say the Federal Reserve’s rate hike in December could help strengthen banks’ finances, potentially freeing up cash for their technology budgets.“We view the Fed rate increase for the first time in a decade as good news for banks and a way to help fund needed increases in IT spend, as institutions look for ways to keep up with the broad changes across the technology landscape,” CEO Yabuki said on the company’s fourth-quarter earnings call last month.Some concern persists that Fiserv could make less money if consolidation continues within the banking industry, either due to tightening regulations or an event like the 2008 financial crisis. Mergers and acquisitions could reduce client count and give those bigger, combined companies more muscle in negotiating cheaper contract prices with companies like Fiserv.However, the reduction in clients hasn't materialized, Veytsman said, and the prospect of more banks bringing tech operations in-house seems unlikely. Fiserv counts Wells Fargo (WFC) among its big clients, potentially signaling a stronger shift to outsourcing among larger banks.Monness Crespi's Veytsman said consolidation could actually accelerate the trend of tech outsourcing.“When they consolidate they also look to see what’s happening with the bottom line and what they’re doing around the costs,” he said. “And if someone was not considering using Fiserv as a client, maybe together, they will.”Yabuki sees consolidation continuing, but stressed that the number of accounts and transactions has kept rising for the company.Foreign exchange amid a stronger dollar could also hurt the company, although its international exposure is limited, Veytsman said. Jack Henry & Associates and FIS are among the company’s primary competitors. Concern also lingers about Fiserv’s debt, although Yabuki cites the company’s $1-billion-plus free cash flow last year.Still, both Biggar and Veytsman say the company’s acquisitions have been relatively focused and restrained.And one might be forgiven for wondering whether a person-to-person service like Popmoney can compete with PayPal’s (PYPL) Venmo, or payment-tech offerings from Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOGL) and, potentially, Apple (AAPL).However, Yabuki said P2P was in the early innings. And Veytsman said Popmoney is intended more as a side dish in its offerings to midcap banks than a main course."It’s very hard to challenge PayPal,” he said.

Rovi (ROVI) stock jumped as much as 19% Friday to an 11-month high, following the company's fourth-quarter earnings late Thursday that beat estimates, as revenue growth reversed four straight quarters of deceleration.The focus now shifts to first-quarter performance and Rovi’s ability to renew licensing agreements with Comcast (CMCSA) and Dish Network (DISH).Rovi provides technology for interactive TV program guides licensed by AT&T (T), Comcast, Time Warner Cable (TWC), Dish and others, used for interactive TV guides and video-on-demand services. It also provides advertising services, including Big Data analytics that provides TV-audience insights and ad campaign management in various entertainment sectors.It posted Q4 revenue of $149.5 million, up 11% year over year and topping the consensus estimate of $130.7 million. It was the first time in five quarters that Rovi revenue accelerated. It reported earnings per share minus items of 65 cents, smashing estimates of 37 cents. That reversed four straight quarters of slower EPS growth.Rovi stock was up 14%, near 20.50, in afternoon trading in the stock market today.During Q4, Rovi renewed a technology licensing agreement with AT&T, which now includes the DirecTV footprint, for a seven-year term, in addition to a renewed licensing agreement with Sony (SNE).“In 2016, Rovi is focused on successfully renewing our IP Licenses with Comcast and Dish and on building our product portfolio,” Rovi CEO Tom Carson said in the earnings release. “We believe achieving these goals will help drive stockholder value for years to come.”While Rovi said it expects to successfully renew agreements with Comcast and Dish, its revenue and EPS from those agreements are not included in current estimates. Excluding revenue from Comcast and Dish, Rovi anticipates 2016 revenue of $490 million to $520 million and EPS less items of $1.35 to $1.65.Andy Hargreaves, analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, said the renewals with Comcast and Dish remain likely but are far from certain."Rovi is in the latter stages of negotiations with Comcast and Dish, as the current deals expire over the next two months,” Hargreaves wrote in a research note. “Rovi’s history suggests it is more likely than not to complete the deals successfully, but a delayed negotiation or even a lawsuit remains highly possible, either of which could drive significant stock volatility.”

As goes Netflix, so goes regulatory approval of cable TV industry mergers? The notion that the Web video streamer is a bellwether for government approval could gain credence if Charter Communications’ (CHTR) proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable (TWC) gets the OK. Netflix (NFLX), which opposed Comcast’s proposed purchase of TWC, is fine with Charter’s deal. The Department of Justice and Federal Communications Commission…

Verizon Communications’ (VZ) spat with Walt Disney (DIS) over sports channel ESPN could be over.Verizon on Friday revamped its “Custom TV” programming packages for FiOS TV subscribers. Verizon FiOS now offers two standard bundles -- one with sports channels ESPN, Fox Sports and NBC Sports and one without them, according to a release.The “Essentials” package without sports has more popular entertainment channels.  Ray McConville, a Verizon spokesperson, said the new bundles still give customers the option of skipping sports. He said the Custom TV revamp had nothing to do with a dispute that flared in April between Verizon and Disney.When Verizon launched Custom TV, its $55 monthly base package for 35 channels excluded Disney’s ESPN, which garners the highest fees among cable networks. Disney sued Verizon claiming it doesn’t have rights to exclude its sports channel from TV bundles under programming deals.Verizon expanded the number of channels in both new packages. The new offering now cost $69.99, along with FiOS Internet and digital voice services.Following Verizon’s Q4 earnings call, analysts speculated that a Verizon-Disney resolution could be in the cards, as IBD reported.Disney, meanwhile, on its Q4 call commented on ESPN’s success as part of Dish Networks' (DISH) online TV service called Sling. Disney is exploring streaming deals with other companies.Disney’s ESPN is also not part of Comcast’s (CMCSA) over-the-top “Stream” TV service.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Federal regulators Thursday moved forward with a proposal to make it easier for consumers to switch from set-top boxes leased monthly from pay-TV companies to new devices sold at retail by consumer electronics or Internet companies. Comcast (CMCSA), AT&T (T) and other pay-TV companies quickly criticized the Federal Communications Commission’s vote to begin making the new rules, calling it unneeded because of…

JPMorgan is bullish on the upcoming “Broadcast Incentive Auction,” which will free up prime, low-frequency airwaves owned by local TV broadcasters for wireless data services.Naysayers continue to contend that the Federal Communications Commission faces many challenges in pulling off a successful auction, which for now is scheduled to start late next month. One risk is that broadcasters might drop out of the auction if they determine that bidding prices are disappointing.The auction is key for T-Mobile US (TMUS), which needs spectrum. AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) own most of the available low-frequency spectrum, in which waves travel longer distances, among other advantages over higher-frequency spectrum.JPMorgan expects at least 70 MHz of airwaves, and possibly more, to be auctioned. The key is that broadcasters that own two local TV stations will sell off airwaves from one and keep spectrum from the other, says JPMorgan.“We estimate that 70-100 MHz will be auctioned, for $25 billion to $35 billion,” said JPMorgan in a research report.Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) and CBS (CBS) are expected to sell airwaves in some markets. While Comcast’s (CMCSA) cable company is a potential bidder, it also owns media firm NBCUniversal, a likely seller of airwaves.Smaller local TV station owners include Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) and Gray Television (GTNA).“We view FOX and CBS as best positioned to monetize duopoly affiliates in large markets, followed by Comcast and Sinclair,” said JPMorgan. Walt Disney (DIS), which owns ABC, is not expected to sell airwaves. Private investment firms such as Columbia Capital are eyeing the auction, says a Washington Post report.JPMorgan predicts cable TV firms will show up, but it doubts that Internet giants will bid."We expect that AT&T, Verizon, and T-Mobile will be the biggest bidders ($21 billion-$30 billion cumulative spend), that Sprint (S)/SoftBank (SFTBY) will not register, and Dish Network (DISH) will at most be an opportunistic buyer," said the JPMorgan report. "We estimate Comcast, potentially in partnership with other cable companies, could spend $3 billion-$5 billion, and private equity funds in aggregate could spend $1 billion-$2 billion."We do not expect digital economy players like Alphabet-Google (GOOGL) or Amazon.com (AMZN) to bid, though they can never be ruled out.”

Video is taking over the Web. Entertainment — led by Web video streamers Netflix (NFLX), YouTube and Facebook (FB) — continues to boost Internet traffic on fixed- and mobile networks, says a Sandvine broadband report. Entertainment accounted for nearly 69% of downstream Web traffic on fixed networks through May, up from 64% a year earlier, said the latest Sandvine report.…
CBS (CBS) CEO Leslie Moonves on Wednesday spilled the beans on Apple's (AAPL) widely rumored "skinny bundle" Internet TV service.

Speaking at the Code conference in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., Moonves said Apple hopes to shake up the pay-TV business by offering a lower-cost service with a limited set of channels, USA Today reported.

"Apple TV is trying to change the universe a little bit as did Sling, as did Sony. What Apple will offer ... are a more select group (of channels) for a lower price," Moonves said. It will compete with other Internet TV services like Dish Network 's (DISH) Sling TV and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue.
CBS "probably" will do a deal with Apple on Apple TV, Moonves said. He met with Eddie Cue, Apple's senior vice president of Internet software and services, just last week, Moonves said.

Apple has yet to publicly disclose its plans to do an Internet television service. It currently sells the Apple TV set-top box for accessing content from third-party providers like Netflix (NFLX) and Hulu, as well as its iTunes download store.

Apple's Internet TV service reportedly has been delayed by the company's efforts to get live programming from local TV stations. Local channels would differentiate Apple's service from Sling and others.

Moonves didn't know how long it would take to hammer out a deal or when Apple would launch its service, Re/code reported. The main sticking point? "Money," Moonves said.CBS (CBS) CEO Leslie Moonves on Wednesday spilled the beans on Apple's (AAPL) widely rumored "skinny bundle" Internet TV service.Speaking at the Code conference in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., Moonves said Apple hopes to shake up the pay-TV business by offering a lower-cost service with a limited set of channels, USA Today reported."Apple TV is trying to change the universe a little bit as did Sling, as did Sony.
