Can satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network reinvent itself like Netflix, the one-time DVD renter that became a streaming-video giant? Dish (DISH) founder and CEO Charlie Ergen was careful making comparisons on the satellite broadcaster's Q1 earnings conference call Monday, but Ergen said he expects Dish's fledgling Internet over-the-top video service Sling TV to one day provide significant revenue."We're excited about where it's going to go," he said. "I think it's going to be meaningful revenue."Dish Network, which lost 134,000 video subscribers in Q1, isn't ready to say how many customers have signed up for the $20 monthly Sling service, launched in January.Sony launched its own OTT service this year, while Verizon Communications (VZ) is ramping up a mobile video service.Apple (AAPL) could join the mix by 2016, some analysts say.Content providers HBO andCBS (CBS) have also launched Web-only services.The services are dubbed OTT because they piggyback landline broadband services sold by other companies. Even if consumers don't buy a traditional pay-TV package, they still need broadband Internet to stream video."The (early Sling) results are encouraging," Ergen said. "We're really encouraged with it. We don't think it's a flash in the pan."Netflix (NFLX), meanwhile, had 41.2 million U.S. streaming customers as of March 31 and only 5.6 million DVD-by-mail customers.Ergen concedes the conventional pay-TV market is mature. Dish had 13.84 million pay-TV customers at the end of Q1, down from 14.1 million a year earlier.Ergen says there are many technical and marketing challenges for Sling, which has suffered streaming setbacks during high-demand periods. Ergen says the economics of the streaming business are much different than broadcast TV."This (OTT) is not as dramatic as perhaps what Netflix went through, but it's somewhat similar in the sense that when Netflix went from a DVD business in the mail to being able to deliver something instantly through the Internet, they started focusing on that (streaming) side of the business. I'm not saying that's going to happen here, but I do think that things like Sling TV are going to become more and more prevalent."Ergen says that for the pay-TV industry, a generation of potential customers, millennials ages 18 to 34, are increasingly cancelling pay-TV service in favor of more affordable, on-demand content.Ergen expects pay-TV providers, including Dish, to continue adjusting the product bundles offered to consumers. Verizon recently sparked a fight with content firms, including Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN, over plans to offer consumers a new "slim" TV package for its landline FiOS pay-TV service."Linear pay television business probably peaked a couple of years ago," Ergen said. "But it's not declining as fast as I would have thought it would."Ergen says pay-TV companies have gained some negotiating clout over content firms as consumers resist price hikes. Contract disputes with content providers contributed to Dish's Q1 subscriber losses as unhappy customers cancelled service. Dish's programming dispute with 21st Century Fox (FOXA) ended in mid-January.In Q1, Dish said it earned 76 cents per share as programming expenses and customer acquisition costs fell. Revenue rose 3.6% to $3.72 billion. Analysts had modeled EPS of 40 cents on sales of $3.74 billion.Average revenue per monthly pay-TV subscriber edged up 4% in Q1 to $86 from $82.36 in Q1 2014.Some analysts question Ergen's strategy of amassing radio spectrum with no apparent buyers of those airwaves — or a strategic wireless partner — in sight.In a recent airwaves auction, Dish achieved its main goal: securing licenses in major markets in order to pressure wireless firms such as Verizon or T-Mobile to negotiate, some analysts say.Ergen said T-Mobile remains a potential partner."We're keeping all our options open, and we admire what (CEO John Legere) and his team have done with T-Mobile," Ergen said.

AT&T (T) CEO Randall Stephenson on Monday said new federal net neutrality rules will be short-lived, though some analysts say they may last long enough to be a factor in approval of the DirecTV Group acquisition.Referring to the next presidential election, Stephenson said: "Administrations change and we're 18 months away from a different FCC and you're a three-two vote away from these rules being modified and improved."AT&T and telecom trade groups on May 13 asked a federal court to block the Federal Communications Commission from carrying out stricter net neutrality rules until lawsuits challenging the rules are decided."We actually believe that the court challenge to this is quite strong and there's a reasonable probability that these rules get modified in some level and in the courts," said Stephenson, speaking at a JPMorgan conference in Boston.The FCC, however, may ask AT&T to accept net neutrality-related merger conditions to win approval of its purchase of DirecTV.Analysts expect regulators to decide on the AT&T-DirecTV deal in June. The two companies on Friday extended their merger agreement. AT&T announced its $48.5 billion purchase of DirecTV (DTV) in May 2014.Netflix (NFLX), Dish Network (DISH), and Cogent Communications (CCOI) are among companies asking federal regulators to require AT&T to comply with stricter net neutrality rules for Internet service providers for up to seven years after the DirecTV deal is approved.The FCC in February voted 3-2 along party lines to regulate ISPs such as Comcast (CMCSA) and AT&T under what Chairman Tom Wheeler called modernized public utility, Title II rules. Net neutrality rules will apply to wireless networks for the first time.Comcast in 2011 agreed to net neutrality rules as part of conditions in its acquisition of NBCUniversal from General Electric (GE).Stephenson said Congress may pass net neutrality legislation if court challenges fail."If I believed the rules that were passed by the FCC on Title II were going to be the rules of the land for the next five to 10 years, it would have a dramatic impact on how we thought about investment," Stephenson added. "We actually have a certain degree of conviction that this will not be the rules of the land in the long term."AT&T shares were up 1.4% to 34.81 by midafternoon in the stock market today.

As Apple's (AAPL) Worldwide Developers Conference approaches, the launch of a new subscription music service looks likely, while an over-the-top Internet TV service probably will be delayed until the fall, according to media reports.

Apple usually saves up some big announcements for its annual WWDC, scheduled for June 8-12 in San Francisco. This year, Apple watchers expect the company to unveil its latest mobile operating system, iOS 9, and a new Apple TV set-top box. They're also looking for the relaunch of Apple's Beats Music service, which it acquired last August when it bought headphone maker Beats Electronics.

Beats Music, launched in January 2014, is a subscription online streaming music service. It competes with services such as Spotify, Pandora (P) and Tidal. Beats costs $9.99 per month or $99.99 per year and is only available in the U.S.
Apple reportedly is planning a global launch for its new subscription music service, which could be renamed iTunes, after its music download store.

Meanwhile, a rumored Apple subscription video service might be postponed while the company negotiates with broadcasters to offer live programming from local TV stations, Re/code reported Friday. Local channels would differentiate Apple's service from those of Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE).

Apple is expected to deliver a long-awaited revamp to its Apple TV set-top box at WWDC. That device streams Netflix (NFLX), Hulu Plus and other services. It competes with gadgets from Amazon.com (AMZN), Google (GOOGL), Roku and others.
The new Apple TV reportedly will have a remote control with a touchpad for scrolling as well as Siri voice search and controls. Plus, it likely will have an App Store.
RELATED:

Never mind a hearty first-quarter beat and the third-highest-grossing movie of all time -- Walt Disney (DIS) CEO Bob Iger was put on the defensive late Tuesday as investors and analysts continued to focus on subscriber losses at ESPN. Shares of Disney closed down 3.8% Wednesday. Here are five takeaways from Iger's sometimes exasperated comments on ESPN and Disney's plans to adapt to…

Walt Disney’s (DIS) first-quarter results trounced expectations as “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” boosted the studio and consumer products segments, though the media and entertainment giant continued to lose subscribers for its cable channels.But Disney CEO Robert Iger said Tuesday that ESPN, which lost 7 million subscribers in the last two years, has “actually seen an uptick” in subscribers in recent months, and has benefited from the growth of light cable packages, particularly from Dish (DISH).In what amounted to a vigorous defense of ESPN during a conference call, Iger said skinny bundles with the sports cable channel had even wooed cord cutters back. The idea that ESPN is cratering is “ridiculous,” he said. “Sports is too popular.”Disney shares fell 3% late.Iger also clarified the reason behind ESPN’s subscriber decline, blaming faulty Nielsen figures. Once Nielsen corrected those numbers, “we concluded that our sub loss was largely due to the fact that ESPN was not part of skinny bundles that had launched,” he said.He said Disney is exploring “new platform providers,” hinting at more over-the-top, or streaming, options for ESPN.Revenue from Disney’s media networks division, which includes ESPN, grew 8% in fiscal Q1. The segment logged higher ad revenue, offset by lower ratings. Higher programming costs weighed on the sports cable channel, due to the timing of the College Football Playoff bowl games, but that was partially offset by an increase in ad and affiliate revenue, said the company."Affiliate revenue growth was due to contractual rate increases, partially offset by a decline in subscribers and unfavorable foreign currency translation impacts," Disney said in a statement.The hubbub over ESPN comes amid industry-wide concerns that cable viewers are taking their dollars elsewhere — namely, to Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN) Prime and other over-the-top streaming services.During the quarter, adjusted earnings climbed 28% to $1.63 a share, well above views for $1.45 per share. Revenue grew 14% to $15.24 billion vs. consensus estimates for $14.75 billion.“Driven by the phenomenal success of ‘Star Wars,’ we delivered the highest quarterly earnings in the history of our company, marking our 10th consecutive quarter of double-digit EPS growth,” said Iger in a statement.“The Force Awakens” crossed the $2 billion threshold in global box office sales over the weekend. Studio revenue skyrocketed 46%, year over year.Disney’s theme park and resorts segment revenue rose 9%, said the company. Consumer products and interactive media revenue rose 8%.Earlier Tuesday, Viacom (VIAB) shares tanked 21.5% after the media company logged its fourth consecutive quarter of revenue declines and Q1 revenue fell short of expectations.Earnings fell 8.5% to $1.18, in line with consensus estimates, as sales fell 6% to $3.15 billion, below analysts’ forecasts for $3.26 billion.Viacom's filmed entertainment revenue tumbled 15% on theatrical and home-entertainment revenue declines. Media-networks revenue fell 3% as domestic ad revenue dropped 4% and ratings declined.

Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) Prime Video may be top concerns for traditional media, but ESPN President John Skipper isn't too worried about cord cutters or stock fluctuations. Shares of media giants tumbled last summer after Walt Disney (DIS) logged fewer ESPN subscribers and cut its cable profit outlook. Disney's stock still hasn't fully recovered from the melee, and is…

How good a deal AT&T (T) will get if it sells satellite broadcaster DirecTV's Latin American pay-TV business for $10 billion depends in part on whether its assets in Mexico are included, says a BTIG analyst. Spain-based Telefonica (TEF), one on Latin America's biggest wireless phone companies along with America Movil (AMX), could buy DirecTV's business in the region for…

Nivalis Therapeutics (NVLS) stock rose on its first day of trading Wednesday in an IPO that raised $77 million for the biotech company. Nivalis is a clinical stage pharmaceutical company focused on the development and commercialization of small molecule therapeutics for patients with cystic fibrosis. Nivalis priced 5.5 million shares at 14, the midpoint of its estimated price range. The…

T-Mobile US parent Deutsche Telekom says it would consider any partner to improve returns for T-Mobile US (TMUS), but says it's under no pressure to do any near-term deal. While T-Mobile and satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) have publicly praised each other, many analysts still contend a merger with Sprint (S) makes the most strategic sense for T-Mobile. A…

Will Apple's  (AAPL) premium pricing strategy carry over into an Internet TV service? Will Apple compete on price vs. other emerging over-the-top (OTT) services, or will consumers pay more for Apple TV, ostensibly for a better "user experience"? Those are questions analysts are asking ahead of Apple's expected launch of a subscription Internet TV service. An announcement could come…

Verizon Communications (VZ) should buy satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network next, after AOL, says Citigroup in a research report. Verizon on Tuesday announced it agreed to buy AOL (AOL) in a deal valued at $4.4 billion. Verizon has touted plans to stream video to mobile devices, and AOL's advertising technology will help boost wireless revenue, analysts say. Verizon could launch…

Time Warner (TWX), which spun off its cable TV business in 2009, has a beef with Charter Communications'  (CHTR) proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable. Time Warner told the Federal Communications Commission in a regulatory filing that the push into online streaming by its cable channel HBO could be impacted by Charter's purchase of Time Warner Cable (TWC). According…

Viacom's programming contract renewal with Dish Network (DISH) looms as a major event not only for the content provider and satellite TV broadcaster but also for other pay TV and media companies, says Pacific Crest Securities in a report. Investors have been down on both stocks. Shares in Dish Network fell 22% in 2015 while Viacom's  (VIA) stock plunged…
Dish Networks' (DISH) Sling Internet video service will reach 2 million subscribers by year-end, estimates Goldman Sachs, offsetting customer losses in its core satellite TV business.

Apple (AAPL) has reportedly shelved its Web TV streaming service because of stalled talks with content providers. If Apple stays on the sidelines, Dish's Sling service could emerge as the leading OTT (over-the-top) service, assuming Goldman Sachs' estimate proves right. Some analysts, though, expect Apple to restart talks with media firms in 2016, leading to the introduction of its own OTT service.

Dish Network did not update Sling's subscriber base when reporting September-quarter earnings. Sling had 240,000 subscribers as of June 30. Some analysts have estimated Sling had as many as 500,000 subscribers by Sept. 30, with other estimates as low as 300,000.
Goldman Sachs analyst Brett Feldman, in a research report Thursday, estimated Sling had 346,000 subscribers "exiting Q3."
"We expect DISH to end 2016 with more than 2 million Sling TV subscribers," he wrote.
Feldman estimates Dish Network will lose 724,000 satellite TV subscribers in 2016, up from an estimated 543,000 loss last year.

The Sling streaming service, which starts at $20 monthly for 23 channels, targets "cord nevers" — young adults who have shunned pay TV. Dish did not include the four major broadcast networks, opting instead to go with Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN and some cable TV channels, mainly from AMC Networks (AMCX)and Time Warner (TWX).
Apple, in contrast, has reportedly been focused on a live TV service.

At the recent Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Dish Network strutted out changes to the Sling app, which now features an "on now" selection of programming and easier access to popular content, said Advertising Age.
Dish Networks' stock has continued its slide in early 2016. Shares in the satellite TV broadcaster are down 34% from February, 2015. The stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 56.

Dish did not include the four major broadcast networks, opting instead to go with Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN and some cable TV channels, mainly from AMC Networks (AMCX)and Time Warner (TWX).Apple, in contrast, has reportedly been focused on a live TV service.At the recent Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Dish Network strutted out changes to the Sling app, which now features an "on now" selection of programming and easier access to popular content, said Advertising Age.Dish Networks' stock has continued its slide in early 2016. Shares in the satellite TV broadcaster are down 34% from February, 2015. The stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 56.Follow Reinhardt Krause on Twitter @IBD_RKrause

Is digital currency bitcoin in Netflix's (NFLX) future as the Internet video streamer goes global? Netflix on Jan. 6 announced its expansion to 130 new countries, bringing its total to 190 countries worldwide. The same day, CFO David Wells brought up Bitcoin during a Q&A at a Citigroup investor conference in Las Vegas.Satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), Dell, Expedia (EXPE) and Overstock.com (OSTK) are among U.S. companies that accept bitcoin in transactions.Netflix, meanwhile, faces challenges as it expands its video streaming service globally. Acquiring content rights is a biggie, but payments and pricing are other issues. Netflix plans to roll out its service in China later this year.Netflix accepts payments in some local currencies, Wells noted at the Citigroup conference. The Netflix CFO says Netflix has aimed to keep pricing comparable to the U.S., where its service starts at $8 monthly.Wells says it's possible that Netflix may offer wireless-only subscriptions in some countries where mobile broadband is actually faster than fixed-line Internet services.Wells says Netflix aims to keep its log-in procedure and payment systems as simple as possible as it expands to more countries."The world in general from an e-commerce perspective is balancing security and fraud detection with friction-less sign-up," Wells said.Bitcoin, a decentralized, peer-to-peer, digital-payment network, is not designed for recurring payments and the digital currency is non-refundable. Still, it may work better in the future with payment systems such as PayPal (PYPL), some analysts say."You have to authenticate, you have to make sure you have the right person, the right bank account, but you don't want to run people through a 20-step process, because that's not going to work," Wells added.Wells has learned from rolling out its service in markets such as Mexico, Brazil and parts of Europe, he says."Payments are becoming more of a global world," said the CFO. "You still have central banks. We'll see where we go from here in the next 10, 15 years. Countries still want to hold onto their monetary policy. But, it sure would be nice to have bitcoin in terms of a global currency that you could use globally."Follow Reinhardt Krause on Twitter @IBD_RKrause.

On the Nasdaq, 1,200 stocks and exchange traded funds triggered five-minute "circuit breaker" trading stops during the session. At the time, CNN…

Father Time is handing over the reins to Baby New Year, and top executives at Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Dish Network (DISH), Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Salesforce.com (CRM) sold or surrendered their companies' shares as the final hours of 2015 ticked down.Alphabet Chief Executive Officer Larry Page on Monday informed the Securities and Exchange Commission of the sale of 16,670 shares for $12.9 million. Other Alphabet executives had similar notions this week. On Tuesday, Chief Financial Officer Ruth Porat disclosed the surrender of 4,839 shares worth $3.6 million. Sundar Pichai, CEO of Alphabet subsidiary Google, on Wednesday disclosed the surrender of 13,655 shares worth $10.2 million.The Mountain View, Calif.-based search engine giant is finishing the year on a positive note, with shares climbing 1% to close at 778.01 for the week. Alphabet has been trading near all-time highs, steadily above its 50-day average. Its Google subsidiary reportedly is in talks with Ford Motor (F) about developing self-driving cars. Autonomous driving is likely to be a big topic at the upcoming Consumer Electronics Show.Salesforce.com founder, chairman and CEO Marc Benioff on Wednesday informed the SEC about the planned sale of 37,500 shares for nearly $3 million. Keith Block, the company's vice chairman and president, on Monday announced the sale of 116,606 shares worth $9.1 million. The San Francisco-based cloud computing company has been trading slightly below record highs, though steadily above its 50-day line. Its stock rose 1% this week to finish at 78.40.This week, Salesforce.com announced that it purchased SteelBrick, a Palo Alto, Calif.-based quote-to-cash software company, for $300 million. SteelBrick's software is primarily aimed at small and midsized businesses.Palo Alto Networks director Jim Goetz on Wednesday announced the sale of 110,700 shares worth $19.5 million. The cybersecurity software company is set to finish 2015 on a down note, as its stock fell 1.1% this week to close at 176.14.Dish Network director David Moskowitz on Wednesday announced the planned sale of 300,000 shares worth $17.4 million. Dish, along with Time Warner Cable (TWC) and AT&T (T) subsidiary DirecTV, reportedly are increasing their rates in the new year. Dish Network shares fell 1.8% this week, closing at 57.18.Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) Vice President Douglas McCorkle on Tuesday disclosed the planned sale of 3,954 shares worth $2.2 million. Tarrytown, N.Y.-based Regeneron's stock rose 1.2% this week, finishing at 542.87.Celgene (CELG) director Ernest Mario on Wednesday informed the SEC of the sale of 40,000 shares worth $4.8 million. On Monday, Michael Casey, a Celgene director, disclosed that he had sold 20,000 shares worth $2.4 million. The company's stock is off 0.6% this week after last week's Christmas gift: the settlement of a lengthy patent dispute over its blockbuster blood-cancer drug Revlimid with Natco, an Indian company that wanted to market a generic version of the drug.Nike (NKE) President of Product and Merchandising Jeanne Jackson on Wednesday disclosed that she had sold 25,000 Nike shares worth $1.6 million. The Beaverton, Ore.-based athletic apparel giant's shares slipped 1.1% this week to close at 62.50.Boston Beer (SAM) co-founder and chairman Jim Koch on Tuesday disclosed the planned sale of 5,000 shares worth $1 million. The brewer of Sam Adams Lager has had a not-so-sudsy week, as its shares fell 1.3% to close at 201.91. The company has had a bit of a hangover of late, its stock steadily trading below its 50-day moving average, which fell below its 200-day line in June.Insider transactions don't typically have a major impact on a stock or indicate major pending news. Rapid liquidation of all or most of an insider's holdings, however, can affect a stock.
Dish Network (DISH) early Monday said it had a net loss of 134,000 subscribers in Q1, but earnings beat analyst views as contract disputes with content providers shaved programming costs.
Dish said it earned 76 cents per share in Q1 as revenue rose 3.6% to $3.72 billion, missing estimates. Analysts had modeled EPS of 40 cents and revenue of $3.74 billion.
While programming interruptions might have angered customers, Dish spent less on content than expected. Dish's contract dispute with 21st Century Fox (FOXA) ended in mid-January.
Dish Network edged down a fraction in early trading in the stock market today, near 67.
Net income nearly doubled to $351 million from $176 million in the year-earlier period, the company said.

Dish had added 40,000 video customers in Q1 2014. Dish had 13.84 million pay-TV customers as of March 31, down slightly from a year earlier. On Tuesday, DirecTV (DTV) reported a net add of 60,000 U.S. subscribers in Q1, up from 12,000 additions in the year-earlier period.
Dish said average revenue per monthly pay-TV subscriber edged up in Q1 to $86 from $82.36 in Q1 2014.

In its earnings release, Dish did not disclose the number of Sling TV online customers it signed up in the period. Dish Network launched its Sling TV Internet video service in January, and Sony (SNE) also started an OTT video service last quarter. Apple (AAPL) reportedly is ramping up a service of its own.

Dish Network stock weakened after the satellite TV broadcaster reported Q1 earnings results. Some analysts question CEO Charlie Ergen's strategy of amassing radio spectrum with no apparent buyers of those airwaves, or a strategic wireless partner, in sight.
Federal regulators are probing Dish Network's tactics in a recent U.S. radio spectrum auction, including $3 billion in discounts won by using bidding partners.

"The now-settled carriage dispute with Fox continued to impact Dish operating performance into the first quarter, pressuring subscriber trends, but boosted EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) on lower costs," Jefferies analyst Mike McCormack said in a research report. "We believe today's results are unlikely to shift investor focus away from the AWS-3 regulatory process, the ultimate outcome of DISH's spectrum, and M&A potential in the space."Dish Network (DISH) early Monday said it had a net loss of 134,000 subscribers in Q1, but earnings beat analyst views as contract disputes with content providers shaved programming costs.Dish said it earned 76 cents per share in Q1 as revenue rose 3.6% to $3.72 billion, missing estimates. Dish Network's  (DISH) Q1 earnings are expected to rise 5% as analysts await co-founder and once-again CEO Charlie Ergen's latest views on trends in the pay-TV, online video and wireless markets on the company's earnings conference call. Dish Network reports before the open Monday. Dish Network stock has dropped about 15% since the satellite TV broadcaster reported Q4 results…

Setting aside more radio spectrum for Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) in an upcoming government auction of airwaves for wireless services could endanger a successful auction, says consulting firm Recon Analytics.The Federal Communications Commission risks rattling TV broadcasters, who would sell spectrum in the auction, by creating rules that prevent AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) from bidding on a large chunk of the airwaves, says Roger Entner, founder and lead analyst of Recon."The fewer the restrictions, the smaller the set-asides, the more revenue will be generated during the auction," Entner said. "This is a particularly important consideration for the incentive auction where the demands of the broadcasters will have to be met before the U.S. treasury will get its cut."Both Sprint and T-Mobile have enough spectrum on a per-subscriber basis, weakening their case for government policy that would tilt auction rules in the favor, said Entner in a blog post Thursday."Perhaps a better idea than giving more spectrum to T-Mobile and Sprint at a discount would be to make 20 MHz available for small rural operators," he wrote.T-Mobile US, controlled by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), and Sprint, owned by Japan's SoftBank, are pushing the FCC to set aside more spectrum for smaller wireless firms in the Broadcast Incentive Auction. The FCC has reserved for smaller firms 30 MHz of the expected 70-80 MHz of airwaves expected to be auctioned.T-Mobile, Sprint and some consumer groups are seeking 40 MHz instead of 30."One should not be fooled into thinking that T-Mobile and Sprint are weak sisters who would not otherwise be able to compete," said Entner.AT&T and Verizon spent nearly $29 billion combined in the AWS-3 auction that ended in January. AWS-3 raised nearly $45 billion. Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) also was a major buyer.Goldman Sachs recently estimated that the big four U.S. wireless firms and Dish Network own spectrum cumulatively valued at $368 billion.

Time magazine has singled out White House strategist Steve Bannon for its Darth Vader cover treatment. Shown is a picture of Bannon looking like a Marvel Comics villain and the title "The Great Manipulator." Bannon dared to identify the liberal media as "the opposition party." Time took offense and demonstrably proved him right.Demonizing the president's aides is something Time and its liberal ilk have not done to Democrats since the days of President Jimmy Carter, when Time was liberal but not nearly as leftist as it is today. At this point eight years ago, the same magazine was profiling President Obama's aide Larry Summers as the "brash and brilliant economic advisor," the "economic wunderkind ... moving at flank speed" who speaks with "an almost poetic clarity."Obama was always center stage. No evil wizard manipulated him from behind the curtains. That only happens under apparently "manipulated" dolts like President Reagan, President George W. Bush and now, President Trump.The new article is headlined "The second most powerful man in the world? Steve Bannon has the President's ear. But he wants more." For Trump, Bannon is "a director who deploys ravenous sharks, shrieking tornadoes and mushroom clouds as reliably as John Ford shot Monument Valley."Decades ago, Time shredded the notion that it is a news magazine, steadily becoming evermore politicized. It's a badly disguised journal of rampaging liberal opinion. But it is a stubborn pretender. It insists that its brand of liberal advocacy passes as acceptably objective inside today's news business, and it's right, of course.Time managing editor Nancy Gibbs unfurled a nasty gram at Bannon in her "From the Editor" letter up front. She cited Bannon's "opposition party" comment and then spat, "To demonize the press, to characterize it as not just mistaken but malign, is to lay the groundwork for repression."These people dish out criticism, but wow, are they incapable of taking it. Criticize Trump, and you are Honorable Dissent. Criticize the media, and you are Nazi Dictatorship.Gibbs thinks her magazine is serenely centrist and objective, which makes her a fool. Lest anyone take offense, consider the alternative: If not a fool, she'd be a raging liar. She boasts: "At a time when the media is ever more fractured and siloed, and much of it partisan on both sides, TIME is one of the few remaining institutions that speaks to a broad and global audience. ... Our purpose is not to tell people what to think; it is to help them decide what to think about."Someone should please make an appointment to meet with Ms. Gibbs for two minutes and simply show her the Time cover of Trump's face melting, and the cover of Trump's face melting into a puddle. Is one not to conclude a wee bit of hostility toward Trump? How traumatically gullible does Time think America is?This kind of bloviation is especially nonsensical coming from Gibbs. Take her valentine to Obama after his first victory. She placed him on par with Christ, saying: "Some princes are born in palaces. Some are born in mangers. But a few are born in the imagination, out of scraps of history and hope." What a bottle of ipecac.Then there's Gibbs on President Bill Clinton during the Monicagate scandal. She said: "In the gaudy mansion of Clinton's mind there are many rooms with heavy doors, workrooms and playrooms, rooms stuffed with trophies, rooms to stash scandals and regrets. He walks lightly amid the ironies of his talents and behavior, just by consigning them to different cubbies of his brain. It's an almost scary mind, that of a multitasking wizard."Put a cork in it. The jig has been up for 30 years. No one's buying the outraged protests of nonpartisanship. What Time is claiming to be news is the very definition of fake news.Bozell is the president of the Media Research Center. Graham is director of media analysis at the Media Research Center and executive editor of the blog NewsBusters.org.RELATED:The Real 'Fake News' Comes From The Mainstream MediaMedia Misreport Gallup Poll Results About Trump's AbilitiesGot Fake News? Biased Press Continues To Misinform Public About Trump

Akamai Technologies' (AKAM) network security business is expected to be a bright spot when the company reports Q4 earnings after the market close Tuesday.Akamai's earnings per share minus items in the December quarter are expected to fall 5% year over year to 68 cents, with revenue rising 4.5% to $605 million.In the current quarter, analysts are modeling 1% EPS growth to 67 cents and revenue climbing 6.5% to $605 million.Akamai is the biggest provider of content delivery network, or CDN, services, which increase the speed of e-commerce transactions, business software downloads and video streaming to mobile devices.Several big customers, including Apple (AAPL) and Facebook (FB), have shifted some of their traffic to internal networks, slowing Akamai's revenue growth. Akamai stock jumped nearly 27% in 2016 just the same.Akamai stock remains near a buy zone after breaking out of a cup-with-handle at a 69.36 buy point a month ago. Shares rose 0.23% to 69.71 in the stock market today. It's trading just above its 50-day moving average, last week passing a couple tests of that line.IBD'S TAKE: While revenue growth is harder to come by for Akamai these days, the IBD 50 roster of growth stocks includes fast-growing Nvidia, GrubHub and Netease. Mark Mahaney, an analyst at RBC Capital, estimates that Akamai's security business revenue rose 46% in Q4 to $106 million. "Security is becoming an increasingly meaningful part of the financial story, accounting for 16% of revenue in Q3," said Mahaney in a research report.Akamai in December bought Cyberfend for an undisclosed amount, continuing its acquisitions of computer security firms."Concern over whether additional top media customers will migrate off Akamai remains a potential future overhang on the stock," added Mahaney.Akamai's top six internet platform accounts (Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple, Facebook, Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), and Netflix (NFLX) accounted for 10% of its revenue in Q3, down from 17% in the year-earlier quarter, analysts say.AT&T (T) launched its DirecTV Now video streaming service in late November."We believe Akamai has been serving as the primary CDN provider for Direct TV Now, although we are admittedly unsure on how much revenue Akamai has generated from it," said Colby Synesael, a Cowen & Co. analyst, in a report.RELATED:Akamai Security Business Shines, Offsets Apple, Facebook ShiftDish Network Taps Netflix As Streaming Battle Heats UpWill The Launch Of AT&T DirecTV Now Herald Net Neutrality's End?

Shares of T-Mobile US (TMUS) hit an all-time high as analysts speculated that T-Mobile looks like the "big winner" in a government spectrum auction, putting the Un-carrier branded wireless services provider in a better position if M&A talks heat up in the spring.T-Mobile stock rose 2.4% to 60.07 on the stock market today, earlier rising as high as 60.64. New Street Research on Monday said Sprint (S)-owner SoftBank could be readying a "knockout" offer for T-Mobile that would include a sizable cash portion.Sprint stock jumped 2.6% Thursday to 8.96, earlier rising above 9 for the first time since June 2014.'The auction results are likely a positive but I think the (T-Mobile stock) move is due to M&A speculation that the end of the auction combined with the new administration and (SoftBank CEO Masayoshi) Son's trips to Trump Tower all add up to Sprint taking another run at T-Mobile," UBS analyst John Hodulik told IBD.IBD'S TAKE: T-Mobile stock jumped in late 2016 on speculation that it could merge with Sprint during a Trump administration. Comcast stock also is trading near an all-time high. Learn more about T-Mobile and Comcast at IBD Stock Checkup.Goldman Sachs analyst Brett Feldman, in a research report Tuesday, called T-Mobile the likely "big winner" in the government's auction of radio spectrum of airwaves controlled by TV broadcasters. T-Mobile likely gained the spectrum it needed at a lower price than estimated, he said.HSBC, meanwhile, upgraded Comcast (CMCSA)and Verizon Communications (VZ)to buy and initiated coverage on Charter Communications (CHTR) with a hold rating.Comcast has also been viewed as a possible suitor for T-Mobile, which is controlled by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY).Comcast stock, which on Friday hit a record high just under 73, edged up a fraction Thursday to 72.61. It's extended from its November breakout at a buy point of 68.46.The Federal Communications Commission's auction of airwaves brought in about $18.2 billion in bids, more than the latest $10 billion asking price of TV broadcasters. Broadcasters stand to get their $10 billion, while other proceeds will cover costs tied to "repacking" the spectrum for wireless services or go to the U.S. treasury.T-Mobile had estimated it could spend $8 to $10 billion in the auction alone. Analysts expect that Verizon and AT&T (T) bid less than forecast. One hitch for T-Mobile is that the TV spectrum might not be ready for wireless services until 2020.Bidders were barred from taking part in strategic talks until the auction closes, which BTIG Research analyst Walter Piecyk says could be in late February. Telecom firms may be free to resume M&A talks by mid-March, he says. Goldman Sachs says the FCC's quiet period might not be over until the end of March."With the close of the auction, attention should quickly turn to M&A, which has largely been prohibited during the auction, for registered participants," Jefferies analyst Mike McCormack said in a research report. "We expect investors to focus on Sprint, T-Mobile, and Dish Network (DISH) as targets, with Comcast, Charter, and Verizon viewed as potential acquirers."Dish stock rose 0.54% Thursday to 61.68, near a 13-month high of 62.97 touched on Friday.RELATED:Cash Key In SoftBank-Sprint 'Knockout' Offer For T-Mobile?Would T-Mobile Spurn Debt-Laden Sprint For Comcast Offer?Verizon M&A Talk Swirls; Charter Stock Up, Yahoo Down

Sprint (S)-owner SoftBank Group could muster a knockout offer for T-Mobile US (TMUS) that would thwart any counter bid by cable TV firms such as Comcast (CMCSA), says New Street Research.Jonathan Chaplin, an analyst at U.K.-based New Street Research, says debt-laden SoftBank would need to pump a lot of cash into any Sprint offer for T-Mobile to get a controlling stake in a merged company.T-Mobile, which is majority owned by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), has a market valuation of $48 billion after a steep runup in 2016. T-Mobile shareholders would expect a premium, with bids by satellite TV firm Dish Network, cable companies or perhaps even a cable-consortium possible, New Street said in a research report published Sunday.In a "knockout" scenario, Sprint could offer about $47 billion in cash and $22 billion in equity, for a combined $69 billion, not including deal synergies, says Chaplin."In this scenario, we assume an offer price of $80 per share," said Chaplin in a report. "We would consider this a knockout bid; it would be tough for a cable company, Dish Network (DISH) or some other interloper to table a more compelling offer."IBD'S TAKE: T-Mobile stock jumped in late 2016 on speculation that it could merge with Sprint during a Trump administration. But short interest in T-Mobile doubled in December. Learn more about T-Mobile at IBD Stock CheckupJapan-based SoftBank seems to be setting the stage for another run at merging Sprint with T-Mobile US. In meeting with President-elect Donald Trump last month, SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son has promised to up U.S. investments and create jobs.Mergers between cable TV and wireless companies has picked up in Europe, and Deutsche Telekom might prefer Comcast as a suitor for T-Mobile, some analysts say. The deals are aimed at creating multiproduct bundles and network synergies.Media baron John Malone last week said Comcast, Charter Communications (CHTR) and other cable TV firms could bid successfully for T-Mobile.SoftBank owns 83% of Sprint, while Deutsche Telekom owns two-thirds of T-Mobile.T-Mobile has openly courted cable TV partners on its earnings calls. But amid intensified wireless competition, the most profit-margin-friendly deal remains a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile, many analysts say.Such a deal, though, would reduce the number of national wireless firms from four to three. The Obama administration blocked AT&T's (T) proposed acquisition of T-Mobile in 2011, saying it wanted to retain a four-player national market of AT&T, Sprint, T-Mobile and Verizon Communications (VZ).Chaplin speculates that a combined Sprint and T-Mobile would sell off some 50 MHz of spectrum to garner regulatory approval as well as raise cash.Sprint stock edged up 4 cents in the stock market today to 8.65. The company's market cap is $34 billion. T-Mobile stock fell 14 cents to 57.05.RELATED:Would T-Mobile Spurn Debt-Laden Sprint For Comcast Offer?Verizon M&A Talk Swirls; Charter Stock Up, Yahoo Down

AT&T, which acquired satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group in July, on Wednesday announced a seven-year license renewal for Rovi's interactive program guide technology. The AT&T renewal bodes well for upcoming negotiations with Comcast (CMCSA)…

Sprint and T-Mobile US (TMUS) are likely to rekindle merger talks before they entertain other deals with a cable TV company, satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network or a foreign entrant to the U.S. wireless market, speculates Bernstein Research in a report. Sprint (S) shelved negotiations with T-Mobile in mid-2014 after the Obama administration made clear that it wanted a U.S.…
Dish Network (DISH) reorganized top management, with co-founder Charlie Ergen, who returned as the satellite TV broadcaster's CEO in February, giving up the position of company president.
Dish Network named Erik Carlson president and chief operating officer. Carlson had been executive vice president of operations.
Bernie Han, who had been COO, was named executive vice president of strategic planning.
In addition, Dish Network appointed Vivek Khemka to executive vice president and chief technology officer. And the company named Warren Schlichting EVP of marketing, programming and media sales.
Observers speculate Dish will restructure and spin off its wireless spectrum assets.
On Dish Network's Q3 earnings conference call, Ergen said there are potential scenarios where "corporate structures could change."

Among Dish Network's options, analysts say, are spinning off its spectrum holdings into a separate company that would lease airwaves to wireless firms, possibly Verizon Communications (VZ) or T-Mobile US (TMUS).
Dish Network has amassed 80 MHz of radio spectrum, but has yet to forge a partnership with a wireless service provider. T-Mobile and Verizon have loomed as the most likely partners.
The Federal Communications Commission plans to hold its next spectrum auction in March. Companies that file as bidders will not be allowed to interact until that auction ends.
Dish Network has about 14 million pay-TV subscribers.
Dish Network stock was down a fraction in early trading in the stock market today, near 60. Shares touched a record high of 80.75 on Feb. 23.

The stock market pressed on with its rebound in afternoon trading Friday. The Nasdaq led with a 0.2% gain, after wiping away an early loss of as much as 0.7%. The S&P 500 was flat after it also erased a sizable drop, but remained below its 50-day moving average.

The Dow Jones industrial average lagged, as Verizon (VZ) continued its sell-off with a 2% slide. The telecom has been sliding since Thursday on talk of a merger between T-Mobile (TMUS) and Dish Network (DISH).
The combination would create a strong rival to Verizon, AT&T (T) and Sprint (S).
Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.
Among breakouts in the stock market today, CarMax (KMX) topped the 73.30 buy point of a cup-with-handle base. But volume was well below average, which makes the otherwise bullish move look suspect.

Luxoft Holdings (LXFT) rallied 4% and cleared a cup-shaped base with a 57.40 buy point. Volume was tracking nearly double the stock's average. The business software company's fundamentals were strong enough to put the stock in IBD's Sector Leaders screen earlier this year. It is not on the current screen, though.The stock market pressed on with its rebound in afternoon trading Friday. The Nasdaq led with a 0.2% gain, after wiping away an early loss of as much as 0.7%. The S&P 500 was flat after it also erased a sizable drop, but remained below its 50-day moving average.The Dow Jones industrial average lagged, as Verizon (VZ) continued its sell-off with a 2% slide. The telecom has been sliding since Thursday on talk of a merger between T-Mobile (TMUS) and Dish Network (DISH).The combination would create a strong rival to Verizon, AT&T (T) and Sprint (S).Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.Among breakouts in the stock market today, CarMax (KMX) topped the 73.30 buy point of a cup-with-handle base. But volume was well below average, which makes the otherwise bullish move look suspect.Luxoft Holdings (LXFT) rallied 4% and cleared a cup-shaped base with a 57.40 buy point. Volume was tracking nearly double the stock's average. The business software company's fundamentals were strong enough to put the stock in IBD's Sector Leaders screen earlier this year. It is not on the current screen, though.

For the first time ever, the U.S. pay-television industry lost customers in the traditionally strong first-quarter, highlighting the difficulties subscription-based TV providers face amid an Internet onslaught from Netflix (NFLX), Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV, Hulu and others, with Apple (AAPL) and others possible players down the road. Pay-TV lost a net 31,000 customers in Q1 and has an annual…

An Apple (AAPL) TV service will likely feature dynamic ad insertion technology based on viewing data that provides upside for media and entertainment companies that partner with Apple, speculates Pacific Crest Securities in a research report.

Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE) this year launched new OTT (over-the-top) Internet video services. The services are dubbed OTT products because they piggyback landline broadband services sold by other companies.
Apple has been widely expected to join them this year or next. Pacific Crest says this year.
Companies are racing to acquire ad technology as consumer viewing habits shift to mobile and on-demand platforms.

Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy AOL (AOL) on Tuesday for $4.4 billion. The acquisition will give Verizon key advertising technology as well as content to offer on its mobile video platform, analysts said.

Pacific Crest analyst Andy Hargreaves does not expect Apple to sell new consumer hardware as part of the TV service launch. Nor does Hargreaves expect a significant EPS lift for Apple from a TV service, at least not in the near term.
Hargreaves says media firms that would get a boost from Apple paying higher programming fees include Time Warner Cable (TWC), Walt Disney (DIS), CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA).
He called an Apple TV service "disruptive" to the pay-TV ecosystems of Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR) and other cable TV firms.

"We expect Apple to provide detailed viewing data directly to (cable) network owners ... in addition to collecting data, Apple's service should be able to provide dynamic ad inventory in content that is live, served on-demand, or recorded by the consumer," he wrote. "At the moment, network owners do not get paid for advertising that is recorded and watched outside of the Nielsen-rated three- or seven-day windows. An Apple service should be able to serve ads based on the viewer, content and time of viewing regardless of whether the viewing is done live.

"We expect the service to be a medium-sized bundle of traditional linear networks with significant stacking rights and a heavy emphasis on on-demand viewing, likely with a base price around $40 or $50 per month. We believe Apple will market based on a superior consumer experience, which, if executed well, is likely to be much more disruptive than a 'skinny bundle' (with fewer channels)."

Dish Network CEO, Charlie Ergen, on the company's Q1 earnings call Monday, forecast "meaningful" revenue from its skinny, $20 monthly OTT service call Sling TV, as IBD reported.An Apple (AAPL) TV service will likely feature dynamic ad insertion technology based on viewing data that provides upside for media and entertainment companies that partner with Apple, speculates Pacific Crest Securities in a research report.Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE) this year launched new OTT (over-the-top) Internet video services. The services are dubbed OTT products because they piggyback landline broadband services sold by other companies.Apple has been widely expected to join them this year or next. Pacific Crest says this year.Companies are racing to acquire ad technology as consumer viewing habits shift to mobile and on-demand platforms.Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy AOL (AOL) on Tuesday for $4.4 billion. The acquisition will give Verizon key advertising technology as well as content to offer on its mobile video platform, analysts said.Pacific Crest analyst Andy Hargreaves does not expect Apple to sell new consumer hardware as part of the TV service launch. Nor does Hargreaves expect a significant EPS lift for Apple from a TV service, at least not in the near term.Hargreaves says media firms that would get a boost from Apple paying higher programming fees include Time Warner Cable (TWC), Walt Disney (DIS), CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA).He called an Apple TV service "disruptive" to the pay-TV ecosystems of Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR) and other cable TV firms."We expect Apple to provide detailed viewing data directly to (cable) network owners ... in addition to collecting data, Apple's service should be able to provide dynamic ad inventory in content that is live, served on-demand, or recorded by the consumer," he wrote.
