The Federal Communications Commission in April thwarted Comcast's  (CMCSA) proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable. FCC general counsel Jon Sallet last month said the Comcast-TWC deal could have slowed the growth of online…

Dish Network (DISH) has no big deals pending and is more likely to sell its wireless spectrum on a fully taxable basis down the road, lowering profits, says Goldman Sachs, which took the satellite-TV broadcaster off its stock "conviction list" on Tuesday.Goldman analyst Brett Feldman maintained a buy rating on Dish Network stock, but he slashed his price target to 77 from 108.Dish has cobbled together 80 MHz of spectrum that it has yet to use, as it looks for a wireless partner in order to offer mobile video services."We are assuming that it will be at least two years before Dish could execute a transaction that unlocks the value of its spectrum licenses," Feldman wrote in a research report.Verizon Communications (VZ) has stated it is not interested in acquiring the satellite-TV broadcaster outright, including its core pay-TV business. But Verizon has the least spectrum per-subscriber among the nation's four national wireless firms, behind AT&T (T), T-Mobile US and Sprint (S).Verizon, though, could acquire more spectrum if it wins rights to the FirstNet public safety network build-out.The FCC plans to hold the TV "Broadcast Incentive Auction" in March 2016. That auction involves airwaves in the 600 MHz frequency block now used by local TV stations.The FCC will impose a "quiet period" that bans negotiations over spectrum, which will likely start at the end of 2015 and extend until the auction is over."Based on the complex nature of the incentive auction, an anti-collusion period could extend through most of next year, if not into early 2017," Feldman said.Dish Network is more likely to sell its spectrum rather than be acquired, he says."We are assuming that Dish locks-in the value of its licenses by selling them at our estimated value of $50.6 billion, but realizes net proceeds of $37.3 billion after paying taxes on a gain from the sale," Feldman wrote.Speculation over a Dish Network acquisition of T-Mobile (TMUS) has cooled.Dish stock was flat in midday trading in the stock market today, near 62.50. Dish stock touched a record high above 80 in February.Follow Reinhardt Krause on Twitter @IBD_RKrause.

AT&T (T) and CenturyLink (CTL) are vulnerable to further broadband market share losses vs. Comcast and other cable TV firms, says Morgan Stanley, based on customer dissatisfaction in areas where copper-based DSL broadband service is available.While cable TV firms — including Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR), Time Warner Cable (TWC) and privately held Cox Communications — already dominate the broadband market, there's still upside for them, Benjamin Swinburne, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said in a research report.Swinburne says that cable TV firms should also target the pay TV customers of satellite broadcasters DirecTV Group and Dish Network (DISH), which currently resell DSL services from phone companies. Morgan Stanley surveyed 2,500 U.S. households during August and September on broadband and TV services."U-verse and AT&T DSL had especially weak satisfaction results, and satellite pay-TV subscribers' broadband satisfaction fell materially year over year," said the Morgan Stanley report. "For cable broadband, satellite TV households remain an opportunity."Cable customers reported an average speed of 38 megabits per second (Mbps), while DSL subscribers said they had 21 Mbps service on average. Verizon Communications (VZ) FiOS customers on average had nearly 30 Mbps service and were happier, despite price hikes, says the Morgan Stanley report.There's also good news in the survey for media firms (Walt Disney (DIS), CBS (CBS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Comcast-NBCUniversal) that own broadcast TV networks ABC, CBS, Fox and NBC."Seventy-five percent of pay-TV respondents ranked the broadcast networks as one of the top three most important channel groups in their bundle. On average, only 25% of total respondents ranked any one cable network group in their top three," said the report.Comcast and Apple (AAPL) are expected to anchor their "skinny" TV bundles, programming packages with fewer channels, likely including the broadcast networks.Follow Reinhardt Krause on Twitter @IBD_RKrause.

Dish Network (DISH) will find a way to make money off its wireless-spectrum licenses, says Deutsche Bank, which initiated coverage on the satellite TV broadcaster with a buy rating, though it says Dish's core business could be pressured by Apple (AAPL). Deutsche analyst Bryan Kraft set a price target of 92 on Dish Network stock. Shares of the company are…

A Verizon Communications (VZ) wireless spectrum deal with Dish Network (DISH) is still possible, analysts say, in the wake of the satellite TV broadcaster's decision to surrender some airwave licenses won at a government auction for rebidding. That's because most of the airwaves surrendered are near spectrum blocks now owned by AT&T (T) and T-Mobile US (TMUS), while Dish Network…

Look for telecom M&A to be on hold until the 2016 conclusion of a government auction of radio spectrum now owned by TV broadcasters, which could raise up to $60 billion if cable TV firms or Google (GOOGL) take part, says Moody's Investors Service. Telecom acquisitions will die down after a busy 2015, in which AT&T (T) acquired DirecTV Group,…

Dish Network (DISH) shareholders should brace themselves for a wireless radio spectrum leasing deal with so-so economics, not an outright sale of the airwaves to the likes of Verizon Communications (VZ), says Barclays.Comments by Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam at last week's Goldman Sachs conference seemed to open the door to renewed talks between the wireless firm and the satellite TV broadcaster over Dish's 80 MHz of radio spectrum, notes Barclays analyst Kannan Venkateshwar in a research report Wednesday.While a wireless firm like Verizon would gain usage rights to spectrum in a leasing deal, Dish would want network access to provide its satellite TV customers with mobile video services. Dish has about 14 million subscribers, but customer losses have plagued its core business."We believe Dish is looking at some form of corporate restructuring with the ultimate intention of monetizing spectrum," wrote Venkateshwar. "Spectrum leasing is the highest probability path, since it allows Dish to monetize the spectrum and retain some optionality (long-term M&A) on the upside. However, we believe that the wholesale leasing deal is unlikely to help the equity value based on the likely underlying economics and scale."Venkateshwar rates Dish stock underweight.Speculation that Dish might be unable to sell its spectrum and could pursue a wholesale leasing deal gained support among analysts in mid-2014 afterAT&T (T) agreed to buy satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group.Verizon has the least spectrum per subscriber among the nation's top four wireless firms and spent only $10 billion in a recent government auction of airwaves. Analysts have also speculated that Verizon might buy a chunk of airwaves from Sprint (S).Dish, meanwhile, has more total spectrum than T-Mobile US (TMUS), which is controlled by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY).

Sprint's decision to stay on the sidelines in the upcoming government auction of radio spectrum now owned by TV broadcasters might be a good development for T-Mobile US (TMUS), though cable TV firms could emerge as bidders, analysts say. In the so-called "Broadcast Incentive Auction" expected to take place next year, the government plans to set aside some 30 megahertz…

Analyst Matthew Harrigan says Dish has been unable to sell its wireless radio spectrum as potential network partners — Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile…

Facebook (FB) shares finished higher after it was initiated at a buy rating Thursday, while Nike was given an upgrade and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was rated a buy.Argus Research started Facebook at buy with an 88 price target, which is below most price targets provided by other analysts. Facebook shares closed up 0.1% to 92.47 on the stock market today after spending much of the session in negative territory.Meanwhile, Thursday news reports said Facebook is testing emojis in place of its iconic "like" buttons to let users share their feelings.Nike shares rose 2.3% after it was upgraded to buy at D.A. Davidson. The athletic apparel giant's stock price touched a new high of 126.49 on Monday. Nike has an excellent IBD Composite Rating of 97, though its revenue growth has slowed to single digits in recent quarters.Burrito chain Chipotle was initiated with a buy rating by SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, which gave the stock an 850 price target. Chipotle shares rose 2% to 734.77 Thursday.Fast-food giant McDonald's (MCD) was initiated at buy with a 117 price by SunTrust Robinson Humphrey. Its stock price rose 1.16% to 102.95 and nearly set a new all-time high intraday.Medical device maker Medtronic (MDT) rose 1.6% after it was upgraded to buy at Evercore ISI Group.Shares of satellite TV company Dish Network (DISH) rose 3.2% after it was initiated at buy with a 92 price target by Deutsche Bank.VeriFone Systems (PAY) gained 4.5% after it was upgraded to strong buy from outperform by Raymond James.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.

Amazon.com (AMZN) could go live with a Web TV streaming service, says a report. "Over the past few months, multiple content owners have told me that Amazon has been quietly asking them about licensing content for a live streaming service," wrote Dan Rayburn, in a blog at website StreamingMedia.com. Amazon Instant Video, operated by Amazon, first offered old TV shows…

Verizon Communications (VZ) CEO Lowell McAdam says the carrier might pursue more digital media acquisitions, though not a major content deal, and he ruled out a near-term sale of its wireline FiOS network.Speaking at a Goldman Sachs conference Thursday, McAdam said "what I want to do is build (our) digital media capabilities. That doesn't necessarily mean content. With commercial relationships like the one we have with Dreamworks, you can deliver the kind of content you need."I don't see us going out and buying network TV, that sort of thing. Digital media, which is the direction we're headed with mobile-first (video), are much smaller companies and wouldn't register in a big way with investors when we purchase them."Verizon rival AT&T (T) in July closed its acquisition of satellite-TV broadcaster DirecTV Group. AT&T also is expanding into Mexico and Latin America.Verizon garners 70% of revenue from wireless services. In 2013, Verizon agreed to buy out Vodafone's (VOD) 45% stake in their Verizon Wireless joint venture for $130 billion.Verizon acquired AOL for $4.4 billion in June. Verizon last year bought Intel's (INTC) online video platform, called OnCue, and in 2013 acquired EdgeCast Networks, a content delivery network.McAdam said Verizon will officially launch its Go90 mobile video service by the end of this month. The former Intel online service supports Go90.Nixes Any Dish AcquisitionMcAdam reiterated that Verizon is not interested in buying Dish Network (DISH) outright, but left the door open to a radio spectrum deal under the right circumstances.Europe telecom Altice Group on Thursday announced a deal to acquire its second U.S. cable TV company in four months, Cablevision Systems (CVC), which competes head-on with Verizon.Citigroup had speculated that Verizon could sell its fixed-line residential business, including FiOS TV and Internet services."I know there's speculation we might be interested in selling the wireline property, but I don't see it in the near term," McAdam said at the Goldman conference. "It's a good asset, returning good returns; it fits with the overall portfolio."If you think about our core business being wireless, having access to those fiber nodes that connect all the cell sites and all the switching is an important aspect."Verizon's acquisitions of AOL and Millennial Media, announced on Sept. 3, put it in competition with Google (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB), which dominate the mobile ad market.Nomura Securities, in an August research report, called Verizon a possible "consolidator" of content companies, along with Liberty Media (LMCA).Former Verizon CEO Ivan Seidenberg, near 45.

Viacom (VIA) stock has been beaten up since Walt Disney (DIS), when reporting earnings, warned about slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees, the payments that media firms garner from pay-TV companies. Federal Communications Commission Chairman Tom Wheeler brought the programming dispute between satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) to a quick end, but the industry's top regulator won't have the same official clout to intervene if Dish and Viacom (VIA) reach an impasse in upcoming negotiations.

The FCC's authority to step in applies only to "retransmission" negotiations involving broadcast signals and not to pure cable TV channel owners such as Viacom, Time Warner (TWX), Discovery (DISCA) and AMC Networks (AMCX), says Guggenheim Partners in a report. Comcast (CMCSA) and Discovery recently hammered out a deal in a closely watched negotiation.
In response to competition from Netflix (NFLX) and complaints over rising monthly bills, pay-TV providers have become tougher negotiators when programming deals with media firms come up for renewal.

The FCC has the authority to step in on matters involving broadcasters such as Walt Disney (DIS) (which owns ABC), CBS (CBS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Sinclair, Nexstar Broadcasting Group (NXST) and Media General (MEG).
Dish Network had asked the FCC to get involved in its dispute with Sinclair.
Dish Network and Sinclair agreed late Wednesday to extend negotiations and suspend a blackout that had prevented more than 5 million Dish customers in 36 states from getting their local stations.
"The FCC will remain vigilant while the negotiations continue," said Wheeler in a statement.
The FCC last intervened in 2013, when CBS and Time Warner Cable (TWC) faced off. TWC paid a price, losing 190,000 subscribers.
Dish Network has had disputes with CBS, 21st Century Fox and Time Warner's Turner Broadcasting unit.
However, a showdown looms with Viacom, say analysts. Viacom has 24 cable channels, usually offered in TV bundles.
A programming contract renewal with Dish Network is "critical" for Viacom, said Deutsche Bank, which last week lowered its price target on the media and entertainment company.
Dish could drop Viacom content, said brokerage MoffettNathanson in a research report.

Dish Network stock was up more than 1% in early trading in the stock market today, while Sinclair stock was up 2.5%. Akamai Technologies has a big play in Internet video, says Deutsche Bank, which joins other bullish Wall Street analysts on the CDN provider's long-term market opportunity with Apple (AAPL) and others.Website Streaming Media, however, says sell-side views that Akamai has a big payday coming from Apple's launch of a Web TV service are misguided.Cambridge, Mass.-based Akamai (AKAM) is the biggest provider of CDN (content delivery network) services to media and entertainment companies. While Apple's launch of an over-the-top (OTT) video service may have been delayed until 2016, Akamai stands to benefit from a wide array of Web video launches, says Deutsche Bank analyst Vijay Bhagavath in a research report."We see a $500 million a year opportunity for Akamai in TV OTT, as the long tail (NBC, CBS (CBS), HBO, ESPN, Apple, Dish-Sling (DISH), Comcast (CMCSA), Hulu) generate the next 10% or more of Internet video traffic," said Bhagavath.Bhagavath joins other bullish Wall Street analysts in saying Akamai's network investments and higher capital spending will pay off.Pacific Crest Securities says Apple will still need Akamai if it expands its own CDN capabilities. William Blair & Co. also says Akamai's higher capital spending will generate more revenue.Dan Rayburn, a blogger at Streaming Media and analyst at Frost & Sullivan, says otherwise."Apple's OTT service will not be a big revenue driver for Akamai or any other CDN right out of the gate," said Rayburn in a blog post. "If Apple signs up tens of millions of subscribers and gives a large percentage of the delivery to third-party CDNs like Akamai, then the numbers could start to add up. But Apple would be lucky to get a few million subs, within a few quarters, with what is expected to be a pared-down selection of content available."Apple is still in talks with programmers over rights to live broadcasts and a limited number of cable TV channels.Deutsche Bank's Bhagavath expects many companies to jump into Internet video. He raised his price target on Akamai to 80 from 77.As more U.S. households cut the cord and use only broadband to get TV, "we note a base of 11 million broadband homes in the U.S., growing 10% year over year (SNL Kagan data), is a significant and growing viewer base for the exabytes of Internet Video traffic that Akamai could monetize over the next few years," he said.Akamai gets a strong Composite Rating of 90 out of a possible 99 from IBD. Akamai stock has been consolidating around its key 10-week line, though after several days of market volatility it has been trading just under that point in the stock market today.RELATED:Akamai Web TV Payoff Seen 'Late 2015 And Into 2016'

As federal regulators ready rules for the next government auction of radio spectrum for wireless phone services, the impact of the AWS-3 auction is still rippling through the industry.The AWS-3 auction raised $41 billion, adjusted for discounts provided to bidding partners of satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH). In the upcoming Broadcast Incentive Auction, slated for early 2016, the Federal Communications Commission is mulling changes that would curtail discounts to bidding entities backed by larger companies.The AWS-3 results, says a Goldman Sachs report, raised the value of other airwaves owned by wireless phone companies. AT&T (T) spent $18.2 billion in AWS-3, the most of any company, while Verizon Communications (VZ) spent $10.4 billion.In all, AT&T now holds spectrum licenses worth more than $91 billion, estimates Goldman Sachs analyst Brett Feldman in the report. He estimates the value of Verizon's spectrum at $79.4 billion.Wireless firms are buying more airwaves for data services, especially mobile video. Sprint (S) owns the most spectrum, but it's high-band and not yet used. AT&T has more low-band spectrum than Verizon, while T-Mobile US (TMUS) lags.In all, Feldman estimates that the wireless industry and Dish own spectrum valued at $368 billion.High-frequency bands require costlier network gear. At lower frequencies, wireless signals travel over longer distances — important in rural areas — and through office walls. The upcoming broadcast TV spectrum will offer wireless firms another chance to buy coveted low-band spectrum. The spectrum, in the 600 MHz frequency band, would come from TV broadcasters.AT&T Happy With SpectrumOn AT&T's Q1 earnings call late Wednesday, CFO John Stephens said the company is well-positioned for now. Besides the AWS-3 auction, he noted that AT&T acquired spectrum from its purchase of Leap Wireless."Needless to say, we feel good about our spectrum position. This takes a lot of uncertainty out of the process with our ability to add capacity and maintain quality in a cost-efficient manner," he said.Verizon CFO Fran Shammo, on that company's earnings call Tuesday, said it's too early to make plans for the 2016 broadcast TV auction.Some speculate Verizon could buy spectrum from Dish Network or partner with the satellite TV broadcaster. Sprint, meanwhile, could put some of its spectrum up for sale."As far as any type of strategic acquisitions or additional spectrum (related to) the incentive auction, I think that we are just going to have to wait and see what the rules are before we decide how we're going to execute on or around the incentive auction," Shammo said.T-Mobile, controlled by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), and Sprint, owned by Japan's SoftBank, are pushing federal regulators to set aside more spectrum for smaller wireless firms in the Broadcast Incentive Auction. The Federal Communications Commission has reserved for smaller firms 30 megahertz of the expected 70-80 MHz of airwaves expected to be auctioned."We believe that AT&T and Verizon remain in a very strong spectrum position for the next five years. ... We believe lack of interest for Dish's spectrum may compel Dish to acquire T-Mobile or partner with Sprint," Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan said in a recent report. "Otherwise, it risks losing its spectrum."

Fortunate flukes play a vital role in product development. How inventors stumble into bright ideas:

 Make do. Some of Americans' favorite food came about because chefs lacked basic ingredients and had to improvise. "The most popular creation stories for the Caesar salad, nachos and the Cobb salad all follow this path," said Josh Chetwynd, author of "How the Hot Dog Found Its Bun."
The entrepreneurial lesson?
When you're lacking assets you think you need, "it's often the best time to innovate," he told IBD.
 Spot opportunity. Some creators simply paid attention to what others overlooked.
"This book is a reminder over and over again of the famed Louis Pasteur quote: 'In the field of observation, chance favors only the prepared mind,'" Chetwynd said.
Take the microwave's inventor.
Raytheon (RTN) employees were in the radar business, and most didn't think much about how those magnetron tubes warmed things — such as a candy bar in staffer Percy Spencer's pocket.
"Unlike all the people before him, Spencer recognized that there could be something special here and started doing tests," Chetwynd said.

 Keep trying. Ralph Wiley had the lowly job of washing lab glassware at Dow Chemical (DOW). When one beaker wouldn't come clean, the 20-something worker kept trying to find a chemical that would break down the residue.

His persistent tinkering led to a job as a research scientist, and that substance he couldn't clear away — once greenish and smelly — was refined into a wrapping for World War II supply shipments, and later the popular dish-covering Saran Wrap.
 Change courses. "If you're only looking for one result and are unwilling to be creative and intuitive, you may very well miss out on a great alternative development," Chetwynd said.
That was the case with door-to-door aluminum cookware salesman Edwin Cox. He was looking for something to give away, to get his foot in housewives' doors.
Back in 1917, coal-fired stoves blackened pan bottoms, so Cox soaked steel wool in suds until he got a foamy scrubber.
As housewives clamored for more, Cox realized he should forget selling pans and focus on manufacturing his S.O.S Pads.

 Find purpose. The inventor of the graham cracker had a dubious intention. "This popular treat was created by a guy named Sylvester Graham for the express purpose of limiting people's sex drives," Chetwynd said.
The preacher, medical guru and vegetarian felt certain food — sugar, oil and white flour — made people excitable, so he created the blander cracker in 1829 as part of his clean living regime.

Graham would die in 1851 at the age of 57, but his cracker would be refined and live on in campfire s'mores. The lesson? "Even the craziest of inspirations can ultimately be turned into something good," Chetwynd said.
 Showcase it. Credit for how the hot dog got its bun is typically traced back to two entrepreneurs:
Coney Island's Charles Feltman put bread and hot dogs together as a portable hot sandwich for his customers in 1871.
A dozen years later, St. Louis meat purveyor Anton Feuchtwanger tried buns as a tidy wrap for his red hot sausages.
Feuchtwanger would ultimately take a bigger bite of food fame.

"At the 1904 World's Fair in his hometown of St. Louis, Feuchtwanger was a popular concessionaire who did really well with his hot-dog-plus-bun combination," Chetwynd said.Fortunate flukes play a vital role in product development. Verizon Communications (VZ) has become the latest pay-TV provider to offer skinny bundles of TV channels to consumers seeking lower-cost viewing options.Following the lead of Dish Network (DISH), Verizon's FiOS service will begin offering a slim package of TV channels, including broadcasters like ABC and Fox and cable networks like CNN and AMC, starting Sunday. It will offer add-on "channel packs" covering genres such as sports, news, lifestyle, entertainment and children's shows, the Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.FiOS Custom TV is targeted at millennials, cord shavers and cord cutters, Verizon spokesman Phillip Burrows said. "It's a simple way for customers to choose the types of channels they want without paying for those they don't," he said.The cheapest plan costs $55 a month and includes a base channel package with over 35 channels (all local broadcast channels and cable favorites like CNN, HGTV, AMC and Food Network), plus two add-on channel packs. Extra channel packs cost $10 a month. Each of the seven current genre-specific channel packs includes an average of 10 to 17 channels.Verizon's skinny bundle offering comes as consumers are starting to demand greater flexibility in selecting channels to watch and lower-cost options. Earlier this year, Dish's Sling TV and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue became the first to offer skinny bundle alternatives to traditional pay TV services. Apple (AAPL) reportedly plans to offer a similar service.Last month, Bernstein Research analyst Todd Juenger said the new skinny TV bundles are unlikely to please either potential cable TV cord-cutters or cord nevers. The offerings are too narrow for existing pay-TV subscribers and are too expensive for people who have opted not to subscribe to traditional pay-TV services, he said.The trend coincides with the rise of over-the-top Internet television services, such as Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN) Prime Instant Video and Hulu Plus, which provide subscription on-demand programming.On a conference call with analysts Wednesday, Netflix CEO Reed Hastings sounded the death knell for traditional linear TV channels."Linear TV has been on an amazing 50-year run," Hastings said. "Internet TV is starting to grow. Clearly, over the next 20 years Internet TV is going to replace linear TV."Programmers are starting to launch stand-alone subscription over-the-top video services. They include CBS (CBS) All Access, Time Warner's (TWX) HBO Now and Viacom's (VIA) Noggin.

MLB Extra Innings provides Dish viewers with exclusive MLB games, news and analysis via MLB…

The online video service added 4.88 million new subscribers worldwide in the March quarter, bringing its total to 62.27 million. It previously forecast adding 4.05 million subscribers. Netflix (NFLX) earned 38 cents a share,…

Facebook, Google and other Internet leaders have grown rich selling products over wireless networks. With Tuesday's agreement to acquire AOL, Verizon Communications served notice that it's fighting back.
AOL (AOL) will bring digital advertising technology to Verizon (VZ) in a battle for mobile revenue vs. Google (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) and others, analysts say.
"This is about Verizon monetizing its network assets through advertising," said Brian Wieser, an analyst at Pivotal Research.
With broadcast TV ad revenue falling as young adults watch more video online and on mobile devices, the race is on to develop new advertising and viewership tools, analysts say.
Verizon stock fell as much as 1.7% intraday but recovered some ground to close off 0.4%. AOL surged 18.6% on the pact.

Verizon, which agreed to buy AOL in a deal valued at $4.4 billion, has touted plans to stream video to mobile devices. Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE) this year launched online video services targeting the home broadband market, with Apple (AAPL) expected to soon follow. Apple is developing an innovative ad platform for online TV services, analysts say.
Verizon Service By June?
Verizon could launch a mobile video service as soon as June that targets millennials, ages 18 to 34, with a mix of live TV, on-demand shows and niche, edgy content.

"The primary target for us is the millennial generation that has very different ideas about what they want to consume — how, where, when," said John Stratton, Verizon executive vice president and president of operations, explaining the AOL deal at a Jefferies financial conference Tuesday.
"Certainly, the (video) subscription business and content businesses are very noteworthy," he added.
The stakes are high for Verizon. In Q1, its wireless service revenue fell for the first time.

"With wireless revenue growth becoming more scarce, despite the growing demand for mobile data, we have seen telecom companies shift their focus toward a digital strategy," Simon Flannery, a Morgan Stanley analyst, said in a research report.

While the wireless services provider stands to gain as subscribers gobble up more video and buy bigger data plans, it wants a share of the mobile-ad-revenue pie too. And Verizon also aims to sell digital media services to large companies and social media firms.
Verizon faces hurdles competing against the Internet giants, which have acquired mobile advertising startups of their own.
AOL Ad Tech 'Unproven'

"Google and Verizon are on a collision course as Verizon tries to create a business model in mobile video delivery," said Kevin Smithen, analyst at Macquarie Capital. Smithen, who on Tuesday downgraded Verizon, calls AOL's ad platform "unproven" in the "nascent video ad-tech space."
Google recently launched a wireless service, renting network capacity from Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) .
AT&T's (T) proposed acquisition of satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group (DTV) is being reviewed by regulators. That deal positions AT&T to sell mobile video services.

But Verizon has charged ahead of AT&T with the AOL acquisition and earlier deals, says Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson. Verizon last year bought Intel's (INTC) online platform, called OnCue, and in 2013 acquired EdgeCast Networks, a content delivery network.
No. 4 In Ad Reach

AOL has the third-largest U.S. online video content network after Google and Facebook, and the fourth-largest U.S. online video advertising reach after Yahoo's (YHOO) BrightRoll, Specific Media and Facebook's LiveRail, says Moffett.

Analysts expect telecom and media M&A to continue. Cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA), which owns media giant NBCUniversal, owns both content and distribution assets. But Comcast lacks the wireless reach of AT&T and Verizon. Some observers speculate that Comcast could attempt to acquire T-Mobile in the wake of regulators thwarting its merger with Time Warner Cable (TWC).

Dish Network, meanwhile, has Sling, its Web-only "over-the-top" (OTT) video service. Dish CEO Charlie Ergen, on the company's earnings call Monday, said that developing better-targeted ad technology is a challenge.

That's where Apple, widely expected to launch its own TV service this year, might come in, says Pacific Crest analyst Andy Hargreaves in a report. Apple, like Verizon and others, has had setbacks in negotiations with media and entertainment firms to make content available online.

But Hargreaves says that Apple might woo content providers with its own "dynamic ad insertion technology" that could increase cable channel revenue. He says an Apple TV service would be a boon for companies like Time Warner (TWX) and Walt Disney (DIS).

"We expect Apple to provide detailed viewing data directly to (cable) network owners ... in addition to collecting data, Apple's service should be able to provide dynamic ad inventory in content that is live, served on-demand, or recorded by the consumer," he wrote.

Verizon will pay $50 a share for AOL in cash, a 17% premium over AOL's closing stock price on Monday. Yahoo has been viewed as a potential AOL suitor, but analysts do not expect it to make a counterbid.

Verizon in 2013 bought out Vodafone's (VOD) 45% stake in their U.S. wireless joint venture, Verizon Wireless, for $130 billion, adding more than $60 billion in debt. At the Jefferies conference, Stratton said the AOL deal will not impact Verizon 2015 guidance. Verizon has shelved stock buybacks until it lowers debt.
Verizon plans to fund the AOL deal from cash on hand and commercial paper. Verizon expects to return to pre-Vodafone transaction credit ratings in 2018 or 2019.

UBS Internet analyst Eric Sheridan expects AOL revenue to remain flat at $1.82 billion in 2015, with EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) rising 1.3% to $514 million.Facebook, Google and other Internet leaders have grown rich selling products over wireless networks. With Tuesday's agreement to acquire AOL, Verizon Communications served notice that it's fighting back.AOL (AOL) will bring digital advertising technology to Verizon (VZ) in a battle for mobile revenue vs. Google (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) and others, analysts say."This is about Verizon monetizing its network assets through advertising," said Brian Wieser, an analyst at Pivotal Research.With broadcast TV ad revenue falling as young adults watch more video online and on mobile devices, the race is on to develop new advertising and viewership tools, analysts say.Verizon stock fell as much as 1.7% intraday but recovered some ground to close off 0.4%. AOL surged 18.6% on the pact.Verizon, which agreed to buy AOL in a deal valued at $4.4 billion, has touted plans to stream video to mobile devices. Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE) this year launched online video services targeting the home broadband market, with Apple (AAPL) expected to soon follow. Apple is developing an innovative ad platform for online TV services, analysts say.Verizon Service By June?Verizon could launch a mobile video service as soon as June that targets millennials, ages 18 to 34, with a mix of live TV, on-demand shows and niche, edgy content."The primary target for us is the millennial generation that has very different ideas about what they want to consume — how, where, when," said John Stratton, Verizon executive vice president and president of operations, explaining the AOL deal at a Jefferies financial conference Tuesday."Certainly, the (video) subscription business and content businesses are very noteworthy," he added.The stakes are high for Verizon. In Q1, its wireless service revenue fell for the first time."With wireless revenue growth becoming more scarce, despite the growing demand for mobile data, we have seen telecom companies shift their focus toward a digital strategy," Simon Flannery, a Morgan Stanley analyst, said in a research report.While the wireless services provider stands to gain as subscribers gobble up more video and buy bigger data plans, it wants a share of the mobile-ad-revenue pie too. And Verizon also aims to sell digital media services to large companies and social media firms.Verizon faces hurdles competing against the Internet giants, which have acquired mobile advertising startups of their own.AOL Ad Tech 'Unproven'"Google and Verizon are on a collision course as Verizon tries to create a business model in mobile video delivery," said Kevin Smithen, analyst at Macquarie Capital. Smithen, who on Tuesday downgraded Verizon, calls AOL's ad platform "unproven" in the "nascent video ad-tech space."Google recently launched a wireless service, renting network capacity from Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) .AT&T's (T) proposed acquisition of satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group (DTV) is being reviewed by regulators. That deal positions AT&T to sell mobile video services.But Verizon has charged ahead of AT&T with the AOL acquisition and earlier deals, says Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson. Verizon last year bought Intel's (INTC) online platform, called OnCue, and in 2013 acquired EdgeCast Networks, a content delivery network.No. 4 In Ad ReachAOL has the third-largest U.S. online video content network after Google and Facebook, and the fourth-largest U.S. online video advertising reach after Yahoo's (YHOO) BrightRoll, Specific Media and Facebook's LiveRail, says Moffett.Analysts expect telecom and media M&A to continue. Cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA), which owns media giant NBCUniversal, owns both content and distribution assets. But Comcast lacks the wireless reach of AT&T and Verizon. Some observers speculate that Comcast could attempt to acquire T-Mobile in the wake of regulators thwarting its merger with Time Warner Cable (TWC).Dish Network, meanwhile, has Sling, its Web-only "over-the-top" (OTT) video service. Dish CEO Charlie Ergen, on the company's earnings call Monday, said that developing better-targeted ad technology is a challenge.That's where Apple, widely expected to launch its own TV service this year, might come in, says Pacific Crest analyst Andy Hargreaves in a report. Apple, like Verizon and others, has had setbacks in negotiations with media and entertainment firms to make content available online.But Hargreaves says that Apple might woo content providers with its own "dynamic ad insertion technology" that could increase cable channel revenue. He says an Apple TV service would be a boon for companies like Time Warner (TWX) and Walt Disney (DIS)."We expect Apple to provide detailed viewing data directly to (cable) network owners ... in addition to collecting data, Apple's service should be able to provide dynamic ad inventory in content that is live, served on-demand, or recorded by the consumer," he wrote.Verizon will pay $50 a share for AOL in cash, a 17% premium over AOL's closing stock price on Monday. Yahoo has been viewed as a potential AOL suitor, but analysts do not expect it to make a counterbid.Verizon in 2013 bought out Vodafone's (VOD) 45% stake in their U.S. wireless joint venture, Verizon Wireless, for $130 billion, adding more than $60 billion in debt. At the Jefferies conference, Stratton said the AOL deal will not impact Verizon 2015 guidance. Verizon has shelved stock buybacks until it lowers debt.Verizon plans to fund the AOL deal from cash on hand and commercial paper. Verizon expects to return to pre-Vodafone transaction credit ratings in 2018 or 2019.UBS Internet analyst Eric Sheridan expects AOL revenue to remain flat at $1.82 billion in 2015, with EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) rising 1.3% to $514 million.
Netflix (NFLX) stock is surging ahead of its first-quarter earnings report on talk of a possible stock split.

Netflix shares gapped up for the second straight trading session Monday after the streaming video company's announcement Friday that it plans to increase its share authorization. Netflix was up 6% to near 483 in midday trading on the stock market today. It's approaching record high territory again. Netflix hit an all-time high of 489.29 on Sept. 9.

In a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Netflix said that it will seek shareholder permission in June to increase its share authorization to 5 billion shares from 170 million. The measure could indicate that the company is planning for a stock split.

Netflix is scheduled to report is Q1 earnings after the market close Wednesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company to earn 69 cents a share, down 20% year over year, on sales of $1.57 billion, up 24%.
For the June quarter, Wall Street is modeling Netflix to earn 91 cents a share, down 21%, on sales of nearly $1.66 billion, up 24%.
Netflix earnings are under pressure as the company pursues a rapid global expansion strategy and continues to invest heavily in original content.
UBS analyst Doug Mitchelson on Monday upgraded Netflix stock to buy from neutral and raised his 12-month price target to 565 from 370.

"We now have increased confidence for accelerating international net (subscriber) additions each of the next few years," Mitchelson said in a research report. "Netflix is a unique play on global online video growth."

The Los Gatos, Calif.-based company has scale and competitive advantages and should be able to weather increasing competition in the over-the-top Internet video sector. Other companies in the OTT television business include Amazon.com (AMZN), Dish Network (DISH), Hulu, Time Warner's (TWX) HBO, Sony (SNE) and potentially Apple (AAPL).
Last week, Citi upgraded Netflix stock to buy from neutral, noting that strong content sets Netflix apart from other streaming rivals.

Netflix's latest original series, "Marvel's Daredevil," premiered Friday to generally positive reviews. "Daredevil" is the first of several shows based on Marvel comic book heroes that Walt Disney (DIS) is making for Netflix.
RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney on Monday reiterated his outperform rating on Netflix stock, with a price target of 550.
Cantor Fitzgerald analyst Youssef Squali also issued a positive report on Netflix Monday. He reiterated his buy rating on the stock, with a price target of 500.

"Given Netflix's significant global subscriber growth potential, improving original content slate, ability to raise prices over time and recent headlines around unbundling, we remain positive on Netflix, the original OTT disruptor," Squali said.
RELATED:

Media Bias: In a classic gotcha interview with a GOP candidate, Bloomberg big shot Mark Halperin sought to discredit Ted Cruz as a "real" Latino with patronizing questions. It goes to show the proprietary sense that the left has toward minorities.In a week-old televised interview discovered and called out by columnist Ruben Navarrette writing in the San Jose Mercury News, Halperin asked the Republican candidate for president in a dour interrogator's intonation what kind of Cuban food Cruz ate, which Cuban musical artists he listened to, whether he identified himself as Latino on his application to college (Princeton, Harvard) and, grossest of all, asked him to say something in Spanish for him.Cruz kept his composure and politely answered all but the speak-Spanish-for-me request. But there was a look on his face that suggested discomfort.Bloggers and Tweeters on the Internet, particularly those of Latin American background, rightfully blasted the interrogation."I was born and raised in Puerto Rico, and, if I had $5 for every liberal idiot who looks at me and says 'You don't look Puerto Rican,' etc., because I don't fit the liberal template of what a Lateeeno/Lateeena (sic) should be like, this blog wouldn't need to carry ads," ranted blogger Fausta Wertz, accusing Halperin of expecting Cruz to perform like '50s comic actor and bandleader Ricky Ricardo.Several bloggers compared Halperin's line of questioning with that of someone looking for a minstrel show. And even on the far left, the Think Progress blog weighed in. "The prize for the most racist interview of a 2016 candidate goes to Bloomberg's Mark Halperin," one of them wrote.The waves of disgust across the spectrum pretty well told the Bloomberg editor he'd stepped in it, bad, and as a result, he apologized Monday, with qualifications indicating that the problem was with the offended, not him. His main regret, he said, was his haste and tone, and he was sorry if anyone was offended. Yeah, sure.It seems the mainstream media, which even after years of nonwhite leaders in high positions, are still unable to get their heads around the idea of a black or Latino running for office who isn't a lockstep Democrat.This problem is not new. The left already has a long history of questioning the authenticity of people like former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, declaring her not really black, and for that matter, Sarah Palin, insisting that she doesn't share a real woman's concerns. Now with a large nonwhite, male contingent among the GOP's presidential hopefuls, the obnoxiousness has started right on schedule.It won't be long before the media starts asking Dr. Ben Carson, chief pediatric surgeon at the prestigious Johns Hopkins medical school and an African-American Republican, if he likes fried chicken.Former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina can probably look forward to some mafia and spaghetti questions. Cuban-American Marco Rubio will be asked if he engages in drug-dealing (a smear that's already been attempted, by the way).And we can't wait to see what they cook up for the multiracial family of Jeb Bush.With Halperin convinced that the problem was his tone, not his line of questioning, the remaining question is why he wanted to know the answers to such questions anyway. The apparent aim was to "prove" that Cruz was not really a Latino if he couldn't name a Cuban dish (he could) and thus could not be considered Latino.Halperin and his ilk have nobusiness making that call. But they're trying, and it's encouraging to see some blowback. Latinos are not the property of the Democratic Party. They are individuals and have the right to be treated as such.

Roku updated its line of streaming media boxes on Monday, with new features to better compete against Amazon (AMZN) Fire TV and Apple (AAPL) TV.The flagship Roku 3, still $99.99, now has voice search, like Amazon Fire TV. Users can use the voice search button on the new remote and say a movie, TV show or actor to get quick search results.The Roku 2 is getting all of the hardware and software of the Roku 3, except for voice search. But the price is just $69.99, essentially matching the new lowered price of Apple's streaming device. People can also download the updated smartphone/tablet Roku app for Google (GOOGL) Android or Apple iOS to control their Roku device. That app has voice search functions.Roku also is making it easier to know when movies are available for streaming. It's Movies Coming Soon feature will be part of a new Roku Feed. Users "follow" movies that they want to see, and they get automatic updates on availability and pricing.Apple TV, in addition to its recent price cut to $69 from $99, appeared to get a content edge as the exclusive digital streaming device launch partner for Time Warner's (TWX) HBO Now, a $15-a-month streaming. But last week Time Warner agreed to make an HBO stream an option on the Dish Network (DISH) Sling TV service.The Roku 2 and Apple TV are among the cheaper full-fledged streaming devices. But the Roku 1 is available for $49.99. The Amazon Fire TV Stick goes for $39, while the Google Chromecast is available for $29.99 on Amazon.Meanwhile, the Amazon Fire TV is still $99, but you can get $50 as part of a Dish Sling TV order.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.

Net neutrality rules could throw a wrench into Verizon's plans to launch a mobile video-streaming service. Analysts expect Verizon Communications (VZ) to join Dish Network, Sony and Apple in launching online video-streaming services. Verizon, which could launch its service as early as June, aims to set itself apart by focusing its service on wireless phone users.But in the meantime, Verizon is battling the Federal Communications Commission over new Internet rules. Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam last week asked Congress in a letter to rewrite the 1996 Telecommunications Act to address net neutrality rules, which ban Internet service providers from blocking or unfairly slowing down any Web traffic.The FCC in February voted 3 to 2 along party lines for net neutrality rules, for the first time extending those rules to wireless networks. The revised rules don't directly ban plans such as T-Mobile's (TMUS) Music Freedom, a plan offering subscribers unlimited music streaming without it counting toward their data caps.That's where Verizon's planned mobile video-streaming service comes in. For Verizon, one potential issue is that wireless customers have data caps that limit how much video, music and other content they can download. If subscribers go over data caps, bills quickly mount.'Provocative Move' By VerizonWhen it launches a mobile video service, Verizon could skirt the data cap issue by exempting some or all of customer OTT usage from data caps. But it's unclear if that tactic would run afoul of net neutrality rules."I think that would be a very provocative move," said Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson. "I don't think the FCC would be pleased."Internet video services target young adults and other consumers who "cut the cord," people who disconnect from pay-TV service in favor of more affordable video content via the Internet. Web-based services generally offer fewer channels at a lower cost than traditional pay-TV services.Apple (AAPL) reportedly aims to offer about 25 TV channels for $30 to $40 per month. Sony (SNE) and satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) recently launched their Vue and Sling video services, respectively.The services are dubbed over the top, or OTT, because they piggyback on landline broadband services sold by other companies. Even if consumers don't buy a traditional pay-TV package, they still need broadband Internet service to stream video.What makes Verizon different is that unlike Apple, Dish or Sony, it operates its own nationwide 4G wireless network. Verizon aims to offer a mobile video service that whisks live TV, original shows and pay-per-view to consumers. While many consumers watch TV in homes, analysts say that Verizon's wireless network would let them watch live sports, breaking news or a favorite show on the go.Verizon CFO Fran Shammo recently said that the company might rely on advertising for revenue, not a subscription model like the other OTT services.Verizon hasn't laid out how an add-on mobile video service would impact data consumption.T-Mobile US last year rolled out Music Freedom. One factor working in favor of Music Freedom's not conflicting with net neutrality, analysts say, is that it doesn't compete directly with music services such as Spotify or Pandora (P).AT&T; (T), meanwhile, has been pushing a sponsored-data business model, where data charges are billed to a sponsoring company and not to AT&T; customers, who basically use an app for free. The FCC's new net neutrality rules appear to allow AT&T;'s sponsored-data initiative, analysts say.Telecom firms object to the FCC's net neutrality ruling, saying that it's unnecessary and will stifle investment and innovation. The FCC revised its net neutrality rules after a Washington, D.C., Court of Appeals ruling in January 2014 gutted much of the agency's authority, in reaction to a Verizon suit challenging the FCC's legal basis to impose Internet regulation.A trade group backed by Verizon and AT&T; already has sued the FCC over its new net neutrality rules.Verizon says that it's premature to discuss its mobile video strategy."It's too soon to provide specifics about a product that hasn't been launched," company spokesman Robert Varettoni said.Video Can Get Costly FastVerizon Wireless has nearly 103 million postpaid customers — those billed monthly, including some 86 million smartphone subscribers, as well as tablet users. Verizon also sells FiOS TV and video services via a landline fiber-optic network.The company is a serious contender in the OTT market, says Alan Wolk, an analyst at TDG Research."Verizon has the potential to be disruptive because whatever play they have will be aimed at their 100 million-plus customers who are all over the U.S. and who are outside its FiOS territory," Wolk said.But a streaming service could be "crazy expensive, given bandwidth caps," he said. "Unless they (Verizon) start selling unlimited LTE plans, all that video gets very, very costly."Like Apple, Verizon is in talks with content companies. Media companies have been leery of undermining their business relationships with pay-TV distributors like Comcast (CMCSA), which pay programming fees. Cable TV companies have pushed a new "TV anywhere" model that requires consumers to log in as pay-TV customers to view programs using an Internet connection. Content companies, though, have struck deals with Dish, Sony and Apple, and would be expected to sign up with any Verizon mobile video service.Content firms want more ad revenue. Nielsen and other market trackers are working on new tools to measure mobile viewing, whether via in-home or public Wi-Fi, or out-of-home cellular networks.Verizon has been developing a spectrum-efficient LTE multicast technology. With multicast technology, Verizon plans to send the same TV signal to thousands of smartphone users in the same area. Sending on-demand video to individuals, in contrast, gobbles up a lot of network bandwidth.For now, the economics of mobile video remain unclear, says Brian Wieser, an analyst at Pivotal Research Group."The vast majority of TV viewing is going to be on a conventional TV set and in the home," he said. "Delivery of video content over a wireless network would not be exactly the most cost-effective approach. There may be subscribers willing to pay for the incremental service, but whether it's enough to justify the costs that Verizon might incur in launching and operating the service is another matter."

Apple (AAPL) made much ado about its standalone streaming HBO Now service last month, but "Game of Thrones" enthusiasts without a cable subscription don't need an iPad to watch the season premiere on April 12.Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV, an over-the-top service, said Wednesday that it is bringing live and video-on-demand HBO to its "Best of Live" core-package subscribers for an additional $15 a month. The core package costs $20 and includes about 20 channels, such as (Walt Disney (DIS) ESPN, (Scripps Network Interactive (SNI) as well as Time Warner (TWX) channels such as TBS and CNN.Shares of Dish closed down 0.5% to 69.73.The move comes as part of a new distribution agreement between media giant Time Warner and the satellite TV provider. The two companies ended their dispute Tuesday, allowing Dish customers to continue to access Turner channels.The deal also comes just in time for college hoops fans to watch the NCAA Final Four games on TBS, TruTV and TNT on Saturday.The exact launch date of HBO on Sling has yet to be announced, but presumably it will come before April 12, when new seasons of both "Game of Thrones" and "Silicon Valley" begin. Sling TV — which is supported by Roku, Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One, Android and iOS devices, Amazon (AMZN) Fire TV and Macs and PCs — said HBO will be available by the season premiere.Apple in March said Apple TV would be the exclusive streaming device partner for HBO. Apple reportedly is working on a a streaming service that would include more channels than Dish's Sling TV.

New Internet television services from Dish Network (DISH), Sony and possibly Apple are unlikely to please either potential cable TV cord-cutters or cord nevers, Bernstein Research said in a report Thursday.The over-the-top video services announced or rumored so far are too narrow for existing pay-TV subscribers and are too expensive for people who have opted not to subscribe to traditional pay-TV services, Bernstein analyst Todd Juenger said in the report.His findings were based on comments made at focus groups in New York City and San Francisco. The groups were composed of people who identified themselves as "highly likely to cut the cord in the next six months," as well as people who felt just the opposite.Based on the focus groups, Juenger is pessimistic on the prospects for Sling TV from Dish Network, PlayStation Vue from Sony (SNE) and a rumored Apple (AAPL) TV service."A strong body of evidence is emerging that suggests to us that none of these services are likely to gain much traction," he said. "Simply put, for existing pay-TV subscribers, the content is too limited (relative to the cost savings); and for cord-nevers, the price is too high (relative to the appeal of the content)."The OTT services are handicapped by having fewer networks in order to achieve a lower price, but not enough networks to make the service appealing."Cord-cutting, in large numbers, isn't likely to happen," Juenger said. "It's one of those ideas that sounds great in the abstract but crumbles when faced with the reality. OTT services seem poised to garner few subscribers, which is more good news than bad. We believe it's better for the pay-TV ecosystem to remain in the status quo than to add millions of OTT subscribers at the cost of blowing the whole system apart."One of the big problems with "skinny" TV bundles is that individuals differ on what the ideal package of networks should be.Content Companies Cutting InAs Dish and others are putting together online programming bundles, some content companies are making stand-alone subscription video-on-demand services. These include Time Warner 's (TWX) HBO Go service, set to launch next month on Apple TV hardware; CBS All Access; and Nickelodeon's Noggin from parent Viacom (VIAB).Complicating matters even more are subscription streaming video services like Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Hulu, which offer original programming as well as licensed TV shows and movies.The concept of over-the-top television is appealing because many people hate their cable TV providers but are stuck with them unless an effective alternative emerges."The vitriol toward the cable companies was intense" in the focus groups, Juenger said. "A surprising number of participants are currently subscribing to pay-TV only because it is actually cheaper than buying high-speed Internet on its own."Bernstein rates Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner as outperform.It rates AMC Networks (AMCX), CBS (CBS), Discovery Communications (DISCA), and Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI) as market perform; and Viacom as underperform.RELATED:Apple building new set-top box for its Internet TV serviceSony pursues cord cutters with over-the-top TV service.

ESPN bills itself as the Worldwide Leader In Sports, and the slogan is not mere hyperbole. ESPN is available in 94 million pay-TV homes in the U.S., and its channels air in more than 200 nations.Clearly, Burbank, Calif.-based Walt Disney (DIS) has benefited wildly from buying an 80% stake in ESPN in 1995. For openers, ESPN, which broadcasts jewels ranging from the NFL and NBA to Major League Baseball and all sorts of college sports, provides a gateway to the hearts and minds of 18- to 34-year-old males. Advertisers covet that viewing audience.But ESPN is also essential for Disney as the worlds of media and technology continue to blur. As such Silicon Valley heavyweights as Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOGL) make inroads into what has been regarded as traditional media ecosystems, media companies likewise must begin to act more like technology companies if they hope to remain relevant.In January, Dish Network (DISH) announced Sling TV, which lets subscribers watch cable channels over the Internet (what the industry calls OTT, for over the top) without mandating a satellite subscription. For a mere $20 a month, OTT subscribers get access to ESPN and ESPN 2, as well as such channels as Disney, the Food Network, HGTV, TBS, TNT and CNN.It's the first time that Disney has made ESPN available online without a cable or satellite subscription. "It's the thing a lot of people really miss when they don't have a pay-TV service," Dish's outgoing CEO Joe Clayton said in announcing Sling TV at the Consumer Electronics Show. "They want live sports. They want ESPN and ESPN2."Disney, though, must protect its ESPN franchise. The company had to consider the move seriously for competitive reasons, say observers."ESPN is a primary profit center for Disney and annually contributes close to $7 billion from subscriber fees alone to the corporate bottom line," Neal Pilson, former president of CBS Sports and now a TV industry consultant, told IBD."ESPN and Disney have sophisticated and talented executive leadership, so it's hard to imagine they would agree to any OTT deal between ESPN and Dish that might, in any way, jeopardize the revenue stream ESPN continues to generate from the traditional cable/satellite industry."But OTT has become a rallying cry, if not a mantra, in the industry."ESPN has been dipping its toe into the OTT space for over a year, mulling whether streaming an ESPN channel might work," said Porter Bibb, an analyst with MediaTech Partners. "It will — and it will be forthcoming sometime in the next year or so."The MSOs (multisystem operators, or pay-TV providers) won't dare penalize ESPN, but ESPN knows the multibillion-dollar fees they currently extract from MSOs aren't going up and upon contract expiry — which in most cases runs to 2020 — will start to go down."ESPN needs to replace that revenue with the only alternative, which is OTT."Downgraded On Ad ChallengesBTIG analyst Rich Greenfield likes ESPN, but on Monday he downgraded Disney stock to neutral from buy, in part on the increasing challenges for broadcast TV ad revenue."Disney is clearly best-positioned among its broadcast/cable network peers, with its must-have sports-driven ESPN networks and non-advertising-driven Disney channels," Greenfield said in a research report Monday. "However, we are increasingly struggling with the question of whether anyone in the sector can flourish as consumer behavior shifts away from traditional television viewing, not to mention a complete lack of interest in wasting time on commercials."But in Q4, Disney reported higher earnings that surpassed Wall Street's forecasts, thanks in large part to ESPN. Disney had adjusted earnings per share of $1.04, topping the 92 cents estimated by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Net income jumped 33% to $1.8 billion.Disney's media networks division, which stars ESPN, clocked in with $1.5 billion in operating income, up 20%.ESPN is crucial to not only Walt Disney's fortunes but also its image, particularly among investors. Under CEO Bob Iger, Disney has established an enviable record for making good on its promises to Wall Street.While Disney's assets range from theme parks to the "Star Wars" franchise, ESPN is rapidly becoming arguably its most transferrable property worldwide. As Viacom's (VIA) MTV unit has somewhat declined in buzz value over the years, ESPN now stands alone at the top of the cable-channel heap.Controlling A DemographicIn a way, Disney is following a tried-and-true formula with ESPN. Disney, of course, is the content king when it comes to enriching the lives of young people with programming that continually appeals to this special demographic — and doing it in many forms, ranging from old-fashioned TV to DVDs and Blu-ray innovations."Walt Disney, for a long time, has had a control over our childhood, from Mickey Mouse and Snow White to Cinderella and trips to Disney World and the old Sunday TV show with Walt Disney himself," noted Robert Thompson, who teaches a course in television and American culture at the Newhouse School of Syracuse University."ESPN basically owns the culture of men, especially young men," Thompson said. "Sports translates so well to new technologies and all media forms, such as second screens, third screens (and) streaming."Sports — especially professional football, which ESPN broadcasts — is the golden goose. The Oscars broadcast this year declined 15% in the ratings, but the Super Bowl goes up."Disney's mandate is to keep ESPN the worldwide leader of sports — and the destination for the key demographic of young adult men.To do it, Disney must continue to tap into the new technology."Dish/Sling is the beneficiary for the moment and is small enough not to rile the big MSOs," Bibb said. "But the writing is on the wall, and ESPN will be right there with HBO, the other 'must-have' cable network, on the Net. And it will be there sooner rather than later."

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) cooled down late Tuesday after the trendy burrito chain served up earnings that topped views, but fell short on sales. Q1 earnings rose 48% to $3.88 a share, ahead of forecasts by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $3.66 a share.
But revenue grew 20.4% to $1.09 billion, just shy of views for $1.11 billion. That was the second straight quarter of decelerating growth.
Same-store sales grew 10.4% vs. a year earlier, fueled by menu price increases. Wall Street had expected comps to rise 11.7%.
"The stock is down because the expectation was that comps would be better than what they reported," Sterne Agee analyst Lynne Collier told IBD.
Chipotle's comps fell below expectations due to harsh weather patterns in late February and March in many parts of the U.S. and the loss of carnitas, a dish made from pork, says Collier.

Chipotle had pulled the carnitas off the shelves earlier in the year from many locations because it had an issue with some of its pork suppliers, which hadn't lived up to its animal treatment standards, says Collier.

Chipotle sees same-store sales growing by low-to-mid-single digits in 2015, reaffirming its guidance made when it reported fourth-quarter results. That would be below the double-digit pace it's been tracking.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a 29% earn ings rise to $4.50 a share in the current Q2 prior to the report.
First-quarter restaurant-level operating margin was 27.5%, an increase of 160 basis points from a year earlier.
"They actually exceeded our earnings estimates on higher-than-expected margins," said Collier.

Food costs were 33.9% of revenue, down 60 basis points from a year earlier. General and administrative expense fell 160 basis points to 5.8% of revenue. That, along with higher menu prices, lifted profitability.
"Its results were a little lower than expected on the top line and a little better than expected on the margin," Collier said.

She added, "Their comps are still very strong relative to the industry. The driver behind that has been their focus on quality ingredients, which is what the millennials truly care about right now. On a longer-term basis they continue to be one of my favorite names."
Chipotle shares fell 5% to 657 in after-hours trading, presumably because of the sales miss. The stock had closed up 0.8% at 692.52, the best finish since the burrito king's Q4 earnings report.
Fast-Casual Alternatives

Chipotle is part of the fast-casual restaurant segment, which has been outpacing the rest of the industry. The segment is pricier than fast-food chains, but offer a better dining experience and a cheaper, faster alternative to sit-down chains.

Earlier Tuesday casual dining chain operator Brinker International (EAT) posted fiscal third-quarter earnings that were in line with views. But sales fell below forecasts. Brinker operates eateries Chili's Grill & Bar and Maggiano's Little Italy. Shares slid 3.7% Tuesday.
Yum Brands (YUM), operator of Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC, rose 4% late Tuesday on better-than-expected earnings. China sales are still falling, but the trend is improving.

If it wasn't April, Sunday's launch of Lilly Pulitzer clothes and furnishings at Target (TGT) may have been mistaken for Black Friday. Shoppers formed long lines outside before stores opened like they were waiting for Apple (AAPL) iPhones. The brightly colored, resort-chic merchandise was picked clean within minutes of the doors being unlocked at many locations. Online offerings, which launched…

After months of beta testing, Sony (SNE) on Wednesday launched its PlayStation Vue television service, which aims to compete with cable and other pay TV offerings.PlayStation Vue offers a starting package of 50 channels for $50 a month, but you must own a Sony PS3 or PS4 game console and have broadband Internet service to receive it. Initially it will be available only in New York, Chicago and Philadelphia.Sony introduced the service in November, calling it a "pioneering new cloud-based TV service that reinvents the television experience."The company also is offering two higher-priced tiers of Vue that include more channels for $60 and $70 a month.PlayStation Vue follows the nationwide launch of Sling TV from Dish Network (DISH), another over-the-top Internet pay TV service. Sling TV offers a starting package of 20 channels for $20 a month and is available using Roku and Amazon.com (AMZN) streaming devices and Microsoft 's (MSFT) Xbox One game console.Apple (AAPL) reportedly is preparing to enter the OTT TV market this fall. Media reports say Apple will launch its service with about 25 channels for $30 to $40 a month. Apple stock has risen three straight days since the Wall Street Journal broke the news.The OTT services from Dish, Sony and Apple are aimed at "cord cutters" — consumers who have quit traditional pay TV services — and millennials who have never received cable. Each offers a different set of channels with noticeable absences. For instance, Sony's Vue is missing the CW network and channels from Walt Disney (DIS), including ABC and ESPN.Meanwhile, several content providers are launching their own OTT services. Time Warner (TWX) will launch its HBO Now service in April for $15 a month. CBS (CBS) offers CBS All-Access for $6 a month. Viacom (VIAB)-owned Nickelodeon offers its Noggin programming for $6 a month.These services both complement and compete with subscription video-on-demand services from Amazon, Hulu, Netflix (NFLX) and others.Programmers wouldn't be participating in over-the-top TV services if they didn't believe it was additive to their businesses, rather than cannibalistic, Deutsche Bank analyst Bryan Kraft said in a research report Wednesday."They believe it could be an opportunity to monetize some of the (about) 18 million TV households that don't subscribe to a pay-TV service today, which we forecast to grow to 31 million by 2020," Kraft said. "Furthermore, they believe skinny bundles are an onramp to up-selling customers to the full pay TV bundle."RELATED:Review: Can you really save money by cutting the cord?Streaming TV services: What you get, what it costs.

Apple (AAPL) is preparing to enter the over-the-top Internet television market this year with a multichannel subscription service that would provide an alternative to more expensive cable, satellite and telco TV services. The streaming video service will launch this fall with about 25 channels, including several broadcast networks, the Wall Street Journal reported late Monday. Apple's service would be available on iOS devices including iPhones, iPads and the Apple TV set-top box.

Apple's service reportedly will include CBS (CBS), Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS)-owned ABC broadcast networks. NBC is not part of the subscription programming bundle, but the Comcast (CMCSA)-owned network plans to offer a stand-alone streaming app for Apple TV later this year, 9to5Mac reported Tuesday.
Apple is aiming to offer the service for $30 to $40 a month. It likely will announce the service in June and launch it in September, the Journal said.

The news follows the recent launch of Dish Network 's (DISH) watershed Sling TV service. Sling TV starts at $20 a month and includes live streaming of 20 cable networks including AMC, Cartoon Network, CNN, ESPN, TBS and TNT. Additional channels are available through add-on packages.

On Tuesday, Sling TV added Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One video game console to its list of compatible hardware. It's the third big-screen platform for Sling TV, which is also available on Roku and Amazon (AMZN) Fire TV hardware. Microsoft said Xbox One owners can get a one-month free trial of Sling TV service.
Sony (SNE) is planning to launch a similar service aimed at so-called "cord cutters" soon.
Apple stock was up more than 1.5% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 127.

Apple's over-the-top television service could lay the groundwork for Apple to come out with its own television set, possibly in 2016, Piper Jaffray analyst Gene Munster said in a research report Tuesday. Munster rates Apple stock as overweight with a price target of 160.
This month, Apple slashed the price of its Apple TV set-top box to $69 from $99 and announced that it would be the exclusive launch partner for Time Warner's (TWX) HBO Now streaming service in April.

The Apple television service could be a low-margin business designed to keep customers using its hardware, Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um said in a note Tuesday. Um rates Apple stock market-perform.

"While this could help revenue, we believe margins may be low when taking content and other costs into account," Um said. "Rather, we believe this strategy could be to drive further lock-in to stem any threats of attrition and potential to gain share (i.e. hardware sales)."

Given Apple's immense size, revenue from the TV service would be "largely immaterial" to the company, Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi said in a note Tuesday. And the service likely would cut into Apple's gross profit margin, he said.

"We see an Apple TV service's principal value as enhancing Apple's iOS ecosystem, akin to other service offerings like iCloud, Siri, and Apple Pay, which we believe collectively help strengthen and differentiate the platform relative to Android," Sacconaghi said.

He rates Apple stock outperform with a price target of 135.Apple (AAPL) is preparing to enter the over-the-top Internet television market this year with a multichannel subscription service that would provide an alternative to more expensive cable, satellite and telco TV services. Dish Network (DISH) founder Charlie Ergen will return as CEO of the satellite TV broadcaster, which on Monday reported Q4 revenue that missed views and a net loss of 63,000 video subscribers, twice as much as analysts expected.
Joe Clayton, CEO since June 2011, will retire March 31, the company said.

Dish Network stocked was up more than 1% in early trading in the stock market today, above 79 near its all-time high of 79.57 touched on Nov. 28. Dish's Q4 video subscriber losses came amid a programming dispute with 21st Century Fox (FOXA). Dish posted a net gain of 8,000 video customers in Q4 2013. Analysts had expected a loss of 31,000 subscribers.

Dish said Q4 revenue rose 4% to $3.68 million. Analysts had modeled revenue of $3.7 billion. Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization fell 9% to $807 million, but that beat views. Dish reported Q4 EPS of 88 cents, including a one-time gain related to a programming contract. Analysts had expected profit of 43 cents.

"Dish's weak Q4 subscriber metrics and strong EBITDA performance were primarily driven by a carriage dispute with Fox and a one-time programming benefit," said Mike McCormack, an analyst at Jefferies. "While results were mixed, it is unlikely to shift investor focus away from the ultimate outcome of Dish's spectrum and M&A potential in the space."
Dish said it added 24,000 broadband customers, missing estimates of 36,000.

The pay-TV firm's earnings conference call at noon ET is likely to be highlighted by questions over its wireless strategy in the wake of a recently concluded radio spectrum auction. Dish and wireless phone companies led by AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) spent nearly $45 billion in the AWS-3 auction, blowing past estimates. Dish, which had nearly 55 MHz of spectrum licenses prior to the auction, spent $10 billion to add more airwave licenses, mainly in large markets.

Among the options being explored by Ergen, analysts say, are spinning off the spectrum holdings into a separate company that would lease airwaves to wireless firms, or forging a network-sharing partnership with Verizon or T-Mobile US (TMUS). But some analysts are not optimistic about Dish's immediate prospects for its spectrum.Dish Network (DISH) founder Charlie Ergen will return as CEO of the satellite TV broadcaster, which on Monday reported Q4 revenue that missed views and a net loss of 63,000 video subscribers, twice as much as analysts expected.Joe Clayton, CEO since June 2011, will retire March 31, the company said.Dish Network stocked was up more than 1% in early trading in the stock market today, above 79 near its all-time high of 79.57 touched on Nov. 28.
