Dish Network (DISH) early Tuesday reported Q3 earnings and revenue below expectations as the satellite TV broadcaster lost 12,000 subscribers, but another apparent radio spectrum gain by founder Charlie Ergen may offset disappointing pay-TV results, analysts said. Dish Network was down 4.5% in early trading in the stock market today. Dish said it earned 31 cents per share in the…

Google won't be there when the Federal Communications Commission auctions off radio spectrum on Nov. 13 — in contrast to 2008, when speculation over whether the Internet giant would bid for licenses dominated the event.
But satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) will be around to provide entertainment.
The FCC's AWS-3, or Advanced Wireless Service No. 3, auction marks the first major sale of airwaves since 2008. Some 65 megahertz of spectrum will be auctioned.
Wireless companies need more spectrum for their 4G data networks as smartphone users stream more video and music.

AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) are expected to bid for spectrum. Sprint (S), which has the most spectrum among carriers after acquiring Clearwire last year, says that it will not bid. Nor has Google (GOOGL), or any other Internet firm, registered to bid.
Dish Network, controlled by co-founder Charlie Ergen, has said that its growth will come from providing mobile video services to pay-TV subscribers. Dish has more than 14 million subscribers.
Dish Network has cobbled together nearly 55 MHz of spectrum and has been looking, so far in vain, for a wireless partner.
Dish figures to be a key player in the AWS-3 auction, says UBS analyst John Hodulik.
"AT&T and Verizon will clearly be the big bidders," Hodulik told IBD. "T-Mobile will also top up its holdings in markets where it is light.
"The big question is whether Ergen will pay 'retail' (bid in a competitive auction) for a lot of spectrum. He did for his chunk of 700 MHz spectrum, but that's a small piece of his total holdings."
In the 2008 auction, Dish Network acquired 168 licenses across the U.S. for $712 million.

Then, in 2012, Dish spent an estimated $3 billion acquiring spectrum from two bankrupt companies. Federal regulators granted Dish Network a waiver to use the airwaves, originally earmarked for satellite services, for 4G wireless services, as long as Dish built out a network.
Industry analysts have valued Dish's airwaves at $7 billion to $17 billion, depending on whether Dish ultimately sells the spectrum to a wireless phone company or finds a partner.
The outcome of the AWS-3 auction will help set the value of Dish Network's spectrum, analysts say. Dish has an interest in seeing bidding heat up and could play a part in making that happen.
Dish could also bid for spectrum targeted by Verizon or T-Mobile, some analysts speculate, aiming to drive them to the bargaining table for a network-sharing arrangement after the auction is over.
Dish Network has registered as American AWS-3 for the auction. It may have joint bidding arrangements with Northstar Wireless and SNR Wireless, analysts say.

Analyst Hodulik estimates that the AWS-3 auction could raise up to $15 billion. Adam Ilkowitz, a Nomura Securities analyst, estimates $17 billion in auction proceeds. Citibank analyst Michael Rollins and Oppenheimer's Tim Horan both estimate that bids could reach up to $20 billion.
"Spectrum bidding will be heavy," said Horan via email. "The wild card in the auctions will be T-Mobile, which may be quite aggressive."
The AWS-3 spectrum is located near frequency bands where Verizon, T-Mobile and AT&T already have holdings. It's adjacent to spectrum held by Dish.
The 65 MHz of spectrum being auctioned includes 50 MHz of "downlink" spectrum and 15 MHz of "uplink" spectrum.

Dish Network has accumulated plenty of downlink spectrum for potentially whisking mobile video to subscribers, but it needs uplink spectrum for two-way communications. Goldman Sachs analyst Brett Feldman expects Dish Network to bid for the 15 MHz of uplink spectrum in the AWS-3 auction.

Besides Dish, other companies will be closely watched in the auction. Nomura's Ilkowitz says that one surprise entrant is an entity going by the name SAAS, which he says is "a combination for former Lightsquared CEO Sanjiv Ahuja and potentially former Vodafone (VOD) CEO Arun Sarin."

Japan-based NTT DoCoMo and Carlos Slim-controlled America Movil (AMX) also have registered for the AWS-3 auction.Google won't be there when the Federal Communications Commission auctions off radio spectrum on Nov. 13 — in contrast to 2008, when speculation over whether the Internet giant would bid for licenses dominated the event.But satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) will be around to provide entertainment.The FCC's AWS-3, or Advanced Wireless Service No. 3, auction marks the first major sale of airwaves since 2008. Federal regulators aim to shake up the pay-TV market by making it easier for online video providers to obtain programming, but out-of-home viewing rights for on-the-go millennials loom as a wild card. The Federal Communications Commission last week proposed giving online video providers the same regulatory status as cable and satellite TV companies. The regulatory makeover would affect over-the-top (OTT)…

If Comcast acquires Time Warner Cable, a nasty sports programming dispute that has kept Los Angeles Dodgers baseball games from many pay-TV customers in the local market might finally get resolved, analysts say.
The Dodgers finished first in their division this year, but the San Francisco Giants, No. 2 in the National League West, went on to win the World Series and will hold a ticker-tape parade Friday.
Meanwhile, the lack of agreements with other pay-TV providers in southern California to carry Dodgers games impacted Time Warner Cable's (TWC) Q3 earnings.

Time Warner Cable reportedly agreed to pay $8.35 billion to acquire rights to broadcast Dodger games over 25 years. DirecTV Group (DTV) and other pay-TV providers, though, have balked at paying the subscriber fees that Time Warner Cable sought.
This summer, Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, pressured Time Warner Cable to end the dispute. But no agreement with other pay-TV providers was reached.

The FCC and Department of Justice, meanwhile, are reviewing Comcast's proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable. Comcast expects the deal to close in early 2015. It's possible that the FCC could put conditions on the deal related to programming, including sports content.
Without regulatory intervention, Comcast (CMCSA) would have more bargaining clout.

"Comcast will basically be the cable provider for all of Los Angeles, so that will help a lot," UBS analyst John Hodulik told IBD. "All of the area cable subscribers will have the channel, and it will put more pressure on the satellite providers (DirectTV/AT&T; (T) and Dish Network (DISH) to take the service." AT&T; is seeking regulators' approval to acquire DirecTV.
Jeffrey Wlodarczak, an analyst at Pivotal Research Group, agrees.
"I assume this will get resolved with Comcast, given they own important content assets that give them way more leverage in negotiations," he said.

Time Warner Cable purchased Dodgers rights amid a rush by media and pay-TV providers to acquire sports content. Live programming is viewed as a key asset to keep subscribers from switching to Internet video and on-demand TV services. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) launched a national sports network taking on Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN last year.
Time Warner recognized losses tied to the Dodgers deal in Q3 earnings.

"(Q3) customer results were strong, pricing improved, and profitability was stable despite investment spending and losses from the Dodgers (regional sports network)," said Nomura Securities analyst Adam Ilkowitz in a research report.
Mike McCormack, an analyst at Jefferies, said that Time Warner Cable's Q4 profit margins should improve.

"While Q3 margins disappointed, management maintained full year EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) guidance of 3.75% to 4.75% growth, implying a healthy sequential margin improvement in the fourth quarter. The improvement is driven by the absence of the Dodgers' rights fees, which are expensed over the baseball season, and a seasonal increase in high-margin political advertising revenue," McCormack wrote.If Comcast acquires Time Warner Cable, a nasty sports programming dispute that has kept Los Angeles Dodgers baseball games from many pay-TV customers in the local market might finally get resolved, analysts say.The Dodgers finished first in their division this year, but the San Francisco Giants, No. 2 in the National League West, went on to win the World Series and will hold a ticker-tape parade Friday.Meanwhile, the lack of agreements with other pay-TV providers in southern California to carry Dodgers games impacted Time Warner Cable's (TWC) Q3 earnings.Time Warner Cable reportedly agreed to pay $8.35 billion to acquire rights to broadcast Dodger games over 25 years. Subscriber growth estimates for T-Mobile US are rising even as its stock falls amid fading prospects that parent Deutsche Telekom will sell the wireless firm, at least until the Obama administration's run is over.

Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY) owns 67% of T-Mobile US (TMUS), the fourth-biggest U.S. wireless firm. Deutsche Telekom says it's focused on extending T-Mobile's market share gains rather than on exiting the U.S. market.

Several analysts have upped their Q3 and Q4 estimates for T-Mobile's postpaid subscriber additions, but others warn that T-Mobile's momentum will slow in 2015 and 2016. One reason is that Sprint (S) has cut prices and made other moves to halt its subscriber losses, especially to T-Mobile.

Japan's Softbank, which controls Sprint, in early August ended talks with Deutsche Telekom over merging Sprint and T-Mobile. Deutsche Telekom, worried that the Department of Justice would block a deal between the Nos. 3 and 4 wireless firms, reportedly had sought a breakup fee that Softbank couldn't stomach.

Deutsche Telekom, meanwhile, never showed any interest in talking to France's Iliad, which bid for a controlling stake in T-Mobile in mid-August. Iliad pulled its bid on Oct. 13, sending shares of T-Mobile down. T-Mobile stock has shed some 24% since June.
Synergies Lacking

Besides Sprint, JPMorgan analyst Hannes Wittig says that none of T-Mobile's other potential suitors — Dish Network (DISH), America Movil (AMX) or Comcast (CMCSA) — offer the right mix of synergies. Only Sprint gives T-Mobile the operational scale it needs to compete with wireless leaders AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ), he says.

A growing number of analysts believe T-Mobile will keep its options open until the next U.S. presidential election, hoping that a new administration will be more open to wireless industry consolidation.

"While DT still has a few options for U.S. deals, none seems as obviously attractive as a Sprint merger would have been," said Wittig in a research report. "The next U.S. presidential election is only two years away and could result in a change in antitrust stance. Deutsche Telekom might deem this worth holding out for."

T-Mobile acquired MetroPCS Communications in May 2013 and began trading as a public company. Deutsche Telekom's stake in T-Mobile fell from 74% to 67% in November, when T-Mobile raised $2 billion in a stock offering and issued 66.2 million new shares.
An 18-month lock-up tied to the MetroPCS merger expires on Nov. 1, giving Deutsche Telekom the option of cutting its 67% stake, Guy Peddy, a Macquarie Capital analyst, wrote in a research note.

Peddy says Deutsche Telekom needs cash to invest in its wireline and wireless networks to compete with Vodafone (VOD) and Telefonica (TEF) in Germany. So, Peddy says, Deutsche Telekom may reduce "the size of its shareholding in T-Mobile ... to invest in domestic infrastructure."

T-Mobile, meanwhile, is expected to spend $3 billion to $5 billion to acquire radio spectrum in a U.S. auction slated for mid-November. Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network also is expected to bid. (See story, this page.) The auction's outcome, some analysts say, could influence the strategies of both Dish and T-Mobile.

Dish Network has amassed some 54 MHz of spectrum that could be used for wireless and mobile video services. Dish has expressed an interest in a deal of some kind with T-Mobile, perhaps a network-sharing pact rather than an acquisition.
Deutsche Telekom would likely resist a Dish/T-Mobile merger because the new firm would carry too much debt, says RBC Capital analyst Jonathan Dann in a report.
But if Deutsche Telekom holds on to T-Mobile, Dann says its profit margins will be suspect amid intensifying competition.
In July, T-Mobile maintained its full-year 2014 EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) guidance of $5.6-$5.8 billion.
T-Mobile raised its 2014 postpaid subscriber addition forecast to a range of 3 million-3.5 million.

Justin Funnell, a London-based Credit Suisse analyst, estimates 4 million postpaid additions, but says customer acquisition costs will run high. Also, promotions will continue pressuring T-Mobile's average monthly revenue per user. In Q2, postpaid ARPU fell 8.7% to $49.30.

"While we are bullish on net adds, some of this upside is lost both in ARPU and subscriber acquisition cost, particularly near term," said Funnell in a report.Subscriber growth estimates for T-Mobile US are rising even as its stock falls amid fading prospects that parent Deutsche Telekom will sell the wireless firm, at least until the Obama administration's run is over.Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY) owns 67% of T-Mobile US (TMUS), the fourth-biggest U.S. wireless firm. Dish has expressed an interest in a deal of some kind with T-Mobile, perhaps a network-sharing pact rather than an acquisition.Deutsche Telekom would likely resist a Dish/T-Mobile merger because the new firm would carry too much debt, says RBC Capital analyst Jonathan Dann in a report.But if Deutsche Telekom holds on to T-Mobile, Dann says its profit margins will be suspect amid intensifying competition.In July, T-Mobile maintained its full-year 2014 EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) guidance of $5.6-$5.8 billion.T-Mobile raised its 2014 postpaid subscriber addition forecast to a range of 3 million-3.5 million.Justin Funnell, a London-based Credit Suisse analyst, estimates 4 million postpaid additions, but says customer acquisition costs will run high. Also, promotions will continue pressuring T-Mobile's average monthly revenue per user. In Q2, postpaid ARPU fell 8.7% to $49.30."While we are bullish on net adds, some of this upside is lost both in ARPU and subscriber acquisition cost, particularly near term," said Funnell in a report.
Time Warner's decision to sell HBO on the Web in 2015 and CBS' plans to launch a subscription streaming service are fresh proof to pay-TV companies that the trend is not their friend.

Federal regulators are mulling rules to help Internet TV providers acquire content and live programming from media companies. Dish Network (DISH), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Sony are ramping up Internet video, also called over-the-top (OTT) services, that may soon debut.

The Web streaming services target young adults and other consumers that "cut the cord," industry jargon for the growing number of people that disconnect pay-TV service in favor of more affordable online video options and on-demand content.

As pay-TV subscriptions fall, cable-TV channels such as Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN and TNT reach fewer U.S. households, impacting their revenue stream. More advertising dollars, meanwhile, are flowing to Google's (GOOGL) YouTube and other online streaming websites as broadcast TV audience ratings fall.
Cable Has Broadband

Shares in Comcast (CMCSA), Time Warner Cable (TWC), satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network and other pay-TV companies fell on Thursday as investors digested the latest moves from Time Warner's (TWX) HBO and CBS (CBS). Pay-TV stocks rallied Friday.
Pay-TV companies face big challenges to preserve their ecosystem in the face of a growing OTT threat.

"The Golden Goose appears to be shedding some feathers," said Mike McCormack, a Jefferies analyst, referring to the annual increases in pay-TV subscriber bills that have fed cable industry free cash flows as well as programming fee increases garnered by media companies.
On the other hand, "The Goose is not cooked quite yet," McCormack added.
Cable TV companies are likely better off than satellite TV providers, he says.

That's because cable TV companies are the biggest providers of high-speed Internet services to homes. They stand to keep that revenue stream as online streaming services expand and likely require faster connections.
Satellite TV Woes
Satellite firms don't sell broadband services. With prospects for video subscriber growth bleak, DirecTV Group (DTV) agreed in May to be acquired by AT&T (T).

Much depends on the ability of Internet service providers to charge a premium for the fastest broadband connections, perhaps bundled with out-of-home Wi-Fi, analysts say. Long-run, Internet service providers could try to impose usage-based billing systems, though regulators might block that course.

To target cord cutters looking for "a la carte" packages, marketing may shift to broadband-first deals. Comcast, Cox and AT&T have stepped up promotions of cheaper, $40 to $50 monthly plans that feature high-speed Internet and basic TV — without ESPN, Discovery and other channels. In the future, pay-TV companies may package their broadband products with popular streaming services from Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com (AMZN) or Hulu, says Moody's analyst Karen Berckmann.
What's clear is that the pay-TV ecosystem is fraying.

HBO's decision to launch a stand-alone Web offering that does not require consumers to have a cable TV or satellite subscription could mark a turning point, some analysts say, by encouraging more cable partners to dabble in Web offerings.
Time Warner had been "the most stalwart protector of the status quo," said Craig Moffett, analyst at MoffettNathanson.

Disney's ESPN sports channel, an early adopter of online streaming services, has required users of its app to log in as pay-TV customers, a process called authentication. The danger for pay-TV companies is that more media companies will stray from the TV Everywhere authentication model and offer content directly to consumers via the Web.

HBO CEO Richard Plepler cited 10 million "broadband-only" homes in the U.S. in explaining its decision. "In 2015 we will go beyond the wall and launch a stand-alone, over-the-top service with the potential to produce hundreds of millions in revenue," Plepler said at Time Warner's investor day. Half of the 10 million homes subscribe to streaming video services, he said. HBO's 10 million figure doesn't refer only to cord-cutters as such, because it includes homes that never had pay-TV.

HBO's rivalry with Netflix as well as 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) aborted bid for Time Warner may have contributed to the decision to launch a stand-alone streaming service, analysts say. HBO generated $4.9 billion in 2013 revenue vs. $4.4 billion at Netflix, whose sales jumped 21% last year.

Netflix late Wednesday said Q3 subscriber growth fell short of its forecasts. The company also reported rising content acquisition costs and gave a weak Q4 EPS forecast. Its stock plunged 19% Thursday.

HBO did not disclose a launch date, pricing, or other specifics of its streaming strategy. One decision HBO faces, analysts say, is whether to make hit shows such as "Game of Thrones" available at the same time to Web and pay-TV customers, or delay Internet availability. Cable TV companies typically charge $15 monthly for HBO as part of top-tier plans.

Barclays analyst Kannan Venkateshwar says HBO still has a lot at stake in the pay-TV ecosystem, including 30 million U.S. subscribers. If HBO's goal is tapping new consumer demographics, Venkateshwar says it can do that by teaming with cable TV firms for "skinny broadband packages."
Comcast's Internet Plus bundle includes 25 Mbps Internet service, basic TV and HBO for $50. Cox's $60 "Flex Watch" package includes 50 Mbps broadband, basic TV, HBO and Starz.

The cable plans now require customers to get a set-top box to access HBO. But, Venkateshwar sees them evolving toward broadband-only services. Cable industry-led plans, he says, "have the potential to reshape the competitive dynamics for HBO relative to Netflix."

If consumers don't buy Internet services as part of a "triple play" or "double play" bundle that includes video and/or phone services, pay-TV firms typically charge $20 to $30 more monthly. Even so, cord-cutters don't have to pay for channels they don't watch. Pay-TV companies have passed on rising programming fees to consumers in monthly bills.

Jefferies' McCormack calls sports programming the "ace-in-the-hole" of pay-TV companies. CBS broke new ground by offering live streaming as part of its new $6 monthly "All Access" service. But, CBS' streaming service doesn't include National Football League games or other live sports.Time Warner's decision to sell HBO on the Web in 2015 and CBS' plans to launch a subscription streaming service are fresh proof to pay-TV companies that the trend is not their friend.Federal regulators are mulling rules to help Internet TV providers acquire content and live programming from media companies. The 13 largest pay-TV providers in the U.S. collectively lost about 150,000 net video subscribers in the third quarter.That was a Q3 all-time record and compared with just 25,000 subscriber losses in Q3 2013, according to Leichtman Research.The data suggest cord cutting continues to take hold as people cancel their pay-TV service and turn to Internet services such as Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN) Prime, and Google's (GOOGL) YouTube to watch TV programs.Cable TV companies took the biggest hit. The top nine cable companies lost 440,000 video subscribers in Q3. Time Warner Cable (TWC) led the list with subscriber losses of 182,000, followed by Comcast (CMCSA) at 81,000.DirecTV (DTV) and Dish Network (DISH), the two satellite TV providers, lost 40,000 subscribers combined.AT&T (T) U-verse and Verizon (VZ) FiOS, the two phone companies offering pay-TV services, were the only major providers to show market gains. AT&T added 216,000 subscribers while Verizon added 114,000.RELATED:AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile, Dish Among Likely AWS-3 Spectrum Auction Bidders.

The Federal Communications Commission could raise the U.S. broadband standard as soon as January, a move that's aimed at increasing network investments but that also might have implications for Comcast's proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable.
Internet service providers oppose increasing the broadband standard from the current 4 megabits per second (mbps) to 10 or higher.
For one thing, most ISPs would need to step up investments to reach that speed, mainly DSL upgrades in rural areas. ISPs want to decide what "broadband" is, not have regulators impose it on them.
And while an increase to 10 mbps appears most likely, FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler hinted at raising the bar much higher in an Oct. 1 speech when he said, "Table stakes for the 21st century is 25 mbps."

Wheeler says that U.S. households need faster Internet connections for high-definition video streaming and emerging apps. He adds that faster broadband would boost education, health care and the economy.
AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and the National Cable and Telecommunications Association in September asked the FCC to keep the standard at 4 mbps.

The Comcast (CMCSA)-Time Warner Cable (TWC) merger is another element of the issue. Opponents of the merger have cited Comcast's broadband market share as a reason why regulators should block the deal or impose tough conditions. Comcast says that the combined company would have 35% of U.S. broadband subscribers.

If the broadband threshold is increased to 10 mbps from 4, then Comcast's broadband market share would rise. Many slower DSL phone lines in rural areas, owned by telecom ISPs, would not reach 10 mbps. And even bigger market share for the combined Comcast-TWC, in theory, lowers the chances that regulators will approve the merger without stringent conditions — if they approve at all.
The merger of the Nos. 1 and 2 cable TV firms, though, isn't the target of the FCC's move to refine broadband, Guggenheim Partners analyst Paul Gallant told IBD via email.

"It's something they've said for a while they want to do," he said. "But nonetheless, it would have the effect of making Comcast look more dominant in broadband, which in turn strengthens the FCC's leverage over the companies for more extensive conditions."
Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, agrees.

"Comcast would be viewed as having materially higher market share if broadband were to be defined as 10 mbps or 25 mbps (rather) than under today's definition," Moffett said in a research report. "This would bolster the FCC's and Department of Justice's 'moral authority' to impose more significant conditions on the transaction or perhaps even to block the deal outright."

Jeff Wlodarczak, an analyst at Pivotal Research Group, speculates that the FCC could require Comcast to provide minimum guaranteed download speeds of 60 mbps to 100 mbps within five years as a condition of the TWC deal.

On Oct. 22, the FCC paused its review of the Comcast-TWC merger as well as AT&T's proposed acquisition of DirecTV Group (DTV). The FCC said that it will decide how to handle highly confidential documents related to agreements with media companies.
Comcast expects approval of the TWC acquisition in early 2015, but some analysts say that the review could stretch until Q2.
The timing is important because if the FCC adopts a new broadband definition in January, it still might be able to apply the new threshhold to the Comcast-TWC review.

"Wheeler has laid the groundwork for aggressive action against Comcast/TWC, portraying the key broadband market as speeds of 25 mbps or more," research firm The Capital Forum said in a report. "This view aligns with those of merger opponents, not Comcast."
Conditions imposed on Comcast-TWC could involve net neutrality.
David Cohen, Comcast executive vice president and chief lobbyist, told IBD that the FCC's broadband speed standard has no relevance to the Time Warner Cable deal.

"It is not analytically connected to our transaction," Cohen said. "The definition of broadband is all about the government's aspirational goals. In a transaction review, the government looks at relevant markets. There has never been a relevant market analysis within the antitrust, FCC or DOJ purview that relied on a definition of broadband speeds."
Nor does Comcast believe that its broadband market share should be looked at nationally. The service areas of Comcast and TWC do not overlap.
"Relevant markets are defined by consumer choice and consumer options," Cohen said. "Broadband is sold in local and regional markets. It's not sold on a national basis."

In 2010, the FCC raised the definition of broadband to 4 mbps from 200 kilobits per second. The FCC in June proposed to redefine broadband to 10 mbps or higher for purposes of its Connect America Fund (CAF) broadband build-out initiative, which provides subsidies to rural phone companies.

Wheeler has aimed to promote "municipal broadband," a term for local governments partnering with the likes of Google (GOOGL) or others, in order to build high-speed networks. Gallant says that Wheeler hopes Google or others offering superfast Internet services will pressure cable TV companies broadly, not only in top U.S. markets.

Speaking at the National Association of Telecommunications Officers and Advisors annual conference on Oct. 1, Wheeler said: "We need faster networks in more places ... . Unfortunately, today there is an inverse relationship between competition and throughput. Three-quarters of American homes have no competitive choice at 25 mbps. That includes almost 20% who have no option at all at those speeds."
Comcast's Cohen says that the TWC merger would not reduce competition.

"Chairman Wheeler notes accurately that as you move up the speed ladder, there is less and less competition. There's no way to dispute that," Cohen said. "The next question is whether there is anything in our transaction that reduces the level of competition in a relevant market at any speed level, and the answer is there's nothing."

Consumer group Public Knowledge and video streamer Netflix (NFLX) in filings have asked the FCC to increase the broadband threshhold to 25 mbps. Dish Network (DISH) opposes the Comcast-Time Warner Cable deal, saying that the combined firm would have 50% of residential broadband connections if the 25 mbps standard is used.
Telecom companies such as CenturyLink (CTL) and AT&T, meanwhile, could be impacted if the FCC adopts at least a 10 Mbps standard.
"This adds more pressure to AT&T to upgrade their DSL network broadband speeds," said Amy Yong, analyst at Macquarie Capital.

AT&T had 14.84 million consumer broadband connections as of Sept. 30, including 12 million customers on its U-Verse high-speed Internet network. The others are either DSL residential lines or satellite broadband customers.

In a regulatory filing, AT&T said: "Given the pace at which the industry is investing in advanced capabilities, there is no present need to redefine advanced capabilities. Consumer behavior strongly reinforces the conclusion that a 10 mbps service exceeds what many Americans need today to enable basic, high-quality transmissions."

AT&T has stepped up broadband investments. AT&T said in September that it has completed rolling out its 1 gbps "GigaPower" service to parts of the Austin, Texas, area. AT&T GigaPower is also available in parts of Dallas and Fort Worth.

AT&T plans to also launch the high-speed service in eight North Carolina cities, including Greensboro, plus Cupertino, Calif.; Houston; Jacksonville, Fla.; Miami; Nashville; St. Louis; and San Antonio. AT&T is studying whether to expand the GigaPower service to 25 more markets nationwide.The Federal Communications Commission could raise the U.S. broadband standard as soon as January, a move that's aimed at increasing network investments but that also might have implications for Comcast's proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable.Internet service providers oppose increasing the broadband standard from the current 4 megabits per second (mbps) to 10 or higher.For one thing, most ISPs would need to step up investments to reach that speed, mainly DSL upgrades in rural areas. Sprint and T-Mobile shareholders punished both stocks on Wednesday after merger talks between the two wireless carriers ended, but Dish Network rose as its CEO demurred on any takeover bid.Struggling Sprint (S) halted its pursuit of T-Mobile US (TMUS), the industry's comeback kid, after concluding that a deal would not win regulatory approval. Federal Communications Commission Chairman Tom Wheeler praised Sprint's decision. U.S regulators prefer a national market with at least four players, including leaders Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT&T (T), rather than three.Besides announcing that it wouldn't pursue T-Mobile any longer, Japan's SoftBank, which owns 80% of Sprint, replaced Sprint CEO Dan Hesse with Marcelo Claure, the former CEO of wireless phone distributor Brightstar.Sprint stock plunged 19%, while T-Mobile stock fell 8.4%. Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), which owns 67% of "Uncarrier"-branded T-Mobile, saw its U.S. shares slip 2.7%. SoftBank's stock tumbled 3.5% in Japan.Analysts see Dish Network (DISH); France's Iliad, which has made an offer; America Movil (AMX); and No. 1 cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA) as potential buyers of T-Mobile, which has gained market share thanks to its aggressive marketing.Despite earlier statements of interest, Dish Network Chairman Charlie Ergen was cautious on the satellite broadcaster's earnings conference call early Wednesday."It's not a surprise that Sprint is walking away from T-Mo. Regulatory officials sent clear messages," Ergen said. "Obviously, we need to re-look at things based on what's happened on the M&A side the last 24 hours."The No. 1 U.S. satellite TV broadcaster, DirecTV Group (DTV), agreed in May to be purchased by AT&T."Obviously the AT&T-DirecTV deal probably lessened some optionality that we had. The Sprint announcement probably increases some optionality," Ergen said.In May, Ergen said that if Sprint and T-Mobile didn't merge, then he would be interested in T-Mobile. And last November, Ergen said that buying T-Mobile was still "on the table" despite Sprint's interest.Ergen has touted mobile video services as the satellite-TV firm's next growth engine as its core business matures.For Q2, Dish reported fewer video subscriber losses than expected but turned in a financially mixed quarter, with EPS light and revenue in line with estimates. Dish said that it lost 44,000 subscribers in Q2, compared with 78,000 in the year-earlier quarter. Analysts had expected a loss of 77,000 subscribers. Dish had 14.05 million customers as of June 30.Ergen Controls Dish VotingErgen, who holds nearly 90% of Dish's voting power, has had wireless setbacks. At one time, Dish pursued MetroPCS Communications, a regional wireless carrier eventually acquired by T-Mobile. Last year, Dish lost takeover battles for Sprint and Clearwire to SoftBank.Federal regulators in 2012 granted Dish a waiver to use airwaves that it acquired from two bankrupt satellite companies for 4G wireless service, as long as Dish builds out a network. To do that, Dish needs to find a wireless partner or to make an acquisition.Sprint — which will likely need cash for building out its 4G network and for upcoming spectrum auctions — and T-Mobile loom as possible Dish targets or partners."With Sprint out of the way, this may finally be Dish Network's moment to bid for T-Mobile," said William Power, an analyst at R.W. Baird"Deutsche Telekom still has several exit options, the best strategically being Dish — who would bring a material amount of spectrum, a customer base, the potential for video bundling and experience in the U.S. market," Sanford C. Bernstein analyst Paul de Sa said in a research report.French telecom upstart Iliad last week made a surprise $15 billion, $33 per share bid for a controlling stake in T-Mobile. But Deutsche Telekom has said that it's not in talks with Iliad, which has been a price cutter in France.According to Reuters, Iliad is speaking with Dish and other U.S. firms to pursue a joint bid for T-Mobile. Potential partners include cable TV firms.Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, is skeptical of a Dish bid for T-Mobile."Is Ergen now a buyer rather than seller?" Moffett asked in a report. "Dish's valuation assumes the company will sell its spectrum. Whether it would be accorded the same valuation (as a buyer) is unclear."Dish has more than $9 billion in cash on its balance sheet and could borrow from banks to fund a wireless deal. Analysts have pegged the value of Dish's spectrum to a wide range of $7 billion to $17 billion. It's not clear if regulators would set conditions on a sale.Moffett, on the other hand, also said that "the logic of an America Movil bid (for T-Mobile) looks very compelling."Mexico-based America Movil, controlled by Carlos Slim, operates U.S. prepaid firm TracFone. TracFone, which leases network capacity from AT&T and Verizon, has almost 26 million U.S. subscribers. AT&T in June sold its 8.27% stake in America Movil for $5.57 billion, making it more plausible that the Latin American firm might make a push into the U.S.Mobile VideoMeanwhile, AT&T's proposed acquisition of DirecTV Group could spur Comcast to bid for T-Mobile US to compete better with AT&T in mobile video services, speculates UBS analyst John Hodulik.Comcast, a one-time investor in Sprint, has touted its plans to expand public Wi-Fi networks. Comcast also has the option to lease wholesale network capacity from Verizon Wireless under the terms of a radio-spectrum sale. But Hodulik says that Comcast would be better off owning a wireless network.Comcast is seeking regulatory approval to acquire No. 2 cable firm Time Warner Cable (TWC).

Sprint's  (S) new CEO, Marcelo Claure, is said to be readying discounts or promotions focused on Apple (AAPL) mobile devices and possibly the iPhone 6 as the wireless industry braces for a possible price war. Japan's SoftBank, which owns 80% of Sprint, has shelved merger talks with T-Mobile. Shares of Sprint and T-Mobile (TMUS), 67% owned by Deutsche Telekom[ticker…

Sprint's (S) stock plunged amid reports it has dropped plans to acquire T-Mobile US (TMUS), which is 67% owned by Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY).Shares in Sprint were down 13% before the market open in the stock market today. T-Mobile's stock fell nearly 9%.Japan's SoftBank, which owns 80% of Sprint, has been pushing for a T-Mobile merger. SoftBank's stock fell in Japan on Wednesday, though the company holds a large stake in Alibaba Group, which plans an initial public offering. Shares in Deutsche Telekom also fell.Sprint also reportedly plans to replace its CEO, Dan Hesse, with Brightstar founder Marcelo Claure. SoftBank acquired control of Brightstar in January.U.S. regulators have signaled they would oppose a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile, the third- and fourth-biggest U.S. wireless firms. Sprint has said it needs bigger scale to take on leaders AT&T; (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ).The Federal Communications Commission last week said it would not let Sprint and T-Mobile bid jointly to acquire airwaves in an upcoming auction.Sprint's prospects without a T-Mobile deal appear dim. In Q2, it lost postpaid subscribers for the 25th time in 28 quarters. Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), which aims to break into the wireless business, looms as a bidder or partner of T-Mobile, analysts say.Dish on Wednesday reported Q2 revenue of $3.69 billion, up 5.8% from a year earlier, in-line with views. It earned 46 cents per share, compared to a 2-cent per-share loss a year earlier. Analysts had estimated profit of 51 cents. Shares were up 2% before the market open."We see significant challenges for Sprint shares given operational weakness, and now an uncertain future," said Mike McCormack, an analyst at Jefferies. "We see little downside support given the large valuation premium versus peers. For T-Mobile, other bidders, particularly Dish, and standout operations, should soothe nerves. We look for comments from Dish Chairman Charlie Ergen on today's earnings call."Bernstein analyst Paul de Sa agrees."Deutsche Telekom still has several exit options, the best strategically being Dish — who would bring a material amount of spectrum, a customer base, the potential for video bundling, and experience in the U.S. market — unlike international buyers (for example, Iliad) who bring nothing except cash and likely overly optimistic assessments of the transferability of their capabilities."French telecom upstart Iliad last week made a surprise $15 billion bid for a controlling stake in T-Mobile, but Deutsche Telekom has said it's not in talks with Iliad, which has been a price cutter in France.Sprint could cut prices to spark growth."We expect the wireless space to trade down on this news as it increases the likelihood of additional price cuts," said Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan in a report.There has been speculation Japan's SoftBank may bid for U.K.-based Vodafone (VOD) if its efforts in the U.S. wireless market stall.

While mobile phone companies worldwide continue to upgrade their wireless networks to 4G LTE technology, some are racing ahead with faster 4.5G LTE Advanced networks.ABI Research anticipates that 45 carriers will have commercially launched LTE Advanced by the fourth quarter. North America and Asia Pacific are the leading regions for the next-generation networks, while Western Europe trails slightly.The total number of subscribers for 4G LTE and 4.5G LTE Advanced is expected to grow to nearly 411 million and 22 million, respectively, by year's end, ABI says. The growing appetite for on-the-go, real-time information and mobile entertainment services is fueling the trend, ABI analysts Jake Saunders and Cheri Wong said in a note.About 337 mobile networks worldwide already have deployed 4G LTE. Global LTE network coverage is expected to cover more than 30% of the world's population by the end of 2014.ABI estimates that nearly 482 million LTE handsets will be shipped in 2014, up by nearly 150 million units from the previous year. It expects that number will grow to 1.34 billion by the end of 2019.In North America, the leading carriers for LTE Advanced are AT&T (T) and Sprint (S), Saunders and Wong told IBD.In Asia-Pacific , LTE Advanced leaders include Telstra of Australia, CSL New World Mobility Group of Hong Kong, KDDI of Japan, Singtel of Singapore, and South Korean carriers SK Telecom (SKM), Korea Telecom (KT) and LG U+.In Western Europe, the leading carriers with commercial LTE Advanced networks include Orange France and Bouygues Telecom of France, O2 Germany, KPN of the Netherlands, Swisscom of Switzerland and EE of the U.K.In Eastern Europe, O2 Czech Republic, T-Mobile Czech Republic and Russia's MegaFon are leading in 4.5G wireless.And in the Middle East, STC of Saudi Arabia is the LTE Advanced leader, ABI said.RELATED:Chipmakers Seen Growing With Connected Devices, LTESprint Exit Opens Door For T-Mobile, Dish Network.

JDS stock closed at 10.90 in the stock market today, near the 10.29 it hit in May, which had been the stock's lowest price since November 2012. The…
Stock futures hung well into negative territory ahead of Wednesday's open.
Dow futures swung 54.5 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were down a strong 17.6 points. S&P 500 and Russell 2000 futures were down 7.8 and 7.7 points, respectively.
The stock market today will try to find its footing on the heels of a weak session Tuesday that raised a defensive flag over the market.

In economic news, the U.S. trade deficit narrowed in June to $41.5 billion, the best in five months, the Commerce Department said. That was better than May's slightly downwardly revised $44.7 billion gap, and much better than expectations for a widening to $45 billion. Exports remained essentially flat, while imports of cell phones, autos and petroleum products declined.
Several pieces of news drove early stock action Wednesday and hinted at an inflection point in recent trends among large-scale mergers and acquisitions.

Sprint (S) fell 14% in premarket trade after abandoning its effort to acquire T-Mobile U.S. (TMUS) due to ongoing regulatory resistance, Reuters and the Wall Street Journal reported this morning. That leaves French telecom giant Iliad, as the sole bidder on the No. 4 U.S. wireless carrier.

Sprint had offered a deal estimated at around $32 billion. Iliad's bid, estimated nearer to $15 billion, aims to acquire 57% of the company. Reuters reports that Cox Communications, Charter Communications (CHTR) and Dish Network (DISH) could also potentially become involved in the deal. T-Mobile shares were down 8% ahead of the open.

21st Century Fox (FOXA) spiked 8% after ending its bid for Time Warner (TWX). Fox had pitched an $80 billion takeover offer, which Time Warner had declined. Fox had pressed the matter, and was prepared to raise its bid as high as $89 billion, according to news sources. But continued resistance, and a drop in Fox shares soured the deal. Time Warner stock fell 10% before the bell, also hurt after reporting mixed second-quarter results. Fox is scheduled to report after today's close.

Walgreen (WAG) dived 11% after announcing it would not use its acquisition of Swiss-based Alliance Boots to "invert" its corporate structure overseas and avoid U.S. taxes. Walgreen said it would acquire the remaining 55% of the pharmacy chain for $5.3 billion in cash plus 144.2 million shares. It put its combined revenue target for 2016 between $126 billion and $130 billion. Management said it aims to reduce annual costs by $1 billion before 2017, and launched a $3 billion share buyback initiative.

Overseas, markets in China slipped and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped 1.1%. Europe's major indexes were down more than 1% at midday, hurt by a surprise drop in German industrial orders and uncertainty massing on the Russia/Ukraine border.
The dollar firmed to a 9-month high vs. the euro and was steady against the yen. Gold and oil rose, but remained not far from recent lows. Natural gas inched up to its strongest level in two weeks.

Will the Internet TV ambitions of Dish Network and Verizon Communications dovetail into a merger or network-sharing deal between them?That scenario looms, some analysts say, as both the satellite TV broadcaster and the nation's No. 1 wireless phone company ready Web and mobile TV services.Dish Network (DISH) is expected to launch an Internet TV service — also called over-the-top or OTT service — by year's end. Dish on Sept. 16 added Scripps Network Interactive (SNI) as a content partner for its streaming video service, which might be called NuTV. Dish earlier signed up Walt Disney (DIS) and A+E Network as content providers for its OTT service.Verizon (VZ) executives, at a Goldman Sachs conference this month, said they expect to offer a streaming video service over broadband networks and their own wireless network by mid-2015. Verizon has been in talks with TV broadcasters and major content providers about its OTT offering.Dish and Verizon are expected to shake up the traditional pay-TV business with their Internet TV services. They're targeting millennials, the generation ages 18 to 30, those most likely to "cut the cord" and disconnect traditional pay TV in favor of free or lower-cost content they can get via the Internet on multiple devices. Dish might price its Internet TV service at $20 to $30 a month, analysts say.Speculation that Verizon might acquire Dish Network, or at least buy its radio spectrum, picked up after AT&T (T) announced in May that it would buy DirecTV Group (DTV), the No. 1 satellite TV broadcaster, for $48.5 billion.Verizon has said it's not interested in buying a satellite TV firm, but Macquarie Capital analyst Kevin Smithen says Verizon would become more interested if Dish's Internet TV platform succeeds."Verizon has no interest in acquiring a linear (traditional) TV business with tail risk on cash flows," Smithen told IBD via email. "However, Verizon has discussed the launch of its own Internet TV service in 2015, and we believe the Dish OTT content relationships could help give that product some scale and credibility."DirecTV has 20.2 million U.S. subscribers, while AT&T's Uverse serves 5.85 million video customers. With so many subscribers, AT&T is well-positioned to negotiate with content providers, analysts say. Dish has 14.1 million pay-TV customers and Verizon has 5.42 million with its FiOS TV.Verizon leads all wireless carriers with more than 98.6 million postpaid subscribers, users who are billed monthly.'Mobile First' Video RightsThe carrier has told some analysts that it expects to be able to negotiate for "mobile first" rights to content, using its wireless subscriber base, rather than based on its FiOS TV and broadband services."Management believes out-of-home content rights will be vastly different than in-home rights given the variability in mobile content consumption — more targeted, shorter duration content," Jefferies analyst Mike McCormack said in a report.So while Verizon has the least spectrum per subscriber among the big four national wireless firms, it still aims to expand mobile video services even though that will gobble up a lot of bandwidth.Dish, meanwhile, has cobbled together more than 50 megahertz of radio spectrum. It could buy more in a government auction slated for November. The outcome of that auction could impact Dish's strategic decisions, depending on how much spectrum Verizon or T-Mobile US (TMUS) acquire and what prices are paid for new licenses. Dish is seen as a potential T-Mobile buyer.Regulators likely would approve a Verizon-Dish merger if the combined company agreed to divest some of its radio spectrum, Andrew Lipman, a partner at law firm Bingham McCutchen, told attendees at the Goldman Sachs media and telecom conference.Verizon and Dish, however, could instead partner in a network-sharing deal, JPMorgan analyst Philip Cusick said in a research report this summer."Verizon and Dish could agree to some level of special relationship around selling video and wireless outside of the FiOS territory, which is only around 16% of the country and mostly outside of Dish's core rural markets," Cusick wrote.Verizon initially could buy around 20MHz of spectrum from Dish, for around $7 billion to $10 billion, and hold options to buy the rest of Dish's spectrum down the road, he says.Both Seeking GrowthDish Network and Verizon have reasons to jump into Internet TV.Revenue and subscriber growth has slowed in Dish's core pay-TV business. Verizon's wireless revenue growth has slowed as well. Verizon views mobile video as a new growth engine.Verizon in January agreed to buy Intel's (INTC) Media unit and Web-based OnCue cloud TV platform. In December, Verizon acquired EdgeCast, a provider of content delivery services. It has also purchased upLynk and its technology for uploading video.Verizon operates an online video business with Outerwall (OUTR)-owned Redbox. That business has enabled Verizon to study a streaming business model and consumer viewing habits, analysts say.At the Goldman conference, Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam said a mobile video offering should be ready by mid-2015, as talks with content providers are ongoing. Media firms have warmed up to offering OTT rights, realizing that's what millennials want, analysts say."That whole ecosystem, I think, is coming together," McAdam said. "It has been primed for a while. But as I say, over the last six months to a year, that dialogue is changing dramatically."The challenge for OTT providers, analysts say, is getting premium live or first-run content to show with OTT services.Goldman Sachs analyst Brett Feldman says Dish and Verizon both aim to get better terms for programming as they expand into Web- and mobile-video services. Dish has a lot at stake, he added in a research report."Dish's current business model of providing linear video over a fixed satellite network is mature," Feldman wrote. "Having an OTT service (could) improve Dish's negotiating position with programmers and lead to potential cost savings for content delivered over its satellite network."

Dish Network (DISH) agreed to disable its ad-skipping "AutoHop" technology for ABC programming as part of a deal with Walt Disney Co. (DIS) that gives the satellite pay-TV broadcaster more rights to whisk content in and out of homes via the Internet.

Dish gained rights for a Web-based subscription service that will stream TV shows, sports and movies produced by Disney cable TV channels, ESPN and broadcaster ABC. The deal covers live content and video on demand.

Disney had sued Dish, with 14 million subscribers, over the "AutoHop" technology, which lets subscribers skip commercials on programs recorded on DVRs. The agreement ends litigation, the two companies said.

The two companies had extended talks, seeking to avoid a programming black-out, after their programming agreement expired at the end of September. Comcast (CMCSA), Time Warner Cable (TWC) and DirecTV Group (DTV) have also renewed deals with content providers such as Viacom (VIA), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), and CBS (CBS).
The wide-ranging agreement also covers advertising on mobile devices and dynamic ad insertion — commercials based on customer viewing data.
"The creation of this agreement has really been about predicting the future of television with a visionary and forward-leaning partner," Dish CEO Joseph P. Clayton said in a statement.
The companies also renewed carriage agreements for eight ABC local stations.

The rise of cord-cutting — pay-TV customers who switch to Internet-only video and disconnect services — isn't stopping cable, phone and satellite companies from raising rates, even after strong revenue growth in Q4.
Rate hikes and add-on fees, while a sore point for consumers facing higher bills, are music to the ears of investors in cable, satellite and phone companies.

Many cable TV firms have tacked on cable-modem rental fees, boosting broadband service revenue. And many pay-TV companies have added new "broadcast TV" surcharges and regional sports fees they say are necessary because of higher programming costs.
"They still have decent pricing power, though margins have been relatively flat," said Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan.

Average monthly pay-TV bills for cable, satellite and phone companies rose 4% in 2013 to $88.67, says market tracker SNL Kagan. And average revenue per user (ARPU) for cable broadband providers rose 5.5% to about $45, says Morgan Stanley.
Wireless phone services had been the telecom industry's growth driver for years, but subscriber growth has slowed amid stiffer competition and market saturation. Now, broadband leads.

Wireless industry revenue rose 4.6% in Q4 vs. the year-earlier quarter, says UBS. But Q4 broadband revenue for cable leaders Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR), Cablevision Systems (CVC) and Time Warner Cable (TWC) rose from 8.7% to 14%.
And total revenue for Comcast, Charter, Cablevision and satellite broadcasters DirecTV Group (DTV) and Dish Network (DISH) rose from 5.5% to 7.2%.

"Broadband continues to be a source of strength for the cable companies," said UBS analyst John Hodulik in a research report on Q4. "High-speed data revenue growth accelerated slightly to around 11% (on average) given price increases and sales of higher-speed services."

One sticking point with regulators for Comcast's pending acquisition of TWC is the companies' broadband share. Comcast added 1.3 million broadband Internet subscribers in 2013, to hit a total of 20.7 million, says Leichtman Research. It says TWC gained 211,000 broadband subscribers, to 11.6 million.
Phone Upgrades Paying Off

Phone companies AT&T (T) and Verizon (VZ), meanwhile, are seeing gains after upgrading their copper networks with fiber-optic technology to offer TV and broadband services. Verizon's FiOS revenue rose 15% in Q4, while AT&T's consumer U-verse revenue jumped 20%.
Rate hikes, equipment fees and surcharges all contribute to ARPU growth.

This year, Verizon has increased monthly FiOS rates by $8 for customers who are in a contract and don't have price guarantees. Analysts, though, say about 80% of Verizon FiOS customers have such guarantees under TV/Internet/phone packages.
The company has stepped up marketing of its triple-play bundle, with 50 megabit-per-second Internet service, for $89.99 monthly.
AT&T has upped monthly bills for U-verse TV customers by $3, and hiked fees $5 for broadband-only customers. It also increases its monthly broadcast TV surcharge by $1 to $3.
Time Warner Cable in February added a $2.25 monthly broadcast TV fee.
Comcast added a $1.50 broadcast TV fee in January and raised 2014 monthly bills by 2% on average. Like TWC, Comcast has profited from new cable-modem rental fees.
DirecTV has increased its monthly rates by 3.7%, or $2 to $3 on average. Dish has announced a $5 increase to its basic TV package.

Amid the industry's apparent pricing power, consumers continue to shift to online video. Industry subscriber losses due to cord-cutting are forecast to continue, as Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN), Google (GOOG) and others add more original content to their offerings.
Morgan Stanley, in a March 13 report, said 19% of existing pay-TV subscribers it polled are interested in canceling service and using online video, up from 15% in 2011.
In Q4, 85.6% of U.S. households subscribed to monthly pay-TV service, down from an all-time high of 87.8% in 2010, estimates research firm MoffettNathanson.
The total number of U.S. pay-TV subscribers fell 251,000 in 2013, to about 100 million, SNL Kagan said Wednesday.

Earlier, UBS had pegged a lower number, saying cable TV system operators lost 1.75 million video subscribers in 2013, with almost half of those at Time Warner Cable. Satellite broadcasters DirecTV and Dish added 170,000 subscribers, down from 288,000 in 2012. AT&T and Verizon combined added 1.46 million new subscribers, up from 1.3 million. That adds up to 130,000 net subscriber loss for the three platforms in 2013.

The phone companies now hold nearly 10% of the pay-TV market, though they've lost broadband share to cable.The rise of cord-cutting — pay-TV customers who switch to Internet-only video and disconnect services — isn't stopping cable, phone and satellite companies from raising rates, even after strong revenue growth in Q4.Rate hikes and add-on fees, while a sore point for consumers facing higher bills, are music to the ears of investors in cable, satellite and phone companies.Many cable TV firms have tacked on cable-modem rental fees, boosting broadband service revenue. And many pay-TV companies have added new "broadcast TV" surcharges and regional sports fees they say are necessary because of higher programming costs."They still have decent pricing power, though margins have been relatively flat," said Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan.Average monthly pay-TV bills for cable, satellite and phone companies rose 4% in 2013 to $88.67, says market tracker SNL Kagan. And average revenue per user (ARPU) for cable broadband providers rose 5.5% to about $45, says Morgan Stanley.Wireless phone services had been the telecom industry's growth driver for years, but subscriber growth has slowed amid stiffer competition and market saturation. Now, broadband leads.Wireless industry revenue rose 4.6% in Q4 vs. the year-earlier quarter, says UBS. But Q4 broadband revenue for cable leaders Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR), Cablevision Systems (CVC) and Time Warner Cable (TWC) rose from 8.7% to 14%.And total revenue for Comcast, Charter, Cablevision and satellite broadcasters DirecTV Group (DTV) and Dish Network (DISH) rose from 5.5% to 7.2%."Broadband continues to be a source of strength for the cable companies," said UBS analyst John Hodulik in a research report on Q4. "High-speed data revenue growth accelerated slightly to around 11% (on average) given price increases and sales of higher-speed services."One sticking point with regulators for Comcast's pending acquisition of TWC is the companies' broadband share. Comcast added 1.3 million broadband Internet subscribers in 2013, to hit a total of 20.7 million, says Leichtman Research. It says TWC gained 211,000 broadband subscribers, to 11.6 million.Phone Upgrades Paying OffPhone companies AT&T (T) and Verizon (VZ), meanwhile, are seeing gains after upgrading their copper networks with fiber-optic technology to offer TV and broadband services. Verizon's FiOS revenue rose 15% in Q4, while AT&T's consumer U-verse revenue jumped 20%.Rate hikes, equipment fees and surcharges all contribute to ARPU growth.This year, Verizon has increased monthly FiOS rates by $8 for customers who are in a contract and don't have price guarantees. Analysts, though, say about 80% of Verizon FiOS customers have such guarantees under TV/Internet/phone packages.The company has stepped up marketing of its triple-play bundle, with 50 megabit-per-second Internet service, for $89.99 monthly.AT&T has upped monthly bills for U-verse TV customers by $3, and hiked fees $5 for broadband-only customers. It also increases its monthly broadcast TV surcharge by $1 to $3.Time Warner Cable in February added a $2.25 monthly broadcast TV fee.Comcast added a $1.50 broadcast TV fee in January and raised 2014 monthly bills by 2% on average. Like TWC, Comcast has profited from new cable-modem rental fees.DirecTV has increased its monthly rates by 3.7%, or $2 to $3 on average. Dish has announced a $5 increase to its basic TV package.Amid the industry's apparent pricing power, consumers continue to shift to online video. Industry subscriber losses due to cord-cutting are forecast to continue, as Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN), Google (GOOG) and others add more original content to their offerings.Morgan Stanley, in a March 13 report, said 19% of existing pay-TV subscribers it polled are interested in canceling service and using online video, up from 15% in 2011.In Q4, 85.6% of U.S. households subscribed to monthly pay-TV service, down from an all-time high of 87.8% in 2010, estimates research firm MoffettNathanson.The total number of U.S. pay-TV subscribers fell 251,000 in 2013, to about 100 million, SNL Kagan said Wednesday.Earlier, UBS had pegged a lower number, saying cable TV system operators lost 1.75 million video subscribers in 2013, with almost half of those at Time Warner Cable. Satellite broadcasters DirecTV and Dish added 170,000 subscribers, down from 288,000 in 2012. AT&T and Verizon combined added 1.46 million new subscribers, up from 1.3 million. That adds up to 130,000 net subscriber loss for the three platforms in 2013.The phone companies now hold nearly 10% of the pay-TV market, though they've lost broadband share to cable.

Institutional money managers who have a mandate to find good dividend-paying stocks don't perform their job much differently from their zero-income, high-growth-focused counterparts.
Those in the first camp tend to invest heavily as the broad economy grows. They like to see stable, low inflation. Some don't worry much about a gradual rise in interest rates.
But top income managers also pay close attention to a company's ability to generate strong cash flow, keep their balance sheets healthy and follow through on pledges to boost cash dividends.
Today, these managers also continue to see a positive environment for this area of the stock market. Why? American firms' fundamentals keep getting stronger.

"Over the past few years, companies have cut costs, strengthened their balance sheets, and hence, have considerably better cash flows and operating margins to dedicate toward shareholder-friendly moves, including higher dividends," Linda Bakhshian, portfolio manager of $1.2 billion Federated Capital Income Fund , told IBD.
"In fact, investors are demanding that management return more in dividend income now."
Through Sept. 30, the fund sports an annualized pretax return of 7.2% since its May 27, 1988 inception. Its 12-month yield is 5.73%.
Clamoring For Cash

Bakhshian offers another reason why income stocks continue to do well. The mindset of the 2010s is very different from the 1980s and 1990s. Back then, market players generally frowned upon managements who returned cash to shareholders instead of reinvesting in the business.

"That stigma no longer holds," she said. "Investors are more vigilant and more vocal about what they would like to see from management, and returning cash to shareholders is a key priority. Just look at how much more shareholder activism there is in the marketplace."

Today, Bakhshian sees potential increases in cash payouts among technology firms. Indeed, a few of the biggest stars in the sector — from Apple (AAPL) (95 Composite Rating, current annual yield of 1.8%) to Microsoft (MSFT) (66 Composite, 2.8% yield) to Qualcomm (QCOM) (84 Composite, 2.3%) — dish out billions of dollars in dividends each year.

As of May 31, information technology made up 9.5% of the fund's equities component. Energy was the top sector component, making up 20.7%, followed by financials at 11.8%, industrials 11.1% and utilities and consumer staples at 8.2% each.
Other top-performing managers look for stocks that show less propensity for big swings in fundamentals and a greater tendency for highly reliable numbers in terms of profits, sales and margins.

"You are looking for a stable, lower volatility investment, from a well capitalized company, that is increasing dividends and paying out a higher yield," Bryan Sadoff of Milwaukee-based family-run investment advisory Sadoff Investments, which has $850 million under management, told IBD.
So, what issues remain on fund managers' minds before they go to bed each night?
The European economy is a hot issue. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia continues to smolder, with the potential to put the brakes on the region's still-fragile recovery.

"We are concerned that a slower European economy and a weaker euro may impact the overall pace of S&P 500 company earnings into the fourth quarter of this year and 2015 and erode CEO confidence," Bakhshian said.
Early Rate Hikes Mean Little
As of the Oct. 2 IBD, the dividend yield of the S&P 500 benchmark was 2%.

Sadoff is more concerned about three other potential developments that could damage the economy and thus dim or even destroy the prospects of dividends paid by companies: 1.) Retail sales go negative. 2.) Consumer prices "begin to falter, which would tell us that underlying demand is falling," Sadoff said. 3.) The jobs market sees losses, not gains.
"You will get a lot of hikes before it makes a dent on the economy," Sadoff said. "It'll be headline news when the first rate hikes happen, and it will be meaningless."

"We also think sometime in 2015 rates will rise. In a rising-rate environment you want to be more overweight equities. Within equities, cyclical sectors tend to outperform defensive, or in other words high dividend growers will likely outperform high dividend payers," Bakhshian said.Institutional money managers who have a mandate to find good dividend-paying stocks don't perform their job much differently from their zero-income, high-growth-focused counterparts.Those in the first camp tend to invest heavily as the broad economy grows. European regulators soon will rule on two wireless-industry mergers that will signal how the EU feels about further wireless consolidation. The pending deals would shrink the number of mobile carriers in two countries from four to three.The European Union has been reviewing Spain-based Telefonica's (TEF) $11.8 billion purchase of Germany's No. 4 wireless firm, E-Plus, from parent KPN. The EU aims to decide whether to clear Telefonica's bid by June 23.If approved, the deal would leave Germany with three carriers: Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), Vodafone (VOD) and Telefonica.The European Commission, the region's antitrust regulator, also is reviewing Hutchison Whampoa's bid for Telefonica's Irish unit. Ireland now has four carriers: Vodafone, Telefonica, Eircom and Hutchison Whampoa.Some U.S. companies, including AT&T (T), have an interest in the outcome of those EU approvals. There has been speculation that AT&T would acquire Vodafone, especially if European regulators allow consolidation in Germany. But such a deal would be unlikely to happen if AT&T goes through with its rumored purchase of satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV (DTV)."AT&T must decide whether it wants to pursue domestic acquisitions to buttress a weakening position or go abroad," said Robin Bienenstock, a U.K.-based analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein.AT&T might look upon a Vodafone purchase more favorably if the Telefonica deal wins approval. Falling prices in Germany for wireless services have been a big problem for Vodafone. Its service revenue in Germany fell 8% in the December quarter."I think that AT&T is waiting, among other things, to see what happens in June. Vodafone is uninteresting as a target if German consolidation fails; if it succeeds, it is potentially very interesting," Bienenstock said.Europe's regulators are under pressure to wring concessions from Telefonica and Hutchison because prices for wireless services jumped in Austria after the EU allowed its market to consolidate to three national players from four in late 2012, when Hutchison merged with the Orange Austria telecommunications company.One option in Germany, analysts say, is for Telefonica to agree to forge wholesale deals with so-called mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs) — companies that rent access to networks and generally sell cheaper mobile plans. Liberty Global (LBTYA) — which sells cable TV services in Germany, Belgium and England — is said to be in talks with Telefonica over access to its network in Germany.However, regulators may insist that Telefonica agree to a broader MVNO structure open to more new entrants in Germany."I think the deal will be approved with conditions," said Stefan Zehle, CEO of U.K.-based Coleago Consulting. "The likely most important condition is that Telefonica O2/E-Plus will have to commit to a mandated wholesale-price access offer. This will ensure that MVNOs get access to competitive rates. With a low wholesale rate, these MVNOs will limit (the industry's biggest players') ability to increase retail prices following the merger.""It could be the template for the whole EU," added Zehle.Europe's regulators have had setbacks.In Austria, regulators required that radio spectrum be divested to allow a new, fourth industry player to enter the market. But no company stepped up to purchase spectrum in an auction. So a fourth carrier was not created to replace the one eliminated by the Hutchison/Orange merger.Analysts say that of Telefonica wins approval of the E-Plus acquisition, then Italy, Spain and France are among the markets where wireless firms may seek mergers that reduce network operators to three from four.U.S. regulators, like those in Europe, have been reluctant to approve mergers that reduce national players from four to three.In 2011, the Department of Justice blocked AT&T's purchase of Deutsche Telekom-controlled T-Mobile US (TMUS).Japan's SoftBank, which last year acquired 80% of Sprint (S), has been looking to spark a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile US, the No. 3 and No. 4 U.S. wireless carriers behind Verizon (VZ) and AT&T. The Federal Communications Commission has signaled that it would likely block a Sprint/T-Mobile merger because it would reduce competition.Some analysts, though, have suggested that a Sprint/T-Mobile deal could be approved if they make it possible for a "new entrant," such as satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), to enter the wireless market. Dish has been cobbling together spectrum licenses and has been testing new data/video services.Or the combined Sprint/T-Mobile could lease network capacity on wholesale terms to Internet or tech companies so those companies can sell their own data services, in competition with telecom and cable ISPs.

French telecom upstart Iliad's surprise $15 billion bid for a controlling stake in T-Mobile US gives parent Deutsche Telekom more options amid expected U.S. regulatory opposition to a possible merger between T-Mobile and Sprint.After Europe's stock markets closed on Thursday, Iliad confirmed its $33-per-share bid for a 56.6% stake in T-Mobile (TMUS), whose stock gained 6.5%, closing near Iliad's offer price. U.S. shares of Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), which holds a 67% stake in T-Mobile, were flat. Sprint's (S)stock fell 5.3%. AT&T (T)and Verizon Communications (VZ) both fell more than 2% on worries over steeper price competition with the possible entry of Iliad into the U.S. market.Japan's SoftBank, which owns 80% of Sprint, has been pushing for a T-Mobile merger. But Deutsche Telekom has been reluctant to pull the trigger because of expected U.S. regulatory opposition, though a deal might prevail in a court battle.SoftBank and Sprint reportedly have been working on a $32 billion offer for T-Mobile US, at $40 a share, with half in cash.While Sprint could make a superior offer, Deutsche Telekom might be interested in working out some kind of deal with Iliad to reduce its exposure in case it agrees to a Sprint merger and the deal is blocked by regulators, says Kevin Smithen, an analyst at Macquarie Capital. Selling off some of its 67% stake in T-Mobile would be an option for Deutsche Telekom, he says.Could Sell Minority Stake"We do not believe that Deutsche Telekom would sell its entire control stake for $33 a share, nor would minority investors with tag-along rights likely accept such a price," Smithen said in a research note. "(But) Deutsche Telekom could sell 10%-20% of T-Mobile ... . Minority holders in T-Mobile should be prepared for Deutsche Telekom to take some money off the table while it waits for a more attractive long-term exit from the U.S."U.S. regulators have signaled that they oppose a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile, the Nos. 3 and 4 wireless firms behind leaders Verizon and AT&T, because it would reduce competition. An Iliad purchase might fare better with U.S. regulators, but it also might boost competition for AT&T, Verizon and Sprint.Iliad's subsidiary, Free, has been a big price-cutter in France's wireless market."T-Mobile has already been very aggressive with its Uncarrier strategy," said Stephen Sweeney, an analyst at Elevation. "With Iliad as a new corporate parent, it would theoretically be even more aggressive, which would be bad for all three of the other U.S. carriers."Some observers have speculated Carlos Slim-controlled America Movil (AMX), Latin America's No. 1 wireless firm and owner of U.S. prepaid firm TracFone, might be eying T-Mobile. And T-Mobile has yet other options.One would be a partnership with U.S. broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), which aims to break into the wireless business.Prior to Iliad's bid surfacing on mid-Thursday, T-Mobile CEO John Legere hinted on the company's Q2 earnings call early Thursday that T-Mobile has options aside from the much-speculated merger with Sprint.Legere says he's confident the Uncarrier-branded wireless phone company will continue prospering, on its own or "inorganically."Could Succeed Stand-Alone"We've been very successful and we see a path forward to be highly successful as a stand-alone company," Legere said. "But we also know that we could significantly accelerate that growth and create an even higher level of competition in the U.S. wireless industry by various forms of accelerating this (Uncarrier) platform."And I would point out that we have multiple versions of things that we can do inorganically with this company, and multiple versions for timing as to when we do them."T-Mobile said it added 908,000 postpaid wireless subscribers in Q2, more than analysts expected in the wake of strong additions announced earlier by Verizon and AT&T.T-Mobile, which swung to a Q2 profit on a spectrum sale to Verizon, raised its 2014 postpaid addition guidance to a range of 3 million to 3.5 million, up from its earlier outlook of 2.8 million to 3.3 million. The company has already added 2.2 million postpaid subscribers, which are billed monthly, in the first half of 2014.Without the spectrum swap, T-Mobile would have posted a net loss. T-Mobile said Q2 revenue rose by 15.4% to $7.2 billion, above estimates. Analysts had modeled sales of $7.04 billion.T-Mobile shouldn't rush into a deal with Sprint, Craig Moffett, analyst at MoffettNathanson, said in a report released before Iliad's bid."The longer Deutsche Telekom waits, the better off they will be," Moffett said. "Sure, within another year T-Mobile's Uncarrier momentum will likely have waned — nothing lasts forever. But by waiting, Deutsche Telekom would get a better deal."T-Mobile's aggressive Uncarrier promotions rekindled subscriber growth in 2013 and early this year.While T-Mobile has momentum, a Sprint turnaround is a work-in-progress.Sprint early Wednesday reported its first quarterly profit in more than six years, but said it lost 245,000 postpaid subscribers, down from 333,000 in the March quarter and from more than 1 million in the year-earlier quarter. Sprint has lost postpaid customers in 25 of 28 quarters since mid-2007.If Deutsche Telekom and T-Mobile bide their time, competition in the U.S. wireless industry may intensify.Apple's (AAPL) launch of the iPhone 6, analysts speculate, could come as soon as mid-September.On Sprint's earnings call Wednesday, CEO Dan Hesse confirmed that the struggling carrier is testing new pricing plans. Moffett says Sprint must cut pricing to be more competitive."Price cuts seem likely as the iPhone refresh approaches," UBS analyst John Hodulik said in a report. "We expect Sprint to come down to AT&T/Verizon levels, if not close the gap with T-Mobile. We could be in a dog fight in Q4, (which is) typically the strongest device-selling season."Hodulik says AT&T should be in a good position when Apple's iPhone 6 arrives, because it has moved away from subsidizing devices and toward installment plans, like T-Mobile. AT&T wireless margins will be less impacted, he says, because its customers are expected to switch to installment payment plans.IPhone 6 A 'Switching Event'AT&T now has some 55 million smartphone users, with 24 million of those — 44% of its smartphone customers — on no-contract pricing plans. That includes more than 7 million customers that have signed up for AT&T's "Next" installment plans. That leaves some 17 million to 18 million that could buy the iPhone 6 and stick with AT&T or switch to another carrier.On his call, T-Mobile's Legere said the iPhone 6's arrival was a likely "major switching event" and a "major upside possibility for us." He noted that T-Mobile has the fewest iPhone users among the big four wireless firms, because it was the last one to sell Apple's popular device."So if a switching event is coming, a major one, I think we've got a huge opportunity," he said.T-Mobile on Thursday maintained its full-year EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) forecast of $5.6 billion to $5.8 billion.T-Mobile's 908,000 postpaid additions included 579,000 mobile phone customers and 329,000 tablet users. Postpaid average monthly revenue per user fell 8.7% to $49.30 vs. a 7.4% drop in Q1.In Q2, Verizon added 270,000 postpaid mobile phone subscribers and 1.15 million tablet users. AT&T added 707,000 smartphone subscribers and 366,000 tablet users.
